Definition: In this task you will be given a review body give rating for this product.

Positive Examples.input: I was very surprised at the high quality of the stitching, the sturdiness of the handles and the padding for my laptop. The price is amazingly low and the look is very good. I am quite happy with this purchase. It fit my MacBook Pro perfectly, with a little bit of room to spare.
Positive Examples.explanation: This rating is based on this review provided by user as he liked the product very much and he was surprised by it

Positive Examples.input:
I am a Google employee and had to chance to use the device for a few months now. This is my own opinion of the device.

Overall OnHub is a pretty no nonsense type router that just works. Its super simple to setup with your phone, is fast and auto updates. I have not looked back ever since I set it up. The beauty in this router is that it gets better over time. You know what I mean if you have a ChromeBook. It auto updates and you never have to deal with firmware and security updates or adjusting settings on the device to get the optimal performance for your WiFi network. It just figures it out on its own.

Why I love it:
1) Auto Updates. Probably the one of the main selling points. I have witnessed this first hand. It uses the power of the cloud to update. No security updates to apply, no firmware patches to apply, no need to plug in your laptop to set it up or flash, etc. It does it automatically through the internet.

2) It's fast. I probably have 6-7 devices connected through WiFi and they all perform pretty well. I didn’t notice any performance differences when streaming Netflix or YouTube using the Ethernet connection or Wireless network.

3) The Android app makes it dead simple to share your WiFi password, perform speed tests on your internet connection, see how much bandwidth devices on your network are using, and updated your typical settings you see in a WiFi router. The added bonus is you can even do it from anywhere you have a internet connection. No need to be on your home network. The default settings worked straight out of the box beautifully. (There is an iOS app, which has similar features)

4) There are 2.4GHz and 5GHz antennas which should cover all your devices. The interesting bit for me, was that you only need one SSID for both frequencies. There is no concept of network-name and network-name-5g if you have a used a router in the past that broadcasted both frequencies. It will automatically figure out which is the better frequency for you and use that.

5) No administrator password to remember or gateway ip to remember to update settings. You control everything through your phone, including adding additional managers to administer the device. Although, I haven’t actually had the need to use this, it might come in handy to help a friend or family member if they had some questions.

6) It looks nice enough that I don’t need to hide it in my TV stand and can leave it out in the open.

Why you may not like it:
1) The OnHub only has 1 Ethernet port, where as my old router had 4. While I thought I would miss this early on, I actually found that connecting all my devices via WiFi just seemed so much simpler and cleaner. If you need more ports for wired internet access, you will need a switch.

2) There is no web interface to administrate the device, but I didn’t really miss it. Well, okay I will admit I did at first, since I was so use to it from my old access point. After the initial setup though, you don’t really need to touch any settings. As I mentioned before, you control everything through your phone, if you need to change anything or check the status.

Future Wish List:
There is a pretty nice looking speaker on top that I heard during setup. It would be cool if this could be used in some other ways, other than just for setup. Maybe a future update?use that. 5) No administrator password to remember or gateway ip to remember to update settings. You control everything through your phone, including adding additional managers to administer the device. Although, I haven’t actually had the need to use this, it might come in handy to help a friend or family member if they had some questions. 6) It looks nice enough that I don’t need to hide it in my TV stand and can leave it out in the open. Why you may not like it: 1) The OnHub only has 1 Ethernet port, where as my old router had 4. While I thought I would miss this early on, I actually found that connecting all my devices via WiFi just seemed so much simpler and cleaner. If you need more ports for wired internet access, you will need a switch. 2) There is no web interface to administrate the device, but I didn’t really miss it. Well, okay I will admit I did at first, since I was so use to it from my old access point. After the initial setup though, you don’t really need to touch any settings. As I mentioned before, you control everything through your phone, if you need to change anything or check the status. Future Wish List: There is a pretty nice looking speaker on top that I heard during setup. It would be cool if this could be used in some other ways, other than just for setup. Maybe a future update?
Positive Examples.explanation: User liked the router very  and has given 5 star rating for this product as he was very overjoyed by the product.

Negative Examples.input: I was very surprised at the high quality of the stitching, the sturdiness of the handles and the padding for my laptop. The price is amazingly low and the look is very good. I am quite happy with this purchase. It fit my MacBook Pro perfectly, with a little bit of room to spare.
Negative Examples.explanation: Here user like the product very much still rating provided is not acroding to the his review. There is no relation between review, title and rating provided.

Instances.input: Stopped working a little under two months after purchase  (seems like an internal component failed) and the asus warranty center consistently cannot process a claim, as their "system is down" every time I have called. It has been a very expensive paperweight for the last week, and will continue to be just that until I can get someone to process a claim under the ~$60 warranty I paid for. I have full intentions of returning it and purchasing a different brand if a refund is an option.
I love it!

This SD is just like any other SD you would buy. It supplies you with 4 GB of Videos, Pictures and Storage. This SD even comes with a plastic case/protective cover for your SD. This is fantastic for the price. I would buy it again. Buy it!

This small, lightweight 12-volt DC power adapter gave my wife the same results on her Toshiba notebook computer as she had from the AC power adapter that came with her computer.  She could use her computer while riding as a passenger in a moving vehicle without exhausting her computer's battery.  This adapter performed as expected for awhile and for a reasonable price.  I ordered this item on a Friday night, it was shipped the next day and I received it the following Wednesday.  Unfortunately this adapter did not prove to be very durable.  After about three months of use, it came apart and tripped the vehicle's breakers.  We had to replace it with an adapter that was larger, heavier, more expensive and more durable.

Hard to figure out how to use. Need to download instructions.
love that it has no buttons to push.
Incorrect cable asm.  The connector for the camera end is not micro HDMI, won't fit or work.

i bought one of this beasts.know i am using Samsung 4k U28D590 motitor with it.even BT4 4k res no fps lower than 30 without AA. i am going to buy one more for sli gaming.And dont forget to mention if you buy one of these free watch dogs code is coming with it ;)

Great reading device that has held up well.

It's very well made and the backlight screen makes reading in the dark possible and very comfortable.

I use calibre to manage the books and that has been a perfect solution.

Battery life is excellent and a simple charge every few months has been more than enough for me.

I like this cover for the Kindle because it protects the reader while it's sitting around and it's simple matter of flipping it open to read just like having a book. I think it makes the Kindle feel more like an electronic book, and not just an electronic device.    You can hold the cover open like a regular book or I sometimes fold the cover back behind so it's more compact and this works great as well.    When I requested the cover, I didn't realize the Kindle actually locks into it. The Kindle has 2 recessed holes in which 2 tabs on the cover snap into. So the Kindle is held securely in the cover.
great product
Works great, exactly what I expected.
I LOVE IT. does everything i need and plays movies great. no lagging or nothing just smooth graphics and reads cd very well.

These work better than the rubber tipped stylus.  They are accurate and stylish looking!  They have not torn and seem more durable than the rubber tipped which tend to tear sometimes.  Do not work great on tablets with a heavy duty cover (i.e. Commando case)
Great graphics Nice and small to fit almost any case not long like some of them that need a really big case. Great price and great picture

I saw this monitor on sale at Amazon. I like the \\"Go Green\\" idea. When I saw I could save power and get 1080p on a monitor I knew I had to get one. The DVI hooked right up to my video card and windows 7 set it to 1080p without having to use the disc. I did not try the speakers since I already have my sound set up. So far I have watched full screen movies with no problems. If you are still using a CRT monitor, you should try this LED monitor, it will save you power and you will have a big screen. In windows 7 when you use snap, the 2 windows have plenty of room to snap together.

Installation was not as easy as made out in the instructional videos, but still fairly easy nonetheless.  There were small air bubbles present after initial application but they disappeared after a couple of days.  I can't even tell there is anything applied save for the texture (it's kind if "sticky" compared to the actual screen) and the corners peel up occasionally, but are smoothed out easily.
My fiance needs it when he is on the road because the laptop has wifi so he uses it when he stays at the hotel if they provided wifi in that area.
These are the worst cables you can buy.the cables work but it takes forever to charge the phone.I would steer clear of this product.
works well, and as advertised, together with an Asus router and I have full home coverage and fast speed ... not much more to say about it ....
We read a lot so this are great for my husband & me. That way we aren't always looking for a book to read-we have one.
Yes I am very happy with the case

It broke after about two weeks . I wanted to get a replacement but unable cause Amazon was out of that model and did not know when have more.
I had to buy at 3rd party. So far no complaints.
Dan
It seems to have a slow response time to my tablet but I dont know if thats the keyboards fault or not.

easy use and very portable. i have tried the nook tablet and it was NOT very good compared to a fire. the price is very great for a product like this. i have had so much fun with it over the last week. The apps on this are fantastic and the resolution is awesome. GET THIS PRODUCT NOWWWWW!!!!!
Love it, good Price, size and power.

This is such a great iPad cover/protection. First of all it is just plain FUN! It absolutely looks like a real old book and its made out of great material! I chose this item over others because of the tough outer layer with the hard covered leather. It also zips completely up to protect it from any splashes, dirt, scrapes etc. Perfect! The look was the icing on the cake. It actually makes me feel better when I work on my front steps. We have some \\"not so nice\\" people who live across the way (I live in a condo) so the little bit of the Book Book disguise makes me feel better, like I can take a little break outside for a bit without it screaming that I have an iPad. I use a stylus so I'm hoping it looks like I'm sketching in a sketchbook or journaling.

I've dropped my iPad once with it wrapped in the Book Book. It fell from my table onto the wood floor. I could tell by the way it sounded when it landed that it was probably going to be ok...just a light thud, no SMASH! It was fine! My iPad never leaves the Book Book!

Just one thing to mention. The leather does scratch and stain...I love it that way as it makes it look more worn. But for those who may like it as it comes in the mail...maybe you can use a protective spray to prevent this?

I use the Book Book with the new iPad (3).

Pretty neat case for the prize, comes with a pen/stylus which is pretty useless unless you're into using that(stylus).  Outside cover creased on first hour of use, and is a little too flimsy for my taste. Overall product is 4/5 stars. You get what you pay for.

Bought this Kindle Fire HD for my grandson. Nothing said that I needed a charger. My Kindle had come with one. When it arrived he could not find a charger in the box. The child does not have a computer to use in order to charge the device. This was so embarrassing for me. And then to charge $20 for this adapter??? What were you thinking? This is not the way Amazon does business and I have done an immense amount of business with you. I have Prime and just renewed it. So I called customer service to get this and they gave me a promotional credit but the child has to wait for it to arrive. You need to do something about this situation immediately. I see other customers irate over the same thing. Don't you guys read the reviews? You should and be responsive to your customers. Either add a reasonable amount to the item and include this, indicate when buying that one is needed (I ordered this with the help of customer service and they never told me about this) or don't send the USB cable which is useless if you are not near a computer so you can charge the device.
I origionally purchased a cover for my hp touchpad at walmart for $35 and hated it.  this one was less than $10 and is fantastic!!!  perfect fit, great color and exactly what the description said.

I got this for my pc at the office so that I could use my bluetooth headset to make skype calls to coworkers overseas. It was a bit of a pain to set up as I didn't do much research right off the bat. I plugged the dongle in and it installed and I got the bluetooth icon in the task bar but I couldn't identify any bluetooth devices. Was pretty frustrating until I went and read some reviews online and the solution turned out to be quite simple. You will have to enable bluetooth services on your local pc start and set them to automatic. This is extremely simple but I'm not going to get into it here. There is plenty of information out there in other places.

Good buy cheap and works well.

My friend has the previous switch easy cover for the iPad 2, and recommended it to me. I bought this mainly to protect my iPad when I am travelling etc., and am very pleased by with the product. It seems robust and looks like it would give my iPad ample protection in the case of a drop or light/medium impact of some sort. I am not worried to stick it in my ruc sack along with various other bits and bobs - it's not going to get scratched/dented or damaged.

I think compared to other covers of similar price I think this is a superior cover - the back is protected by a reasonably thick plastic veneer, and the canvas cover protects the screen perfectly. It does add some weight to the iPad, but I think that is to be expected.

Excellent product at that time as a reading instrument Now with new products on the market this item is less desirable eg could not use properly wifi. Could not updated to go beyond the level of experimental tools as announced.
Works as expected and needed in order to operate!

I don't have much experience in the video capture/media capture field but this product really made it easy, I didn't use the included software in lieu of CyberMedia PowerDirector 5 (which also is very nice) but the product itself is very easy to use.  WinXP recognized the hardware w/no problems, and I was off capturing old VHS home videos in no time. All in all, good product, and I would recommend it, maybe USB or s-video input connections could make it better.

This tote is roomy, yet not overly large.  I can fit my laptop, charger, mouse, file folders and a few personal items (kindle, meds) in here with ease.  It's stylish and I get compliments on it quite often.

This battery def helps my computer stay on for a longer period of time (about an hour now) without being plugged into the power source. Before it was only about 10 min, so def an improvement. The only thing I disliked about it is it does not fit properly in there and has effected my mouse pad, causing it to push against it and get stuck.

It sucks that I can't use a case with this keyboard but the instant on connection, light weight, good build quality, and the use of magnets to turn the screen on automatically when u open it make up for it.
It is everything I wanted and more. Just the right size, shuts off when I close the case and turns on when I open it.  I LOVE IT>
Would highly recommend to someone that wanted a good dependable inexpensive day to day computer. It was just as advertised.
I lost my cable that came with the CD/DVD player. Fortunate for me, this cable works quite well with the player.
The unit does glow really bright it would be nice to not have the led so bright, but make no mistake this unit was the nicest one I could get and use.

Unlike the human mind, computer memory is pretty much unlimited in its capacity. A large external back-up drive makes it possible to store everything, safely, `outside the box' ... Just in case. The Seagate Free Agent is great.
The days of storing computer data back-up on CDs or DVDs is pretty much over. Unlike the human memory, good external hard drives are getting bigger and bigger (in capacity) and more and more reliable to use to back-up and protect your information. The Seagate Free Agent Desk 1.5TB External Hard Drive is a great example of a simply huge amount of storage space for a very reasonable price.

The size of available hard drives, both internal and external, has increased exponentially in the years since I first put my fingers to the keyboard of my first computer, an Apple 2-E. In those days of yesteryear (the late 1970s) a reasonable hard drive was somewhere between 500 and 100mbs (1/2 - 1 GB.) Even Bill Gates thought at the time (and was much quoted as saying) that anything more than that would be silly and unnecessary for the personal PC user.

Today, my desktop contains two internal hard drives, each 500 GBs, for a total of one `Terabyte', a word unknown to most of us only a few years ago. As more and more data is saved on them (various programs, documents, music and video files) a reliable system of backup becomes increasingly important. In a worse-case scenario, a `crash' can destroy a HD in an irreparable instant.

The Seagate Free Agent 1.5TB External Hard Drive allows me to back up everything on my computer without compression - a risky proposition as it involves a series of coding and decoding processes that can go awry - as its total capacity actually exceeds by a full 50% the full internal hard drive space of my DELL 530 Inspiron.
Set to automatically keep EVERYTHING on both internal hard drives fully backed up by updating once a week, should my computer ever go down in a flaming mass of anguished lost memories, it (or another) could be simply and straightforwardly restored to include everything I had on it by copying the Seagate backup data to new internal hard drives.

There are a lot of these high-capacity external hard drives now available. The Seagate Free Agent has a lot to recommend it specifically as a good choice. Cost, simplicity of operation and reliability are really the only things that really matter and with this Seagate External Hard Drive, all three criteria have been more than satisfactorily met.

The cost is the easiest and briefest item to address. Listed at about $200, the Seagate Free Agent can be found through multiple on line retailers for prices ranging from $99 - $150. Like everything else, it pays to shop it around. Whatever you pay for it, it is warranted by Seagate for a full 5 years. I don't think you could find a better or more secure value in the industry today.

The set-up and operation is straight forward. Plugged in to AC (the adapter and connecting USB2 connecting cable are both included in the package) and plugged into the USB port, VISTA finds and loads the most current drivers, the set up screen comes up and after less than five minutes, you have set the automatic settings for frequency and for which files are to be backed up and you're ready to go.

Again, because of the sheer size of the available hard drive (1.5 TB); this Seagate Drive will hold everything for me. I don't need to pick and choose what to back up and what not. It simply does it all and updates it, automatically, per settings that can be as frequent as one each and every day. The initial back up took an hour or so. The incremental updates takes only a few minutes as only new information replaces old or, if new, is added to the backed up data.

The design is thoughtful, technically proficient and up to snuff for most any home computer user. A brief rundown of the technical specs is as follows:

Dimensions:
Width: 1.3 inches
Depth: 6.8 inches
Height: 6.9 inches
Weight: 2.2 pounds
Enclosure color: Silver

The Seagate Free Agent can be positioned either to lay flat or to stand in its side (a stand for this purpose is also included.) There is no variation in functioning according to its orientation.

Spindle Speed: 7200 rpm
Interface Transfer Rate: 480 Mbps
Interface: 1 X Hi-Speed USB2

It is fully compatible with all versions of Windows from XP through the new Windows 7 OS and is compatible with both 32 and 64 bit systems. It runs quietly as there are no internal fans - the nature of its design render one unnecessary.

Irrelevant though it may seem, this silver colored device is extremely attractive. The set up also allows for the use of an internal low energy light that shines through the template-cut Seagate logo on the front of the enclosure to highlight its presence in your work area.

I have had and used this Seagate Free Agent 1.5TB External Hard Drive for several weeks now. Its performance has been flawless. More importantly, it has given me one less thing to worry about - losing information and entertainment that I have stored on my computer. It's a great deal of insurance for the cost. Like all insurance, it is a gamble we hope to lose (never need.) But, just in case ...

I am aware of some critical reviews of this Seagate Hard Drive but have found the complaints to be unfounded in my own experience.

If you are exploring a large external Hard Drive for back-up, I strongly suggest that you check out this Seagate Free Agent 1.5TB External Hard Drive. One less thing to worry about makes the whole world a better place.... For me!br />Dimensions:

Great product

I bought the Inspiron Mini 10 at Sam's Club for $329.  I knew I would be paying a little more, but I wanted to be sure I could return it if I had a problem, and I was glad I did.  First one had all the stickers for Windows 7 Starter out of the box, but was loaded with XP.  It had keyboard issues and would lose two hours of time about every three days.  I exchanged at Sam's with very little hassle, and it has been running great ever since.  Keyboard is a great size and easy to type.  It took a bit to get used to the touch pad, as it would think I was scrolling when I didn't want to.  I turned this feature off and no more problems.  Screen resolution is good.  Windows 7 runs smoothly, without any problems.  Works great as an \\"extra\\" PC for web surfing and light photo and music use.  I wanted the six-cell battery, and it only lasts about 5 to 6 hours, not the advertised 8, but this is enough for me.  Overall, very happy with this purchase.
Works fine, it is right one for the laptop, very low cost, I don't know what more you coud ask for a power adaptor.
the best headphones ever they are easy to use and you can adjust the volume and change tracks without having to turn on the ipod and change the track... worth the money
Like the colour, fits perfectly.
This worked great with my MX Air Mouse.  Although I'm not to crazy about t he mouse for gaming.  I use it for my work PC now.
Absolutely love this product. I thought I would miss a book but it really is the same. Download of books is so qiuck.A great buy and big enough to!
Very high quality' looks great, works great. My wife loves it!!! Would recommend this to anyone, good value and choice of colors.

The case is super generically made so  my harddrives kind of rattled inside of it, The cables worked as well as i needed them to. the soldering on the bored itself looks like it was done by a very well trained monkey(the sata to board is the one im referring to) but i liked it and it works. It works wonders in my MacBook Pro. With two of this memory I upgraded to 16GB total and I can process massive quantity of pictures in LR

As a technolgy genius, I can't scretch enough about not buying overpriced cables.

HDMI is HDMI, if there's any fault or error in the cable, it was start to produce \\"noticeable\\" picture problems, so its even yes or no.

Don't worry about mbits of speed, because like I say if its not giving you the full 1080p speed it will start to produce error.

Comparing a 40$ HDMI cable vs 0.20$ HDMI \\"that works correctly\\" will have the 100% exact same result.
Good sound for size and prize. Worth it!
This Kindle II cover is well designed : protective but folds back so it is comfortable in your hands.  I have yet to need to remove it to read in bed, on plane or in the beach chair.
It takes a little time to get used to the difference between this and a regular mouse, but worth it.
Great computer so far, I love it!!!!!!!!
This is a sleek looking router that has great range.   It was easy to set up.  I am using it with a media extender and streaming video with it and it works flawlessly.
Using this as external hard drive for Xbox one. It's working out great! Great size for portability and has fast load times

My other kindle started getting lines on the screen.  It was still under warranty and Amazon sent me this new Kindle to replace my defective one.  I love it.  I have a hard time getting use to the advertisements that display but I still LOVE it!!!
Roomy and light. I can nicely fit my iPad, phones, back batteries and sketch book. I'm happy!
It's quiet and does what I need for the price I wanted to pay.  The only annoyance is it goes into energy saving mode sometimes and fall asleep.  I'm sure there's some way to tweak it somewhere.

I finally replaced the two I purchased with two Samsung SSDs... not one BSOD. I really wanted the larger capacity of the XT750, and was willing to live with the performance sacrifice. However, my use case was to use them in a RAID 1 mirror boot volume, and BSODs are unacceptable.

I'll keep them for lower risk use cases, but really feel like I was foolish purchasing them.

This product works and does what it says, but definitely comes with some caveats.  It's quite finicky, and an absolute nightmare to setup and get working properly.  If you're using this to run non-Displayport monitors, you're in for a long day of setup and configuration.  It's not simply plug and play, more like plug and pray.  I'm using it on an nVidia Quadro K2200 to support a total of 4 monitors.  If the two devices you're plugging into it are native Displayport monitors, it most likely will work without too many issues.  If they're anything else such as HDMI or DVI, chances are only one of them will work if both are the same type of connection.  My current working setup is two identical RCA HDMI TVs and two Acer V246HL monitors.  I have one Acer monitor connected directly to the Quadro card's DVI port, one RCA TV direct to the card's Displayport with an HDMI to Displayport cable, and this Accel MST hub plugged into the video card's other Displayport.  Into the MST hub, I have one RCA TV plugged in via HDMI to Displayport cable, and one Accell active Displayport to DVI adapter feeding the other Acer monitor.  This is the ONLY configuration of these four devices that would work.  I am a seasoned IT professional, and tried every assortment of connecting these four devices, with every passive and active adapter imaginable, this is the only way I could get 1920x1080 on 4 separate monitors.  Also, this hub will do strange things with EDID information.  The nVidia control panel kind of sort of knows there are four monitors but not fully in the same way as if you had four plugged straight into a video card.  If EDID matters to you in your setup, this may not be the device for you.  I had to export the EDID information of the RCA TV's plugged straight into the card actually to a text file, and tell the nVidia control panel to read it from there, because somehow the use of this MST hub caused the card to not recognize that other RCA TV on reboot, requiring a physical unplugging and replugging of that display on every reboot.  The order of which I plugged things into the video card and into the MST hub made a big difference in getting everything recognized properly.  Also, two HDMI TVs on this MST hub flat out would not work, and two DVI monitors (with either active or passive adapters or one of each) on this MST hub flat out would not work.  Also, it should be noted that it would appear that this MST hub superimposes a null audio signal onto the HDMI feed out when HDMI audio is disabled (!!!) in Windows playback devices, which is a big problem for me, because it causes the TV to think its getting audio when clearly it's not, and will not mix in the 3.5mm analog feed.  The trouble with all this newfangled Displayport stuff is that all of these caveats and technicalities are not well documented anywhere, and unfortunately the unsuspecting user like you has to turn to reviews like this for help, because you cannot just Read The (Friendly) Manual, because there isn't one.  After lots of unplugging and replugging and rebooting and whatnot, I finally have a working stable configuration, but for most users, if you are using this to go from 3 monitors to 4, you are likely better off just buying a video card with four distinct ports on it.

It arrived within 2 days. I immediately tested a number of these memory card slots. I didn't experience anything negative or defective, like others experienced in the negative reviews; like the pins breaking. Maybe other reviewers didn't know which slot to put their memory card into. It helps to read the small diagram/instruction sheet that describes each type of memory card it accepts; TF, Micro-SD, SD, Mini SD, SDHC, MMC, XD, MS, etc. It does not read SIM cards. If you handle it with kid gloves, it should last.  It's made in China, just like everything else that's low quality and cheap in price.  It has a usb cord that is detachable. I was hoping for something that had a collapsible plug-in usb.  It's works fine, especially if you don't have the money to spend on one that is a better quality.

I got this Kindle to replace my old first generation Kindle w/ 3G.  I wanted the 3G on this one but it was a gift and let's face it, you can get wifi most places now.  I couldn't be happier with the paperwhite part.  It was difficult to read at times, especially in bed with questionable lighting with my old Kindle and I felt a lot of eyestrain.  This is a miracle from that perspective.  The only drawbacks I have found are:  1.  It is significantly smaller than my old Kindle (my old one had a keyboard as opposed to a touchscreen)  and I find it a little more awkward to hold.  2.  The touchscreen is actually a bit of a pain in the ass.  It is pretty sensitive and sometimes when I touch to turn the page it shoots forward a chapter instead of a page (which really sucks trying to find where you were at since the bottom does not display page number but "location") and sometimes it brings up the dictionary (which you just have to touch again to get rid of).  Also it sometimes it brings up the main menu <sigh> .  I also REALLY miss the buttons on BOTH sides of the Kindle for page turning.  I like to alternate sides when I'm laying in bed reading and if I am on my right and holding with my left hand I have to switch hands to turn the page which makes it much less convenient.  I would like my buttons back.  I know everything is touchscreen now but if they could return the buttons too for page turning convenience I would be a happier Kindle owner.  All-in-all I love my Kindle and would highly recommend the paperwhite to anyone.  Also make sure you turn wifi off (put in airplane mode).  Battery lasts much longer this way and you can just turn it back on if you need to download a book.  My battery was a lot longer lasting in the old Kindle but the sacrifice for the back lighting is well worth the relatively small decrease in battery life.

Absolutely love this keyboard. The key action is awesome - it's very satisfying to type on and the clicking noise is pretty minimal. I'm a professional software engineer and type all day for a living. I have a Kinesis Advantage Pro at work, and use this at home (so that my wife can type on it). I love my kinesis, but this thing gives it a run for its money. The keys actually feel MUCH better, and I can definitely type faster on it. The keyboard itself feels heavy, sturdy, and of overall very high build quality.

Other than the awesome keys, my favorite feature is the fact that the cord is detachable. This is actually super useful, allowing me to swap it between my various PCs and my laptop very easily. I also very much like the smaller profile (without the 10-key on the side) - and this is one of the few keyboards out there that actually manages to get this layout right without jacking around with the standard key layout (a cardinal sin for keyboard makers!!! I will NEVER buy one of those keyboards with the non-standard ENTER key!) The reduced travel distance between keyboard and mouse really helps.

Overall awesome keyboard, and I highly reccomend it.

These are effective enough to listen to throughout the adjoining living room to my office, however, these are probably not the best choice if you use your computer as your only stereo.

I received my Kindle Fire yesterday and of course got a cover for it (as well as a screen protector).

There are 6 little \\"brackets\\" to hold the device in place. I was skeptical but they're actually very sturdy. To create a hands free system for watching movies, you can take the Kindle out of the last two brackets so that four are holding the top portion in place. The bottom part will then rest on a grippy section on the other side of the cover. I was also a little suspicious that this wouldn't work but it does!

There is a hand strap one can use, but I don't find it to be necessary. The case material is textured enough (I guess it's supposed to be leather) that I don't feel the need to have my hand in a strap. There is also an elastic strap to hold the case closed, which is handy.

The case does not feel flimsy and I think this case is a worthwhile investment. I think it's a fairly sophisticated looking case and it functions well. I would hate to drop my Kindle Fire even with the case, but then I'm the paranoid that has an OtterBox case for my phone and I still hate dropping it. This case does feel cushioned enough that I think it would be okay if it happened to fall.

I give this product five stars as it does everything it is supposed to do and while I've only used it less than a day, it does these things to satisfaction.

There is a lot of wiggle room in the new i360 whereas the older version has a snugger fit. It still rotates however I have one side propped up to level it out otherwise it the top of the monitor leans into the iMac it is sitting next to.

The HTC EVO View 4G is a great tablet that is very powerful and versatile. It is easy and fun to use and makes performing tasks much easier. While it can be used with a data plan, it is not necessary to have in order for the tablet to perform.

The Pros of the tablet:
- Bright screen
- Evernote integration is very handy for keeping notes in meetings and for creating lists and reminders.
- Having the expandable memory slot is very helpful, and adds to the already significant amount of memory that the tablet ships with.
- Very quick and apt at multi-tasking
- Audio quality of the speakers is very good

The Cons of the tablet:
- The battery of the tablet is not removable and parts are somewhat difficult to find, so if something happens to the tablet, it is harder to get fixed.
- The battery life is mediocre, and with heavy use I usually only get about 22 hours of use on a full charge.

This tablet is great for people who want it as a personal device but also powerful enough to perform in a business setting, making it useful to many different types of people.

This laptop is almost awesome, except for one crucial problem: the touchpad. It is so bad it makes the laptop almost unusable without an external mouse.    The touchpad is a BAD knockoff of the apple touchpad from their macbookpro line. The HP/Synaptics touchpad on this model of laptop allows for multi-touch gestures, though scrolling is the only one that seems to work. Despite this multi-touch ability they did not enable two-finger touch to be a right-click. Massive drawback.    The touchpad has the feature that if you push down on the touchpad with pressure, it will physically \\"click\\".  Here is the problem:    Left clicking: A light tap on the touchpad, anywhere, counts as a left click. But a heavy tap that makes the \\"click\\" in the touchpad happen, only works INSIDE of the little drawn rectangles that are the right and left \\"buttons\\".  This is hugely counter-intuitive. You'll be scrolling away down a document and go to left click on something and because you pushed it a hair too hard, and it doesn't count. This becomes infuriating after the 10th time. It has to be lightly, or inside the little drawn on box.  Accidentally drag another finger over the touchpad while you are clicking? NOTHING. no click. Leave a finger of the left \\"button\\" like you would on a normal touchpad with buttons?  NOTHING. no click    Right Clicking: Apple made their multi-touch mouse right click when you touch it with 2 fingers. HP, when deciding to make a knock off of their mouse, left this out. Instead left clicks can ONLY happen inside of the little left button box that is drawn onto the touchpad. Light taps in the box don't work, must be a hard tap so the touchpad \\"clicks\\".  A light tap, even inside of the \\"left button\\" box, is a right click.    The rest of the laptop: Decent. With a core i5 and plenty of ram, this laptop is snappy running Windows 7. The screen is gorgeous. Onboard hdmi, vga, esata, and gigabit nic are all nice features. I'd like more than 3 usb ports, but that's not a deal breaker for me. They integrated the hp quick launch buttons into the F keys, which would be annoying if I used them. I never used them, however, on my previous HP and didn't plan on it for this one, so no big deal.    The laptop isn't exactly light, but it is lighter than the previous model with the same size screen. Overall weight I would rate as good. It has a full keyboard with number pad, which is nice.    Overall: Laptop is good if you don't plan on using the built in touchpad. If you plan on using this touchpad constantly, keep looking. I've used it for 2 weeks now and still haven't gotten used to this strange touchpad.  HP massively missed the mark when coping apple's multi-touch touchpad, and completely fubar'ed it.

I had already purchased a cheapie five-buck cover for my Kindle Paperwhite. It was very basic, but fit the Kindle perfectly, included strong magnets to keep the cover closed and turn the Kindle on and off, was padded, and looked nice. But I had a picture that was perfect for my Kindle, so I bought this cover.

The cheapie cover is nicer than this one in every way except for the custom printing. This one doesn't fit the Kindle well. It doesn't have magnets. The hand-strap prevents the cover from fully closing unless you put the elastic strap around it, and then the front cover bends around the handstrap, which means that the handstrap is putting pressure on the Kindle screen. It's kind of lumpy where the elastic straps are sewn into the cover, and has some odd bulges in the middle of the covers, and the edges aren't straight. Overall, if you were to ask me which cover is the cheapie one and which is the certified one, this one would be my guess as the cheap-o.

The custom image is neat. I had to futz around a bit during the ordering process to make sure my picture uploaded correctly and then filled the entire cover. The resulting printed image looks really good. It is very high resolution and sharp. The only problem is that the printing isn't very bright, so the white sections of the image look rather gray, and the colors are dull. It's not bad, but it's not ideal. I would have thought that the printers would have laid down a white background under the image instead of printing the image directly onto the dark cover.

Overall, 2 stars for the cover itself, 4 stars for the custom printing. If I could figure out how to move the printing to the old cheapie cover, I would.

A secretary at work and a fellow bibliophile did her best to convince me that the Kindle was worth a go. My knee jerk reaction was that the book couldn't be improved upon, and I sure didn't want to spend more time staring at backlit screens. She showed me how great her screen was, and some of the other features, but it took me a while to warm up to the thought of an electronic book. Much of what I read is off the beaten track, often scholarly books on topics many would find odd.     The Kindle isn't an electronic book. It is a whole library, instantly searchable. Over the past several months I've noticed that many of the books I most want to read are available on the Kindle many of them as free downloads. Our house is overly crowded with books and it can be nearly impossible to find what we want to read or reference because there are just so many titles and my husband and I have very different ideas about how they should be organized...which results in organizational chaos.     The Kindle is a joy to read. It is my new favorite thing. The first one I had arrived with a small mark on the screen. I was reluctant to return it because I didn't want to be parted from it and didn't relish the thought of customer service red-tape. After a few days I made myself call, and couldn't have been more delighted. The polite and friendly person on the other end arranged everything. A shipping voucher arrived by email immediately and I was able to keep reading right up until the new device arrived. Switching my library to the new machine was easy, though I have to refile the books into their proper catagories.    There are some flaws in the system, but I'm confident that any company as helpful and proactive as Amazon will have them resolved. Some issues are up to the publishers, but if anybody can nudge them in the right direction it's Mr. Bezos, my new favorite CEO (Watch his interviews with Charlie Rose, very insightful). Some books are not easy to navigate if one is searching forinformation and jumping around (publisher issue). There is still a little glare on the screen but I'm sure the engineers are working hard to fix it.    Wonderful company, amazing product.

If you're a tech hobbyist like me, you probably have tons of spare computer parts lying around, as well as an extra OS license or two. There is simply no other way to get this powerful a GPU in a laptop at this price. Tomb Raider gets 30 FPS average on Ultimate detail with TressFX enabled. The quad-core CPU is in no way a bottleneck, AMD processors excel at multi-threaded tasks. Configure the machine exactly the way you want - it has room for 2 SATA drives (RAID capable) and 2 memory modules. It features HDMI and Mini DisplayPort, so this machine can double as a powerful desktop with support for large, high-resolution monitors. The keyboard is brilliant with its blue backlighting and well-spaced keys. Driver installation is a snap, the CD installs all drivers with 1 click (you may have more difficulty if you're not using Windows 8). One odd thing that I like about this laptop is that it has no branding on it whatsoever. It comes in a plain box that says "Laptop", and the machine features no logo, just a plain black lid. I feel like the machine is truly mine, personalized to fit my needs. Five stars, great product.

First I'd like to say to take this review with a grain of salt, since its been a long time since I used this product and I'm going off of total recall.

The keyboard types nicely and due to the plastic case, doesn't make a metallic ringing like the Matias Tactile Pro. That having been said, this product has its own fatal flaw, which makes it difficult for me.

It's a power hog. When it works, it doesn't seem to have very much reliability or range, at least when powered off of two Nickel Metal Hydride batteries, which provide 1.2 volts of power each. You can work around this in two ways:

One is to power it via U.S.B.

Granted, the whole point of a wireless keyboard is to have it detached from your computer, either to reduce cable clutter or use it from a distance where a cord would prove inconvenient. You won't have fewer cables this way but the keyboard can be distanced from the computer, if you use a U.S.B. charger of the sort you use for mobile phones and MP3 players. I prefer the ones built into surge protectors, as to not block the outlet for the sake of a relatively low power ac/dc converter. However, one of the sort that comes with every iPod and iPad should work fine regardless

[Sidebar: It should be noted that if you do decide to plug it into the computer, you'll still need to have the wireless dongle plugged in for data transmission purposes, so you'd generally be worse off than if you'd bought a wired keyboard to begin with, since you have to block two U.S.B. ports at a time.]

The other solution is to use higher voltage batteries.

The typical AA battery is the common 1.5 volt disposable Alkaline. This should work fine on occasion but if you plan to use the keyboard frequently, the cost of throwing away your batteries adds up. A rechargable battery type that may work is the relatively uncommon Nickel Zinc chemistry, which provides 1.6 volts on average. I have [[ASIN:B0029NZVZ0 PowerGenix ZR-PGX1HRAA-4B 1 Hour Quick Charger with 4 AA 1.6v NiZn Rechargeable Batteries]] I hear the additional tenth of a volt can be too much for certain sensitive devices, such as camera flashes but for the brief amount of time I used them for the xArmor U9W, they seemed to work fine, albeit still drained rather quickly.

I'm assuming anybody who cares about the keyswitches on their keyboard enough to buy this particular product will be using it frequently, so this can be a bit of an additional hidden cost to use the product as intended. It's a fair bit of an inconvenience too, especially since I personally haven't seen NiZN available in any walk-in store.

When I bought this keyboard it was the only wireless mechanical keyboard available on the market, given that the Filco Majestouch bluetooth keyboard was out of production. There's currently another option now, the kbTalkingPro, I actually much prefer judging by M.S.R.P. values, not only because it averts this problem but also because it's more featureful. I'll talk about that more on that product's page though.

The xArmor remains still noteworthy for a few reasons reasons: One is that it currently has a lower street price that more than makes up for the cost of NiZN batteries, if you don't quite have the capital funds for the kbTalking Pro in your budget. More importantly, it remains the only Wireless U.S.B. option for a mechanical keyboard, if you can't use Bluetooth for some odd reason. There's a wireless mouse combo with this keyboard too, called the U27, although I don't think that's available any longer. It also has brown switches, if that variant of the kbTalking Pro ever happens to sell out.

Nevertheless, the power consumption problems makes it difficult for me to rate the xArmor U9W any better than mediocre at best.

This CompactFlash is designed for serious professional photographers who demand a fast, rugged, and a durable memory card. Amateur/Professional photographers who work under less than ideal conditions will find this card to be fast, reliable and offer good performance. I thought about buying one 2GB card but settled on two 1GB cards, because they are actually a little faster (performance wise) than the 2GB card. The other reason is that I didn't want to be in a situation that if that one 2GB failed, I wouldn't have another to pop in the camera and go unless you have the $$$ to buy two 2GB cards. Besides, it was cheaper to get two 1GB cards than buy one 2GB card. I bought two of these 1GB high speed cards to use with my Canon DSLR 30D and am very pleased with them. My camera doesn't have a problem push the high resolution images to the card.

Approximate Number of Photos per Card Using \\"hi-res\\" JPEG Mode using a 1GB card

Resolution #of pictures

1MP 2925

2MP 1137

3MP 853

4MP 512

5MP 409

6MP 320

8MP 292

If you shoot images using RAW (like many pros do), you might want to look ar the 4-8mb cards, because RAW images are much larger and you use converted RAW files to manipulate images (contrast, color, etc.) to produce more detailed images, using packages such as Adobe Photoshop, Adobe Elements or Paint Shop Pro.

Overall, this is a very good card. I've used it on several trips and have not had any problems.

Cons:  Because no fans are installed you are limited to a Celeron or Core Solo (single core version of a Core2Duo), which makes this just as fast as all of the single Core Atom net-tops on the market. Faster processors generate more heat, thus you need a fan, no way around it.   No optical drive, but USB powered DVDRW drives are about $30, and it allows you to hide this device somewhere.   Use the Rii Mini to control this device, available on Amazon from many sellers.   Drivers are simple to find and the built in WiFi makes this very self sufficient.

It is hard to get it all in any of the choices for an iPad air case. It seems whatever you choose, compromises have to be made between, protection, usefulness and bulkiness. This case does everything very well. I cannot imagine a better choice if your priorities are largely protection and usefulness. Because this case add great protection, of course it will add a slight bulk, but nothing I am unhappy with.

The pros:
1. You can position the screen in any angle you desire with the velcro strap and it holds that position very well.
2. Great protection. Very secure when routinely transporting/traveling.
3. Easy to use in the case while keeping the iPad in the case with the case open
4. Handsome case. Very nice materials, nice textures.

Cons:
Only one. Adds a little bulk, but hardly an issue for me. There is no perfect case.

In summary I cannot imagine a better case that shines in all the important reasons for buying a case for the iPad. It does everything well. Also great price.

Seems to be an EXCELLENT unit. I LOVE how easily it slides open and how firmly it shuts without needing any screwdrivers. Very light-weight. Definitely USB 3. Good looking.

My only complaint - and for which I docked a star - is that it appears that there is no way to put it in a mode that allows pass-through access to the drive itself. I put a Samsung 840 EVO 1TB SSD in it, and it works very well, but the Samsung software tools don't recognize the drive as a Samsung drive, because the enclosure remaps things. I don't mind that it remaps things - I gather that's probably necessary for the UASP feature - but I wish I could switch the UASP on and off so that when I want to, I can easily use the Samsung tools e.g. for drive stats and diagnostics.

Back on the positives, this is the only 2.5" external drive enclosure I've ever owned with an on/off switch, and I do love having that feature.

In short : looks great, feels great, super lightweight, very easy to open & close without tools yet firmly held together so it won't slide open by accident. A pleasure in every way except only if you care about direct drive access, which I suspect most people will not.

I just picked these up for $100 with the hope of replacing my Logitech Z520's.  I gave them 4 stars but would have gone 3.5 if it was available.  The Creative T3's are very good.  The bass is great... It's crisp and defined and definitely not \\"fake\\" sounding.  There's a knob on the back of the subwoofer that allows you to adjust the level.  If you're  going to place the sub under a desk (at your feet), you're not going to need much more than one-quarter level to vibrate the room.  The (2) satelite speakers can handle their own at approximately 15 watts each but do sound just a bit flat. What's missing is the mid-range.  Each satelite is 6 inches tall and 3 inches wide on the stand.  The volume cube is nice and allows for a very good range from low to high.  These are great for jazz and something a bit slower but I don't know if I'd like them for rock.  What's equally nice is I'm able to hook these up to my tv (via the headphone jack) and add some nice bass and 2.1 surround for movie-watching.  I do think they can rival the Bose Companion 3's but only because of the price I paid.  I haven't played a game yet, but have no doubt they will do very well with the sound effects.  If you can get them for no more than $120, pick them up.

Speed

Paperwhite has a nice screen for B&W reading but my wife is used to color, searching the internet and other apps plus a headphone jack.  We went out and bought a Kindle Fire and my wife loves it. I just bought this product yesterday (03/26/2011), and I thought I would report what I found. This is a very aestically attractive router, light weight and clean looking. I bought this router to replace a 3 month old Netgear router that works perfectly fine. However, the range INSIDE house was very disappointing, as this is not a huge house, so I thought maybe this Cisco M10 router would be a great improvement. The bottom line is that it is an improvement, but only slightly. I still have a very LOW connectivity in some of the rooms, and its just hard to understand why.
The setup process was very easy using the installation key. I did have to use customer support as my modem has an internal battery and I didn't know how to completely power it down. BTW, customer service is EXCELLENT. I was through after 3 rings on the first call late Saturday afternoon and John walked me through the process like a pro. There are some extras that I really like with this router, such as a guest access with there own password, and extra security features if you have children. I would highly recommend this product to a friend.

I must say on Christmas I was extremely exited about this tablet, especially because it was my very FIRST tablet.

After about a year the device has became extremely sluggish. YouTube videos freeze and crash, apps do not work fast enough like they used to. My Andriod 2.1 with a single core processer runs better than the Kindle Fire!

No camera, either. This was a big dissapointment. The Nexus 7 and Lenovo Ideapad A1 are the same price AND they have cameras, as well as the Google Market. So there is no need whatsoever to root those devices. The Kindle Fire, I was about ready to root but something inside told me not to - and I'm glad I listened, because I sold it for the Lenovo Ideapad A1.

If you're looking for something nicer, please consider the Nexus 7. Andriod Jellybean is almost perfected Gingerbread - it's a bunch smoother, including Project Butter.

~Pros

1. Amazing Customer Support
2. Great for Reading

~Cons

1. No Cameras
2. Extremely Sluggish after time
3. No Google/Andriod Market
4. Custom Skin Gingerbread 2.3

This is the second Samsung SSD I have purchased, one for a loptop (most recently), the other for a desktop (about a year ago, older model). Both devices have snappy performance. Apps open very quickly.

The hardware is sturdy and a reliable brand; the software is not so understandable.If you are a techie, it may be great for you; if you are a layman and want a simple solution, it may not be the one for you.

I ordered and received this monitor from Dell about 2 weeks ago (Amazon actually has a better price on this monitor right now). I wasn't sure what to expect as I wasn't able to see it in person ahead of time to get a sense of the visual created by the monitor. I'm very particular and monitor clarity, sharpness and brightness are important to me for my needs as I'm on the computer ten hours a day most days. I discovered this monitor initially as Dell was offering me a special price on it when I ordered my computer through them. I looked at the reviews on Amazon and thought it was worth taking a chance.

I have been nothing shy of incredibly happy with this purchase. Everything that was important to me is inclusive with this monitor. The sharpness and clarity are amazing. The brightness is perfect. It's very bright but at same time very easy on the eyes. It has a non-glare screen, which I am not usually a fan of as for my taste, the monitors without the non-glare screens always seemed to produce a sharper image, but this monitor has converted me to a non-glare screen fan. I love the non-glare now and I have learned for those who spend a lot of time on the computer, the non-glare helps reduce things like eye strain and headaches. I still would not purchase just any non-glare screened monitor but this one I can confidently recommend.

Features: The monitor can slide up and down on the stand, depending upon the height you prefer and it slides very easily and securely without much effort. You can rotate the monitor toward you or angle it straight, etc. It's very easy and smooth to move it toward you or away from you. It has a nice, 1/2\\" thin bezel which I always think is more apppealing and far less distracting than the wider bezels. The wider bezels also just take up extra space unecessarily to me as it makes the monitor just be bigger for no reason. I find the 24\\" monitor, in this case, to be the perfect size - not too big and just perfectin terms of viewing screen space. It does not have speakers but that is not a problem for me. It may be a problem for others or you could just purchase speakers. I have sound coming out of my Dell computer instead. The quality of the monitor itself is visible and there is nothing cheap looking or cheap feeling about this monitor. It has the power button on the bottom right of the bezel and has 4 other adjustment buttons above the power button. I have not tried adjusting the color as I have not needed to do so, so I cannot comment on the customization of that - but I understand it's fairly customizeable. This monitor is also 1980 x 1200 which is slightly better resolution than most monitors and that extra resolution punch I think does make a different. I beleive most other monitors are 1980 x 1080 and that extra 120 I think must definitely help stretch the clarity of this great monitor.

I see no faults or criticisms to even mention as I am extremely happy with my purchase and would whole heartedly recommend this monitor to others. I do believe Amazon has dropped the price in the past two weeks as the cost was $369 prior and I believe now it is $269 and at $269 it is a bargain for this quality of a monitor. It's definitely pricier than most other monitors as you can buy a decent monitor for about $200 but in my opinion the extra money on this monitor is well worth it if you spend a lot of time on the computer like I do, or are particular when it comes to sharpness, brightness and clarity of a monitor. Get it while you can at the $269 price :)

This case fits my Kindle Touch perfectly with no possibility of it shifting or falling out. The purple color is slightly darker than shown in the photo, which gives a more classic appearance. It did have a strong smell when I first removed it from the packaging, but it was almost completely gone after just one day.  This case is very comfortable to hold while reading for longer periods, and the front flap flips over and lies neatly against the back. Rather than just having corner slots or rubber bands to hold it in, the inside completely frames the screen. Magnets keep the cover closed tightly when you're not reading, the corners of the case are just a bit wider than the Kindle itself, and the outside of the case it slightly padded (but not bulky), all of which keep my device well-protected while being toted along in my purse. Overall, it looks great and seems to be worth much more than I paid for it.

I followed the advice offered in another review modifying the installation process to include starting with clean hands and making sure that the tablet screen is clean of dust and fingerprints. Then the company's installation instructions work easily. I used a credit card to smooth out the air bubbles, as it was a bit larger and the process of eliminating or minimizing bubbles went a lot faster. Just be careful not to press too hard; take a little more time and work patiently, and you will have an installation nearly free of bubbles. If bubbles occur, you can lift up the protector and redo it. Start at one edge and apply to the tablet screen while holding the other edge off, then slowly lower the screen as you work out the bubbles. Takes 5 minutes or so, and you're done. I'm confident that I can now use the tablet without fear of scratching it. I've used these protectors on my Droid smartphone for years, and they've kept it looking like new. I expect the same here.

First off, I only used this for about an hour before other circumstances put the WD HD I bought to use with this went into service in a laptop. It took me 20 minutes to figure out both black panels come off to allow you to install the drive. I also was unable to install one of the side screws without widening the hole. I was debating on whether or not to dock another star, but as long as the controller doesn't fail, these are minor quibbles.

If you plan on taking your hard drive with you this case is a good investment. I ordered this case along with the purchase of the Toshiba Canvio Plus 500 GB USB 2.0 Portable External Hard Drive. The hard drive fits well in the case and the case seems to be well made. I would recommend this case.

We've been using our Kindle Fire for several weeks now, and have been really pleased with it overall.  It's a nice tablet for the price.  The touch screen works well, and I like being able to zoom in easily while web browsing, and the virtual keyboard is convenient. Page turns are occasionally choppy, or don't catch - so I have to page again - but not too often.  I haven't had any issues with battery life, and have used it while travelling with no issues.  Since it is a little on the heavy side, I find myself shifting my wrist around a lot for comfort while reading, or viewing.  The gyroscope is a little too excitable and tries to flip the page orientation with the slightest shift in position.  I usually end up moving back to the same position that was uncomfortable before to keep the page the way I want to view it or fiddling with the angle to try to right it.  When I read for long periods at a time, it can be annoying, but for casual browsing it's really not a problem.

I seldom write reviews because most products are simply in the middle the curve in terms of quality, and are usually well-covered by other reviewers. In this case, however, I'm going to write something to try to warn other potential buyers of this product about its gross shortcomings. First, I will mention a couple of mildly positive aspects. The build quality of the machine is quite good, and it is very light. The flip screen seems sturdy enough that it will likely go through a lot of use before having any issues. Those things said, I will turn to the negative. My main gripe about this product is related the functionality of the track pad and the response of the software to track pad inputs. I'm a long-time Mac/OS user, and really believe that Apple has perfected the operation of their track pads. (In case you're wondering, the only reason I purchased this XPS is because my job requires that I often use a program that runs only on windows, and I travel a good bit). I'll spare you an entire novella about the various problems with the Dell trackpad, and will simply summarize them as such: cheap quality and utterly inconsistent responsiveness. The pad works like a Mac sometimes (just a touch, no clicking) and other times not, it is extremely fussy about where exactly you're touching it, i.e. if you're trying to do a highlight/cut/paste, it's nearly impossible to get a consistent response out the machine - one time it accepts the highlighting exactly as intended, and the next three times it highlights half a line, no line at all, or highlights it, then drops it when you try to cut). Just incredibly frustrating. Problem #2 of many - the combination of this awful track pad and windows system forces the user (and I admit I'm not a power user) to go up to the upper left-hand corner of the screen and click in order to move among active programs. Unlike the Mac, the problem with this machine/software is that it's extremely fussy about the movement and speed of the pointer when you're trying to do this action. One time it works, the next time you'll move it and millimeter too far, or just slightly too fast, and it jumps to another screen without warning. And last - Windows 8 is a really awful product, full of junk, advertising, and useless "functionality" designed to get you to buy more microsoft and Dell products. Avoid this product if at all possible.

Eventually the battery was totally depleted. I removed the battery for a little while, then plugged in my dead laptop with the adaptor and the chirp started again. The sound is coming from the adaptor. Laptop has been off and charging for a good while but it's still completely dead.
Boo. Don't waste your money.

The old IBM legacy of top end notebook computers is over now that Lenovo has taken the product line. This machine is not up to IBM standards, and do not expect IBM quality.
It is quiet, and has a nice display. However, the most used input device on a notebook PC is the mouse, which in this case is a touch pad. This is the worst touch pad I have ever used! You will try all the settings and never get it to work correctly. Just try doing a right click on the background to set display resolution and the background picture. On my Sony Windows 7 notebook this is trivial. On the Lenovo touchpad it is nearly impossible- this thing will not recognize right click! Try to create a short cut on the desk top to your favorite programs- sorry- not possible on this machine!
This touch pad does not have true buttons. Instead, it relies on pressing a certain area of the touch pad. I still can not locate where that area is, so good luck with your experiments in trying to get this to work. It will go back in the box and I will now consider other brands of PC, such as Toshiba. Lenovo has now killed what used to be the BEST notebook brand in the world.
I did note that battery life seems to be OK, and the weight is acceptable. My machine came with a 256 GB solid state hard drive, and this is a nice touch for faster system operation. It should also help the battery last longer, as spinning a hard drive takes a fair amount of energy.
The ultimate solution to making this machine useable is to forget about the touch pad interface, and purchase a nice USB / wireless mouse or external touch pad. Now you can use this machine and make some serious progress on all your computer work. It just means when you travel with this PC you must carry along another piece of hardware- a working mouse.

I've had problems with the Magic Mouse being hard to grip and move for big hands, so when Fliders promised \\"a smoother, more precise experience\\" and saying that \\"moving the mouse becomes easier and less strenuous\\" I was excited to order. I just received the nicely packaged product, and was somewhat surprised that it's just two adhesive strips of felt instead of the spacey green polymer suggested by the photo, making the $9.95 price tag a bit steep. But OK. Whatever works. I'm happy to pay for convenience over having to start a crafts project. Totally fair.

I applied the strips, and... well... it basically stops the Magic Mouse dead in its tracks when I use it with my mouse pad. (Which I need, because it has a built-in wrist support.) The description says that Fliders will let you use your Magic Mouse WITHOUT a mouse pad, though it's not clear that it makes the mouse useless WITH one. So I tried using the mouse without the pad. It so happens that my desk is covered with a type of linoleum cutting matte surface (and an actual self-healing cutting matte). On both surfaces the Fliders make it significantly more difficult to move the Magic Mouse.

Luckily, the Fliders came off fairly easily, with some peeling and scraping and futzing, and did not damage the plastic. Maybe this product works if you're using your Magic Mouse on a glass desk, or a polished wood. I don't know. But please be aware that this product will make your mouse basically useless if you're using it WITH a mouse pad, or on plastic surfaces.
Does the Job

I've owned many kindle through the years and this one is just an upgrade from my HD kindle. I like this device very much. It's thinner, sleeker and has a rear facing camera. The screen is huge and the device is surprisingly light. My only complaint is that it doesn't have dynamic perspective like my fire phone or offer the Google play store.

Packaging: Not a fan of the packaging considering the distance it traveled (Hong Kong, China to Wichita, KS, USA). It was just the mouse itself wrapped 4 times over in bubble wrap and put into a bubble wrap bag.
Delivery Time: Expect it to take a while because it will be shipped from China. The package was delivered 3 days early. :)
Product: I received the product today and I plugged it in an it works fine. The mouse DOES change colors with that top button (so you can't change DPI's from the mouse itself); red, blue, and purple(saying that lightly). The preview images, as you can imagine, are more saturated than the real thing. Red looks like the picture only a little lighter; good for me because it's my favorite color. Blue looks the best (even distribution of color); MUCH lighter than the picture though. Purple(?) looks NOTHING like the picture; It look like they made purple by turning on both blue and red LED's (purplish in some regions and blue in others). The mouse feels plastic and light (cheap) but looks super cool. I didn't expect the cord to be so short; probably like 4.5 to 5 feet. The cord feels cheap and durable at the same time; feels like the surface of a vinyl record. the cord's connection to the mouse feels kinda loose and I think it'll be the first thing to go. Overall, I am satisfied but I don't expect this product to last more than a year or 2. I don't play League of legends but if I did I wouldn't expect this mouse to last more than a year. Good thing I bought it with a gift card :). Need a cheap gaming mouse to get you by (1.5 months after purchase)? This is the product for you.

EDIT: After playing KOTOR 2 for about 5 hours with this mouse: It's very comfortable. Another reviewer said it was made for people with large hands and I have large hands and found it to be a little on the small side (same size as my old logitech mouse) but still comfortable. The black parts of the mouse create ridges/bumps that you can feel, like the black is higher than the white/opaque-transparent(that the color comes through) parts. The top is very smooth and the side have a rough texture. The sides feel cheaper than the rest. Also, a very light mouse as you can imagine.

I'm no expert on mice, I just wanted to make a review that paints a picture of the product. If you have any questions, feel free to contact me.

My E4200 was sitting in a box waiting for me to have time to replace my older Netgear router with it. Last night the wireless function of my Netgear router suddenly died, and the wireless internet and my Ooma phone service stopped working. After I determined that the problem was with the wireless capabilities of my original router, it took me ~10 minutes to bring Linksys E4200 on line and get the internet connectivity back.

The router comes packaged with an ethernet cable and a setup software CD. I followed instructions from the setup CD and it was very easy. When prompted to setup the network name and password, I entered my old network's SSID and pass phrase, and all devices (PC laptop, Mac laptop, and an Android Tablet) connected to the router without a problem.

I have Charter Cable 20 Mbps connection using Motorola SURFboard SB5101U. I don't do any online gaming; only email, internet browsing, Netflix, and occasionally some Youtube videos, so I did not notice any increase in speed compared to my old router whether one or many devices are used simultaneously.

I did not notice heat to be a problem as another reviewer mentioned, and I do have port lights ON. I have the router inside the TV stand behind the glass. The TV stand has only one major opening and it is in the back, and, although the ventilation is not great, the router is still just warm, but not hot.

I realize that this router is an overkill for my needs, but I am reviewing my experience with it, such as ease of setup and the fact that it works well with all my devices for anyone who is interested in these aspects. Overall, I think that this is a great router, although an expensive one.

This has been an excellent little product and at a great price. It is much smaller than I had expected it to be, and easily fits in the palm of your hand. Sound quality is great if you hook it up to a decent system, and to the casual listener, there's not much different between this and plugging straight into a 3.5 mm jack.

Allows me to play straight onto my surround sound from my Nexus 5 or Surface Pro 2 with no hassle and incredibly simple pairing. Not only is it convenient and allow you to play music without being tethered to a cable, but it also keeps me from having to plug a 3.5 mm plug into a headset jack for either of those devices, so it spares me the wear and tear I might otherwise have to deal with (I've had multiple phone headset jacks go bad from that).

All in all, a great and simple little device.

This worked perfectly.  I got it to extend my network to some far bedrooms and now I went from no signal to 3 out of 5 bars.  I live in an adobe house and the wall are very thick and dense. You have to wire-connect the range extender and your computer/laptop to your router.  Run the setup wizard software which asks for admin password for the router, which wireless network you want to extended and what SID you want to use for the extended network. That is it for the initial setup.  There are more features, but you don't need them to get it working.  It was very easy and has worked flawlessly since I set it up.    Router is D-Link DIR-655 using WPA encryption.

I heard a lot of good things about Lenovo so I decided to give it a try. So far, I'm not impressed.

First, I hate Windows 8. Just hate it. Microsoft needs to stop coming up with these stupid \\"new and improved\\" ideas and forcing them on the consumer. At the very least, give choices instead of making it ridiculously hard to find older versions that are better. One thing that drives me nuts is when on the internet, a screen keeps popping up about \\"only show secure content\\". I continually hit \\"ok to show content\\" on the same site and it keeps popping up. Seems on older versions, this would no longer pop up. If I have to go through more steps to make it stop, then MS took a step backwards.

The other things (more hardware related) that I don't like:

1. The touchpad is too touchy. It keeps changing the size of the screen (enlarging and shrinking), even when you are trying to stop it from shrinking or enlarging. It happens consistently which is really annoying.
2. The screen I am typing on will keep changing to another screen and I have to go back and find the original page. Heck, it just happened again while typing this review.
3. I also don't find this laptop to be any quicker than my older one which as less memory. I expected to see a difference.

I'm sure there are some positive things about this computer but between Windows8 having a \\"too busy\\" look to it and the distraction of the screen changing sizes, I can't come up with anything.
Exactly what I needed and great service

This chromebook is excellent, it meets every expectation I had. I remember researching it before I purchased and there were some buyers who speculated about the Arm-based processor. To be honest, the processor is very snappy, and I have yet to see the device boggled down, even with 10 browsing tabs open. I have been told Google had yet to unlock the potential of the Samsung Arm-based processor and as time goes on Google is working on building software to utilize the capability. Perhaps this is why the processor is so snappy at this time, because there has been a considerable amount of time for proper drivers to be designed.The build quality feels great, and it's easy to tell the chromebook was designed to combat minor bumps or knock overs. However, because the casing is plastic I bought an iPearl shell (which was quite affordable) to prevent scratches. The screen quality is average, not mind-blowingly great, but good enough where it never bothered me. I am familiar with all the current operating systems (Mac, Linux, Windows, Chrome) and would have to say I never feel limited in the Chrome OS. I had a windows netbook a couple years back and used it for essentially the same thing (browsing, movies, flash games, online banking, instant messaging). I never used the netbook for intense games or graphic design because it was running an intel atom processor. Although I liked my netbook, it lacked the speed, security, stability, battery life, low price, seamless updates, virus vulnerability, and solid feel/finish that the Samsung Chromebook has. Thank you for making such a great machine Samsung, and thank you for making a such an excellent OS Google! I highly recommend this chromebook for anyone looking in it's price range ($200-$250)
