After trying various Logitech and Cyber Acoustic 2.1 systems that sounded more or less \\"okay\\", I finally decided to give the Klipsch ProMedia 2.1's a try. In a word...there's NO COMPARISON. (Okay...that's two words.) The Klipsch 2.1's blew away all the other 2.1 systems. Granted, the ProMedia's cost about 3 times as much, but still...You FEEL the music with these speakers, even at low volumes (which, in its own way, is even a better test of a speaker system than blasting them til your ears bleed.) No other system I tried resulted in the ability to feel the music like the ProMedia 2.1's.

A while back I made a USB flash drive with all of my favorite songs to play in my car -- over 1,200 songs, covering all different genres. So to give these new speakers a real world workout I plugged that USB drive into my laptop, loaded everything into WMP, hooked up the ProMedia 2.1's, and after the first few tunes I was in heaven. I hadn't heard so much out of these tunes since my old Atlantic Technology 3 piece system died. The bass took on a life of its own, as did the highs, mids, and sound stage.

I can't speak to the durability problems since I just got the speakers at Best Buy yesterday. But judging only by the sound, they are amazing, especially for the price. Would I prefer an on/off switch? Yes. Am I a bit concerned about the problems cited with the DIN plug? Yes. Do those issues offset the sound coming out of this system? Not at the present time. But I'll certainly update this review if/when the DIN problem arises. For now, I'm just enjoying music in a way that I can only describe as thrilling. And I haven't had that experience in quite some time. Listening to the ProMedia 2.1's showed me, almost instantly, just how much I'd been missing.

I like the mouse for use when I'm using the laptop in bed or on the sofa because it works on my leg and most fairly smooth surfaces. It doesn't need a large area.  It didn't work across wrinkled fabrics or my ultra-fuzzy bathrobe. I would not recommend it as the only mouse option because the finger band isn't comfortable for hours of use and it gets in the way if I want to do serious typing on the keyboard. The Amazon picture shows it being used on the index finger but I found that awkward. The picture on the package showed it on the middle finger with the index finger going across the top of the unit and the thumb pressing the buttons and scrolling. This made it much more stable and easier to control. It also helps with typing since the index fingers type more than the middle fingers. Rotating it more toward the thumb was also helpful. I have a wireless mouse that I use when working at a desk, I can seamlessly switch between the two without unplugging either or making any changes to the settings. It feels cheaply made, but how else could they sell it for so little. I've only had it for about 3 weeks, but so far so good.

Straight out of the box, the middle flex point was slightly raised so the cover stood up like a dome on my iPad. I tried to fold it down and it would stay for some time before popping back up. Also, the magnets barely deactivate the iPad. The cover does Not stay on if I flip the case over. Sometimes the iPad turns on because the cover pops in the middle. So I have to always keep it face down on the table to keep it turned off.

The material itself is like a slightly shiny black plastic. The inside is soft as well as the part that touches the back of the iPad. However, the plastic that surrounds the boarders of the iPad is not padded. The grip is very tight though, so I don't there would be much movement and I'm not too concerned about scuffs/scrapes from the case.

Overall, I'm happy with the material and fit of the case. I am very unhappy with performance of the cover.

I bought this yoga 8" tablet while on vacation in the Philippines (i'm not sure if the one I bought is available in the US, with "voice") , this tablet comes in three versions, the one I have is the quadcore "voice". I got home in california and took the sim card out of my samsung note II and cut the sim card to a micro sim card and stuck it in and it worked fine (I have ATT&T).

At first people laught and thought I was silly to have an 8" tablet as a cell phone and I was feeling bad. But its been almost a month now and I love it.

I no longer have to find my tablet & a cell phone. I also bought a Rapoo little blue tooth keyboard to go with it and the combo is great! I can talk on the phone while replying to an email and then pull up my email or calender and be taking notes and making appointments way better than trying to do it on a smart phone.

My laptop has pretty much replaced my desktop, and this little gadget with MS Office and cloud computing is very quckly replacing my laptop computer, I only take my laptop with me on about half my trips since I can do almost all of my work on this little tablet. It was very convinet on the plane too, my laptop was too big to open on the plane, but since I usually don't fly coach, I don't see that problem happening again.

The built in stand is fantastic too, it was hard to find a case for it, but i eventually did. If you text and email 90% of the time, then this gadget is for you, I only talk on the phone 10% of the time, so making a phone call on speaker phone isn't really bad. I would not have bought this product had I known it was a Chinese company, since I do not support communists, but it has been a great product.

The only reason I didn't give it five stars is because I'm still earning how to use it and samsung did have more user friendly ways of writing quick memos, but overall I love this thing. I has a long battery life too.

The JKase(TM) Executive Series Premium Quality Custom Fit Folio Case Cover is not necessarily a surprise. It simply is exactly what is described. The leather is of high quality. The stitching is tight, neat and secure. It fits the Kindle securely and matches the screen just right. There is a tiny bit of room around the edges of the screen. This is important since some of the functions of the Kindle require tapping or touching at the edge of the screen and you don't want the leather creating distance or changing the way you touch/interact with the screen. The back of the cover has a well stitched leather strap or slit attached to sturdy elastic. This allows you to slip between 1 to 4 fingers through the back with either hand so that the Kindle is suspended from your hand and doesn't require you to clutch the Kindle between thumb and fingers. It sounds silly as I write this but I often read for 4-6 hours straight on the weekend and little muscles begin to quiver and shake from trying to manipulate and hold the Kindle. This back-slit is way more important than it may sound (the first time a friend showed me theirs I thought, yeah you bought a cheap marketing ploy - I was wrong). The case is lightly padded and I feel safe putting my Kindle in a satchel or briefcase. The case comes with a matching black elastic band that can strap the case closed or be bound over the back of the Kindle, out of the way. My only concern - and I have no evidence either way - would be, how long will the elastic on the back-slit and the elastic strap that closes the unit last before it is loose or begins to unravel. Again, this isn't a design criticism, it's just something I don't know because I've only had the case a few months. All in all, I'm very happy with this case. It's elegant, high quality and functional. I recommend it highly. UPDATE: 1.5 years in, the case is still in great shape, the elastic is still strong. Initial impression stands.

I received the item listed as 'new' with a huge crack in the screen.  Not sure if damaged in shipping or warehouse?  As for the tablet itself, it is a major hassle to use, but once you get it functioning, it is fine.  If you copy files from your pc to your tablets appropriate folders, it does not reccognize them.  The computer registers the files as being there on the tablet, but when you try to find them on your tablet, there is nothing on the screen.  It was an awful frustrating time trying to transfer my books to the tablet and I am still struggling with that a couple weeks after the purchase.  Maybe mine is just bad or something-it did appear damaged so I don't rule out the possibility.  I also think the processor is kind of crappy.  It takes forever to load applications, like the Kindle reading app for instance.  It also locks up sometimes.  As for positive things about the tablet, once you finally do get it working, it fuctions well as a reader.  I have tried some simple gaming applications with no trouble as well.  My overall review is that you get what you pay for.  If you want a cheap tablet, you get a cheap tablet.  If you buy this tablet, don't be expecting it to be like a Kindle-its not.  However, if you can figure out how to transfer the books, its a great little device; fun for road trips or a quiet pass-time.  Had I recieved mine in the new condition described, I would have given it a 4 star rating.  If it were in new condition AND I could get my books onto it, I would give it a 5 star rating.  As I received mine, cracked and possibly defective, I rate a 3.  It functions but its incredibly aggravating.

I was surprised to see that so many people have complained about this mouse because I specifically logged in to write a glowing review for it! I've had this little guy for about 18 months now, and after recently buying a different, supposedly \\"high quality\\" mouse for another computer, I ended up swapping it for another of these mouse units.

The biggest surprise to me in other users' complaints is the mouse's performance on various surfaces; I've used mine on two different styles of standard mousepads (one gel & one rubberized), a vinyl desktop cover, the kitchen table, my desks at home and at work, the floor, the arm of my recliner, and on top of several books, all with ZERO issues. I personally like my mouse to always be visible on screen, even when typing, and I adjust the settings for quick movement, and the only problem I've ever experienced is that when I was using the mouse on my recliner, it would occasionally roam--but that could easily be due to either the microsuede material (certainly not an intended surface!) or the fact that the recliner is also a rocker, so it's less stationary than a desk.

In short, I'm sorry to hear that others have had issues, but for me, this is the best mouse I've used and I absolutely would recommend it.

The P9X79 Workstation is easy to work with and provides a stable foundation for my i7 3930K. Since this is my first Intel and ASUS combo in over ten years, I can tell you this is a great board for programmers/designers or enthusiasts. The new point-and-click BIOS is so simple to use your system should be stable on first boot up. The layout provides 6 expansion slots and there are plenty of SATA connections as well...I ran out of drive bays before I ran out of SATA connections! With 7 HDD and 1 SSD, a video card with 3D, RAID and audio cards along with a Blu-ray combo ROM and a DVD/CD burner...not to mention an Antec 920 and 5 other fans...with all that, this board runs very cool. Even the 32GB of G.Skill memory runs cool. If you need more USB ports or and external fire wire connection, ASUS provides cards...but you use up an expansion slot.

In short, this board is all you'll need. Do not hesitate...buy it now! And if you're still not sure...check out Tom's Hardware site.

I have had the Kindle Keyboard and the lighted case for that device for a year now and I've been very impressed with the quality of that case.  I just recently purchased the new Kindle and the new lighted case.  What a let-down!  This new case is a major step backwards in terms of quality and engineering.    First off, let's go through the positives of this case:  1.)  The light is now centered over the Kindle, which provides more even lighting than the Kindle Keyboard case.    2.)  The rubberized housing in the case has sufficient grip to allow me to feel that my Kindle is being held securely.  That's about it for the positives.  Now for the negatives:  1.)  The light is very flimsy.  The hinge on the swing-out light is loose and the plastic is so thin and light-weight that one decent snag on a sweater or bag will probably break the light right off of the case.  2.)  The front cover of the case is far too flexible, providing just above zero protection for the fragile e-ink screen.  It wouldn't take much pressure on the front cover to crack the Kindle's screen underneath.  3.)  The leather on the front and back of the case has no texture to speak of, so the case is slick in the hands and it scratches easily.  Within 30 minutes of receiving my case, I already had a scratch on the front cover and that came from simply putting the Kindle down on my desk and sliding it a few inches.  4.)  The rubberized housing which holds the Kindle in place does it's job a little too well, making it difficult to actually press the back and forward page turn buttons on both sides of the device.  With the Kindle out of the case, pressing either the back or forward buttons with minimal force gives a satisfying \\"click\\".  With the Kindle in the case, you have to exert much more force on the buttons to get them to register and the \\"click\\" is gone, making it more difficult to determine if you've actually pressed the button or not.  I spent about 20 minutes with an Xacto knife and a file to remove a good chunk of the rubber and plastic housing in order to allow me to press the buttons easily again.  5.)  There is no method for keeping the cover closed.  The Kindle Keyboard cover has a nice elastic band that keeps the cover closed, even when you're tossing it in a book bag.  There is nothing on this new cover.  So the cover can and will fly open if you aren't careful with it.  All in all, this is a poorly designed case that apparently was not even tested before being shipped out.  I could forgive the flimsy cover and cheap leather, but having the rubber conflict with the page turn buttons is unacceptable.  I shouldn't have to resort to cutting and filing the plastic and rubber in order to fix a problem that should have been caught on the first day of quality control.  The fact that Amazon is charging $60 for a cheaply-made cover that provides almost no protection is completely outrageous.  This case would be overpriced at $20.

Every-so-often, the buzzing goes away for about 1 to 2 minutes, but it ALWAYS returns with a vengence!  Otherwise, the enclosure has held up and worked nicely for almost 1 year.  I'm definitly going to get rid of it though once I find an enclosure that is equally aesthetically pleasing and as reliable, but not NEARLY as noisy!!! To start off, this is my first keyboard that does not have a traditional flat design. I wanted to try something new and have an enhanced typing experience.

This keyboard have a very attractive appearance, in my opinion. It's rather large and all the keys are generously spaced. All of the "extra" functional keys around the outside of the keyboard work well and can be assigned to do any task through the software that Logitech provides. The wrist/palm rest is big bonus. This isn't your typical hard plastic palm rest. It's actually padded with a faux leather type feel to it. Very nice touch, Logitech. All in all, I'm giving it an A for appearance.

Now lets talk functionality and typing experience. The wave ergonomic form of the keys allow your fingers to lay very comfortably on the home row. Originally I thought that I would have to get accustomed to the curve of the keys but that is not so. I plugged it in and was able to type on it no problem. In fact my typing speed increased quite a bit from my original keyboard (Logitech K360). I used to average around 72 WPM. On this keyboard, I average around 84 WPM, a significant bump in my opinion. There are two negative remark that I have to make about the typing experience. The first being the wave shape towards the middle of the keyboard. The wave shape rises right in the middle where the T U keys are. This makes your hand stretch just a little to reach them which is unusual to me. Another minor complaint is the feel of the keys. They're a little "mushy". The light action of the keystroke makes up for the mushiness but it's just something to note. I think Logitech did this to make it more of a silent keyboard because in the noise sector, this keyboard is SUPER quiet. Overall, the typing experience is an A-.

The addition of the mouse to this package is what really makes this worth your money. The mouse is awesome. It's a little heavy with both batteries in (but it actually works with one if you prefer the lighter weight). Besides that, the Logitech laser technology is extremely accurate and the mouse sits very comfortably in the hand. There are three button on the left side (forward, backward, and a programmable button). The "infinite" scrolling is also a useful addition. It allows you to scroll through documents or web sites very quickly and you can stop it at any point.

Overall, this is a great package and worth every cent.

I hate mouse pads.  They're obsolete with today's optical mice that can track on any surface....or so I thought.  I bought this pad on a 'maybe it will work' whim when I bought my G5 mouse.  All I can say is WOW.    Tracking is incredibly smooth.  The pad surface allows you to fully unlock the potential of a premium gaming mouse.  The Speed side is incredibly smooth, and my mouse just glides.  The control side it a little more course, so you are more aware of the mouse movement on the pad.  I can't tell any difference in pointer tracking on either side, but each side definately offers a distict tactile feel.  Both sides are equally functional, so which side you use depends on your own preference.    On a side note, I have a Logitech wireless MX600 that will not track on this pad, but works great on any other surface.  I think you may need a premium gaming laser to accurately track on this pad.  That was no big deal to me, as I was happy to use my G5 for everything and ditch the wireless.

Setting up the cards is mostly painless, though the instructions and software are not the most user-friendly. No problems transferring jpg images and videos from either camera to a Motorola Droid running Android 2.2.3. or uploading to Flickr. You can pick and choose in camera or set the card to upload everything. If you're transferring photos to a mobile device rather than a home computer, I would not advise transferring everything automatically; battery life in the mobile device will suffer.

UPDATE: Just returned from a 2400-mile round-trip train trip from Los Angeles to Portland, Oregon and back. I used the Coolpix P7100 and the 8GB Mobile X2 card to shoot photos and video from the train and on hikes in the Portland area, transferring photos wirelessly to my Droid phone. I did have a couple of times near the end of the return leg of the trip where the camera said the card could not be used. This occurred twice when I powered up the camera and once trying to review already taken photos. All the photos and videos I took did record just fine. I don't know if this was an issue with the camera or the card, but removing and reinserting the card fixed the problem. A minor annoyance, but worth mentioning. Also, the cards are not the fastest I've used. There was a bit of lag sometimes where I'd have to wait for a photo to write to the card before I could shoot again.

First off, USB 3.0 is really fast. It's more than I expected since I usually really underestimate the listed speeds. They're always a bit exaggerated so I didn't expect super speed. But since I just bought a laptop with USB 3.0 slots, I have seen an amazing increase in speed.

Pros: Solid construction. Fast transfer speeds. Large capacity. Great price ~$28.

Cons: The cap doesn't clip and so you'll lose it, but I really don't care. It gets hot, but that's because so much information is streaming through every second. If you fill it up in one transfer, like I did, you'll be surprised at how hot it gets. I worry about some heat problems but only if you transfer 20gb + all in one go. Even then I wouldn't worry much. It IS cheap to replace.

I upgraded my son's computer graphics card which is 5 years old over this past X'mas since the games coming out now are more graphic intensive, and could not keep up. The Abit motherboard is just as old running a Pentium 4 at 3.0 GHz with 2 Gbytes of PC3200 RAM on a Windows XP platform with DirectX 9.0c. The old graphics card is an ATI Radeon 9600 with 256 MB DDR. When playing \\"Crisis\\" in developer's mode (devmode), graphics were poor with lots of lag time, jitters, and an average frame rate of 6 to 8 frames per second (fps).     Installation was straight forward. Uninstall the old graphics drivers first before removing the old card and replacing it with the new card. I used the ATI Catalyst uninstaller utility since I had old ATI drivers. Even before this, I downloaded the latest graphics drivers from Visiontek, e.g. ATI 8.11n for AGP. For some reason, these drivers would not recognize the new graphics card. I ended up using the drivers on the included installation disc that were slightly older, but it worked.     What a difference!!! Details, textures, shadows all came alive. Motion was smooth. Framerate was kicked up to about 24 fps on average for \\"Crisis\\" in 1280 x 800 resolution. My son is happy.     2009 will probably be the last year that graphic vendors will offer AGP cards as it is old technology and is already getting harder to find. PCI-e is the new standard. I consider the Visiontek Radeon 3850 512MB GDDR3 AGP card to be top of the line for the AGP slot as there are no other higher line than this. If you cannot wait another year to upgrade your entire hardware system with Windows 7 (Vista is not an alternative for me), and you have an older system with an AGP graphics slot, then seriously consider the Visiontek ATI Radeon 3850 512MB GDDR3 for AGP.

This was not the cheapest mouse out there, but worth the few extra dollars to me.
Very easy to install, and it worked right away on my Nexus7 tablet. The mouse is a little heavier than a corded mouse, presumably because of the two AA batteries in it. It glides and operates smoothly on every surface I've tried (including my pants-leg and shirt). It also has a surprisingly good range, true Bluetooth range, farther than you'd ever be able to see a tablet's screen at least.

The buttons are a tiny bit harder to click or scroll than other mice, but it does at least let you know for sure when you've clicked, and it's hard to miss-click by accident.
Also, since it's Bluetooth, it occasionally takes a second to wake up, and sometimes has an almost imperceptibly small lag time (possibly due to wireless interference). I think that's just the nature of Bluetooth though vs. using a corded optical mouse.

Bought this after getting frustrated with my 2013 razer mamba wireless mouse which was basically useless in wireless mode and I finally wanted to be able to uninstall the buggy mess that is razer synapse. I've used logitech's performance mx mouse in the past so I knew I'd like it's rather odd-seeming form factor.

Pro's:
+ Reliable Wireless Connectivity/Performance
+ Awesome form factor (good for my big paws, comfortable)
+ Mouse wheel can either spin freely or go normal with the push of the button underneath (just like the performance mx)
+ Stable software as usual with Logitech
+ Lots of buttons, customize-able, can set DPI quick switch or DPI clutch (which I couldn't figure out how to get working properly, just kind of gave up)
+ Accuracy and feel seems about on par with my old mouse, no noticeable lag or anything. definitely much more reliable

Cons:
- USB Cable is VERY stiff and the mouse feels so sucky to use while plugged in, with my old mouse (razer mamba) at least the cable was a kind of cloth sheating and very flexible. This cord has your regular cheap low grade cable insulation (not a nice flexible silicone or anything). Will have to make something to keep the cable elevate to help alleviate the dragging feeling. Really disappointed with the cable, you'd think for a gaming mouse this is one aspect that wouldn't have been so overlooked. Oh well.
- Logitech Gaming Software. Keeps switching profile back to default #1 whenever I unplug and replug which seems like a stupid fixable bug.
- Battery life could be better. With it unplugged I could get a few hours of use before it goes down to one bar. Suppose this could be fixed by buying a higher capacity nimh rechargable AA battery.

I was looking for a product to add a 2nd hard drive to my Dell PC since the motherboard did not have any SATA ports available.  I plugged it in and connected the hard drive, booted up, and everything seemed to be OK -- I did not need to install any drivers -- it just worked..  I was able to access the files on the hard drive (good, because the last PC this hard drive was in totally crashed and died).      I should have stopped there.  Instead I wanted to boot from the hard drive attached to this device.  I wasn't able to, so I thought, \\"well, I'll install the software\\" from the mini-disk included.  I put the mini-disk in, ran setup for VIA device, and the install failed (using Windows 7 64 bit).  But Windows 7 asked me if I wanted to try again with new settings (a feature in windows), so I did.    PC had to reboot to finish install, but upon reboot, I got a black-screen message that the disk had errors and needed to be checked.  The checking never completed (it ran all night but didn't complete).  Tried a few more reboots, connecting hard drive to motherboard (bypassing this card by disconnecting the DVD drive to free up the SATA port).  Same issues.      Ultimately I had to pull out this device and the hardrive.  And the hardrive is now toast.    I gave two stars because it did work for a few hours before I installed the mini-disk software.

[...]    [...]    [...]    [...]    My Review of the Lenovo Essentials series B575    My Mission upon searching for a new laptop this time around was the following...  1. My budget was VERY tight..(350$ Total MAX everything included tax also)  NO refurbs unless they came with alike NEW warranty  No used  2. I needed it to do basic tasks while being able to handle Light gaming (World of warcraft,Diablo 3,SC2,Steam games) and still have a respectable battery life  3. I wanted the build quality to also not TOTALLY suck even though it is an extreme budget class.  Tall order for a 350$ budget right?  This laptop accomplished that on 299$  Purchased from bestbuy  Let me start by saying this will be a fairly short review (Though i will add additional information upon request if someone wants to know something specific)    Full Specifications:  CPU: AMD E 450 APU 1.65 Ghz Dual core  GPU: ATI 6320 Intergrated into the APU  HD: 5400 RPM HD 320GB  Ram: 4 GB DDR3  Display: widescreen LED (1366 x 768) 15.6  OS: Windows 7 64 bit Premium  Wireless B+G+N  Fingerprint Reader  Port Locker  4 USB slots  HDMI OUT  Webcamera 0.3 MP  Product Height 1.3\\"  Product Width 14.9\\"  Product Weight 5.2 lbs.  Product Depth 9.9\\"  Keyboard Full size Chiclet with Number pad  6 in1 media reader slot    Performance: Thus far i have play tested Diablo 3 And world of warcraft with the following results  World of Warcraft using Lowest settings and the default Resolution Provides a consistent 30-45 FPS in a large scale Battleground enviorment (Settings can be turned slightly higher in 5 mans or questing solo)  Diablo 3 Is quite playable at 20-30 FPS on lowest settings i was very surprised this game was playable at ALL on this machine let alone respectably playable at that  HD movie playback 720P is without issues on Netflix  Multitasking is ok as long as you don't get TOO unreal once i had Pandora WoW Chrome with 4 tabs open you could notice slowdown not apparent in better CPU's.  The machine sadly howevercomes with TONS of bloatware you either need to uninstall or do a fresh reformat to get the max performance out of this machine    Build Quality  The keyboard is great with almost zero flex unless pushed very hard, palm rest area is equally strong..My biggest concern is the plastic behind the LCD is VERY weak and can be flexed VERY easily...I can produce no screen ripple pushing upon it..however it is a worry if the laptop sits inside a bag for long periods traveling and gets bumped around a ton.  Also the DVD drive is a bit worrysome as it shoots out much like a bullet and the tray is very stiff..not smooth at all.  The biggest annoyance is the USB/Power cord slot...they are the stiffest i have EVER encountered...i thought i was going to have to buy a mallet to work a USB mouse into any of the ports...it's insane you REALLY need to push to get anything in them..The power cord is also slightly stiff but not as bad.  The Screen is what it is..it has apparent light leakage to be expected for a budget machine but is largely not noticable when gaming or video watching..it's Plenty bright even on LOW which is fantastic for battery savings.    Battery  Thus far the only test i have run was playing World of Warcraft on LOW brightness but HIgh performance the laptop lasted 3 Hours 22 Minutes before shutting down.  I will add further Battery tests as i go through them myself with time.    Heat  Heat on this machine is fairly non existant even when gaming under load their is a tiny bit of warmth on the left Palm rest side when under heavy load but nothing of major concern.    Ultimately i went with lenovo as when you are dealing with this price range you are dealing with cheap build quality across the board and compared to similar brands/specs this was the best built of the bargains and Lenovo has a great reputation

I haven't seen a review for the S102 model, so I thought I might write down my thoughts even if I don't know much about gaming keyboards.

The keys give a pretty satisfying click, and I haven't had a single issue with typing so far. The F1-F12 can also be used to change settings such as muting, play/pause, sleep mode, etc. Additionally, you can switch the back-light to one of seven different colors, but I think the red looks the best due to the color scheme.

I don't think the description really highlighted this well, but the six red keys on the left allow you to create macro commands, and it is very easy to do. As of right now, mine are set to open specific menus and purchase items for a multiplayer game I play (DotA 2 anyone?), and I find it extremely useful. The mouse also works pretty well. There are two buttons wear your thumb rest, which are relatively easy to click without lifting your thumb.

All and all, I am pretty satisfied with this purchase.

I started out with the Linksys wireless camera.  It was terrible. Minimum features and video quality was poor.  It doesn't have a fraction of the features compared to the Panasonic, granted Pano is three times as much.  But spend the money and don't waste your time with Linksys.  The BL-C131provides good video quality and the pan, tilt works great.  Accessing and setting up from the free web portal is easy and slick.    The bad things about the camera: documentation was poor, I got the zoom feature to only work with MJPEG in windows Explorer (but it works well), the night vision is useless (shows a black screen), the MPEG4 was difficult to make work and didn't self install like the manual said.  The record GUI had problems installing but once I self installed MPEG4 it worked like a champ.    Overall this camera has been stable and is probably the best on the market. I bought this after my Antec cooling pad broke (the cable stopped working). The previous one worked fine(that is until it broke), but was fairly heavy, a bit loud, and very uncomfortable to set on my lap. The Logitech cooling pad is almost the opposite, it is lightweight, very quiet, and probably more comfortable than just having my laptop in my lap. Plus it looks nice! It has some more subtle perks too though. The USB chord wraps up into the bottom and can be wrapped such that chord come out either side (another thing my last one got an F on). Also, my computer's headphone jack is in the front, and I like sitting in a way that causes the plug to bend and press into my stomach. But, because this cooling pad has such good grip, I can scoot the laptop back so that the front edge of the cooling pad acts as a sort of barrier. An odd pro, yes, but just another thing I love so far about this.   Oh and I guess it cools pretty well too. haha. But really it does. As others have said, the fan is a bit weak, so my computer still gets a little warm. The Antec did cool a little better. And the parts that are warm are in the front where the fan isn't located (by the logitech symbol).   Now I've only had this for a short while, so I can't say much in terms of it's life span, but so far it's great.

I am very sad I have to return this laptop.  It is a great little netbook.  The 12\\" screen is just the right size screen for me when I need something portable.  The battery life was great (when the battery worked properly) and performance was way better than similar Atom based netbooks I've tried.  It was even able to play L4D2 at low settings very smoothly.  I was using it all day at work without plugging it in and still had charge to spare.  The multitouch on the trackpad was nice (not perfect, but usable). If this thing was issue free, I'd keep it and give it 5 stars.  Unfortunately there are several issues which seem to plague many of these laptops.  Some people seem to get non defective ones, but judging by the amount of returns and comments online, there is a large percentage of these things failing.      The issues mine was having (which led to me returning it) where as follows:  1.  The trackpad would become unresponsive after a few hours of use and require a reboot to fix.  2.  The battery stopped charging to 100% and would charge all day and only get to slightly above 80%  3.  The computer would randomly shut off without warning and act as if the battery was dead even though it still had plenty of charge.  4.  The computer would frequently not wake from hibernation and would require a full boot.    Problems 2 and 3 may have been a defective battery.  Problem 4 may have been related to the defective battery or an issue that could be fixed with a bios update.  Issue 1 was poor design or incompetent fabrication.  If you search around the web, you can find fixes for problem 1 that involve removing a sticky shim from under the trackpad.  This indeed fixes the problem.      I just got fed up with the issues and decided to return the laptop since it did not work as advertised.

Hey Folks,
I'm mostly happy with my purchase. I got the kit and a 320GB hard drive for $76 before taxes and that's not bad (at least in 2010). I did run into a few problems that I will let the company know about and hopefully they can help others avoid. First of all, double check whether you have an IDE drive or a SATA drive before you order (if you don't understand these terms, this may not be for you). Once you're sure you have a SATA drive (this review is for the SATA drive kit), I'll feel better.

If you are currently running Vista and you are planning on cloning your existing drive, there are a couple of preparatory things you should do. For one, you should download the Vista Recovery DVD. I used the one located here: [...]Also, when I went through the install, I decided to do the \\"typical\\" install, but afterward, I regretted it. I bought a 320G hard drive, but I only have 280G available. This is partially because my original HP hard drive had a 10G partition for recovery. It's also partially because when the typical install occurred, it expanded the recovery partition to 16G for some reason. It looks like I may have lost additional gigabytes elsewhere- I don't know for sure, but if I were you, I would customize the install and make sure that the partitions are the size you desire.

To download, you do have to use BitTorrent (download and install) and after you download the Vista Recovery DVD, you will have to burn the ISO to a DVD. If you don't understand a word I'm saying, turn back now- go to the Geek Squad instead. I was not that excited about using software downloaded via BitTorrent from a site I am not familiar with, but it turned out that it really needed to be done.

Most of the process worked the way it's described at the Apricorn web site. I connected the cable to my new drive, I plugged that in to the USB port (USB 2.0 is preferred, of course). I then loaded the CD, ran the software and chose to run EZ Gig III. It did recognize the new drive, the old drive and it let me select the source and destination drives. The cloning process went smoothly. I ran into a problem when I installed the new drive. Instead of booting up directly into Windows, I got an error:

\windows\system32\winload.exe
Info: The selected entry could not be loaded...

After searching around google, I discovered that this problem could be fixed by using the Vista Recovery DVD at neosmart. So, I downloaded that, burned it onto a DVD. I then put the DVD in the drive and started the computer. This time when the computer started, it began to load files from the VRD. It looked like it was trying to install Windows, but eventually I got to a screen that had a menu option \\"Repair computer.\\" I chose this option, it detected a problem and gave me the option of fixing it. I chose to fix the problem. The computer rebooted, I ejected the DVD and the laptop came up in Windows as I had hoped. It was a bit more effort than expected, but if you're prepared, you'll have less angst than I did. I now have a 7200 RPM 320G hard drive instead of a 5400 RPM 160GB hard drive, so I'm happy.e the new drive, the old drive and it let me select the source and destination drives. Once you understand the limitations of the technology, this drive is extremely easy to use and has extended the useful life of the computer it's in for years to come. I currently have two of these drives, both maxed out at 4GB a piece, one handling the system paging file and the other handling various memory intensive applications. Now some people are going to look at this thing and instantly say \\"Eww, only sata 1?\\" Well given the speed at which you are able to access random data and the total capacity of the drive, sata 1 is all you need. Unless you are filling and emptying the entire contents of the drive repeatedly you don't need a faster connection.

Now I see there has been a lot of talk about how this thing is bulky and takes up two PCI slots. INCORRECT. Yes, it is bulky, but I easily placed both of the drives I have in consecutive slots without issue. All you need to do is ensure that the solder points on one card don't touch the other. For this I used a couple layers of electrical tape, and vwala, two cards occupying two slots. Above them I have my graphics card occupying it's slot and that's another tight fitting beast, but so far I've had no heating problems or memory issues and the drives have been in operation for a few months now.

The only thing I can complain about is the predictable subject, storage space. 4GB a piece is not a lot. However this is one of the only Ram Drives I have even seen. Acard makes a couple of models but they are still unreasonably expensive. As for standard SSD's, why would I want to by a flash based SSD when I'd just have to replace it in a few years when memory clusters start to fail? If you're looking for a quick, easy solution to speeding up access times and don't mind limited storage space, this is the drive for you. If you want something bigger and faster and more expensive, go look up what Acard has to offer. Just don't fall into the flash SSD trap.

Update: 01/07/2013
Do not expose toheat! Being one of the many people hit by Sandy, I lost power for about two weeks, needless to say the batteries in the ram drives dies within hours. This isn't a complain, just a simple fact. What is alarming though is that when my power was restored, damage to the wiring in the cellar pegged my thermostat at 90* and for two days my apartment was a sauna. During this time the drive batteries recharge and then proceeded to engage in a rapid, uncontrolled disassembly. Luckily no damage was caused to the drives or the computer as the battery contents exploded away from the more sensitive components. Needless to say though, as with all lithium technology except lithium iron phosphate, heat is very dangerous. I'm also now on the hunt for replacement batteries.

Got these yesterday, and they're great, though they do take a bit of fiddling to set up in some cases. Yes, it's plug $ play, but if you have a 64-bit system (what gamer doesn't these days?) they aren't 'officially' supported.

It's no problem though. Just plug them into a USB port, make sure the blu light turns on. Windows 7 64-bit will recognize them as Speakers rather than a headset. Go to Devices and Printers, it'll be listed at the bottom as 'USB Composite Device\\". R-click and select Sound Settings. You'll now get a list of all your audio outputs. In my case, there's Speakers//Realtek High Definition Audio (the ones I have connected to the green audio jack in the back), Realtek Digital Output (the optical audio port I have nothing hooked up to), and Speakers//USB Audio Device (This is your new toy!)

Select that third one, and set it to default, now everything will come through the headset (there might be a few games you'll have to set it in the in-game audio options for. I did with Amnesia). One last step, hit Properties with the headset selected, then go to the Enhancements tab, and make sure you check Virtual Surround. That's the way you get it to work with the surround sound. You can turn on the Bass Boost if you like, but DON'T touch Room Correction. The OS thinks these are speakers, remember, but you don't want to calibrate them as speakers. I'd not touch Loudness Equalization, either, but that's just me.

That's it. Go to one place and click two things, easy peasy! You can mess with your mic settings and such in there, too 9I had to tun it up a lot, but I don't play mp much anyway).

Buy these, is my opinion. I have heard the band breaks for some people, but I take care of my things.

Oh, and I got some weird LaserShip carrier for the free 7-day shipping. They left the box in an odd spot, but it was at my house the very next day after I ordered, hours before the mailman even came, can't beat that!

Hope this helps.

They run very well, as fast as any desktop PC that I have used.  Applications such as Office, etc. run great.  At first I did not like Windows 8 but now that I have used it for a bit I do like it.  I have been in I.T. since Windows NT and so far Windows 8 seems to be the most stable release. You cant really compare this thing to an IPAD because it does everything an IPAD does and more.  But don't get me wrong, the IPAD is a good device, just not on par with a Surface.  Considering this is Microsoft's first (that I know of) attempt at a PC they created a good product.  I would not hesitate to purchase another and I have recommended the Surface to many people.

More than any other PC laptop I'm aware of, it is clear that this was designed beat a MacBook Pro with a Windows 7 PC. Of course this is an impossible task as the MBP hardware is so integrated with the Apple operating system. But within the context of what was possible, there's no doubt what the designers were trying to do. As somebody who has owned several dozen PCs (through my company) and has owned four Macs, I believe they have succeeded. I'm thrilled with it and recommend it to others. Of course I haven't used it for a long time and that will be the ultimate test. But I did know before buying it that my nephew has been banging around with his 17 inch HP for quite awhile and it still works fine.

Before I do that I'd like to address the issues of service and the issue of the expensive additional hardware for changing a disc drive or adding a new one brought up by Eric O. I would never have thought to do this without reading his review, but within a minute or two I went to the HP site where I downloaded their parts guide. It clearly states that this part isn't provided and gives a part number. I put the number into Google and found numerous places that sell it for $65. That price is nuts and obnoxious but at the same time they could have made more money by supplying it and adding ten dollars to each computer. I would guess that less than 10% of their users will take advantage of this. But I'm not going to defend the $65-- that's nasty and bad business--but Eric O. should know that he at least got a free $65 for not reading the online manuals and going through all of his stress and wasted time. And as I want to talk about the MacBook Pro, can you put a second drive in it at any price?

As far as service goes, I spent many hours investigating the service on every computer I was considering. The comments on them were all horrible from every brand. So I then looked at things like the nerds at Best Buy, etc. and the sheer fury that people had about them burned my fingers at my keyboard. Eventually this led me to a company called SquareTrade. Again, I spent a lot of time looking at many dozens of people who loved everything about this company. I found one negative response--from a guy who wanted to get more from SquareTrade than they offer in their contracts. I called them and was impressed and ended up buying a plan for my iPad. I don't have anything to do with SquareTrade, but they were great on two phone calls and followed up with my email confirmation with a phone call and a letter about my iPad contract.

I have 90 days before I have to buy a Warranty on the Envy. The SquareTrade plan is $200 for three years. As I was buying my Envy from J&R Music world which was selling it for $100 less than the HP website or anyplace listed on Amazon at that time (it's up now) that meant I could get three years of service for an additional $100.

On to the MacBook Pro comparison:

Price - The MBP costs $1100 more than what I paid for my Envy

Keyboard and design - As everybody says, HP has stolen the look and the backlit keyboard. But there is a keypad and more keys in general. I'm not crazy about the arrow buttons and I keep hitting the num lock button because it's next to the backstage button. But for my usage - score the keyboard as a win for the Envy as it has more stuff.

The MacBook Pro wins on the TrackPad, weight and I suspect overall strength and durability. The processor speed is 2.4 i7 and on the Envy it is only a 2.2. It has Thunderbolt, which is awesome. Does it have a better screen? I love the Envy screen and I don't care.

RAM - The Envy has 8GB vs 4GB MBP

DVD - The Envy comes with Blu-ray and the MBP doesn't.

The Envy hard drive is 750 GB 7200 rp vs 750 GB 5400 rpm drive (ugh!) on the MBP. $50 extra for 7200 rpm. There is no excuse in 2012 to have a 5400 drive not standard on a top-of-the line laptop. Displays - You can connect three displays to the Envy and two to the MBP.

Do you get more speed from a processor that's .2 better or from double the RAM and a 7200 rpm drive? My experience is no.

Ports - The Envy has 3 fast ports (USB 3.0) and one normal (USB). The MBP has one fast port (Firewire 800) and three normal speed ports (USB 2.0) But it has Thunderbolt which puts the MBP in an entirely different dimension if you are a pro editor, musician, etc. If you need that, then get the MBP. On the other hand, firewire 800 ports have already begun to be phased out by some music hardware companies that had them before. Apple doesn't include their firewire 400 connections now. Maybe in the future they will go all Thunderbolt to make you buy more stuff from them.

Graphics - Everybody complains that the Envy has AMD Radeon, but guess what? So does the MBP. I'm going out on a limb to say the Apple one is a lot better. But it is still the dreaded Radeon that everybody seems to hate.

Displays - You can connect three displays to the Envy and I don't know how many with Thunderbolt. A lot. Fill your house with displays? Having four screens seems enough, but that's just me.

Music - No contest. Envy's Beats Audio slaughters the MBP.

Camera - I personally like the Envy camera much more than Apple ones I've used (they adjust better for lighting changes) and it comes with silly software that kids will like. In fairness I haven't spent time with the camera on the newest MBP yet so maybe it's just as good.

Battery - the MBP has a good battery. But I need to complain here that my battery on my iBook never lasted more than an hour or so from its first day and swiftly became non-functional. This was the word on the battery by 100% of the people on the Apple community board before I bought it. T But I needed a new iBook and there was no other option. Is saying that a new Mac laptop has a long-lasting battery a way of saying that the older ones were pretty bad?

Heat - This Envy is the coolest running laptop I've ever had. I run it all day and it isn't even warm. It wasn't pleasant to put my iBook on my lap... a scorcher. No idea about the new MacBook.

Warranty - HP gives you a one year limited warranty, but they currently have a special on their site for a free two-year warranty. I believe they have been reading the bad comments on this page about their service. Before and after I bought the computer I was quickly able to get a helpful person on the phone. After my problem was solved I got a phone call later just to make sure I was okay. I don't like that kind of thing, but it does show they are trying. You can buy more coverage from HP for $200. AppleCare is $349 for three years. Ouch!

Digital Media Reader - The MBP has it this year, but this is one of those, \\"Isn't that amazing?\\" Apple improvements over something that's been pretty standard on PC laptops for years. If you don't have this year's MBP, I don't think you have this.

Included Software - Apple computers used to come with iLife, but I don't think they do these days. Envy comes with Adobe Photoshop and Premiere Elements, which are great programs. They are both harder to learn, less fun, and more powerful than the two similar iLife programs you can get for $40 (and get GarageBand and other great stuff too) Premiere Elements is more like the semi-pro Final Cut Express than iMovie. On the dark side Envy comes with Norton which I guess is okay unless, like me, you want to get rid of it. If so, good luck! You can get other software to remove it (as I did) or buy another copy of Windows and start clean. Once Norton moves in, it has no intention of ever leaving. Tip: Their uninstall doesn't work until you activate the program. There's a limited version of Office, but what good is that?

Finally, what I loved about Apple computers when I first started using them were these special treats you get. Stuff they didn't have to do. This computer comes with a velvety cover. That's a little thing but I really like it. You can do wireless audio. There is apparently something called ProtectSmart which protects your data when you drop the computer. Add that to the cooling tech and the Beats Audio, etc. They are out there trying to excel. In my opinion, these days Apple is putting a lot of their imagination into the iPad and maybe the MacBook Air. They're coasting on their regular computers.

On the downside with the Envy is that they don't give you much printed documentation or even good PDF. I don't want a lot of little files, I want a good manual. You have to use their online support, which I don't like. They don't make it easy to see how to make a recovery disc which is something you should do on the first day--when you go to \\"Recovery\\" you don't get that info. (And you better do it right--you only get one chance) They sell you recovery discs but that is really cheesy. Recovery discs should come with the machine. These are the kinds of little details where they would provide a much better customer experience that are well worth charging customers a few bucks more for.

I'm not an expert and don't pretend to be, so I hope some people will come in and fix the mistakes in what I've written above.

My playbook didn't work when I got it. It showed a red light followed by four or so blinking yellow lights. It wouldn't charge no matter how long I tried. After being really angry for an hour or so, I finally found the answer on you tube. Take your tablet and hook it up to a computer. Go to blackberry.com/software and download the blackberry desktop software on to your computer. Do not unplug your tablet. The desktop software will search for an update. This is software that make the hardware work. It will take about an hour to install. After install it will tell you to unplug your tablet and charge it, mine was dead. After the battery reaches 20 percent, takes forever, take it back to your computer and finish the process. Mine works GREAT now. Some blackberrys arrive fine, some arrive like mine. I replaced my playbook because my older one was breaking. The main port that the cell phone like charger goes into broke and I thought I would have to throw it away but there's another port to the right that is magnetic so I bought the blackberry playbook rapid travel charger off Amazon and I love it. I can't believe how fast it charges. I don't even use the other charger for my new one. Hope this helps.

I noticed a lot of so so reviews and was wary until I read a professional review praising it's easy set up. I decided to go for it and boy am I glad I did. I happen to be a novice setting up PC related stuff but this router was cake to set up. Be forwarned; however, my intention was to simply set up wireless with encryption and nothing else. I had no desire to set up a full blown network with file and printer sharing. I simply wanted encrypted wireless for my xp windows pc and vista windows laptop in the house. I figure I can print stuff by using the pc with the printer or using a flash drive so I had no desire in oversteaping my technical boundries.

That being said... it was as simple as putting the disk in, following directions printing the encryption code and connecting the router. Easy as cake! I had more trouble configuring the recieving vista windows laptop and xp windows pc! Which wasn't that hard either. The router is connected to my windows vista desktop and my windows vista laptop and seperate xp windows desktop are recieving the signal. It was as easy as plugging in the code to the recieving laptop and pc.

The signal is always strong and no breaks in three weeks of constant use. Despite other comments, the signal strength is awesome even with the unit under a shelf. Unless you live in a 25 room mansion or set up the network wrong... you should have no problems. I have absolutely no complaints. The cherry on top is how awesome this router looks and with no antenna! You could easly hide this under a shelf but why would you want to! It's beautiful and you could use it as decoration! I admit, it is pricey but well worth the money in the headaches you will save setting it up and the aesthetic factor. Highly recommended especially for novices who simply want wireless in their house.

CHEAP but Not cheap...weird i know. but this is actually a really nice mouse. I have a 70 dollar Logitech G503 gaming mouse, and purchased this for my guest gaming PC. I have ended up using this over my 70 dollar mouse (even though it doesn't have that sniper button). The feel is not cheap manufacturing and the fit to my hand is nice. Its not super heavy or light has a good balance of weight. It glides over my mouse pad and the side buttons feel natural when i need to click them. Other mice i have used feel like I'm reaching to far forward or to far backwards to click their buttons. I've watched a few reviews on youtube and have read a few reviews on amazon about this mouse and none of the issues mentioned have been a problem for me. For instance the software that came with the mouse, first time install; worked perfectly. Regularly the DPI changes as the color changes. But you can set your favorite color to your favorite DPI setting. Also have a "breathing" light (where it fades in and out) you can turn that off as well. I HIGHLY recommend this mouse. IF you interested but are not sold yet. BUY IT and TRY IT. If you don't like it guess what..send it back. its cheap enough for a trial so you not blasting 70 plus tax just to try a mouse. ya know.

Again the feel of this mouse is all my opinion. But i game a lot and feel this will suit just fine for people looking for quality, performance and budget.

Games i play with it so far: Planetside 2, Dota 2, Archeage, Tomb Raider, Borderlands, Smite, and Sleeping dogs.

This computer is also known as L55-A5284. Let me state right off, I received my computer super fast, packed well and in good shape. I have had 2 Toshiba computers, and loved them. I loved them so much, my next one had to be a Toshiba. It took me over a month to shop for one, and I came up with this one. I hate it. Do not waste your money if you want a consumer friendly computer. This computer is loaded with so many quirks, and ads you cannot get rid of. The major problem is the tracker/mouse. It either will not work, or you have to click it so hard it is scary. Or, it is so sensitive you cannot get through a sentence typing without the mouse taking you to other pages, and programs. You cannot even leave the curser for more than 20 seconds without it deleting the email, taking you to another program or places unknown. We have gone through all the advanced options and did what we could to prevent these problems, but it doesn't work. If you are typing an email, you cannot get far before side bar tools come up. You click to get them closed, doesn't work another pops up. This is just the start. This is without a doubt the worst computer I have ever owned. I will not get another Toshiba, and I discourage anyone from buying this model. There are times I have lost paragraphs in the blink of an eye. I am not computer illiterate either. I have had IT people look at it, and they suggested I use a plug in mouse, which I do. it is still bad.

Another thing with the mouse pad is there is just a 1/4 inch corner of the right and left lower corners allowed to use for regular use. If you move outside that area you are in other programs. You have to bang to click it too. There are times it does not work at all.

I will say, battery lasts several hours of use. It is light weight, and fairly slim. The sound is good, and screen is crisp and clear. Color is good. I only use the Toshiba tile, which is like the classic windows. I do not use anythingelse. Too much trouble. It is so preloaded with companies who probably paid Toshiba tons of money to promote them.
Never again. In a few months I am getting an Apple and get rid of this consumer unfriendly computer .

Finally, after about 2 or three months of use, one of the 2 metal plug prongs came completely detached and remains in the wall socket when unplugging. After a week or so of risking electrical shock and removing the individual prong from the wall with pliers and refitting it into the charger, we've given up completely and we are just gonna spend the 13 bucks to get a new one - different brand of course. The television remote control.  The bagless vacuum cleaner.  The airblade hand-dryer. The Kindle Wireless Reading Device.  The best inventions ever.  Not for the whole of humanity, of course, just for me in terms of making my life easier/less annoying.  This was my fourth kindle - I bought one for my daughter, and I also dropped one from a height onto a hard surface, breaking it.  Amazon replaced the one I broke without charge or fuss, meaning I now heart Amazon beyond all reason.   Kindle is so convenient, so portable, so easy to read in bed or anywhere else, I now resent when I have to read something from a stupid old paper book, but, in the interests of fairness and in denial of my irrational love for a huge, multinational, American-based corporation, I must list the minor drawbacks:    1. Not enough books are available on Kindle.  Many of the books I want to read aren't yet in Kindle format.  2. Lots of books are not available in my region (outside the U.S.), but are recommended to me anyway.  3. I ended up buying a lot of drivel, because the review system is such that a few bonkers people giving a book five stars will skew the overall rating upwards.   I know this isn't Amazon's or the Kindle's fault, but it is a drawback.  4. The cost.  Because buying a book is so easy and fast, I have ended up spending an absolute fortune.  Again, not the Kindle's fault, more to do with my own lack of fiscal discipline, but be warned.    On the other hand, you need never be stuck for something to read again.  Will work anywhere, as long as there is mobile phone coverage.  Books download in minutes, and the operation of the Kindle is - I was going to say child's play, but most kids are way more techno-savvy than I am - middle aged woman's play. Can be operated one-handed, which really counts when you're snuggled up under the duvet.  I synch-ed mine to my IPhone, so in idle moments in queues or waiting rooms, I can haul out my phone and continue the book I'm reading, without having to lug anything around in my bag.      Finally, people ask if I miss the texture and smell and tactile experience of reading \\"real\\" books.  Em, no.  Not even slightly.  No more stacks of books building up on my bedside table, no more packing heavy volumes to take with me when I travel.  No more waiting days for books to come in the post, or to get into town to visit the book shop.  We still have hundreds of books in our house - we converted one of the bedrooms into a library - most of which I want to keep, but if I never bought another again it wouldn't bother me.      So that's why Amazon has joined James Dyson in my personal pantheon, and no, I don't work for either of them.

This is a great, easy to use router.  Setup was straightforward, following the steps clearly laid out in a setup guide (available on a CD and online).  The process was operating-system-independent, refreshing for this linux user who is accustomed to "your OS is not supported" messages in technical documentation.  The user's guide is clear and understandable, e.g., the discussion of security options is the best I have seen.  The online interface for the router is similarly clear and uncluttered, a pleasure to navigate.  The only thing I had a bit of trouble with was the procedure for allowing SSH access on port 22, but I eventually figured it out (go to Advanced > Firewall > Virtual Server Rules, and create an entry for port 22).  All in all, a great purchase.

I was quite disappointed with this product. Amped Wireless does a good job promoting their increased wireless coverage in areas with interference, as well as their \\"Elite Support\\" tech support service, but these claims don't pan out.

Negative:
1) Signal quality: no actual improvement, even with firmware upgrade, from Linksys E4200 (v.1). Devices showed more \\"bars,\\" but actual throughput did not improve over the Linksys. I purchased the R20000G hoping to overcome interference issues in my apartment (25+ AP's visible on the 2.4 band). It performs no better than the Linksys E4200 it was intended to replace.

2) Feature set: lacks a common consumer router feature called \\"port translation\\" when configuring firewall rules. Amped tech support confirmed their products lack this feature. In addition, many advanced technical settings available on Linksys/Netgear/D-Link routers are not available on the R20000G

3) Tech support: I used the Amped web support form to submit a question about port translation (referenced above). I received a two sentence email response *two days* later, saying sorry, their products do not support that feature. They promote their free \\"Elite Support\\" service, but a two day delay in response to a simple email inquiry is unacceptable in my opinion.

Postive:
1) The physical product seems reasonably well built and includes ventilation on top & bottom.
2) The initial setup wizard was fast and easy, and could have be completed by a novice.

I am returning the product to Amazon since it lacks a very basic and common feature (port translation).

I really wish I hadn't caved in and bought a cheaper tablet for Chirstmas, because I definitely regret not going for a bigger brand, like Samsung or HTC.

First of all, it's performance is absolute garbage, despite what it advertises what it seems to be. Takes forever to move through running apps and is extremely sluggish when doing simple tasks. On top of that, constant freezing/crashing when loading HTML5 video, playing on many apps, and even basic internet browsing on Chrome. My Samsung Galaxy S3 out-performs it in every way, despite being an older device. It also doesn't help that the hard-drive on mine was 2 GB when it was advertised as 8.

Don't believe in the advertised camera quality either. Pictures come out looking like the lens was covered in frosted glass, with horrendous quality and fuzzy images. Also the video recording is extremely laggy.

On top of that, for whatever reason, on the corners of my tablet, there are extremely bright white lights that shine through the back of the case (which is made by a really cheap material that bends easily, by the way) and is very obnoxious/distracting in dark environments.

The touch calibration is also awful. The pointer is almost always nowhere near my finger and takes many tries before I can press a button/tab accurately. On top of that, the screen continues on the left pass the black area, so part of the display is "missing" in a way. On top of that, you cannot re-calibrate the touchpad, so you're stuck screwing around with your finger on the screen.

It also came with a ton of bloatware apps, like performance boosting apps or cleaning apps that barely work. In fact, these apps always show pop-up menus or are impossible to exit out of, so they constantly get in your way until you uninstall them.

To top of this heaping pile of garbage, the display is not as great as they advertise it to be. I can literally count the pixels on the screen. Following this, my wallpaper always re-sizes itself whenever i go back to the home menu, incredibly zoomed in so it looks awful. I constantly have to go back and re-set my wallpaper, only to have it resized and zoomed in all the way again.

Please, muster up the will to spend an extra $50 dollars or so to get a better brand tablet, because this genuinely isn't worth the money at all.

I have one of these and they last pretty long. What makes them great is that they are gold plated and thus less prone to corrosion. I have had other cables that would corrode on me and being close to the ocean my electronics would do this often. If you live by the ocean, you know what I mean. Also, these cables are bi-directional which means that they will allow the printer to communicate with the printer driver to inform the user of such things as low ink, low paper, paper jam, etc. Not all parallel printer cables are bi-directional as older printers were output devices only. As time went by printers became smarter and so bi-directional printer cables were needed.

I chose the Google Nexus 7 tablet because I trusted the Google brand, the price was right, and the reviews looked positive.
I had a friend who had bought one in late 2012 and had various problems with his, but figured his was a lemon.
Nope, the problems are pretty widespread, it seems. If you do a quick search online you'll see that I'm not the only person with ongoing issues with charging. The problems started when the charger stopped working. I would plug it in and nothing would happen. This caused the battery to completely drain out, which then messed up the system somehow. I checked with Google support to do a "hard" reboot and that started it up, but the charger still only actually worked about 1/3 of the time. That slowly turned into about 5%--and I noticed that it would lose power even when it showed it was charging, so something else was wrong. It would be plugged in, show the "charging" signal, but I could sit there and watch it lose power a percentage point at a time. At this point I thought maybe the charger was broken, and I bought a new one on Amazon. This one didn't work any better.
Google said it wasn't covered by warranty and I should refer to the store where I bought it. The store said I needed to contact ASIS. I had a hell of a time getting in touch with Asis, who then said that I had voided the warranty by using this second charger and not just the charger that came with the device.
Man, oh man.
So, my Google Nexus has been sitting on my shelf, "charging" for several weeks now, but will only occasionally turn on just long enough for it to ask me to plug in my charger and then shut itself off.
I do not recommend the Google Nexus. Better to spend a little bit more and get a product from a company with a proven history of quality and customer service.

I discounted complaints that this unit was not HDTV quality, as composite video or s-video out will, at best, give you quality between VHS and DVD. The unit delivers a picture of this quality.

One difficulty I had was that my USB hub did not provide enough power to the unit, as the unit is powered by a USB cable that you can plug into a computer. It still \\"worked\\", but the image flickered once a second, with a quiet \\"click\\" coming from the video screen. I thought this was a problem with the unit (perhaps it was not quite lining up the TV scan rate with the computer scan rate). Eventually I tried plugging the USB cable into a USB charger, rather than my USB hub, and then it worked just fine.

I got this drive because I have the custom bay for it in my desktop. I also have the bay for the HP Pocket Media Drive, which I leave connected all the time and haven't had a problem in years. But this much larger (in physical size) drive, not so much. After just a couple of days, I noticed a loud noise coming from my PC. It was this drive. Concerned about keeping the drive healthy, I ejected it. I leave it in the bay, but not pushed in all the way, so it isn't connected to the USB plug at the back. When I want to copy something to this drive, I push it in all the way, wait for it to mount, do my copying, and then eject it. It works, but it's a bit of pain. I got it fairly cheaply, and I like that it fits in the PC bay instead of taking up more room on my desk, which are the only reasons I'm giving it 3 stars instead of 2. I much prefer my Seagate and Western Digital external hard drives.

I got this case without expecting much, and I ordered a couple others at the same time. They were all relatively cheap.

This one quickly proved to be the best of the bunch and I was immediately impressed with how solid it feels. I am careful with my electronics so I haven't seen whether it will make any difference if I drop the drive but so far it feels like it will take a bit of abuse without issue.

The connector on it feels solid and the LED indicator light works well. I'm not a fan of the super bright blue LEDs you commonly find on these but this one isn't too bad.

The drive fit into it well and doesn't wiggle around. I used a standard size 2.5 inch Hitachi 320GB SATA drive and I get about 60 MegaBytes per second transfer rates using USB3. The case doesn't really enter into that but if they messed up the chip on the USB interface I suppose it could.

All in all, this is a great little case to turn an old laptop drive or other little hard drive into a nice portable storage solution.

WELL IT WORKS PERFECTLY FOR MY PS4 UPGRADE TIPS FOR TROUBLE FREE UPGRADE. 1. FIRST OF ALL BACKUP ALL YOUR SAVE DATA. (NOTE IF YOU HAVE PSN PLUS ITS AUTOMATICALLY UPLOADED AND YOU CAN DOWNLOAD BACK TO YOU SYSTEM. TO BACKUP UP NEED A USB DRIVE WITH AT LEAST 4GB. YOU WILL BE USING IT TO UPDATE SYSTEM. 2. THIS VERY IMPORTANT AND SAVES YOU TIME. ON YOUR COMPUTER GO TO SONY PLAYSTATION 4 WEBSITE AND SCROLL TO THE BOTTOM OF THE PAGE OR LOOK FOR THIS TOPIC "Perform a New Installation of the System Software" This procedure is for initializing your PS system and performing a new installation of the system software, such as for when you replace the hard disk drive. THIS IS WHERE YOU GET THE UPDATE FILE FOR YOUR NEW HARD DRIVE( THERE IS A NO INFORMATION ON YOUR NEW DRIVE FOR THE PS4 AND THIS WHAT YOU NEED. THERE ARE THE WORDS "DOWNLOAD NOW" JUST BELOW. CLICK IT. NOTE: YOUR FILE SIZE SHOULD BE LARGER THAN 700MB 3.On the USB storage device, create folders for saving the update file. ON YOUR computer, create a folder named "PS4". Inside that folder, create another folder named "UPDATE" THEN PLACE THE FILE YOU DOWNLOADED IN THE UPDATE FOLDER. 4. GO TO THE PS4 SITE AND FIND HOW TO INSTALL YOUR HARD DRIVE....(IF YOU CANT FIND IT GOOGLE IT ITS ALL OVER) ENSURE PS4 IS FULLY POWERED OFF BEFORE INSTALLING. 5.AFTER YOU FINISHED INSTALLING YOUR DRIVE.connect the USB storage device that the update file is saved on to your PS4 system, and then touch the power button for at least 7 seconds. UNTIL YOU HEAR TWO BEEPS The PS4 system starts in safe mode. 6. Select [Initialize PS4 (Reinstall System Software)]. Follow the on screens direction to complete the update.  HOPE THIS HELPS SOMEONE OUT THERE

Well, it's been a while since I wrote an official review, but since I've accumulated eight of these babies I figured I ought to contribute.

Starting with Amazon's shipping standards, I can't complain. I've bought HDDs from the Egg before, and Amazon raises the bar by a mile. I assembled this 8 drive array in three parts, and each shipment was perfect.

I bought the first four drives in January for installation in a self-built home server. The server is an AMD A6 dual-core, 4GB RAM, an old Antec 850W PSU, running Ubuntu Server. I'm using mdadm to control the RAID and it is EASY.

These drives are large, they're secure, and I feel I'm using the best product out there in terms of price, reliability, and build quality.

I would absolutely recommend these drives for a home RAID implementation.
I would not recommend this for a single-drive system, what would be the point? Buy a Green.

My husband bought me a Kindle Fire for a Valentines present. Since I am an invalid and can't go out to libraries, bookstores,movie theaters and such he thought it would allow me some independent activity and to choose books and magazines and stream movies and music I liked. I am also having severe vision problems,so having the backlit screen and enlarged fonts. I loved it when it arrived, and still do when it's working properly. Some things weren't as good as we hoped, the battery life is very limited, only 6 hours, very poor compared to other models. Definitely needs improvement. I don't dare download movies or music, because it only has 5 GB of space, a chunk of which is needed for the OS. The more it's loaded the slower it goes. The Cloud space is limited to 5000 books, once you buy them, they're yours forever and once the cloud is filled that's it. For a heavy reader like me I'd like to see options for increasing space, even if I have to pay a reasonable fee. The magazine selection is poor,the newspapers section worse. As for apps I found a few, but honestly they're mostly for children or young people.

But the piece'de resistance, is the ongoing problem with charging unit and cord. Apparently, when they developed the unit,the metal they used make the cradle for the charging plug inside the unit isn't strong enough and fatigues rapidly, creating wiggle room so the unit soon charges with prolonged and increasing difficulty. I am now on my 3rd KF and my husband just bought me an Ipad 2.[[ASIN:B0051VVOB2 Kindle Fire, Full Color 7\\" Multi-touch Display, Wi-Fi]] Steve Schuerger and Mary Ann Coy

I bought my 1 TB 6 months ago, transferred all my files from an off-brand 500 MB, and started adding all my RAW photography pictures to it when one day (yesterday) the light turned red, stayed red, and my external drive disappeared from my computer. The external is still running, a noise that gets annoying when you are a light sleeper, but there is no drive recognition on my computer. I tried a new USB cable, a new power cord, tried it on three different computers, opened the disk manager from the My Computer menu, and nothing.     Customer service was very unhelpful. I can return it, but I have no guarantee of regaining my files, or getting a replacement within any decent amount of time. When trying to porblem-solve the situation, I found nothing helpful from their website. I knew it was a bad sign when I did a general search on the internet of other people with the same problem, and found numerous complaints about the red light of doom.     I recommend that anyone looking at this external hard drive think twice before buying it. if you do buy it, buy a back-up, because it will likely crash on you. If you depend on your external hard drive, this is not a dependable device. If you like helpful customer service, please consider any device other than this one.     As for me, I hope to find a local business that can recover my files and transfer them to another external hard drive. I'll probably get a back-up too, since this is the third external I've tried that's failed me. If you like dependable and ong-lasting, like I do, think twice before getting any external hard drive from this company.

I bought this because I wanted the best screen protector. I was cautious going in because the gist of the reviews, good or bad, seemed to indicate that I needed to really take my time and follow the instructions to the letter. I had been using the tablet for a few weeks and not gotten a scratch, but it was very dirty. After cleaning it to a like new state, following the directions and taking extra precautions against things like dust and moisture, I applied the 'armor'. I was again concerned because it looked thick and filmy after being squeegeed and re-positioned several times. Then I went to bed. Now, its 6pm on MAr. 26th (the next day, 18+ hours). I asked my wife how she liked my screen protector and she said, "I don't see it." HA! I can feel it, but, without looking for the edges, it's not there. Shining it in the light revealed two small surface defects that remind me that there's plastic on there and those happen to be on the parts where the screen is not lit (the frame??). And it's only been 18 hours. I wouldn't be surprised if they disappeared tomorrow.

I'm charging it right now and I'll tell you what... If there's a problem with my machine, I'll come back and rip these guys a new one. But I've had lots of experiences with things like this and I can already tell, this is going to do what they say it will. If you don't see an addendum to this post, or another post by me below, assume it's because everything's fine and it's as good as they say. I don't write a lot of long winded posts for product reviews, but these guys deserve it. "I can't see it.".... WIN WIN WIN !!!!!

The back of the case was a hard plastic bonded with a synthetic leather that had "fingers" to grip the front of the tablet. The smart "snapped" closed.
