This laptop runs smoothly and has given me no trouble thus far. It is important to mention that MSI installs a LOT of random crap on this product. Things ranging from their own software to Windows 8 applications. Just be warned. About 50 GB of the 120 in the SSD was filled by their junk (and the OS of course). It would be nice if they gave you the option to install certain applications that were located on a CD that came with the laptop. Either way, it is still pretty good.

I will be removing 85% of the applications that came pre-installed on this laptop in order to clear up room for what I originally got it for: gaming and working.

EDIT: I have changed my original rating of 4 stars to 1 star. This is because there was faulty hardware in the system. I got this error when trying to boot up one time - PAGE_IN_NONPAGED_AREA. Essentially, this means that there is something wrong with the RAM or GPU. Not exactly sure which one it is.

I was having problems very early on running games like League of Legends and KOTOR 2. LoL would randomly freeze/hang for 2 or so seconds whenever a fight started, and then would fast forward to my death. KOTOR 2 is an older game and shouldn't have any problems with 1) running less-intensive graphics and 2) running at a lower resolution. However, occasionally when a fight would break out, the game would hang for 1-2 seconds, then resume. I was able to move my mouse but the actual game content froze. This would also happen when I tried to open up boxes, transition into certain areas, etc.

The most interesting thing about all of this is that I was able to run games like Far Cry 3, Skyrim (with mods), and Sim City 5 at the max resolution and graphics settings without any hang at all! At no time did the game randomly freeze or give me any sort of issue. So, when the hardware worked, it ran beautifully. However, I didn't pay $2000 to own a faulty machine that didn't run all kinds of games smoothly (or only ran them well part of the time).

I'm just glad my problems with this laptop started arising within the first two weeks of me owning this product. I'm returning this product today using my 30-day warranty. Please be aware that if you do buy this product, you run the risk of purchasing faulty hardware. I would buy a warranty plan with this laptop in the event of hardware failure.

I have another brand of case from i-Blason. Compares to that, I think this case by Fintie is better for the following reasons:
1. This Fintie case has better/tighter fit. iPad doesn't move at all when put into the case. This is important because if you drop your iPad on the corner, if it moves too much in the case, it will actually hit the landing surface and damages your iPad. The corner of my iPad already been damaged while I used the i-Blason case before.
2. The base/back cover is a little bit bigger. This is also important in protecting your iPad when you drop it. The larger back offsets the iPad away from the edge of the case further thus gives the iPad more tolerance not to hit the landing surface when dropped.
3. The magnet on the cover is stronger. This holds the cover in position better.
4. Great Price!

I bought 2 for my sons' iPad. I'm buying one more for myself.
I would recommended this case.

Updates 08/31/15:
After I got one for myself and used it for over a month. Personally, I think there's one design flow to this case. As I mentioned in my original review, the bottom/back side is bigger than the other brand I had before which provides better drop protection. However, later on I realized that only the outer edge where you open the cover is bigger which is what actually provides drop protection when drop on that edge. The problem I see now is the inside / bottom edge is too small. When I put the iPad in the standing position, the bottom of the iPad itself actually protruded out and hit the table surface. And because of that, if you drop your iPad on this edge, the iPad might be damaged. I suggest that the manufacture make the inside edge 1/4" larger to give it better protection. However, doing so may make the fit of the cover "loose" as there might be too much slack on the cover but I rather have better protection than tight fit. Other than this issue, this is a great case. For this reason, I removed 1 star from the original 5 stars I gave.

I was so excited when this new kindle hit the market, but after further investigation I am considering not getting it, and continuing to use my kindle 3g keyboard model. I have loved the keyboard model save one missing feature which the new paperwhite has, lighting on the device. I have tried the cases with a light that hook right onto your kindle, I have tried clip on lights, (don't advice,) and now have settled with using a kindle light that attaches to your device. I have not upgraded to any other model; I have been using the 3g keyboard kindle, waiting for a model to be released that had its own lighting- paperwhite. I was all set to click purchase until I read a review that said they dropped the mp3 from this model. Now I usually READ the books I download, but at night, when eyes are getting tired, I bookmark the spot I am at, and turn on the text to speech setting, listening till I fall asleep. (Since book marked, it doesn't take to much effort to find where I fell out, and stopped listening so I can continue reading.

It is this, and only this that is keeping me from upgrading to the paperwhite. Any chance that the developers will add mp3 again to a new release of paperwhite will have me jumping to buy. I just don't think I will purchase one until this happens. I am really disappointed about this. I have waited for years for a kindle with built in lighting. Any attached light, in any form, is not as comfortable a reading experience as it is without a light attached.

I'm a huge android fan and was trying to decide between this and the Samsung tab for my daughter. I have a Samsung Note and everyone in our home has Samsung Galaxy S4 phones. I've also had other Android tablets in the past. I picked this because it had a bit faster processor speed than the Tab and the tech reviews online were glowing. However, I've found it to be an awful watered-down version of an Android tablet, with many Android apps and features just not available because of the dumbed down interface that forces use of Amazon app store and prohibits access to the main and largest Android app store, Google Play. It also lacks other great android features commonly found on the Samsung and Nexus Android tablets.

What this means:

If you have bought apps in the Google play store in the past (for previous tablets, phone, etc.) you WILL NOT be able to access them, download them, or use them at all on this tablet unless you root it, which then invalidates all warranties, etc. (and you also need decent tech abilities were you to want to try to root it). The interface does not allow you to download the Google Play store, nor can you try to get apps from it via the browser, as something about the way they've programmed the Fire essentially makes it invisible to the Android Play store, so that the store doesn't recognize the Fire tablet as being an Android.

Even if you've never bought anything from the Google Play store, it's still a bummer for you because the Amazon app store has a VERY limited selection of apps. If you're getting this for your kid, they want to change the wall papers and personalize the tablet. There is a very limited selection of not very interesting wallpapers and it's just not optimized to enhance your experience by customizing it with apps you'd like because the selection is so very limited. I have about 30 some apps in my Google play account. Once owned, you can use them for any of your Android products (usually) and once you login to your google account you have easy access to download them all to your new device. Can't do that with the Fire at all. So even if it does have some of the apps I like and use, I'd have to pay for them again, via the Amazon app store in order to have them. I have a bunch of medical apps that I use and some of them are available in the Amazon store, but most are not. Same with the apps my daughter has and even more so with the wallpapers and other personalizations that are typically available for Android products.

My daughter, when checking out this tablet and attempting to customize it, was seriously disappointed and upset with it, stating "my Android phone has more capabilities and things to do with it than this tablet!". If your kid is at all tech savvy they will hate this tablet.

Unfortunately it seems like Amazon has taken a great little tablet but stripped it of it's great abilities in order to force-funnel all owners into buying from their limited app store, streaming only their videos and music, disallowing access to other great media and news and useful applications that are found in the Google Play store, thus limiting it's capabilities. There may be other sites that it limits the use of as I didn't do an exhaustive search, prohibiting Google Play access was enough for me to know we'd never be happy with it. I'd say the apps it comes with, already loaded are disappointing as well when compared to what comes on a real android tablet (one that lets you access the full world of apps, music, books & magazines, blogs & posts, etc. that most every other Android tablet can access) It's kind of like buying a truck but blocking off the back bed area (the box area where you can put tons of stuff, the essential part of a truck that makes it so useful..) so that you can never put anything in it or use it, you can only put stuff in the front cab - why bother with a truck then?

If you want a true Android with allthe capabilities of an android (and I can think of no reason that you wouldn't want that...) then you really need to buy an alternate Android tablet. I'd suggest looking at the Samsung tablets, such as the tab or note. I am not an Apple fan at all, but I would even say to get an iPad over this tablet as it's capabilities have just been too stunted by the limits imposed by Amazon's interface. It's very disappointing as in general I'm a huge Amazon fan and I love my Amazon Fire TV and basic kindle. However, with this they've very much disappointed me. This tablet is limited to streaming video & music from Amazon, downloading Amazon books and light/limited internet browsing. It's true capabilities have been cut off.

SUMMARY: Severely limited use as you can't access the thousands of apps and goodies on Google Play as the Amazon interface prohibits downloading the Google Play app and has made the tablet unrecognizable as an Android if you access Google Play via the browser. You'd have to root it in order to change this which will invalidate your warranty. This denied access to Google Play severely limits the capabilities of your tablet. If you want a real Android tablet with full functionality look at the Samsung Tab or Samsung Note instead. The decision by Amazon to prohibit full access to the plethora of Android features and apps is very disappointing.the capabilities of an android (and I can think of no reason that you wouldn't want that...) then you really need to buy an alternate Android tablet. I'd suggest looking at the Samsung tablets, such as the tab or note. I am not an Apple fan at all, but I would even say to get an iPad over this tablet as it's capabilities have just been too stunted by the limits imposed by Amazon's interface. It's very disappointing as in general I'm a huge Amazon fan and I love my Amazon Fire TV and basic kindle. However, with this they've very much disappointed me. This tablet is limited to streaming video & music from Amazon, downloading Amazon books and light/limited internet browsing. It's true capabilities have been cut off.

SUMMARY: Severely limited use as you can't access the thousands of apps and goodies on Google Play as the Amazon interface prohibits downloading the Google Play app and has made the tablet unrecognizable as an Android if you access Google Play via the browser. You'd have to root it in order to change this which will invalidate your warranty. This denied access to Google Play severely limits the capabilities of your tablet. If you want a real Android tablet with full functionality look at the Samsung Tab or Samsung Note instead. The decision by Amazon to prohibit full access to the plethora of Android features and apps is very disappointing.

I ordered nearly $200 worth of these ethernet cables to stock up on various lengths of CAT6 ethernet cables from this Amazon third party supplier, all in sets of 10, on the faith that according to the product's picture, which happens to show 10 different colors, that I would in fact receive in a given length 10 cables of 10 different colors, despite the mention of just one color in the verbal description.     When I received, promptly it must be said... in my case... boxes and boxes of nothing but GREEN cables, I was greatly disappointed. I immediately called the third party supplier who claimed, \\"Yes, I know the picture is misleading, but Amazon won't allow us to change the picture.\\" He then offered to do whatever it took to make me happy... while muttering under his breath that some of the other colors were in some way of inferior quality. I almost believed his mea culpa claim about Amazon until I subsequently visited his own corporate webstore where presumably they DO have direct control over the images used for their various products... and yes, there were the same MISLEADING pictures of 10 cables in 10 colors.     CONCLUSION:  This merchant knowingly misleads its customers... and I haven't even tested the veracity of their claim to being CAT 6 yet! I don't recommend doing business with merchants who intentionally mislead their customers.

I've always wanted to build a computer for years but I could not find the right case. It was always either overly designed (\\"gaming cases\\") or just plain boring. The really nice cases such as Lian Li were too expensive. When I found the Define R4 I had to get it. The reviews were mostly, if not all, very positive.

I'll try to touch as many bases as I can:

[PROS]

- doesnt look like a typical gamer fast and furious honda civic sir crx rice rocket case

- all 7 fans are 140mm; able to run lower rpm while keeping temps very cool and quiet.

- easy-access dust filters. just slide out, clean, DONE.

- built in 3 speed fan controller (5v, 7v, 12v) for up to 3 fans. i have it controlling 2 intake fans and turn it up to 12v for gaming.

- built in cable management grommets and tie-downs with included zip ties. makes me look like a freaking PRO

- adjustable hard drive cages; turn it 90 degrees, remove top cage. move it back to fit a front radiator. or even remove it completely!

- sound deadening material on the top, side panels, and behind the front door

- very minimal subdued design. blank front panel. case is free from any branding.

- thick chassis and panels make it extremely solid.

- extremely roomy interior

- extremely versatile case for air cooling, watercooling, leave hd cages and use as a NAS box. it can be anything you want it to be without any modifications.

- SO MANY FEATURES for less than $ 100

[CONS]

- due to manufacturing, the fan cutouts on top slightly concave down. The base intake cut outs also concave inward.
(I've contacted Fractal Design and they stated they have corrected that flaw. Not sure if it qualifies as a defect but its hardly noticeable unless you really stare at it.)

- this may be knit picky but there is no dedicated HDD activity light, just a single BRIGHT blue power led.
(you can connect the LEDs to the hdd activity instead of power led)

- fan controller connector disconnects when you remove the entire front panel

- side intake fan vent has no dust filter

- reset button is not recessed deep enough to prevent accidental resets

- 5.25\\" drive bay is not removable--like the Midi Arc R2

*******Just some details to know********

- if you're only using the lower hdd cage, installing a 3.5\\" 7200 rpm hard drive on the lowest tray will cause the hd's vibrations to resonate through your case. it will be a very audible and annoying, at least for me. no amount of anti-vibration products will fix that unless you move it the hdd else where. it only happens on that bottom tray. I have it installed in 5.25\\" drive bay with brackets. i barely notice it spooling up.

- make sure you connect the fan controller molex the right orientation to the PSU molex or the fan speeds wont work correctly.

- some fans, like Noctua, need at least 7v to power on and spin. 5v is not enough and you will see your fan twitch but not spin.

- if you plan on using custom casefeet, be aware that the front/rear screw holes are not aligned. the rear screws are closer to the outer edge to allow clearance for intake cut-outs and dust filter. i put larger casefeet (akin to hi-fi amplifiers) and the rear feet stick out way more. i actually kind of like it staggered look but thats me.

4/5 stars bc my vents concave. everything else is absolutely perfect.

I use PowerPoint for presentations, and like to roam.  This allows me to roam quite a ways and still be able to control my slides.  The laser pointer isn't very powerful.  It would be fine in a room with 30 or so people, but for larger audiences, I would recommend a separate laser pointer that is more powerful.  I've forgotten to turn it on a couple of times, and of course it doesn't work when turned off, but after figuring that out, I haven't had any problems with it.  The blank feature works well, although that is not something I regularly use.  I don't use the program switcher button at the top, and am not sure how helpful it really is.  If you are doing other than PowerPoint, there isn't much use for this remote.  For PowerPoint, it is fantastic.

I love the Kindle more than I thought.  For someone who reads everyday and loves to have a wide variety of books at my fingertips, the Kindle is a dream come true.  Like many, I was one who thought I would miss the feel of a book.  Well, I still have books and I'll still read conventional books.  But the Kindle is a fantastic supplement so to speak.  It's perfect for reading in bed too, especially with my little clip on light.  Then I can just read until I'm sleepy.  I did buy the leather folder cover for it so it feels more like a book now but even before that, it was fine.  I just wanted to splurge a little.       The Kindle has so many features I love.  I love being able to determine the size type I want (although the standard is perfect for me and as easy to read as a conventional book).  I love being able to scroll down my downloaded books and if I've started reading, for the Kindle to \\"open\\" at the place I left off.  I love being able to download excerpts and read them at my leisure.  I love the highlighter function so I can just look at all my highlights in a book whenever I want or find it easily when I want to share a passage with a friend.  I love the almost instantaneous downloads of purchased books, i.e. I was listening to a CD the other day and the speaker mentioned a book that seemed really interesting.  So right then and there I downloaded the book and started reading almost immediately.  I love that I got so many classics for free and that so many books are available for .99 cents, $2.99 and $4.99.  (I initially downloaded 30 books for $42.99).  I love having the dictionary feature right there so I can look up a word.  And I love being able to shop in the Kindle store with the wireless capability while sitting in my favorite easy chair.  I haven't looked into the e-mail capability yet, but that in itself is a wonderful feature to have.    It took me awhile to take the plunge because I really do love the look and feel of books, but now I am SO happy Idid.  I just LOVE my Kindle and can't wait to take it on vacation.

I like NetGear equipment but this router has one feature that I do not appreciate. It's the port forwarding concept. It will only allow the user to choose either a range of ports to forward or a single port to forward using the same port-to-port numbers. I was unable to inbound a port number and outbound a different port number. i.e. 60001 -> 5815. It won't work. The NetGear WNDR4500 allows the user flexibility to range ports and do port to port with different numbers. But not this one. Not all networks fall into the "standard" and a user needs flexibility. The only option is that the user has to change connected equipment port numbers, if possible. Would be so much simpler to just do it at the router... and let the router do what routers do....  but not here with this router. It looses 2 stars for the extra work it caused me.

This headrest mount for tablets is pretty universal and generically designed. There are several other brands at this price range and have very similar design and function. This one is no special in terms of design and function, so it is just basic headrest mount for tablets. Installing was easy and straightforward, and it stayed in position well and sturdily as well, once installed. Since I have the passenger's headrest pretty low, the plastic parts that were holding the metal bar did not bother the passenger's seating.
One thing I'd like to mention is that once installed, there wasn't much room to juggle for angle adjustments and inserting the tablet. It was not impossible to adjust angles, but it was not easy to loosen the joint and tighten again after the installation. Overall, this mount works well for my needs; it is a cheap and quick way to entertain kids in the car for a occasional long ride. Holding a tablet to watch something in the car for kids is not so comfortable. This cheap mount is a quick solution to that, and my child is happy to sit back and relax. If you happen to have a bluetooth headset, then it's all set to go.

I have been looking at several of these and reading reviews. This week a consultant was here and we used one of these that he brought with him to analyze diesel fuel and particles in it. After a couple of dozen analysis, snapping pictures of the results while we showed them to the group on screen, I placed an order for my own.

We actually did not use the stand. It worked well sitting directly on top of the membrane with the particles in them (covered with a plastic film).

Wherever we went, we just plugged it in and slid it around the membrane to show the particles, mostly in the 1 to 40 micron range.

Here are a couple of pics of samples just with the macro on a normal digital camera, plus additional pictures taken through the microscope. [...]

Mine came and it is great. I can see why people comment on the stand, but I don't use it. People are amazed at how dirty their fuel is.

I like old things. I love old movies (30s, 40s, 50s) and I love old books, the smell, the feel.  But I also like long Novels and series...for example, I have about 15 of the Eternal Champion Omnibus editions...bringing only two of those huge books on a trip would add some weight to whatever bag they were in.    My first experience with a kindle was a kindle 2 white versions a CEO at a company I worked for received from Amazon. Then, I thought it would be a phase or something like the webTV or web appliance things that companies bring out every few years. The CEO booted it up and showed me how \\"cool\\" he thought it was, but I remained unconvinced that anyone would prefer that over a book.  Cut to 4 some odd years later and a coworker is showing me his Kindle 3. Smaller, lighter, and brighter, the Kindle 3 amazed me...and having been using the iPhone for a year, I kept trying to turn the pages by swiping the screen!  I told myself that I would eventually get one.    After drooling over it for more than a year, last week I picked up the 3G+wifi version as an early Father's day gift, from Best Buy.   My first impression: They need to put a small sticker or something in the Quick Start guide that says something like: The screen on your kindle is not an overlay. Please do not try to remove. Simply turn the unit on!!  Like others, I was trying to figure out how to peel off the button layout \\"Overlay\\" after pulling off the screen and case protectors. In a rare moment of clarity, I turned the unit on and was amazed. I was literally going to ask if someone had a razor blade I could use to pry!!    It's smaller than I thought, with a leather case/light; it's about the same size as a DVD case with slip cover, very convenient.  With the big books I mentioned above and even some of the thicker paper backs, reading can be a strain on my hands, arms, and shoulders, but my neck as well. The kindle is light even with the case.    The buttons are ok. I'd have preferred a QWERTY keyboard with separate numbers, but it's not a deal breaker. The page turning buttons are a bit confusing for me. Both sides of the kindle have the back and forward button in the same orientation...and it's taking me a bit of getting used to. Often I hold the kindle with my right hand and hit the next page button with my right thumb...to go back a page I have been mistakenly hitting the left forward button. I understand that having the buttons the way they are is convenient for both lefties and righties, but my poor old brain is having a time adjusting. This is more my fault than the layout of the kindle.  Page turns are crisp and efficient.  Reading multiple books at once is as easy as going back to the home page and choosing a new book...I don't even have to worry about bookmarking the page, each book selected goes back to the last page I was on. Nice.    The screen, in daylight, is amazing. The eInk is clear and very readable. When I was picking it up at best buy the salesmen was suggesting I need a light. At first I wasn't going to bother but I did want a case and saw the official leather case with LED light so I got it.  My only complaint with the light is that it is angles so it's facing the top right corner of the kindle with the rest of the unit getting the part of the light. So far I haven't had any issues reading in complete darkness...but I would like to have been able to bend the neck of the light a bit to cover more of the kindle.       Reading books couldn't be easier. Although, I would like to be able to customize the \\"table of contents\\" for the kindle...meaning I would like to be able to put which books I wanted on the home page...almost like what you can do with apps on the Android or iPhone...A customized home screen, if you will. I would also have liked to be able to customize the screen saver...an app to create grayscale copies of your fav pics to be added to the kindle would be awesome!     I picked up the 3G+Wifi because I when I do travel, I might not have access to wifi hotspots...in checking the coverage for 3G, even remote areas I have been to and will travel to in the future, such as Oxcutzkab, Yucatan, Mexico, have coverage!    I definitly recommend to anyone that likes to read...get the kindle...well worth it.

I'm still not totally sold on this over my mouse.  I use the trackpad a lot when using my Macbook Pro, but using my MacPro at home I have always used a mouse.  This is taking some time to get used to at a desk setting.  Nice quality though - seems to work just like the trackpad on my laptop.

Webcam is a definite plus.  Pictures are clear and usually ready for print.  When skyping the picture on the other side is spectacular I am told.  Must be nice to get a clear picture.  The camera on my lap top is never clear no matter the lighting used.  Good camera.

Film grain is very apparent on this webcam. Even in a well lit room, you can see the grains compared to the C910. Also, the focusing on this camera is worse than in the C910. On the C910, my room whole room would appear crisp and in focus.

Mic still picks up too much background noise. The C910 wasn't any better in this regard. Disappointing that this isn't fixed on the C920 by at least increasing the resistance a little or have it done in software.

It has come to my attention (from comments below) that this webcam actually has a 3 megapixel sensor and Logitech gets its 15 megapixels by using software! That explains the worse image quality.

Pros: The C920 has a standard tripod mount. This is useful for mounting to mini-tripods that can be placed anywhere on your desk. On board video encoder means it will reduce CPU usage (but still wasn't enough to use on G+ Hangouts with anymore people in the room than with the C910 on a laptop running with AMD C-50, 2GB ram)

Cons: Worse image quality than the C910. This might be due to the fact that it uses a 3 MP sensor versus the 5 MP on the C910. Tests were done subjectively in Skype, Google Hangouts, and from recorded video via Logitech's own software at 720P and 1080P. Running on an AMD 965 BE quad core 3.4 Ghz, 4 GB Ram, Windows 7 64 Bit. Honestly, its hard to tell if there's any CPU reduction on a desktop like mine since it doesn't tax my system enough.

Works flawlessly. Haven't seen it drop a connection yet since I bought for Christmas, I have about 16 wireless devices in my home. They all work perfectly. No problems with speed either. Decided to upgrade to Comcast Extreme speed, all AC devices had no problem hitting around 115Mbps through wireless. I verified using speedtest.comcast.net. N and G devices performed pretty well too, but AC speed blows em out the water, and the router speed is very consistent. No problems at all with range either. Seem like it was definitely worth the money.

Most of my N devices seemed to achieve the best speeds with 5Ghz. I found with 2.4Ghz freq that I achieved the best performance with Explicit beamforming disabled, TurboQAM enabled, set channel 11, set channel bandwidth 40Mhz, and QoS disabled. Hope this helps guys.

My computer does not have any Molex power connectors (Dell 9100) and all of my SATA power connectors were in use, so I purchased this and [[ASIN:B002N2EHVQ StarTech.com PYO2SATA 6in SATA Power Y Splitter Cable Adapter - M/F]] and I now have two working Molex power connectors without giving up any SATA power connectors.

I pulled the SATA power connector out of my DVD drive (as I seldom use it anyway, so any power requirements from my Molex devices would unlike be negatively affected) and put that plug into the SATA splitter. I put one of the other ends of the SATA splitter into my DVD drive and the other end into this Molex splitter and everthing is working as expected.

Of the four computers I've owned so far, this computer is by far the greatest and most satisfying. I have not had a single problem with it other than some minor bugs that are to be expected.

I'm not a big fan of Windows XP, however. The computer did come pre-installed with a lot of stuff I never intended on using, so I got rid of a good 4GB of files the first day I got it. However, other than that, it's a wonderful machine, and is very affordable for how top-notch it is.

Pros:
- Great build quality, solid mouse
- responsive as any wired mouse I have used to date.
- works as advertised. Literally anywhere, except probably gravel.
- free spinning wheel scrolled through a 600 page PDF with ease.
- can be used with 2 AA batteries or just 1 (I like 2 for the weight)
- small form factor and free fitted mouse bag make it a nice travelling mouse.

Cons:
- wheel does not middle-click, but the button just behind the wheel does.
- storage of \\"unifying receiver\\" requires removing the back plate of the mouse
- i'm not entirely sure what the light on the top of the mouse is for. (battery level indicator?)

Overall:
The mouse took a little while to get used to, especially with the wheel that can change from free spinning to ratcheted. After using it for about a month now as my only mouse, prefer the button middle-click to the wheel middle-click. I have a \\"claw\\" style mouse grip, so this mouse suits me perfectly, but after thinking about it, people who use a palm grip might want to find the mouse in a store somewhere to get an idea for how it feels. The mouse could be ambidextrous, but the back/forward buttons are positioned for right-handed users. My last gripe is that there is no auto shutoff feature (well... there isn't one listed), which means I leave my mouse on overnight wasting battery power. Regardless, this mouse is the best wired or wireless mouse I have used to-date.

I like this case very much. It is a bit oversized for the majority of Micro ATX mobos. But, for the price, I'm not complaining. There is only room for the one included 80mm case fan which is reasonably quiet. There's an additional rectangular mounting area along the bottom of the case towards the front. I've no idea what would fit there.
One important caveat: This case is NOT "Compatible with Any Micro Atx Power Supply" as the description states. Nor just any SFX PSU, as SFX and Micro ATX seem to interchangeable terms for the same PSU form factor. I had a difficult time sourcing a reasonably-priced PSU for this case. I finally got a used SFX from eBay. That PSU, as with many SFX PSUs, has the fan mounted externally. That PSU would not fit in the PSU cavity of this case. I managed to alter the PSU to get it to fit but I certainly would not recommend that approach. Sentey used to offer on Amazon their slim cases with PSUs for only $20 more. Too bad they no longer do so.

Router technology is more than a decade old, this absolutely is old hat for most companies. Yet each time I've complained that the RT314 is simply randomly failing (i.e. all lights are on and functioning, but apparently nobody is home and my permanent high-speed Internet connection is unavailable) they have suggested another upgrade patch.
Well, 3.25 was the last one, and I still don't have reliable service. The worst bit is the inconsistency. Sometimes it's one computer that doesn't have Internet, sometimes the other, sometimes both. Sometimes rebooting the router helps, sometimes reprogramming helps, sometimes nothing helps but the passage of time.
It is amazingly frustrating to have no fixes to keep the router working more than a day at a time. To date, Netgear has not fixed the problem, while acknowledging each failure with another update that should "make it more reliable."
After a year of this, I simply had to write and share such foibles and poor equipment and software results.

It is fast. For an average user, after you install the OS on the drive, there is a much faster startup time on your computer. And files opens much faster. (well this is true for most good SSD)

The migration software seems to be pretty useless. I used paragon disk manager to migrate and expand the OS partition from my old HDD.

The samsung magician benchmark gives faster figures than crystaldiskmark. But still, the random access figures isn't reaching the specs in both of the benchmarks. But I don't really care since my computer turns on in few seconds and most files open in a split second.

The magician software interface is a bit confusing. It's only useful for viewing the status of the drive.

The drive I have gotten comes already installed with the firmware that caused bricking when installed with magician. So no worries about updating firmware on the drive, for now.

Well so those are the experiences of using this drive for an average user. For more detailed benchmarking and stuff just look at others' comments or read website reviews.

I just received my keyboard today, and I'm still trying to get a feel for it. I bought the Galaxy Tab and keyboard because I will be doing a lot of traveling and commuting over the summer and next year, and I wanted a portable and lightweight way to be able to type class notes and some minor written assignments while I am away from home (I'm a grad student on the side). At home, I usually work on a netbook for convenience, so I am used to typing on small keyboards. This one is taking a bit of time to get used to, however, because it has soft keys similar to those that you see on roll-up keyboards like the ones at Brookstone and in Skymall. I've had a bunch of keystrokes repeat on me, which is a becoming REALLY obnoxious, and for some reason the screen keeps flashing \\"English (U.S.)\\" at the bottom, as if the keyboard keeps disconnnecting and reconnecting. I am not noticing any inability to type or any disconnect, but I am betting it is related to my double character issue. My biggest key placement complaint is the apostrophe ' key, which is in an awkward place at the bottom For what it's worth, I'm still able to type pretty quickly on the keyboard, unlike another reviewer who commented on that issue.

I wanted so bad for this to work for me. In a number of ways it did, but in the end there were too many things to detract from what could have been a perfect "bridge device".

Pros
* Its Android, nearly pure and simple.
* The laptop tablet was perfect for me. It was very comfortable for me to poerate as I could just set it in my lap. Hand fatigue is always an issue with me and tablets.
* Its very light and portable.
* Android vs Windows 8
* Price
* All of my Apps transfer right over
* Sounds pretty good

Cons
* BATTERY LIFE on my unit was dismal. 3-5 hours max
* Screen is just sad. Very noticeable color banding, horrible viewing angles. It does not look 1080p. Its washed out and hard to read/look at.
* It gets very hot in a couple of spots, but it seems most laptops get hot.
* It isn't always sure if its a tablet or a phone.
* The touchpad is also just sad. The click actuation should have never left R&D this way. The sensitivity is all over the place.

There a lot of nice things that would happen when I opened this thing up. ok google at any time, widgets, oh the widgets. Google services were effortless.

I hope this isn't the last attempt at this. The CONS I listed are simple to fix and I would gladly pay alot more for a 14-16 inch version of this with an ips display and a touchpad that worked.
The battery management has to be improved as well. But like I said, if someone tries this again with better components (looking at you samsung, htc) I would be on it.

This stand is awesome. I have recently rebuilt my basement and added a home office to the mix. I decided that the foot print that my monitor stands took on my new desk were too great so I started looking for a stand that would hold my 2 - 27" monitors. I read the reviews for most of the ones on Amazon and decided to purchase this one due to the review and the price. I couldn't be happier! The monitors are very sturdy and the adjustments you can make to the positioning is awesome. I didn't expect the level of customization that you could do in terms of monitor location. Once you get the monitor in your desired location you can tighten the arms down in a fashion where the monitors can still be rotated easily by hand but they are stable and you do not have to worry about them falling.

I was also worried about making this purchase because my new desk has a glass top and I was afraid that the mounting bracket would crack the glass because of the type of device used to tighten it to the desk top. Once I put it in place and began to tighten it I found that my worries were not valid and the product worked perfectly. I did cut some of the box that it was packed in and place the cardboard over the metal screws at the bottom where it touched the glass just to be safe but it was probably not even needed.

I am very pleased with this product though and if you are in the market for a dual monitor stand I highly recommend this product. For the price you can't go wrong.

This is a tremendous value buy if you're rolling your own server.  I prefer Intel processors for many different tasks, especially anything even remotely mobile.  But Intel charges a king's ransom to unlock the full power of their virtualization tools and in a use case where more cores is a good thing you need a mortgage on top of the ransom to buy Intel.  This is an area where AMD really does shine.  I built a very powerful rig to play around with VMWare using this chip and saved a fortune.  It loses out to single threaded performance all day long, but for my needs this was an obvious choice.  It's also great to support the last company keeping Intel honest!

Most USB flash drives come with a cap to protect the USB interface and a lanyard so that the device can hang around the neck or from a peg. This device is designed differently. Unfortunately, the construction of the slide is poor and it feels flimsy and likely to break at any moment. It probably won't but frankly, I expect something that feels significant less cheap for this price. Other than that, the device in unexceptional and does what you would expect from a USB flash drive.

I was upgrading my old HDD to a new Seagate SSHD on my netbook, trying both a USB to SATA adapter and an external USB laptop SATA drive case.  I tried Seagate's own DiscWizard, Macrum Reflect, and EaseUS, all of which refused to even try to clone my drive over; unfortunately, my new drive had a sector size of 4096, while my old drive had only 512, preventing me from doing a sector to sector clone. Further, file by file cloning wasn't an option for any of these because they kept reporting hard drive errors that chkdsk wasn't detecting.  After ordering this, I even tried downloading Apricorn's software (a free download) and using it with my own dongles while waiting for my order to arrive, but it would not run correctly without Apricorn's own dongle.  Finally it arrived and it ran without any issues.  I literally connected the dongle to my drive and netbook, started the software, selected my source and destination drives, and clicked start.  Just over an hour later (my netbook only has USB 2.0), the clone was complete and I replaced my hard drive and booted up with no issues.

This unit is relatively well built in general construction. It comes up short in a couple areas. The first is packaging. I refused the first unit because it wasn't covered on either end and looked like it'd been slid on concrete and rolled across the shipping warehouse. The second unit came with much better packaging and on a small skid. Looked like manufacturer's packaging and was probably lost on the first unit it shipping. Good corner protection. That said, at 130+lbs at fall or tip leaves obvious signs of shipping damage. The packaging of the second unit looked good. After removal I found the main door had a bent hinge pin and a crease on one of the corners with paint chipping off. The second point, the hinge pins and bushings are really not up the challenge. The shipping process made the bushings look like the door had been used everyday for a year before I got it. They should try taping the door or installing shipping spacers to secure the door during shipment.

Other that those relatively major issues, it appears to be a flexible and solid unit. I like the layout ease of use.

Provides a decent breeze for the \\"Computer operator\\" which is why we bought it. I found myself needing a wireless antenna for my tower in order to connect to my backup internet signal - as a home-based employee, I don't get paid without internet access. I didn't order the tower last year with a wireless card, as I have a heavy duty laptop for use when the power is out, and I have had a pay-as-you-go dial-up plan since 2006 for those moments when the cable is down. Found out the hard way earlier this month that the dial-up service went kaput (not even so much as a warning email), so I had to act fast to obtain backup internet access. I added a portable hotspot to my cell service, which would give me 4G LTE data speed... and the laptop connected to it instantly. But the tower needed an antenna. After reading various reviews, I opted for this one.

It set up easily on the Windows 8 Pro x64 tower - driver loaded from the supplied CD, plugged the unit into one of the USB 3.0 ports, and it found the hotspot right away. Was able to connect to my work server with no problem, and a speed test showed reasonable speed... not as fast as my cable (60 Mbps down/6 up), but certainly comparable to DSL at 7 down/3 up... and way better than 56K dial-up.

This antenna is exactly what I needed - it's portable (can be carried forward to a new computer), doesn't require a power cord or transformer, and it works as intended. Can't ask for more than that.

Nothing special here. Just some nice simple copper heat-sinks for Raspberry Pi. Simply clean the three chips on the board with alcohol, let dry, peel off the plastic backing on each heat-sink and stick. That's it.

Really, you don't need heat-sinks on a Raspberry Pi for normal use. However, I made a Raspberry Pi into an outdoor webcam and put it in a "HBPRO-601HB Outdoor CCTV Camera Housing" that I bought here on Amazon as well. The HBPRO-601HB has a built in fan (and heating element) and I figured the fan blowing over these heat-sinks would ensure my Raspberry Pi has the best chance of remaining within operating temperature tolerances during the summer months here in Texas.

And I appreciate Harman Kardon giving these speakers an honest 80 watts \\"RMS\\" rating instead of some funkier, faker, exaggerated rating. My biggest criticism of the HK595 speakers is that the Bass and Treble controls don't provide a lot of range. I usually have the Bass at minimum and the Treble at maximum, which might suggest a tendency towards muddiness if the tone controls were centered. But the equalizer in my Winamp media player is sufficient to push more than enough trebles for speech and snare drums. The speakers can reproduce 'em easily, but there's just not a lot of treble boost from their onboard adjustment, so you'll need some additional equalization before the signal gets to these speakers.

When everyone leaves the house and Jimmy Hendrix gets turned up to eliminate any residual inner-ear cilia that haven't died yet, I might also turn up the Bass control on the 595s. That eliminates the need to have the bass sliders getting too wavy on the Winamp equalizer. But the equalizer will need to boost the trebles, anyway.

The dog has a different opinion. When the volume gets that loud, she leaves.

This is all with analog coming out of the computer's regular speaker jacks. Maybe the tone controls have completely different behavior if you use digital audio input. It would be interesting to hear.

With analog input I have added an inline rotary volume control [[ASIN:B00001P4XH Koss VC20 Volume Control]] for convenience. Check out my review for those.

I just got this delivered earlier today morning via Fedex. Package was in a padded envelope, would've preferred a box. Was replacing a 2.5\\" Toshiba 160GB 5400rpm hard drive in my mid 2009 MacBook Pro 13\\" (with 8gb of RAM). My laptop is only compatible with SATA II (3gbit/s transfer) and not SATA III (6gbit/s) - this SSD drive is SATA III, but is backward compatible with SATA II as well. Installation of the SSD drive was pretty simple, had to remove the bottom lid and four t6 torx screws from the HDD itself. Fired up the laptop and started the install of Mac OS X Leopard. I had to format the SSD drive first, so that Mac OSX would be able to recognize the ssd drive. After OSX was installed, i started to test the speediness. Boot up time from hitting the power on button used to be 53 seconds with the Toshiba HDD and now is 14 seconds flat (SSD) till I see my desktop! I'm real satisfied with the drop in time for a cold boot up. I use my laptop mostly for VMWare and Excel spreadsheet work. A virtualized Windows XP machine now takes about 41 seconds to boot with the SSD, while the Toshiba HDD took about 57 seconds. Opening an Excel spreadsheet for the very first time (after boot up) with the SSD takes about 3.5 seconds, it took about 16 seconds with the Toshiba HDD (after boot up as well) - big jump in speed! I listen to Pandora a lot on Firefox and was hoping that Adobe Flash, which is utilized predominantly by the site, would function better, but alas it does not - still causes occasional stuttering. I suppose an SSD can't alleviate much of that frustration. Firing up Mozilla Firefox 3 is near instantaneous, though it was speedy earlier as well. I did happily notice that when i quit out of Firefox while Pandora is playing, it's instant - used to take ~2 seconds before (annoyed me back then). I'm not seeing too many 'rainbow wheels' so far, but that could be alluded to the clean OSX install - that's normal for all new operating system installs. Since this drive is only 64gb in size, one should get it if they intend to install only their operating system/mission critical applications on it - large videos/music should be kept on either an external USB drive or a regular platter based HDD. I myself still have about 30gbs left after copying my important documents and (1) virtual machine. Prices for SSD drives are still very expensive @ $2.00/gb, whereas a regular HDD is about $0.11/gb as of today. Only four stars due to the high price! Hope this review helped, please feel free to comment with questions.

Fool me once, shame on Asus.  Other than its relatively slow eMMC internal storage specification, the TF700 boasted a pretty spectacular set of specs on paper and was lauded as a groundbreaking design when introduced in mid-2012.  It's a tablet I have used for hours a day since buying late that year.  However, as numerous others have described in support forums and customer reviews:  with ongoing use it has become chronically laggy and slow (far slower than dial-up speed slow); yet under warranty terms, users may not unlock it to install required fixes.  When it takes 19 minutes to navigate four web pages and send an email link from each - an operation that should take 60 seconds in a skilled operator's hands - game is over.  Worse:  Asus stopped issuing needed software updates just one year after release, so buyers are still stuck on Jellybean 4.2.1 as of Dec 2014.  That's disappointing (and probably a little outrageous) for a tablet priced far higher than its competitors and hyped as a premium model at time of sale.  Ironically:  had Asus pushed a Kitkat update (instead of stagnate this model at v4.2.1), it probably would have gone a long way to correct many of the storage inefficiencies that drag this model into the toilet.  Quite a few individual owners have jailbroken their TF700s to force a Kitkat upgrade - and found their nearly-dead TF700s gain remarkable new life.  That manual upgrade, along with a few efficiency utilities, help overcome one of the prominent reasons for TF700's poor performance:  its use of eMMC storage.  (The HowToGeek site provides a smart explanation for how that becomes a performance bottleneck in "eMMC vs. SSD: Not All Solid-State Storage is Equal":  eMMC storage works well for data storage but provides slower access than SSD, so it's better suited for long-term storage than it is for, say, fast reads/writes required by an operating system.)  Another major TF700 performance drag:  bloatware.  I never grasped how significant that can be, till I owned a TF700.  I always thought bloatware meant:  a few extra unwanted apps that the consumer could ignore or uninstall.  But independent developers have identified TF700 bloatware modules which persistently communicate its device status back to Asus (current software version, GPS location, more).  When still supported by publisher, such utilities made some sense (after all, TF700 received a few pushed upgrades during its initial months) but once the publisher abandoned the model, these legacy apps, still aggressively chewing up resources, act more like an anchor.  After unlocking and learning how to use ADB (Android Data Bridge), I removed the associated CMClient, DMClient and Parental Lock - and experienced a remarkable performance gain as a result, in just one of my own experiments with the model.  So the solution is:  buy a replacement (better) tablet, or rescue this expensive model by repairing or replacing its software.  I prefer a repair, rather than tossing away this expensive model.  But applying a replacement custom ROM is skilled IT work requiring a self-study project to safely deploy - and as I learned, the vastly greater operating speed may also come with issues not fully debugged for bluetooth or DRM support:  I temporarily lost bluetooth remote speaker stereo pairing (since fixed) and permanently lost Tivo streaming because the Tivo publisher blocks that app if the tablet has been repaired by consumer (a publisher choice that robs consumers of fair use of an app for which they paid for supportive streaming hardware - poor choice by Tivo, and one that has rankled many owners).  Betrayed - tired of fighting it - and apparently resigned to having to buy a replacement tablet (since even good custom ROMs built by enthusiasts and freely offered, have their bugs that in my own case broke apps I use all the time):  sure, yeah, I concluded:  I'll buy another tablet.  But:  it won't be an Asus tablet.  Not after this experience.  Ironically, Istill have an Asus desktop tower PC and Win 8 laptop, which continue to be well used and I really like - but they're not locked formats, so they will likely have a longer useful life.  I'll simply advise friends:  how can you trust that the next Asus tablet won't be similarly abandoned by its publisher support within just a year?  - P.S. - Since publishing the above, I've gained some industry and market perspective - and found a custom ROM by one of the open source developers that reshaped my TF700 into a (nearly) new tablet, with stable, fast, highly functional performance.  Perspective.  Asus is hardly alone in marketing tablets with short lifecycles and premature planned obsolescence. Product research suggests the tablet category is premised on short useful lives, presumably to goad consumers into replacing their gear with the next model.  Tablet manufacturers should take a lesson from the music industry, which had to reprice and repackage its products when consumers recognized its price gouging for what it was - and simply stopped buying albums, en masse.  We may already be seeing such a reaction with tablet sales; the latest market projections declare a surprise downward trend, and actually attribute the drop to consumers seeking to extend useful lives of their expensive models.  Can't blame consumers - conditioned to buying cheap, powerful desktop PCs:  they compare value, and feel ripped off if a premium priced tablet has a useful life only 1/3 as long as a comparatively cheaper desktop PC, or comparably priced laptop.  My own moment of zen:  thanks to excellent work by some of the android custom ROM developers who publish in forums (though I may not link here, you'll find them):  I'm happily using a zippy fast "Vanir" Kitkat v.4.4.4 custom ROM now on my TF700, and the sole shortcoming is that Tivo app whose publisher won't let it stream to a rooted tablet (but for now, I'll live with that single fail).  We're all learning, as we go.  Looks like I won't be buying a new tablet soon, after all.  But when I do, I'll seek out a Google Nexus: perhaps unique in the category, they tend to receive publisher upgrades well past their first year.  ____  March 2015 update:  I found a great successor tablet.  Now reviewed at product page for:  Dell Venue 8 7000.

I bought the first Kindle on the day it came out. I have moved from one model to the other as they have improved.

All in all, the Kindle DX is the pick of the litter. It is black & white so the battery lasts for a transatlantic flight, or a weekend trip with no problem. It is a reading machine. It does not do movies, e-mail or games. It does not interupt you with facebook messages or software updates. It lets you read your darn book.

The screen is nice. It gives you an acre of text on a page for context. Photos and graphs expand to fill the entire screen making them more legible that they would be in the 'real' print version. It is just the right size to fit in your hand.

I suppose I could do without the keyboard, and maybe a touch-screen would be nice. That said, for the serious academic or or reader, the Kindle DX is the cat's meow.

Despite all the negative reviews (quite a lot, though the number less that positive), I purchased this for 2 reasons: (1) It has back-lit keys and (2) it's part of the Logitech Unifying family (I have 3 mice on 3 computers and they work like a champ).

Reason number 1 (back light) is almost a fail. I'm using this with an HP laptop which also has a back lit kbd. The laptop kbd is like all others: too cramped, too close to the screen. I needed the back light because of where this laptop is stationed in my home. Not really much chance of decent lighting in that corner.

The KB800 has this annoying habit of resetting your back lighting settings on you, whenever it feels like it. I set mine to 10 minute timeout and 50%. Without rhyme or reason, the KB7800 resets itself to 1 minute and %25. The only way to get it back where I want it is to turn off the kbd, open the SetPoint program and reset everything like I want it. Click OK to exit then turn on the kbd. It works great, just like I want it, until it stops working like I want it. This may take 30 minutes, it may take 3 minutes.

I'm always fighting this thing to keep the back light on.

Reading the "support" forum for Logitech and the KB800, I see this is a known problem and has been since 2010. No fixes at all from Logitech. Not even an acknowledgement of the problem. Users trying to help users, no relief in site, and Logitech ignores the issue.

So half of my reasons for choosing THIS kbd are gone. The 2nd reason isn't all that strong of a reason; I can use bluetooth, and probably will. There are other choices out there for back-lit kbds using bluetooth.

I'll stay with it another week to see if I can change my habits and expectations to work with this faulty kbd. If i get the sticking keys issue that so many others complain about, I'll be sending it back to Amazon sooner rather than later.

Cost is also high because you can find less expensive Bluetooth keyboards for iPad like [[ASIN:B0096M8VR2 Anker® T300 Ultra-Slim Mini Bluetooth 3.0 Wireless Keyboard for iPad Air, iPad Mini 2, iPad Mini, iPad 4 / 3 / 2, Galaxy Tab and other Tablets - Black]]

Build quality is decent, but the openings are made to fit only RJ-45 sized keystone jacks. I am building an A/V rack with various connections, RJ-45, coax, HDMI, USB, etc., and only the RJ-45 jack fits in. The product description does not make this clear, plus it specifically describes using coax jacks, which definitely will not fit.

For those wondering, the keystone module specification calls for the face of the inserts to be 14.5mm by 16mm, these openings measure approx. 14.5mm by 12mm.

If you are purchasing this for networking only, then this product will work great. Otherwise, find a different product that will support full-size keystone inserts.

This is basically perfect. It feels exactly like the keyboard on a Thinkpad T-series - I assume that's actually exactly what it is. The only difference is the lack of a trackpad, which in my opinion is an improvement. The trackpoint is perhaps slightly stiffer than I'm used to but that's easily remedied by turning up the mouse acceleration. It's also very light but it doesn't feel fragile at all. I've had absolutely no problem with doubled keystrokes and I type quickly - I think if that was ever a problem then it's been dealt with.

I'm using this keyboard with Xubuntu Linux 13.04. Here's how I get the trackpoint's acceleration up to the speed I prefer:

xinput --set-prop \\"pointer:Lite-On Technology Corp. ThinkPad USB Keyboard with TrackPoint\\" \\"Device Accel Velocity Scaling\\" 15

The mouse settings dialog only goes up to \\"10\\" which isn't quite enough.

Very nice mouse. Lightweight, easy to use. AAA batteries mean lighter weight than AA would. Has a little (removable) pad on the back for the heel of your hand to rest one. It fits my hands just right and my hands are a little larger than normal for women. Really eases wrist strain. To be fair though it does transfer a little strain further up your arm. I simply switch off between it, a regular mouse, and a trackball pistol grip mouse that strains my thumb. That way no one thing takes all the strain all the time. This one is very quick to respond when you pick it up after using another mouse a while. It has a space underneath for the dongle to store when traveling. DPI switch is on top. Scroll wheel also is a button and has horizontal tilt. Lots of large sliding pads underneath so it slides easily on desk or pad. So far the only small complaint is that it is too easy to accidentally hit the back and forward buttons with your thumb. Everything else about this mouse is perfect. The e-reader capabilities are great, the picture is crisp and clear on movies, I've had no problems with apps, and I love that I can watch downloaded movies or Netflix from my Kindle on my TV! The only problem I have with it is a lack of Flash player (that's and Android thing) and that the screen shows fingerprints badly. I feel like I am constantly wiping it off. Also, the internet browser is a bit slow sometimes (and it's not my internet connection, I checked). Overall, this is a great product for reading, listening to music, surfing the web, and watching movies or TV shows.

The last reviwer was very thorough . As stated you need this for the lens or you could buy a generic IR Lamp . I originally was dissapointed but it turned out you must have a absolutely clean windown and camera lens . I would get some lens cloths and newsprint to clean your windows with if going through them . The lens is a 80 degree feild of veiw with the IR lamp set at 70 degrees . It is bright and will work for the  stated distance well . It is rather narrow though it doesnt illuminate the whole field of camera view equal . Basically you get the center coverred and it fades out to the edges . It has 28 LED's . It comes with a 20 foot power cord . It also turns itself on and off as needed . You can sadly see 28 red dots if you look at it but it sits semi hidden if its the only light in that area you cant miss it so you do loose stealth they should of had a one way lens cover . You can easily supplement area lighting with another lamp but you need the lens that comes in this so just buy it unless you have another way to get the lens too . The threads on the lens are very , very fine so be cautious .They say to focus the camera when and where you put the lens in infront of your monitor . I forgot and had to go back and forth it is much more difficult so listen to them . This is a good ..infact IMHO a must have item if you want to catch theives in a area of no lighting it works perfect inside and very good outside for the stated distance subject to narrow beam limitations . God Bless .

The unit works fine and installed easily in a 3.5\\" bay on my desktop computer.  The only downside is that it needs an available USB port to connect to the computer.  The can be on the motherboard (rare) or via a hole in a supplied blanking plate to a port on the rear on the computer.

Yes, this case fits nicely, and I also liked it a lot at first. But I just discovered a very serious and fatal flaw. Specifically, there's a little bit of slop in the front cover (much more than in Apple's front-only cover). So this case's magnets (which also seem to be weaker than Apple's), which tell the iPad that it's covered and to shut off, inevitably move by themselves just enough to turn the iPad back on (especially if it's inside luggage and experiencing turbulence, or any motion, for that matter). As a result, the iPad battery drains and dies in a few hours.

Worse, since this case covers both the front and back of the iPad, it thermally insulates the iPad from the air around it. The air ordinarily naturally cools the iPad when it's on, but this simple process can't occur with this cover on, so the iPad gets very very hot when this happens. Since the iPad 3 has a tendency to run a bit hot in the first place, it gets even hotter in this unnatural configuration. As everyone knows, heat is the enemy of digital electronics, so this case could actually harm the iPad, or at least reduce its lifespan.

This problem needs to be fixed. A stronger spine should do it. In the meantime, this case definitely shouldn't be used for travel.

I was really hoping for a great computer. The Asus Notebook K55VD-DB51 15.6-Inch Laptop seemed to have everything I would want for a few years. I am Still, months later, still trying to keep from throwing this piece of junk across the room or across the street. Where to begin... 1. After hours and hours of adjusting basic \\"default\\" problems and installing my basic Email and social media pages - I found that the 64 bit Windows has a problem with the RAM. I like to use RealPlayer to download a movie on one tab while watching another movie on another tab or window. Well, that's not happening. There is so much ASUS crap and other Pre-installed Stuff that the C drive was showing FULL even though it wasn't. Yet it reacted as if it were full. So the RAM wouldn't handle two movies at once. That was expected in a $150 computer - but not an $800 computer with 8 Gigs sitting there. So after another few hours (now into days) of twisting the computer into a capable machine - it STILL will not handle more than 2 tabs at one time unless I split between Windows and Firefox.
And on and on. This Windows 7, 64 bit is about as sound of a computer as the Yugo was a car. 2. Even the card reader requires twizzers to pull the card out after downloading. 3. The keyboard is completely Open - allowing the slightest dust under the keys. I haven't seen such Crappy construction since I had Windows ME. 4. The keyboard is flimsy - needing a solid punch to make the key actually strike/count. 5. The plug for the Internet connection is weak and often Disconnects if the computer is moved. This is a problem I now find was a problem Asus has had for quite a while. 6. There is WAY too advertising about their Extra Features that, once you turn the damn thing on - COSTS Extra after their 2 or 3 weeks of Trial. And if you Keep all those Special Extra Features - figure spending another $175 Plus.
I don't mind having to Uninstall their pre-programmed Extras. It's having to search for all the loops all of those Extras have intertwined with other software that takes hours and hours to search for, and Re-Install drivers, update all the new downloads, etc., etc.
This computer was the worst purchase I have ever had from Amazon. And I know it had nothing whatsoever to do with Amazon and would never hold them responsible for this. \\"Buyer Beware\\" is the name of This Computer.

I've had a few other bluetooth keyboards for my iPad mini but this has become my favorite. This is because of two main features:
1) It attaches to the iPad mini with a magnetic hinge much like the Apple smart cover
2) It has a small built-in stand that hold the iPad mini in both portrait and landscape modes (though landscape seems a bit more stable)

Otherwise it functions like any other bluetooth keyboard. Pairing was easy (it has a dedicated \\"Pair\\" key at the top right of the keyboard). Keys are small but this is to be expected on a keyboard this size. Also, per Belkin, it has \\"Function-specific keys for copying and pasting text, moderating volume and controlling music.\\" They worked as advertised for me.

All these features makes this keyboard a good option for a student taking notes in class or a worker doing the same in a meeting. When finished, you just attached your iPad to the keyboard with the magnetic hinge and it doubles as a cover (aluminum, like that back of the iPad) for the iPad's screen. Pretty cool--aesthetically it matches the iPad mini quite well. That said, it should not replace a proper protective case--it would afford little protection to either the mini or the keyboard itself if dropped.

I was led to believe (by a review or two) that this product was necessary for the task of replacing the hard drive of an older Macbook ('06-'07) with a solid state drive (SSD). It is not, which is great since I could return the product and get my money back (less shipping). So the star-rating here is neutral, and does not have a bearing on the quality of the product itself. I don't have any input for a Unibody Macbook, because mine is the previous-generation Macbook.

In general though, I can say that for anyone with a 6 year-old Macbook needing more drive space, or simply wanting a little faster computer (quicker boot-up times, less wait for web page loading, etc), replacing your HDD with a SSD is a great step to take. All you'll need is a SATA-to-USB cable, your new SSD and a tutorial on how to clone your drive. There are dozens of articles on the web from reliable outlets on how to do this. It takes about 10 minutes to follow the steps and then a few hours to copy the entire drive. You won't be sorry you did it!

I preordered two 7\\" devices as birthday presents for my kids. In Amazon's words they sounded fantastic - powerful, rugged, with a worry-free 2 year warranty and all kid-friendly content you can wish for! The reality was far from what they described.    First, the good things:    - The devices are good quality, and so are the cases  - The setup was pretty straightforward  - Adding your Kindle content to kids' profiles was simple, both on the device and through amazon.com interface    The bad:    - Adding anything other than Kindle content is pretty much impossible  - Overdrive library app is not considered educational  - All freetime content is dumped in three jumbo lists (book, apps, videos) with no way to filter or sort them  - Freetime content is generally unimpressive  - No apparent way for kids to access their email or record notes  - The device cannot connect to secure networks  - No camera app (I'd add this to the \\"ugly\\" list, but with very limited amount of memory on the device it's kind of a blessing in disguise)    The ugly:    - About 3.5 gigabytes of usable space, so no movies and no music for your road trips  - No way to clean up kid's content from the parent's profile  - It is *super easy* to cheat on the reading requirement: open a book, flip through a few pages, put the device down. In about 10 minutes when it will go to sleep pick it up and check the remaining reading time - it will decrease by those 10 minutes. Rinse and repeat until the games are unlocked (don't tell this to the kids!)    Sadly, all indicates that Amazon both cut the corners on the hardware (3.5 gigabytes, really?!) and then rushed this product to the market before the holiday season with lousy, bare bones software. The last part can be fixed in the subsequent updates, but the first one will plague this device until the next hardware revision :-((    Right now I'm planning to return our Kindles as soon as my kids (inevitably) start complaining about constantly running out of memory, and replace them with some other Android tablets.    *** Update ***    And just as anticipated the first of my kids to receive his gift already ran out of memory. Of course I found out about it right after buying Minecraft app, when it refused to install. I could not clean up kid's stuff from my parental account (good decision, Amazon!), so I had to hunt for downloaded items in the unsorted mess of the kid's account. After I went through every single item twice, there are still about 2GB that are unaccounted for, leaving about 800MB of usable space for everything from now on. Wow... I expected the memory becoming an issue, but not as bad as this and not fast as this! These devices are heading back to the mothership first thing over the coming weekend :-(((    *** Update #2 ***    One thing Amazon does perfect is handling returns. I shipped both devices back and they initiated return as soon as UPS code was in the system. A couple days later I got my money back and ordered two ASUS Nexus 7 (2013) tablets. Between Netflix and YouTube movies, and Kindle and Overdrive books kids will have enough content.    A final note: one of other reviewers mentioned this quote from Bezos: \\"8GB is dead on arrival. We're starting Kindle HD at 16GB\\". This was said full two years before Amazon rolled out this disaster of a product, so, I guess, they don't really take to the heart what their fearless leader says. Perhaps they should, next time.

If you are buying a pair of speakers for a desktop computer, or that will be sitting in one place all the time, don't waste your money on these. You can get better for only a little bit more. HOWEVER, if you are buying these for a laptop/netbook, they are worth it! The reason I bought these speakers was because my netbook's speakers are very soft (as would be expected from a netbook). What's nice about these speakers is that they are powered off of the USB port on my netbook so that I can carry them wherever I want and not have to worry about plugging them into a wall outlet.   That being said, these are great sounding speakers if you take them for what they are. They are 1.2 watts total... i.e. very weak speakers. However, I would never have guessed that. They have great highs, very good mids, and the bass is adequate for small, portable speakers without a subwoofer. They were worth the money I paid for them (albeit, I paid less than what they are right now).  P.S. I listen to a few different types of music. They include acoustic/piano (Sara Bareilles, Ingrid Michaelson, Jason Mraz and that type), dubstep/house/electronic/dance, instrumental only music. and all of it sounds good on these speakers (the electronic type music definitely sounds better with a subwoofer, especially dubstep. but these speakers still do fine with it).

I was wary considering one of the previous reviewers, but thought I should take a chance since this one of the only screen protectors for the Tegra Note 7. I opened the box and, lo and behold, the solution bottle was empty. Given it's packaging and the fact that the box was still intact, there is no way the bottle leaked so it had to be empty to begin with. I'm not sure how that happens, but that is righteously not cool.

For kicks, and in dire need of a screen protector, I had some Zagg solution lying around and got the protector installed. I've installed quite a few so I did the dance of making sure my hands were clean and that the screen was spotless using the included micro fibre. It was definitely harder to install than ones I've done in the past (on phones and tablets).

All-in-all I do not like the way it looks on the Tegra. I could probably blame some of the quality on my method of install (using Zagg solution), but with the screen off the protector lays flat with few visible impurities. When turning the device on however, the blur and distortion of the protector is horrendous. Prior to installing it I had no problem reading text, post installation I have to hold the tablet a lot closer just to read text I was previously able to from my lap.

I would not recommend, especially since I'm the second person (at least as far as reviewers go) to receive a box with no solution.

Worth noting is that the laptop compartment has one zipper. The larger compartment (for books or other storage) has two zippers, and so there's more chance of leaking if the two zippers meet in the middle (or top of the bag.)
Otherwise, this bag is great, have received compliments on it. It is professional enough to carry in the workplace, it is very comfortable and does not feel heavy with a laptop, three medium binders, and assorted pens. The front pocket comfortably holds a wireless mouse and smaller items, such as headphones or tissues. The penholder inside the bag is very flat, so it is unobtrusive if not in use.

Purchased two, these now have 40Gb IDE drives, network is Windows 2000. These work fine, and are reasonably fast. Contrary to other reviews these load automatically on reboot for me, and must be disabled if you do not want this feature. In other words if \\"unmounted\\" at end of session these do not appear on explorer after reboot, and must be \\"mounted\\" to see them again. If the PC is turned off with the drives left \\"mounted\\" they reappear automatically after reboot. Both drives work together, show as two drive letters. No special formatting required, boxes accepted drives as-is (FAT32).   Also contrary to reviews these boxes can be opened for drive swap. There are two holes in the sides to slide case open. It is not easy, but doable.  Trials with a Hitachi SATA II 2Tb drive and an adapter backboard failed, Ximedia software recognized box but said no drive present.

I received this stylus as a gift for my Acer Eee Pad Transformer, primarily so that I could draw and take notes on the table. The length of the stylus is what recommended it to me: I want a stylus that I can hold in my hand like a pen. I used the OTHER kind of stylus -- the short, rubber-tipped kind -- when I had an iPad and I never could get used to the feel of the thing while drawing. The Jot Pro definitely has a nicer feel and weight to it.

The stylus works well against a bare screen -- it glides smoothly and precisely across the screen -- but after I installed my Zagg screen protector, the plastic disc at the tip would catch and stutter. There's too much friction between the screen protector and the disc! After considering the problem for a while, though, I stumbled on a low-tech solution to the problem: I took a small square of Scotch tape (the standard opaque kind, not the satin or high-gloss kind) and stuck it to the bottom side of the tip. Voila! The stylus glides right across the screen protector, just as smoothly as it did before. I finally have a stylus that I can use to draw on my tablet!

My only concern now is the twist-off cap, which can be something of a nuisance if you're in a hurry to jot down a quick note. However, since I'm using the stylus primarily for longer drawing sessions, it isn't a huge issue. I would definitely recommend this stylus to others as the best available.

PROS:
- Decent length and good weight; it's almost like holding a pen in your hand.
- Precise: unlike the shorter, rubber-tipped styli, the narrow tip on the Jot Pro makes it easy to see just where you're laying down those lines; important for detailed artwork

CONS:
- Doesn't work well with Zagg screen protectors, unless you have Scotch tape handy
- The twist-off cap doesn't make for convenient note-taking
