I think most people will use this fan for radiators.  The amount of air it sucks into the case across the radiator fins is insane.  It typically runs at about 20% and doesn't go above 30% while converting video files AND playing Crysis (AMD 1090t).  It is also reasonably quiet at 20% and I like knowing that I can bump it up if I ever decide to go up over 4ghz (or more).      It is loud at full power but if you didn't know that before buying it then you should stick your tongue between the fan blades while it is spinning at 100%.

I ordered this keyboard case last week and received it yesterday and I have to say that it was exactly as described.  So this keyboard case is a clamshell keyboard case which kind of makes the iPad mold into a sort of netbook design.  Inside the package: You get the keyboard case which is assembled as a single piece so there is no fixing or assembling required. You also get a charging cable which is a mini USB cable the sort you would charge android smartphones with which is to recharge the keyboard. The case mentions that the battery should last through 500 recharge cycles which in my estimate of using wireless iPad keyboard should exceed the life of the iPad itself because the battery on these keyboards last almost a month. You also get some literature describing how to connect/ pair the keyboard with the iPad. Also included are some promotional materials about the manufacturer.  Unboxing and pairing: The unboxing is pretty standard, like I mentioned no parts need assembly so its quite simple. The keyboard case comes with battery charge included, I'm not sure how much charge it already held but it did last me through more than an hour of typing until now and it still has charge in it. Pairing the iPad and the keyboard is pretty easy. Go to settings - Bluetooth on your ipad and after you turn it on you should be able to see the keyboard as 'Bluetooth keyboard' ready for pairing. If it doesn't appear press the pair button on the keyboard and voila! Its connected !  Build: As far as the build quality and such goes the whole case is pretty well built. I do have to confess that I don't do a lot of work on my ipad, its mostly used to watch videos or browse the internet, but this case has been wonderful even for that because of the multiple available viewing angles. There are two slots/stoppers to place the ipad in and there is an extendable neck in the back which would help adjust the viewing angle. The results is that there is an amazingly large number of configurations that you can place the iPad in for optimal viewing which in itself makes this case really nice.  All in all, its well worth the price and well built and I highly recommend it as a first case or even as a spare case for those who already have some sort of iPad case.

I thought I'd been sent the wrong product.      The case is too big to fit the Kindle 3 properly.  It fits the length fine, but the width is too big about an inch, allowing the Kindle to slide back and forth in the case.  That's sloppy.    The quality of the materials and construction is fine.  When the case is open, the zipper teeth are well away from the edge of the opening, and are smooth, so there's no risk of scratching your Kindle 3.  And the opening is big, so it's easy to get your Kindle in and out.      But I'm disappointed that a case advertised for the Kindle 3 wasn't made to fit the Kindle 3 correctly.  Why not?    I wonder if the dimensions of this case allows Gizmo Dorks to sell it for more than one product?    It makes no sense to include a carabiner with this case.  There's no place where it would attach, so what's the point?      Why Gizmo Dorks include it is a mystery.  Gizmo?  Not really.  Dorks?  Well . . .     James

This enclosure is completely \\"Meh\\". Nothing even remotely interesting about it. Aluminum body with plastic endcaps. The soldering on the small PCB inside is acceptable. There is one \\"gotcha\\" with this unit, however:

The \\"Features\\" listed on the back of the box states \\"Internal Power Supply Eliminates Bulky Adapters\\". At the same time, the same side of the box states that the contents contain \\"Power Adapter and Power Cable\\".

Just so you're clear, this unit DOES require the use of a \\"Bulky Adapter\\", to the tune of 12V at 2A, so don't be mislead (it does come with the required BULKY adapter that it says it eliminates). The USB 3.0 chip used inside the enclosure is an ASMedia ASM1051, which has the following specs (no extra charge for the Engrish which was copied directly from their site):

ASM1051 is the single chip solution to bridge both SuperSpeed USB (USB3.0) and High Speed USB (USB2.0) to Serial ATA. It is highly integrated with ASMedia SuperSpeed USB3.0, High Speed USB2.0 and SATA1.5/3.0/6.0 Gbps self-design PHYs. With ASM1051E customers can easily enhaced their storage device performace since this product integrated CPU and embedded RAM to provide a leading edge solution in USB to SATA device enclosure market.
- Features
* Compliant with USB3.0 Specification Revision 1.0
* Compliant with USB Specification Revision 2.0
* Support USB Super-Speed, High-Speed and Full-Speed Operation
* Bus bandwidth of USB up to 5Gbps
* Support USB Mass Storage Class, Bulk-Only Transport Specification Revision 1.3
* Compliance with Serial ATA Specification Revision 2.6
* Bus bandwidth of Serial ATA up to 6Gbps
* Support ATA/ATAPI Packet Command Set
* Support ATA/ATAPI LBA48 addressing mode
* Support 20MHz External Crystal
* Support I2C NVRAM for Vender Specific VID/PID of USB Device Controller
* Support SPI NVRAM for Vender Specific Application of USB Device Controller
* Support up to multi-GPIO pins
* Integrated 3.3V to 1.2V Voltage Regulator
* HBM ESD 2.5KV
- Package Type
* Green Package QFN 48L (Pb-free)

There are better USB 3.0 bridges for $50.00.RAM for Vender Specific Application of USB Device Controller * Support up to multi-GPIO pins * Integrated 3.3V to 1.2V Voltage Regulator * HBM ESD 2.5KV - Package Type * Green Package QFN 48L (Pb-free) There are better USB 3.0 bridges for $50.00.

I have been using Logitech products for quite a number of years now and have yet to be in the least dissatisfied with any item. This mouse, the Logitech M305 Wireless Mouse is no different. It does precisely the job I paid for it.
This is a workhorse. There is nothing particular fancy about it; it simply works the way it is suppose to work, and works well.

The design fits my hand perfectly and is quite comfortable. The plug-in nano-receiver is quite small. I use this particular mouse on my lap top; the one I travel with and do my work on the job with. The nano-receiver is plugged into the SBU port (I am currently using a Dell Inspiration which is several years old) and that is where it stays. I need not worry about removing it constantly. As the receiver is quite small, there is little to no chance of it being broken or accidently chipped off despite the fact that my lap top takes quite a beating.

This mouse uses a single AA Battery. I have been using this since last December 2009 pretty constantly and have had only one need for a battery change. I always carry a couple of extra AA Batteries with me as I despise using the computers touch pad for the type of work I do.

The scroll function works quite well but if you are looking for the superfast scroll feature you need to look at another model. I personally don't need or want that particular feature. I have tried using this mouse on just about every surface you can imagine from desk top, to my leg, to the floor and everything between. It always works and works smoothly

Please do take note. This is not a high tech mouse of the sort a serious gamer would be happy with. I handle the ones my grandsons have on their computers and they are in a world of their own with adjustable weight, high speed this and that's and to be quite frank, I am sort of afraid to touch the things for fear of having my hand either being evaporated or transported into another dimension. No, this is a work horse of a mouse with limited features; which is precisely what I needed and wanted.

Set up was absolutely nothing. No programs were needed, not down loads were needed. You just plug in the little bitty chip thing and you are ready to go.

The price here is quite easy on the pocket, something I loved about it, and you actually get quite a bit for your money, something which is becoming quite rare now days.

I have absolutely nothing to complain about in reference to this product.

Don Blankenship

I installed this drive in my heavily-exercised Mac Mini -- a development system generally running MySQL server, a Ruby/Rails development environment, numerous terminal windows, a Windows virtual machine, major audio and video processing and so forth in 8GB RAM. A principal reason I use the Mini for this work is it is so quiet; and the Seagate Momentus upheld this standard. You don't hear it.

I've used this drive for a month now, and am really impressed. Many generic operations are much faster, and my bootup duration dropped to 17 seconds. I just participated in a professional video project, and one of the co-workers was using a brand new Mini with 16 Gb RAM and solid state drives. He said his bootup times were just \\"boom.\\" I said, \\"What's boom? How many seconds?\\"

So we rebooted his system, counting the seconds for startup and it was a dead tie.

That means a lot of bang for the buck from the XT 750. At present prices, I don't think you can beat this drive.

This router was a great purchase.  I have owned a Virgin Mobile Broadband USB card for over a year, and wanted to be able to share it over WiFi.  As stated in its description, this router worked right away with the modem, and I took it to Florida for vacation with my family.  It was great to be able to share the connection.  The only problem was that we get very poor cell coverage where we stay, around 1 out of 5 bars, so the battery didn't last very long.  The modem would get hot after 20-30 minutes of usage, but I understand none of this was the fault of the router.  It's great to show this to my friend, who constantly brags about his new Verizon hotspot that came with a 2-year, $60 per month plan for 5gb of data.  I have unlimited data for $40 only on months that I need it.  I will also be using this device as a car router since I have a touchscreen computer mounted in my car and a Napster subscription, so the passengers can select and listen to anything they want.  I highly recommend this product.

It's a great thin case. Nicely design. However, the edge doesn't hold. Both edge broke on mine by volume control and speaker after a few months owning it. Customer service told me there is no warranty beyond 30 days to cover crack or broken. For $30+, this is not worth spending.

Hello all, I purchased a Kindle Fire 2 weeks ago, after weeks of research comparing it to other tablets around (especially the Nook tablet). And I must say, after going through all the reviews on Amazon that say not to buy the Fire, I found them all to be totally incorrect.

One of the repeating \\"cons\\" that I saw, was that the power button was on the bottom, making it very easy to accidentally turn off. I've never had this problem. I read, watch movies/tv shows, play games, write emails, go on Facebook, all the time on my Kindle, and I think you'd have to try REALLY hard to \\"accidentally turn it off\\".

The next thing I saw was the Fire has a lack of privacy, with everything you just watched showing up on the Carousel. Well guess what, if you hold your finger down on any icon on your main menu/Carousel, there's an option to remove it from the Carousel. So there.

Various reviews complained about the browser being slow.. but I say unless you're some computer geek with a really souped-up computer system, it's not slow at all. It's incredibly easy to type on the keyboard function, and web pages load pretty quickly. It's super easy to sync all your email accounts to the Kindle Fire, and the notifications let you know when you have new messages.

I haven't been able to put my Fire down since I got it, I love everything about it, and encourage people to take poor reviews with a grain of salt, because most of them are misinformed or biased!
love it very durable works very well on keeping tablet protected.  i would deffinatly say it's a great buy! my daughter loves it too

I cannot urge you enough to look elsewhere for an external HD. These products are GARBAGE.     I bought this along with my new iPod (ironically because I have a smaller 120GB external from these guys that has been everything I could ask of it), intending to store my iTunes files on here, rather than using up all that space on my laptop's HD. So... I get the drive, burn about 250-300 cds onto the drive.... and it craps out. Data gone. Oh man, I was livid.     Seagate replaced the drive, which is fine, but they only replace broken drives with refurbs... so, you replace your broken drive with one that was ALREADY BROKEN. Why this didn't occur to me at the time, I don't know. And guess what they charge to recover data from broken drives? $50? $200? No!!! FOURTEEN HUNDRED DOLLARS!!! $1,400!!!! No joke. I've bought cars for less.    Anyway, I get the replacement drive, and this one lasts all the way through all _520 CDs_ I own. FIVE HUNDRED TWENTY CDS. I get them all stored on the drive, and I'm making a playlist up right before I move the songs all to my iPod...    ...and the new drive craps out.    Seriously. I wish this was a joke.     I don't know yet if the data is all gone this time, but I have had enough. If I get my music files off this heap by some miracle, I'm taking this drive out in my yard and I'm going to go \\"Office Space\\" on it. And then I'm going to take the little bits, and set them on fire. I got the iPod in March, and I have yet to listen to one lousy song on it. And it's all because of Seagate. Their products are garbage and I will NEVER buy ANYTHING from these guys again.

I broke my other APU on my OEM Asus desktop because when I went to examine the heat-sink, honestly? The APU was stuck to it and had to be removed with pliers. In the end, I broke some pins and had to replace it. Funfact: This is the ONLY brand-new FM1 socket-based processor that I could find on the Internet. However, that is not a bad thing. Looking at the pricing history for this APU, it really hasn't devalued in price whatsoever, so it shows that AMD still relies on this APU for their customers and while do like the idea of "saving money" (it may be listed at the "original price" of $150, but it was basically still the $100 price tag it already had since its release in 2012), regardless of the business' policy of the pricing, this APU is worh every penny I paid for it.

Yes, its an older processor with only four cores (compared to my even OLDER AM3+ FX-8320, which has 8 cores), but just like my FX-Processor for my other desktop, this has the ability to be overlocked. I personally find this a nice option to have, especially when I'm on a deadline and I need to render a video for work. However, I won't be pushing the processor too much. With that being said, even with 4 GB of RAM (soon to be upgraded to of 8 GB Ballistix Tactical Series Memory w/ a GeForce GTX 750Ti), it really does add a bit more kick to my OEM's overall performance.

I was told not to purchase this processing chip because it would be cheaper to buy a whole new computer than upgrade an old one (I beg to differ for me personally), but I am happy to say that I am not regretting that decision of this purchase.
Works great for its intended use

This device is great, it does everything I expect it to do. I'm a college student, and purchased this device mainly for notes taking in class. I did NOT purchase it to replace a proper laptop/desktop, and did not expect any high performance out of this device. Yes it will run autocad, inventor, photoshop, but you are way better off with a proper computer(unless your computer is ancient).

From my 2 weeks of using this device, I found that the main bottleneck of this tablet's performance is still the CPU. Yes the new atom Z3740 increased performance dramatically compared to the last version, but it is by no means FAST. I found it constantly turbo boosting to 1.8Ghz, and running at ~30-40% usage when playing a simple youtube video.
I was amazed at the optimization of windows 8, initially I was very worried that the 2GB of RAM will simply not cut it, as I have 16GB in my desktop and 8GB in my laptop, and I'm constantly using up 4-5GB of the RAM when not doing much. But windows 8.1 amazed me, the RAM usage stayed at 0.9GB while idling, and I have never seen it above 1.7GB other than when I was installing new software or opening multiple applications. And even then the tablet does not feel "laggy", if there are any, it's from the CPU, which you will be finding is running at 100% usage. The RAM optimization is definitely better than windows 7, and miles ahead of XP and vista if anyone still uses those legacy OS...
The internal storage is small, but I have about 32GB ish left after I installed my software that I will be using on this machine, which is not much. It is not fast, it is not a SSD, it's the same storage device found inside your typical tablet and smartphone. The read speed is fairly normal compared to a 7200rpm HDD, the write speed is extremely low. But you probably won't be installing stuff all day on this tablet so I don't think that will be too big of an issue. Looks like I will not be putting in a microSD, as the space left is more than enough to store my pdf, ppt, excel, and word documents, but you do have the choice of adding another 64GB.
I got about 5 days on a single charge of mainly standby, with occasional screen on time, at the end of the 5th day, i was at 27% charge. When I tried to use it for real, I got nearly 16 hours of battery life for word processing, this was way better than what I hoped. For mixed usage, Asus's estimate is about right, I got about 10-11 hours, and for watching video file with an external HDD connected, I got about 6 hours. This definitely gets the same if not more battery life than my Asus Tf300 which runs android 4.2.1., and yet this one runs a full blown x86 system. Intel's new atom bay-trail CPU might not be a performer, but the power draw is just amazingly low.
Never tried to play games on it, and is not planning to do so, as this is not supposed to be used as a computer replacement anyway, just a way more useful tablet/notebook than ipad or android tablets at a fraction of the cost. I paid $379+tax for my device, and I think the current amazon price by sellers are just too high.

Haven't seen any quality issues with my unit, some earlier batches may have issues. But if yours is manufactured in the later half of Dec 2013, you should be good.
I can see how keyboard could be an issue for people who have large hands, or fingers rather, my hand size is considered average in males, and I do not find it very hard to get used to typing on it. In fact I typed this review on this device.
My main complaints about this device is the very small right shift key..I keep hitting the up arrow when I want to hit the right shift key, for quotation marks, question marks etc.. they could've made the arrow key more compact and made the shift bigger.
Also the keyboard and touchpad makes a lot of noise compared to my laptop. The touchpad mouse keys are especially bad, I try to avoid using the keys unless I have to right click something...but you can always use your fingers. Won't reduce a star because of it, simply because of the price point, if this was a more premium device, it would be a different story. There is also no backlit for the keyboard, but I don't look at the keyboard when I'm typing anyway, plus at sub$400 what can you expect?

If you are an elderly person, or one with very bad eyesights, the fonts/icons/menus WILL BE SMALL. The DPI is pretty high on this tablet. So be aware of that before you purchase. It's not an issue if you use metro apps, but will be an issue if you want to work in desktop mode. I found the size to be fine for me, as I like smaller fonts/icons anyway to allow me to see more, when I showed it to my mother however, she claimed that it's "tiny" and it make her eyes hurt. The font sizes can be adjusted in the settings in windows 8 based on your preference, but even then she still says it's small for viewing in desktop mode.

People have complained how difficult it is to install.

Here's some advice from someone who has installed 2 of them on the ipad, and on several phones.

Once everything is clean, empty 3/4 of the bottle of spray on your ipad screen, put the rest on the shield.

You won't be using the spray again, so use all of it.

By lubricating the ipad screen, it's easy to slide the shield around to get it in the correct position.

[[VIDEOID:d7277d6fd92f0537556c94f8a2e2ba00]] The Aukey® SuperSpeed Aluminum Dual Bay USB 3.0 Enclosure was sent to me (free of charge) so that I could provide an unbiased and an honest review.

The housing is brushed aluminum and solidly built. The doors snap in and secure the drives perfectly. The lights will indicate if one drive is not seated correctly. The doors also lock with a small key. The fan will help with thermals on the drives. The USB 3 root cable is plenty long and was ideal for me to put it in a rear port on my desktop. The power cable is a brick and those cables are plenty long as well.

The power button being placed where it is a HUGE plus for me, in that I can turn the box off and turn the drives off when I want to. That saves electricity as well as extending the life of the drives.

I bought  a sister version of this computer, the DV6-33010us.  You can see my review under that model.  However, since that was my third lemon from HP in five years, I have since done more research and I suggest that anyone who plans to buy a HP do their own research.  Look at the reviews for any three HP models.  What you are likely to find is that a significant minority of buyers have had major problems with their purchases. For a more comprehensive analysis look at SquareTrade, the company that provides warranties for Amazon.  It rates HP  last in reliability for the eight major brands it rates.  HP computers have a 25 percent failure rate within three years, worse than Dell, Acer and Gateway. (ASUS and Toshiba have the best ratings)  No major company should allow a such failure rate on their products. As consumers we should insist they do better before we buy their products.

I replaced a flaky Belkin 7-port hub with this Plugable based largely on the positive Amazon reviews. I agree -- this is sturdy, easy to read (with the LEDs) and provides ample power to some demanding peripherals (3A is pretty beefy for a USB hub power adapter; the largest I've ever seen on a hub was 4A). I use multiple USB condenser microphones for podcasting (a Blue Yeti Pro and a Blue Snowball) through this hub into a MacBook Pro, and whereas my previous hub would often freak out/make terrible noises/disconnect the mics at random, this one has been rock solid for several weeks and multiple shows now. As my other machines' older hubs die, this is the one I'll be buying to replace them.

My wife started listening to spotify around the house on her smartphone and netbook. The music was tinny and sounded like a 1960s transistor radio. While the reviews were a bit mixed, I went with the Logitech Bluetooth Audio Adapter to let her push her music to our speakers. So far it has worked much better than I expected. The sound is a little muddy/muted compared to music connected directly through the speakers but it is certainly much better than the smartphone (Galaxy S Blaze) and netbook (Asus PCee) speakers.

I figured it would stream perfectly near the speakers and in direct line of sight, but I've been able to walk just about all over our first floor (a good 30-40 feet) with intervening walls (but with open hallways around) and the music played just fine. It did help to reboot her smartphone as that cleaned up some initial choppiness that occurred when we first tried it out.

I downloaded the HP driver another reviewer recommended (google sp44774.exe) and the driver installed OK on the Asus windows 7 netbook. I also installed a small application on the netbook called switcher (there are others google windows audio switcher) that let her *easily* switch the audio output from the netbook speakers to the bluetooth adapter and back with two clicks.

Now I'm tempted to get a few more of these and connect them to anything with a speaker so everyone can use existing speakers around the house to play music from their phones/laptops. This helped make my existing livingroom Panasonic stereo system, bought in 1989, useful again by playing music from more sources.

Update:

Playback was fairly muddy, to the point I decided maybe I should try wifi/dlna. Checking my connections I had attached the adapter to the phono input of my stereo amp. I changed it over to the aux/video input instead and the sound cleaned up completely. I do recall something about phono inputs sometimes having extra circuitry just for record players and so that might have been it. It is almost crystal clear now.It is almost crystal clear now.

I picked up this monitor to use for my home office, as I'm getting older squinting to read my laptop screen has become more and more of an issue. I can already feel the difference in my eyes at the end of the day. Setup was quick and easy, I took it right out of the box, hooked it up and hit the Auto Adjust button and voila! I was ready to go.    For just a hair over $100, this monitor was a great upgrade at a great price. It is not a huge monitor, so if you're looking for that \\"big screen\\" experience in this monitor I would not recommend it. But if you need something light, thin, bright and clear then this is the monitor for you! Could not recommend it more highly!

The title says most of it. I bought two of these almost two years ago, one for work and one for home. I primarily used them to connect a keyboard and mouse to a Lenovo Laptop. From day one I had problems with the hub seemingly going dead - the key board or mouse would just quit in mid-click. We had 6 of these Lenovos at work, and our, since we build USB devices we quickly discovered the Lenovos were slightly off the USB spec in several ways. This made me cut the hub some slack, even though my USB devices did work better when attached directly to the Lenovo.   A few weeks ago the Lenovo died and I replaced it with an Asus. To my annoyance, both my hubs still go dead. I'm off to the store now to try some other brand.  Except for the dying thing these hubs are not bad. The purple light is pretty with the silver finish, and the price was OK. The Power brick is quite weak - trying to charge my phone takes 3x longer on the hub than with the phone's charger. I would not try to run a USB hard drive through this hub.   I'm giving it 3 stars instead of 1 or 2 because both hubs are still (almost) working after 2 years. That's better than a lot of cheap electronics these days.

I really enjoy using my new Kindle Touch and now understand why so many avid readers are buying kindles.  The Kindle touch downloads books quickly and the response time for new menus and pages is great.  It is also is very user friendly, setting up an account to purchase books so easy and registering the kindle was simple. There are so many free books and excellent novels under $1.00.  However I wonder if I bought the right Kindle for me.  1st complaint is that I can't read in bed (no backlight)  2nd complaint is that I bought the Kindle with the Offers and Sponsored Screensavers and find that kind of annoying.  I haven't decided if it is worth putting up with the annoyance as it is $30 cheaper than a Kindle touch without the offers.  I understand that I can opt out of the Screensavers and that Amazon will kindly charge me $30 dollars.  3rd complaint is that the text to speech feature is poor as the computer generated voice frequently mispronounces words and doesn't seem to know much about punctuation.  My final complaint is about the audio books.  They are very expensive and do not allow you to follow along with the story as it is being read.  So yes I like the Kindle, but there are many improvements that can be made.

This solid state drive does exactly what it is advertised as: Provide blazing fast speeds when used on a 6GB/s SATA connector. It's the fastest drive I've ever owned and I don't think I will ever be able to go back to traditional harddrive as my boot drive.   Physical installation was painless and easy, as expected from a modern drive of this form factor.  I use this drive as primary boot drive that holds my operating system (Windows 7/64bit) along with a select games and software such as Visual Studio and the performance improvement is very very noticeable. The most noticeable benefit so far has been moving my  Star Wars: The Old Republic Beta installation to this drive. The results have been nothing short of amazing, with load times for changing planets as well as the occasional texture pop all but disappearing.   There's however a regrettable flaw with this drive:  Out of the box and even after updating it's firmware, my computer would hang and shortly thereafter crash about once per day, always during a write operation to the drive. The computer's BIOS would forget it's bootorder afterwards and require manual configuration to resurrect. Data was lost and corrupted during these crashes.  This is a serious issue and a bit of sleuthing on the internet confirms that it is relatively widespread. OCZ has not been forthcoming with support or even acknowledged the presence of the problem. While the presence of such a critical flaw should cause the product to be rated 1/5, the fact that I was able to find a solution for the problem (a registry modification to change certain settings for intel based storage controllers usually found in sandy-bridge mainboards) leads me to a 4/5 rating. The dramatically improved responsiveness of my computer alone makes me forgive and forget the significant time and headache this bug caused me until I found the solution.

I got this netbook back in july, wanted to give it some time before writing a review on the item. So, here goes...  After opening the box and charging the 1005hab for the specified time in the manual,I was finally ready to fire it up. 1st, the case is a magnet for fingerprints, but overall fit and finish seems nice. Startup and seting up the netbook for first use was very easy, no more than 20 minutes and I was already connected to my network in my home. Wireless is great,built in n speeds was nice for a $300 netbook, My router is in my basement and I can get 75% strength on the 1st floor at the other end of the house, 2nd floor has ok signal so overall very good. The touch pad for me is not the greatest, just trying to move the pointer around with it sometimes goes into a scrolling effect rather than the mouse moving, and the left anf right buttons don't always seem to register every click. Got a bluetooth mouse and solved those issues. Keyboard took a little getting used to due to the size, also the size of the screen makes viewing some documents and web pages tough, I have to be wearing my glasses to see the screen clearly, i use a 22\\" monitor on my home computer so i can get away with no glasses with that, not the netbook though. But then if I wanted something that was big and easy to read, i would have bought a full size laptop. Hard drive storage is good at 140ish GB free out of the box. Lets talk battery... where did they get 4+ hours of life from this thing? I haven't timed it out to see for sure but it's more like 2-3 hours depending on what your doing with it. it may stretch out to 3.5 before shutting down from low power but i just charge it before that anyway. Students couldn't get through a school day on a single charge. The processor power is good for what it is. I use it for mostly internet and I design and maintain a few websites with macromedia software, so its great to bring with me when going to meet up with people to talk sites. Fits inside my motorcycle side case with ease. I also bought a 2GB memory chip but saw very little diffence with it. If your running that many memory hogging programs that you really need to upgrade the netbook, you probably should have bought a fullsize laptop with a faster processor. changing the chip was very easy though, 1 screw and a little cover on the bottom comes right off.  Overall if you want a compact, easy to use computer to take with you for email, word documents and some picture editing software, or just to browse the internet, I'd say this is for you, if your going to be editing video or mutlitasking larger programs, you might want to think laptop

Have used this case many, many times. Simple, inoffensive appearance. Compact size for its features.

Pros:
high build quality
swing-out 3-slot (1 slot tooless, 2 slots screwed) 3.5\\" internal HDD cage - very nice
2x front-panel floppy/etc. slots (3.5\\")
3x front-panel optical/etc. slots (5.25\\")
nice power indicator light in ring around power switch
includes reset switch, which many cases omit now
easy to work in, well laid-out

Cons:
comes with 350W power supply; would rather be able to save those $$$ and buy my own
not all HDD/ODD slots are tooless

InWin makes some great cases, and this is a very nice combination of quality, cost, appearance and function. The only things I'd really like to see are the ability to purchase it without a power supply, all slots being tooless, and having the swing-out HDD cage support 4 HDDs instead of 3, but that's the trade-off for a fairly compact case with all the other features. You can always stick the 4th HDD in one of the other front-panel slots, since they'll hardly ever all get used for the front.

Bottom line: buy this case. You'll like it.

I've been using this product for about 30 days now, and overall I'm pretty satisfied with it. I would echo what other reviewers have said regarding the quality of this product - overall, for the price it does a very good job of recording high-quality video, and I see little to no delay on real-time HDMI on the TV. The software is simple to use, although for my purposes a bit TOO simple, as it is basically a trim and capture software, although if you have another video editor suite this is of little concern (I use Premier) and it is very reliable.

However, this comes with one caveat: IF the device that is powering the HDMI is disconnected or the USB is disconnected during capture, any previous video that was recorded is lost and as far as I know there is no way to recover. I had this occur when my cat rubbed against the front of my 360 slim (due to the touch button, it powered down) I had approximately four hours of video at that time that I was recording through. When it was off I noticed I couldn't hit stop on the recording, and once I powered it back on it allowed me to hit stop, however when I looked at the video it was just the 9 second clip from it powering on. Prior to powering it back on I noticed I had approximately 300 GB free on my HDD, upon powering on and stopping the recording it instantly went to 320 GB free.

So not only did it not record the previous video in transcoding it, but it also automatically deleted the raw file so I had no way of getting it back. This would not be that big of a deal even if it wasn't transcoded (if it at least left the raw file so I could attempt to salvage any video that was in there) but it is a fairly major flaw for an otherwise great product. I have no idea why it would delete the raw file, this doesn't seem necessary at all, and to me seems like a pretty major issue with the software. I could also not find this information listed in any documentation elsewhere regarding this product. In the futureI'll know if something similar happens to go in and relocate the raw video file so the software cannot delete it after I stop the recording, but its unfortunate to lose such a big chunk of recordings, especially if there is a lot of unique captures that are nearly impossible to reproduce on it.

As everyone says the dock is absolute junk. Given that work bought Lenovo E530 laptops, this was my only option to use dual monitors. When you have a traditional dock, all your accessories are connected to the dock and you simply attach the laptop to the dock and hit the power button on the dock and your running. No need to get out your laptops travel power adapter. Not so with the USB3.0 based docks. The USB3.0 docks require you to plug in the USB cord, get out your travel laptop adapter, plug it into the wall and your laptop, physically open your laptop to turn it on, turn on the USB3.0 dock and wait for it to boot up before you can see anything on the monitors. Then when you try to use the computer the mouse performance is jumpy. Forget plugging the mouse directly into the computer, that doesn't fix the problem. I absolutely HATE this dock and I didn't even have to pay for it. I forgot to mention traditional docks will actually charge your laptop. The only way to charge or operate your laptop is to plug in your travel adapter.

I bought this computer as a floor model from Best Buy almost 6 months ago for $459 and I have to say I've got no major complaints. I primarily bought this for web browsing, Microsoft Office, editing photos in Picasa and my iTunes library. I have had 30 windows open, run iTunes in the background and was typing a document and it could handle it all without lag. I have even run Adobe Photoshop CS3 and it does alright as long as the projects aren't too complicated. I did try the photomerge function (in Photoshop CS3) with 20 photos and then the program finally choked. All in all, if you're looking for web browsing, streaming netflix, a computer for your iTunes library and some basic photo editing with Picasa then this is a pretty darn good computer for the value. I wouldn't recommend it for gaming or graphics work. Also, the speakers are pretty quiet so you'll definitely need to invest in some speakers. I picked up a pair of compact USB Insignia speakers so I can travel with them and they work a charm! I would definitely recommend this computer to someone.

There was a certain retailer who was selling this eMachines laptop for just under $300, and at that price, this laptop is an excellent deal.  Much above that price and you should probably look elsewhere.    As others have said, the display is excellent - very bright.  The keyboard is OK - not great, a bit \\"spongy\\" but not bad.  The speakers are awful, perhaps the worst I've ever heard; attaching a pair of cheap USB-powered speakers makes a big difference when you use it at home.    The CPU is a standard 2.2GHZ Pentium (Dual Core) T4400, which is a sweet budget CPU (a budget version of the now-being-phased-out Core 2 Duo CPU).  It's actually quite a fast CPU for basic stuff. The thing DOES NOT get hot (compare that to the AMD-based laptops) beyond a little warm on the bottom.      The two biggest downsides (beyond the speakers): only two USB ports and no webcam (even the Acer version of this laptop that has a webcam curiously has no built-in microphone).  So as I said, for the price I paid, I can put up with it.    One little annoyance I've noticed lately:  The touchpad is a bit wider than I'm used to, and I seem to rub the left side of the touchpad with my left hand too often, causing the mouse pointer to jump.  This seems like a curious design feature of this particular model; when typing on other 15.6\\" laptops of this same era, I don't have this problem.    RAM is DDR3 despite what official specs say.  Easy to upgrade.  The wireless card is easy to upgrade as well - you can upgrade it to an Intel 5100 \\"Draft-N\\" card that is an excellent wireless card for $10-$15 on ebay, very worth doing. You can use either a half-height or full-height mini-PCI wireless card in the slot, I've used both.  SATA hard drive is easy to swap as well - I've already done that.    You can run XP on this thing too if you really want to - but you must first upgrade the BIOS to at least 3.06 (so you have to boot up Windows 7 for that most likely).  Then you have to set the BIOS SATA option to\\"IDE\\" not \\"AHCI\\" and then XP can boot easily (you'll need drivers from Acer on the Emachines support page for this laptop).  I did have trouble with Acer's supplied XP driver for the included Broadcom wireless card - it froze the laptop every time I enabled the card, but as I have since replaced the Broadcom card with an Intel card, I have no problems with wireless in either Windows 7 or XP.

If you use parental controls be careful not to use anything but characters in the descriptions.  For example, don't add \\"Joe's iPhone\\" or \\"Sally's laptop\\".  You must OMIT the apostrophe (Joes iPhone) or it will lock out the parental controls tab! This is a good speaker, BUT it is NOT a 180 Dollar speaker.

I have bought and tried probably 20-25 different Bluetooth speakers of varying price ranges. This HP Roar does not do anything or sound any better than some of the speakers I have which were in the 50 -75 dollar price range. I am still confused as to why this speaker has such a high pricetag. I read the manual over and over hoping to read about some feature that I overlooked, but no such luck.

The product description states that the triangular shape is a unique design, but that's not really true since a lot of speakers have this same shape, as well as the silicone controls on the end.

This speaker is not full stereo either. You need 2 for full stereo sound. The bass is not very powerful at all. It does sound clear otherwise and not tinny (until you turn it up and and have the distortion ).

At higher volumes, this speaker starts to sound pretty bad with crackling and distortion. I am not talking about max volume either. I am just talking about turning it up not even half way. The louder you have the volume on your phone, the more crackling and distortion through the speaker as well.

It is a nice size and feels solid. It has rubber strips on the bottom to prevent it from slipping or sliding. It pairs quickly and easily. I am not really impressed with the sound though, especially for the price. At the 50 dollar or so range is where it belongs. I would give it more stars if it had a lower price. It just seems way too out of range for the quality and performance.

This will be a running review. The short version so far is that it does what it is supposed to and is accurate enough. Updates to come but so far this seems to be a solid product that measures accurately down to 10ma and up to 2A for Ipad charging.

I purchased this drive to store my music exclusively and use my Mac Mini to transfer the data to our Sony streaming divice via wireless router. I followed some online advice and attempted to download the latest firmware from Seagate only to find that no new firmware was available, as of my writing this review.  Furthermore, I've noticed that the drive is not always fully accessible in my Mac's Finder.  I'll be doing my research and replacing this with a better drive, probably Western Digital.  Note: I have a WD drive hooked up to the Mini for the Time Machine backup and it works flawlessly and NO chirping!  I only bought the Seagate over WD due to it being the available drive meeting my basic requirements at my local Best Buy at the time.  I'll be ordering a WD (or something else, perhaps) this time, and through Amazon.

I bought this tablet a year ago (2011). I shopped around and looked at all the stats; speeds, weight, memory, etc, etc, and I finally settled on the Acer A500, and I haven't regretted it. I am SO glad I got this. I got the 16g and bought the 16g sd card to go with it. It has not let me down. It may not be as fast as the Ipad or a few of the other tablets out there, but, it's functional, durable, speed is acceptable, ease of use is outstanding. Both cameras work very well, and I haven't had any problems with the wi-fi usage. The battery can last me a whole day, sometimes, it charges very quickly, and streaming Netflix is not a problem as long as there's a good signal. I really liked the USB and SD card ports. Downloading was a breeze, but, you will have to get a file manager app to move your media from the internal drive to the SD card/flash dive and vice versa.
On the downside, it is a bit heavier than the other tablets. It's also a bit thicker...not as slender as the Ipad, so, there's some weight. also, there aren't too many protective covers or accessories out there for it (or there weren't when I first got it). I started experiencing problems with the picture turning off, then quickly coming back on, but, I DO lend the tablet to my teenage son, whom I'm sure have have dropped it a few times (and the 1 or 2 times I've done that as well), so I attribute that to my clumsiness, not to a bad product.
Overall, I'm very happy with the Acer A500. And because of this tablet, I'm looking for an Acer Laptop as well. I rated this 4 stars. I would of given it 5, but, deducted the 1 star because of weight. But, it IS a good investment, in my opinion.

I rarely write reviews about products and I particularly dislike writing bad reviews and therefore try to avoid products with bad ratings. Avoiding products with bad ratings has worked well for me in the past, but this router was an exception to the rule. I bought it because it had decent reviews and was independently ranked well by PC magazine etc.

However, in my 20 years of experience dealing with many networking products at home, IT industry, and at the University where I teach and manage networks, this router is definitely the worst networking product I have come across. Here are few of the issues (and upgrading firmware does not help):

1. The first and foremost the router does not streamline connections to the internet via a broadband cable modem. It took odd combinations of power cycling and cable-modem resets to get it to finally connect. Note that I was using static IP and consequently even DHCP negotiations etc. don't apply and my observations suggest a basic protocol implementation errors in the router as 3 other routers work just fine without any issues. So connecting to the internet is an issue -- so what else is the router going to be god for?

2. The wireless access point did not correctly start-up. The configuration and setup is sufficiently cumbersome and non-intuitive. Nevertheless persevering with it was futile and the wireless when it turned on was fleeting and flaky at best.

3. To top it all, the overall user experience for this router is terribly slow. Just accessing the built-in introductory page takes a solid 15-20 seconds. When each mouse click takes 15-20 seconds, in today's world that is practically eternity. This product claims to have a 1 MHz processor and it does not add up at all given that the system was responding as if it was running on a 1Khz processor. I have need better results from a 133 MHz Pentium II

4. The form factor of this router is ungainly, big, and does not fit into networking enclosures.

5. Not that you would be dealing with the setup and UI often, but the few times you have to deal with it, it is rather painful. It almost feels like the different parts were thrown in in an haphazard manner without streamlining the system as a whole.

Overall I discourage users from investing into this router.networking enclosures.

Overall I discourage users from investing into this router.

Basically, as has been noted in the other two reviews already up, this is a flash drive that essentially performs the same function as any other flash drive: at heart a memory device. So, if used as what it's advertised for, it's a form of backup.

At fifty bucks for 8 gigs of memory (the capacity of the unit I tested), it's really, really pricey. You can get a SanDisk 8 gig memory card right here on Amazon for about 4 bucks. This is over ten times more expensive.

I can't figure out anything it can do that you can't do on any other memory card. It is, of course, much more robust than a memory card, so you do get physical protection of your data.

At 8 gigs (or even 16) you're not going to be able to store a huge number of pictures, or especially home movies, on it.

The advertised longevity of the stored data is 100+ years. I have no idea how long data will remain uncorrupted on a memory card. A long time, I suspect, if it's not being accessed and altered.

If you're looking for secure backup, external hard drives are waaaaaaay less expensive per gig of RAM.

I'm really puzzled as to what market niche SanDisk is trying to access with this device.

I WANTED to LOVE the Kindle Paperwhite, but it falls just a tad short for me. And I blame Apple for that. I've been reading books through the Kindle app on my iPad for about a year now and I do love that. I think it has spoiled me.

I bought the Kindle Paperwhite for a few reasons:
1. the iPad can be heavy; the Kindle, of course is very light weight, especially in comparison
2. I wanted something I would be more comfortable taking on public transit when I just want to read (the Kindle will be less attractive to thieves - I THINK, plus it's very portable and can fit nicely in my purse)
3. I wanted to be able to "borrow" books from Amazon via the Kindle; the app doesn't allow for that.

So in regard to all those reasons I bought the Paperwhite, I believe I got what I was looking for.

But... I just find the device itself is a tad too small for me to hold it comfortably. I could probably fix that with a case, but then it wouldn't fit so easily in my purse...

Mainly, though, it comes down to functionality. I find the Paperwhite a bit awkward and clumsy; the touch screen seems kind of clunky and slow. I have seen the Kindle Fire (first generation) in action. It's quite nice to navigate. I borrowed a first generation Kindle to read a book on. It was okay, not great. I was hoping the Paperwhite would be closer to the Fire in operation (because of the touch screen) than to the original reader. It's not.

I'm not sorry I bought it and I will definitely use it, but I'm not in love with it as so many other people seem to be. It will serve its purpose, but next time I might just spring for a small Kindle Fire.

We have had this wireless router for over a year when suddenly it started dropping the connection.  After reading the reviews here I figure it was going bad.  However, I noticed a distinct pattern as to when the router was dropping the connection.  It only happened in the evenings when my husband was home. (He travels and when he was gone for a week no problem.)  Then I realized this started happening when he got his new PDA which connects to our wireless router.  When he brought the PDA home and it was off there was no problems.  The same problem occurs when he brings his work laptop home.  The problem does not occur when he connects to the wireless router but as soon as he disconnects either the PDA or work laptop then I can not connect with our home laptop computer.  To correct the situation I have to unplug and replug the router in.  We have the mac addresses for the PDA and his work computer configured in the wireless router and the problem continued.  After turning the broadcast off the problem has stopped occuring when he uses his PDA or work laptop. While the router still drops connections occasionally it is not as bad as it use to be.  I would say it drops about once every 2-3 weeks and there is no pattern now. Sometimes it occurs during the day and sometimes at night.  Hope this helps someone who may be having the same problem.  Maybe we can figure out a way to correct this.

I have a previous gen 802.11n Airport Express that I really like due to its form factor. This Netgear router follows a similar design cue (complete with foldable power plug). This Netgear is more boxy than the rounded Airport Express. Also, the picture with the hand holding it made it look smaller than it actually is.

First, some advantages over the Airport Express. This Netgear can be powered via USB, which can be convenient during travel. Also, it has two ethernet ports (vs only one on the previous gen Airport Express), and the WAN ethernet port can become a LAN port, depending on the setup. iOS app is decent, and has a great feature in monitoring bandwidth usage. Really flexible setup, and can be used to share an existing wireless connection to wireless.

Minuses: it supports only 2.4GHz 802.11n. No 5GHz. No gigabit ethernet. Power slider is tiny can can be switched accidentally. Also, I find that the unit can get confused if I switch from wired to wireless mode (and vice versa) without turning it off first (the Airport Express doesn't even have a power switch). I am used to the Apple Airport Express setup, thus setting up this Netgear via a browser is really confusing at first. Device can be unstable at times. Connectivity is usually great, but there are random times where my wifi devices suddenly can't recognize the router momentarily.

I think Apple's Airport Express is still the gold standard, but it is unfortunate that Apple decided to go with a different design on the latest one. This Netgear is great for traveling and in a pinch, but I would not rely on it as a main full time router. I would get at least a dual-band router for home use.

I have a Lenovo T60 running XP since around 2006, and it's been about a month since I received this battery. Like everyone who's gone through this, my original battery was great, but died and I didn't feel like paying $120 for a new battery for my backup to my backup PC...so I decided to try Anker. As per Amazon standards, it arrived on time in perfect condition. I was pretty surprised it had a 76% charge, but I'm getting ahead of myself. Different batteries (depending on capacitor and other factors) have different best practices, so I always like to follow manufacturer instructions for charges. This time was no different and I followed them to a T. When I finally booted up, I was again surprised - I don't even remember my original Lenovo battery holding a charge the way the Anker does. Btw, I keep the auto-dim feature on but other settings remain the same in full feature mode. I went through some basic tests that my backup PC does: you know, surfing youtube while watching TV, playing music while vacuuming for a couple hours, the usual. All did great and battery was/is out-STAN-ding at holding it's charge in performance and standby.

Here's the down side, and it's pretty fundamental and significant: if you move your laptop the wrong way, the connection of the PC to the battery is lost. Yep, you know what that means. In fact, last night I was using it for about 2 hours streaming...no problem...I put the laptop back in its spot and plugged it in. No problems. Closed the top. Still no problems. Went to open the top this morning and junst (jeunst...sp?) it in I guess what was the wrong way aaand...all systems down. Booted up once opened and it was fine, but the charge was only at 58%, so it must have died somewhere last night...not really sure what's up with that.

So what have I learned? You get what you pay for? Ehhh...nah, it's still a good product. The shame is the true fit design. It's a backup.... I'm ok with having to leave the top up, or at least not fully closed...maybe take some extra precautions when doing certain things. I don't do much development or create any new files on this PC without sending to a neutral zone, but I don't think I'll ever get rid of my XP. You understand. Would I purchase again? - yes. Would I recommend to someone else who didn't have 5 PCs? - no.

I bought this monitor because I already had an existing SyncMaster 191t and the Samsung Sales Support person told me this was the comparable unit.  I was setting up a dual monitor situation in my office and wanted a monitor that closely matched my existing monitor as much as possible.  While the size and shape lined up nicely, the coloring was off enough to be noticeable.  The colors on the SyncMaster 191T were richer and more vibrant.  While I played with the colors on the new SyncMaster B1940 I just could not get them to be the same.  Both monitors are useable but there are times when I really do notice the difference.  My advice is to buy two of the same monitors at the same time for a dual monitor set up to ensure minimal differences.

I'm still a believer in POTS (Plain Old Telephone System), but needed a dirt-cheap way to make long-distance calls and receive other calls, so I decided to try Ooma for my 2nd line after reading lots of reviews, and it didn't dissapoint.    I hooked up it's \\"modem\\" jack into my router, as opposed to directly into the DSL/cable modem as they want you to.  I set it up with a static IP and told the router the Ooma Hub is in a DMZ, just to ensure it can do whatever it needs without firewall configurations, though it did seem to boot up fine without it.    I hooked up its \\"phone\\" jack into my home wiring as line 2, and have 2 dual-line phones from which line 2 on each uses the Ooma.    Call clarity has been great, and it works as a nice answering machine.  It hasn't noticeably affected my network during a call, doing simple web browsing and e-mail. I would expect if I were watching Netflix during a call to have some issues, but have not tested that.    So, I'm a satisfied customer, using an Ooma Hub in a non-standard configuration.

I've been using this device for a few days now. I like it a lot. I do have some disappointments, however:

1- I would have paid 50-75% more if the casing had been aluminum, or something heavy to give it some weight. It does feel plastic-y and cheap.

3- I use a Microsoft Natural Keyboard. It works, however, the CTRL key doesn't seem to work with my iPad, which I suspect has more to do with the iOS than it does this device. When I'm writing, I use CTRL+Backspace, and CTRL+Arrow Keys to skip past words, or highlight entire lines of text. I'm having to change my typing habits to get the most out of this.

Let me first say that I've never been disappointed by a piece of Logitech equipment which makes this M705 a first.

I've seen a number of reviews mention odd tracking behavior on the mouse. I noticed these as soon as I used the mouse for the first time and checked for obstructions on the sensor, tried different surfaces, tweaked software settings, and since it was used on a laptop the mouse was inches away from the USB dongle eliminating any possible signal issues.

I eventually discovered why the mouse was acting so weird, a design flaw that I can't do anything about. Unlike nearly every mouse you've used over the years where the sensor is in the very center of the mouse, the M705 sensor is placed on the far right edge of the mouse, near where your pinky finger rests. The result is that many slight mouse and wrist rotations that other mouses would not act on are instead exaggerated as mouse movement.

Any mouse movement you make with your wrist that rotates the mouse even a little will result in different behavior than what you're used to, especially in horizontal and slightly angled lines. Even habits you may have picked up such as slightly lifting the mouse to the side to reposition it on your desk will work differently. No amount of tweaks will fix this, you will need to re-learn your mouse behaviors or this mouse will always feel strange.

Otherwise, this mouse is well built and feels solid but this is the only Logitech product I've ever regretted purchasing and I can't recommend it.

Just because it is big doesn't mean that the tip of the stylus is any less accurate than the tip of a traditional thin stylus. And no problem when I drop this stylus - this aluminum is tough.

When working with the stylus in my hand, it is solid and feels great in my hands. It is not too heavy, just heavy enough to know I'm firmly holding it while working with my device.

The rubber tip is very accurate. For example, I can easily slide tiles on and off the board in Words With Friends. There is no dragging feel to this stylus tip - it doesn't drag at all across my screen - it is very smooth. It does feel \\"smooth as silk.\\"

My drawer is filled with old, traditional thin stylus because I prefer this big stylus over all the rest.

If you don't mind the size of this stylus, then you will get an excellent stylus.

The Buffalo clear screen protector kit for the Kindle Fire HDX 7 is a joke to get installed on the face of the tablet.  To start with the instructions are in Chinese  with one simple set on the back of the folder in English.  Once you can get figured out which side goes where, then the "fun" begins.  Getting the air bubbles out --according to the instruction sheet-- is simply gently pushing the air bubble towards the side of the tablet.  Uh huh, sure, right.  That would be fine if there weren't so many bubbles and if the plastic surface of the screen protector didn't fit so closely against the tablet frame that there is no escape for the bubbles.  It was an hour-long horror to get the protector on to the machine.  I do not recommend it to anyone and will no doubt replace it with a more friendly item as soon as I can find one. This is a high-quality cover - and at this price point, it's a solid value.  As noted by another reviewer, upon unpackaging (and for a few days thereafter) this item, it presents a rather pungent chemical smell - likely due to the softeners used in manufacturing of the faux-leather that this protective cover sports (similar to what causes \\"new car\\" smell... only this odor is more reminiscent of turpentine).  Regardless, this drawback is tolerable, as it subsides in a few days - and the overall look is rather nice.  So overall, this is a great accessory... BUT PLEASE NOTE:  The corner of the flap inside of the cover (not entirely sure what the flap's intended purpose is) creates a minor protrusion in the center of that surface, such that if you close the cover, it will make contact with the center of the Kindle Touch's screen... and will inadvertently trigger whatever action is currently presented on the display at that time.  As a result, I have made two accidental purchases of Kindle books; the \\"Buy this Book Now\\" option/button is EXACTLY aligned with where this flap contacts the screen.  If you have a book sample on your home screen, and close your Kindle Touch without turning it off (something I no longer do), that very \\"buy\\" menu is immediately pulled up... and if you so much as graze the cover after closing it (easy to do if you're stowing your Kindle Touch in a bag, etc.), the flap will go ahead purchase that particular book for you.  Not ideal - but neither is the fact that you can't deactivate 1-Click purchasing on any Kindle device - but I digress...  Of course, there are obvious work-arounds in avoiding this (placing book samples into \\"collections\\" folders, making sure to turn off the Kindle Touch before closing the cover, or even cut off the flap entirely), but I'm currently out $50 for a couple of days until Amazon gets around to refunding these accidental purchases.  I'm guessing this inside flap is present on other MoKo covers/accessories as well - sojust be aware that under the right conditions, this odd/unnecessary feature can cause users some unexpected inconvenience.

This 4TB portable hard disc drive from Seagate is super fast and completely USB powered so you're not tethered to a power supply! USB 3.0 is part of why this drive is a speed demon, but it is also backwards compatible with USB 2.0 ports (although you won't see the 3.0 speeds.)

Another big reason this drive is so speedy is that it is really two 2.5\\" Samsung 2TB SATA drives that are in a RAID-0 configuration. RAID stands for Redundant Array of Inexpensive (Independent) Disks. There are several RAID levels, which refers to how the data is distributed between the drives. This is RAID-0, which is optimized for speed with no mirroring or parity (no redundancy.)

So what does that mean to the user? It means you will get very fast data transfer speeds but if either of the drives should fail, you will lose all of your data since data is written simultaneously onto both of the drives. So does that mean RAID-0 is bad? Nope. It just means that this should not be your primary back up drive and that data written to this drive should be backed up regularly to guard against data loss in the even of a drive failure.

The drive itself is surprisingly small and without the need for an a/c power adapter, it's highly portable. The top of the drive is a matte finish aluminum and the sides and base are a matte finish plastic. It ships with two USB cables. One is a Y cable for laptops and computers that can't power the drive via one USB port so you can plug it into two USB ports.

It comes with Seagate Dashboard software pre-installed on the drive, but can use your preferred back up software instead. I like the Seagate back up software fine but I'm not especially enamored with the social media applications.

So I've loaded mine with movies and family videos (that are all safely backed up) we can watch on the television and it works great for that. I was very gratified to see how quickly I was able to write all that data but I did notice this drive got very hot during the process. You won't want this thing sitting in your lap while it's working. ;-)

The drive is really, really quiet and I had to glance at the slow blinking white LED on top several times to reassure myself it was still busily writing.

As a side note, it is interesting to me that the 2TB drives inside can be installed in a PlayStation 4 gaming console to double the storage. Of course, it would void the 3YR. Seagate warranty but if you're even moderately comfortable installing a HDD, you could upgrade your PS4 and your laptop storage with the two drives within.is drive got very hot during the process. I give this product one star, not because it is a defective product, but because the online product information falsely implies that the system will perform other than it actually will.
BEWARE: For this powerline adaptor to function, the router and the receiving station (be it computer, Blu Ray player, gaming console, etc.) MUST be on exactly the same circuit breaker. If they are NOT on the same circuit, there will be NO signal, and hence, no extended internet access.
I did not discover this until I could not get my system to operate. I then contacted NETGEAR. They told me exactly what I have outlined here.
So be advised: It is not necessarily true that you can simply plug one adaptor into your router in your family room, and have it connect via another adaptor to your computer in the attic, or the basement, or wherever else you might wish to have an increased signal. The electronics MUST be on a common circuit.

I bought a POS laptop from Circuit City for college.  It had severe overheating problems and Circuit City wanted to take 30% of the purchase price as a restocking fee, which I couldn't afford.  So I kept the awful bottom of the line (Averatec brand) laptop.  (Never heard of it?  Didn't think so.  There's a reason.)    I purchased the Targus branded cooler after my Antec one died... it is of slightly better quality than the Antec, though not by much.  (I waited until after the Antec died because the Targus branded cooler was more expensive).    Amazon has a great price on both the Antec and the Targus, $12.  When I needed the cooler (in college, usually on an emergency basis), I had to rush out to Best Buy and sink $25-30 for the Antec or $40-50 for the Targus.  So you can see why $12 is a bargain to me.    The Antec and the Targus both have a life expectancy of one year (in my experience... if you get a dud, it can be less...)  FYI Targus has a good warranty and will be helpful in making an exchange of your dud for a working cooler.    If you've already sunk your money in a craptascular laptop, then a cooler might be a good idea.  If you haven't purchased your laptop yet, you might consider buying a laptop without an overheating problem.  Or at least don't buy your laptop from Circuit City.

I bought this router through my ISP since I figured they'd have great knowledge on the best routers to use since they're in the biz. Boy was I wrong. I have had nothing but problems with this thing since the day I brought it home. It drops the signal constantly when connecting to it. And that's standing 4-5 feet from it! And when I say constantly, I mean that every 15 minutes to 1 hour at the most it drops the signal and I have to repair the connection. Every day it does this! And before I get nasty comments - yes I've updated the firmware, yes I've tried changing the channel to other channels and yes I've tried moving the router to other spots. It gets terrible range too. I've even added their antenna's [[ASIN:B001QFY2X4 ZyXEL ANT1106 802.11b/g/n Omni-Directional High-Gain Antenna]] in the hopes that it would boost signal output. I also went so far as to buy the Zyxel WAP3205 [[ASIN:B002LITI7K ZyXEL WAP3205 Wireless N access point, Ethernet client, and universal repeater]] for repeating. So, while I now have greater range I now have two devices that repeatedly drop the signal. Nothing helps. I've given this thing every possible upgrade/tweak I could find and I've had it! I'm getting myself either the new Trendnet TEW292GR when it comes out in April or the new Linksys E4200.

Overall, I got this kindle on sale for $60 off during Prime day. It was the only thing I wanted on prime day. It is still all the limitations of an amazon tablet vs a regular tablet -- including the REALLY annoying aspect of going through the internet to use youtube when obviously an app would be a lot easier and less temper-tantrum-throwing on amazon's part. It also feels a bit cheap--plastic-y and a bit of bulk and girth for being so hollow seeming inside. It has some bugs--it tends to freeze up quickly, and it tends to get really confused during high-demand apps like netflix and I've had to power it down and restart it a couple times already because of this issue. I have to completely get out of the program before turning the screen off to fix this.

But for $100, it has a lot of memory and space, it saved the day when I needed something else with internet access when the wireless card on my laptop went out, and I use amazon frequently since I have prime so I have access to the shows, and the music, and all of that jazz. I also like having it small enough to shove in my purse or bag to take with me. I do want a bigger tablet eventually, but this is perfect for pulling up a recipe I need to cook with from online, or plugging into the stereo to play music while I do things around the house. It's a great little tablet, if you can get over the amazon-only limitations. A lot of people can't, which is understandable.... but hey, I have a smart phone, and a laptop, and between those two things I can deal with it. Also it DOES support netflix, which is the other really big thing I use it for.

Having prime? I think for $100 this tablet is worth it. I would NOT have paid $159 for this tablet, but I thought the $100 price tag was fair.

The Macbook Pro is the premier choice for college students. First off, I would say that 75-85% of the Mac's on my campus are Pro's, rather than the Air version.

Why?
Weight isn't as big of an issue as they make it out to be.

Performance is much much better on the Pro, especially if you install an SSD on it. (150$ish)

The Bad
I would rate the mac as a 4 star simply because not all the software I need is available to Mac's. Purchasing Parellels to run Windows fixes the problem, but that's just another added cost to the already high price. Also, it is a pain to sync up a Droid phone because Mountain Lion isn't compatible with the Droid software yet.

The Good
The good news is the resale value is so high. You can spend $1,300 on a mac, and 3 years later still get 700+. A windows version will set you back $800 or so, and constantly have to be updated, and the value after 3 years will be 300$ if your lucky. This means a great deal to me as a college student, because I want something that will last a few years, but one that will also have a high resale value. Apple software in general is much easier to use than Windows also, so it is more user friendly.

All in all, I highly recommend Mac's to college students. (Especially to Graphic design/Communications majors)

I have had this slate for 3 weeks now, and am still learning how to use it. All the YouTube videos make it look very easy, but this is a tricky machine to master.
First, it is useful to note that the tablet comes with a leather case that holds the stylus in the hinge. It would be great if the case had a fold to prop it up. Any other case that I have found that fits this tablet does not have a place to store the stylus.
I really bought this slate to take to meetings to take notes in Microsoft Onenote. I want it to work with handwriting with the stylus. It works very well to just write the notes on the slate. The small tip stylus is just like writing with a pen. Ink to text works reasonably well, but it is very far from perfect.
Drawing is much more difficult. I am a contractor, and I hoped that sketching would be easier and more flexible.
The stylus affects the screen by just hovering, so you can suddenly find yourself typing endless aaaaaaaa (I found a setting to change that), or closing a window, or opening another program.
Panning and zooming with fingers is not near as smooth as some android tablets I have seen. They say that in automatic mode that you can just tap twice with your finger, and then it will recognize fingers for pan and zoom, but the truth is that this is sporadic at best. There are supposed to be \\"flicks\\" that you can be program to do whatever you want, but getting that to work is a large challenge too.
It did lock up on me once, and it wanted to restore to an earlier restore point. I could not find how to manipulate the options when the computer was in it's pre-windows state. Luckily, I had a wireless mouse and I was able to plug the receiver into the USB slot. That solved that problem, but I could not find a way to do a hard reboot.

Ultimately, you might want to install Windows 8, but the natural screen resolution is too small to run most of the apps that come with W8.
All in all, I would say that they did not quite get the software right for my intended use. I still believe that with practice, I will get better at using it, but it is not as easy as HP would like you to believe.

1. Two-day shipping to them = 5-10 days
2. It seems like the Chinese company WASD Keyboards have no quality control and uses a THIRD PARTY shipping delivery system
3. Package arrived, and though the envelope was perfectly sealed, the inside plastic rap was not, and the item was missing.
a. If the item was taken at port, then the envelope would of came with a notice from the port that it was seized, the item did not have a notice.
b. The envelope has no signs of seal or reseal, thus I conclude that the item must of been taken out (stolen) before it was sent out.
c. I don't think any manufacturing company would be sending empty envelopes, so the item was probably there.

Other possibility: Often companies in the US that sells the product, are products that are produced, assembled and shipping in another country (usually China or Taiwan). Sometimes a new product would be shipped in bulk, (which is why two day shipping or even one day shipping doesn't mean anything here), which means they won't ship your product until they meet a certain # of sells. This would mean that the bulk is shipped to the US, and then there must be a separate packaging. So somewhere along that line, someone stole the product.

I have ordered a new one from WASD, and though Amazon claimed it 1 day shipping for me, as they do when an item goes missing, the expected date is 5 days from now. I am just glad I didn't buy my mechanical keyboard from them.
One arrived broken and since we were leaving the country the next day,  we had no time to deal with it. You get what you pay for.  I wish I had spent more.

I am writing this review here because I can't write it where I purchased it. I bought this item from Best Buy.com and the product is no longer on their website. I was so excited to get this tablet when I looked at it online. I looked perfect for what I wanted. I have an iPad 2 which I absulutely love, however I wanted a smaller tablet for better portability. The price was great and for what I need the 8GB storage was fine. Has a sd card slot so that seemed great too. Kickstand seemed like a nice extra feature. Has a lot of great features that others mentioned in their reviews and that other 7 inch tablets on the market don't have. As I said really excited to get this tablet. It came in two days and that is where my troubles started. I plugged it in to charge and waited for the light to start blinking like the quick start guide said. After 14 hours it never happened. So I figured that the tablet must be charged by now and turned it on. It came up on a screen which I now know to be the lock screen. After many frustrating minutes I finally figured out how to get past that screen. It took me to the home page. It never went into a setup walk thru so I could put my wifi network into it. I found that walk thru finally and forced it to run where I configured the settings. So after much frustration I tried to register the product thru their app as was stated in the quick start guide. It would never connect to their servers. I tried to update the firmware thinking that was it. Again no luck. Wouldn't connect. I tried the browser and again nothing. No web pages would load. Tried to connect to the android market and create a new account. Nothing. After 3 days of trying everything I could think of to get this tablet working I contacted tech support. I received an email stating that I would be contacted in 2 business days. That's been 5 business days ago and still no response. I found this tablet to be EXTREMELY slow when even trying to load web pages before telling me that the page didn't exist. Also the battery didn't seem to hold a charge for very long as another reviewer stated. In summary I have a paperweight that is going to be returned to Best Buy. I will never buy an Archos again. Looking at either a Samsung or Toshiba.

I was looking for a simple case for my new iPad to protect it from scratches and stand it up when I wanted to type or watch video. This was perfect for me because it is simplistic and has a cute design that has gotten me multiple compliments. The part of the case that snaps onto the iPad feels a little bit foam-like because of the printing, but it is sturdy and stays on the iPad tight. The feature that puts the iPad to sleep when you close the case has worked just fine for me--no issues, and I generally carry the iPad in my backpack with textbooks around campus. The iPad does tend to fall out of the lowest slot for the stand, but I haven't had any problems with the two slots closest to the iPad.
