The label on this products says it have 12v1, v2,v3,v4... +12v6, this is not true, all 12v+ are taken from a single +12v, this power supply uses PS223 to control protection, it only supports vs1 and vs2, I buy this on 2013 to have it for posible replacement, today at only 2 month of use, this thing starts to drop the 5v+ rail to 4,27v causing an unstable state of my computer, if you all ready have one use a multimeter, you will notice the bad regulation it has, it is variable voltage drop, 1 minute to 10 min and then it drops voltage, my computer is: gigabyte z77-ud5h, i72600k, 16gb, ssd and Nvidia gtx 650ti boost, 650W required this PSu was supposed to deliver 1000W it not true , in this PSU +12v1 and +12v2 are mixed in one and only +12v ... Because it passed 2 years i can not turne back for replacement, When you test it out of the box (no motherboard) with multimeter you have to put some load a CD drive, hard drive and a 10w 10 ohm resistor on the 3.3v regulated ATX conector simulating a .33 amp load, you will notice the voltage drop... The 5v rails affect hardrive, cdr, and some shipset of the MB causing instability, usb periferals failures, reboots, and shutdowns.... Bad PSU thats what you pay Sorry for my English i only speak sapanish. Lo barato sale caro....

This card has serious potential, but it's erratic transfers and limitations on how and when you can transfer things, really puts a damper on this card.

When I tried this card, it seemed on the surface that this thing would really be great. My Canon SL1 has code built right into the firmware to recognize the card and the card can connect to my home network for transfering my pics to my home PC as well as my and my wife's phone.

Sounds good so far... until you try to use it.

1) The first thing I noticed was when transfering something, sometimes the transfer would be blazing and finish fast, the next one(keep in mind, I am sitting right next to my router or if going to the phone, right next to the phone) would be slow as molasses or be quick for a few seconds then STOP, then pick up slowly and eventually finish. Not consistent at all.

2) Second, if I transfer something to my PC, then I can no longer send it to my phone. If I send it to my phone, I can no longer send to to my wife's phone and if I wanted to send it to my PC, I'd have to have my PHONE do the transfer of its copy of the pictures because the card wouldn't allow a photo to be transfered twice, to anywhere. Once the card sent the photo somewhere, that was it. The card would not send it anywhere else, period. Terrible implementation.

3) When I shoot, I have the camera create a JPG and RAW files for each photo. The issue is, the eye-fi treats the files as one. So if I send it to my phone, I get forced to take BOTH the JPG AND RAW file. I don't want to wait for the RAW file on my phone, I don't need it there.

The basic problem with this card is it only PUSHES things FROM the card and doesn't give you the ability to PULL something from it(other than putting in a card reader). So when the card connects wirelessly to either a PC or Phone, it will push whatever \\"new\\"(aka never been transfered anywhere) photos are marked as \\"Protected\\" (assuming you use the selective transfer or all new photos, if you aren't using that mode). Since cameras mark the photo in general as \\"protected\\" and not have the ability to mark just either the JPG version and/or the RAW version, the card pushes both.

Eye-fi needs to get with the times and allow their Phone app and PC app to be able to wirelessly PULL from the card, like the Transcend and EZ Share cards allow for.

The push on this card is a nice feature, but to be the ONLY method of getting a photo from the card and allowing it to only ONE device is not a very good implementation.

Until they add more flexibility to how and where photos can be transfered, this is not the card for me.

The Good:

The cover works exactly as intended. Lifting the cover always wakes the ipad when it's covered. The case is phenomenal at protecting the screen when the ipad is in a bag. While it offers no protection for the back of the ipad, the cover is minimal and ensures that the primary device can be used with one hand at all times, and from all angles. Despite appearances, the hinge has held strong despite rough usage.

The Bad:

The magnets just are not strong enough. When I flip the cover to the back, it sticks, but any bump will cause the back to fall and just hang. The spine of the cover sticks without a problem most of the time, but it comes off easier than I would like. When using the case as a stand, it collapses with very little urging unless it's positioned just right and on the perfect surface. I've had many occasions where I've been watching a movie while doing something else and someone will bump the table. The stand collapses into a heap. I've not had any damage as a result, but it's a but annoying.

The Ugly:

This thing feels cheap. It works great for the most part, but it feels cheap. I really wish I could switch the side this connects on. I know that's a very minor problem, but it's something I'd like to see in the future. \\"How are they supposed to do that?\\" I don't know, I'm not a designer. I'm just saying that it's something I'd like to see.

In conclusion:

I bought the cover, and I'd happily buy it again. I wish it was a little cheaper, but I knew what I was getting into. If you're looking for a minimalist cover that protects the screen of your ipad while traveling and doubles as a reasonably capable stand, this is the cover for you. If you're looking for a protective case, it's not. Despite its flaws, the cover works as intended and is a great compliment to your ipad.

I bought these speakers to replace the ones that came with a computer.  At this price my expectations were pretty low, so I'm not disappointed.  The sound is average - highs are pretty good, but the bass is lacking.  There is a power on/off, volume control, and 3D button - no bass/treble.  The 3D button does enhance the sound a bit.  There is enough volume for me, though some may want more for gaming.  The power output is 18 watts.  The sound did not distort badly at higher volumes.  The speakers must be turned on to get any sound - they are not passive.  An AC adapter is included.  I find the speakers attractive with a nice cloth grille, and pretty small footprint.  Overall, I would recommend them for anyone who needs new speakers and doesn't want to spend a lot.

The module is fine - Lots of problems getting it to work, kept thinking there
was something wrong with Raspian or the RasPi itself: It turned out that
the 'backup battery' on my module was dead-on-arrival (-0.5 pt).
I know - sometimes they put chargeables in these things .. but this battery was dead
and stayed dead. The backup battery is soldered in (-1 pt).
It seems that will cause all manner of unusual behaviour. Replacement battery is CR927 (3V).
Installation (where/how to plug it in) on the RasPi (2011.12)
is just as pictured (starting on GPIO pin 1 "inner" side). Specific information
on this module provided in the Q/A section - is solid.

WD has to be the worst company out there.  I was hesitant to buy from them to begin with as they're not known for their networking products.  I received my first bridge and it would not connect to my network.  I called their support and the technician was absolutely useless.  Told me the product was defective and I needed to return it. It works but could be a lot better. I wanted a drive that I could set up with two sides. One side for home use and the other for access from the internet and this drive will do that. I made two folders Web and Home.

The Home Side

DLNA works very good.. all my TV's, radio, and PC's have no problem and movies or music plays very good to everything.

File Sharing.. works very good and easy to map a network drive to both Web and Home Side. File copy speed is good but I only used wireless. Ethernet connected would be faster but not practical in most homes. I was getting about 15 -20 Mb per second over wireless AC.

The Web Side

It was fairly easy to set up but the instructions are not very clear. I wanted a URL that I could give to users with an ID and Password but there is nowhere in the instructions as to how to get that URL. When you connect via the internet, the browser will display [...] and that would be the same at every home that has the LinkStation. I finally figured the link is (with secure access disabled in setup)

[...] Name You Give Your Web During Setup/

A good way to make a bookmark/favorite in Windows 7. Right click the desktop, click New Shortcut, when the window pops up, copy and paste the link like above into the box, click next and next window pops up, type a name for your Web shortcut. It will save to your desktop and you can copy it to your Favorites folder in Users/Your Name/Favorites/

Do not set it up for secure web access ([...] or IE will not want to allow access since you won't have a site certificate. I doubt one would work if you did buy one.

The software running on the LinkStation seems out of date since it recommends Internet Explorer Ver. 8 or Firefox Ver. 3.5... I think IE is now Ver 10 or later and I installed Firefox and I think it was Ver 21 so not many people will be going backwards in browsers to access a LinkStation. I use IE 10 and put it in compatibility view... It works good for the web access part but when I go to the setup part, I have to remove the compatibility view so it will display right.

The software needs work. I also don't know of anyway to backup the software that runs on the LinkStation. It will backup the data but what if something goes wrong with the LinkStation software? There is also software that installs on your PC and for first time set up, it works but after that, you can uninstall it and just use a bookmark to access the drive set up. The only thing I left installed is what it uses to notify me by email if there is a drive error.

No need to download any firmware, it will do that in set up. Best to do that first when you connect to it and start setting it up.

Download software and instructions here:

[...]

The USB port: It's 2.0 and would be better if 3.0. It can be set up for using a USB drive or a printer. I was going to use it as a printer and it showed up in My Computer/Network but I had a problem. When I clicked it, Windows 7 pops up a window to install a printer and if your printer is not in the list that Windows 7 provides, it gives the option to load one from disk. The problem is I have a HP printer and HP does not provide a simple driver anymore. Even the basic driver that HP provides is an exe file for printers and when ran, it expects the printer to be connected directly to a USB port or it will not install. So much for a printer.

Edit 08-26-2013 Printer problem on USB port solved. It was complicated but I got my HP printer installed and it works good. I ran the basic driver exe file from HP and told it to continue without connecting the printer to a USB port. It completed but did not install the printer. It did create a HP folder in C:\Program Files and in that folder are the drivers and inf files for the printer. I went back to My Computer/Network and the LinkStation where it displays lp for the USB port. Clicked it and told Windows I have disk in the C:\Program Files\HP folder and it installed the printer. A bit complicated and it should be easier. After Windows installs the printer, it's ok to uninstall the HP software but don't delete the printer in Devices. Windows copies all the files it needs to the Windows folder.

Edit 08-27-2013 I checked Firefox 3.5 and Internet Explorer 8 and both are for Windows XP. I knew that any keyboard for an iPad that was built into a portable case would be small; however, the keys on this keyboard are tiny and all jammed together. The keys on the Zagg keyboard are about the same size but are spaced out so it feels more like typing on a regular size keyboard. It seems like the New Trent keyboard did not take full advantage of its available space and just mashed everything together. This is a good wireless router for a budget if you're willing to get your hands a little dirty. Setting up a custom SSID and password isn't as simple as it could be, but the instructions that come in the box do a decent job of explaining how to do it. More advanced settings are readily available, but an explanation of their functions are not.

The range isn't all that impressive (barely usable at 20 ft), but if your needs are fairly minimal it should be fine. The unit I have seems to drop its connection every few days, but this is fixed by turning it off and on again. This may be a unique issue with the source of the connection, however.

After several weeks of continual use, I would recommend this product if your needs and/or budget are limited.

This is a great PC - just about as much PC as 90% of the people need to have.  Intel i5 processor (more than most need...), big hard drive, 8 GB memory, 1 GB Video Card with HDMI.  One thing I should warn people about, however, is that if you are running 802.11n wireless networks, the PCIe mini card will only handle a maximum of 150 mbps which is what I was getting.  This PC has a Ralink RT3090 PCIe 802.11n Wireless LAN Card.  I disabled this wireless connection and installed a Refurbished Linksys AE1000 USB adapter and now get my full 300 mbps.  So, no matter what PC you buy, if it has a Ralink PCIe LAN card, you won't be able to realize the full potential of your N Network.  I would bet that the maximum of ANY PCIe LAN card is 150 Mbps.  Other than that, this PC screams - you'll love it.

My biggest pet peeve of all was that this device supposedly has \\"DNLA certification \\" but it honestly should be revoked. After speaking on the phone with tech support for over two hours on two seperate occasions, I could not get this product to stream to my xbox (and also a PS3) . In the end, when you map the internal hard drive as a network drive, you are unable to take permission of it . I've worked with IP cameras for a while. This one is far better than my old D-Links that were between three and five hundred when I purchased them. Most of the instructions are as bad as others have said. I skipped the installation CD since my network IP address space is the same as the default on the camera (192.168.1.X). The camera comes from the factory with a static IP of 192.168.1.126. I didn't have any other device at that address so I plugged the camera into my network, opened my browser and entered the IP address ([...] This address seems to be a factory default but can be changed using the administration pages accessible once you sign onto the camera via the browser.

The default user is 'admin' with no password (you can change this in the admin section as well.) You'll need to plug a network cable in and access it via the IP address to set up the wireless. You can change the IP port to the normal 80 that browsers use if you'd prefer to not use the :81 port designation at the end.

Additional follow up:
This camera has a great picture and overall I'm pleased with the performance. I hard-wired this camera -- one, because I could easily and two, the wireless seemed to be unreliable. The only other negative I found is that the date reverts to December of 1969 if you reboot the camera for any reason. I tried using an NTP server (the NTP servers already listed seemed to be incorrect) without success. For the price and quality of the image, I'll accept the wireless and time problems.

After working out issues with the product (via software), I'd say this is a fairly solid deal.

Streaming:
My main goal was to live stream my console gameplay to Twitch.tv - I could have gotten an internal capture card, but I looked at the reviews and thought I'd give this a spin for now. I'm also hoping to livestream my gameplay for a fundraising/gaming event in November. So it was time to start early and test things out.

For the first day that I used the LGP, I downloaded XSplit software (the unit I bought came with a 3-month Premium License). XSplit itself seems very straightfoward and easy to use. However, I wasn't feeling confident about the LGP because the quality coming from the unit itself looked very pixelated, with ghosting in any dark colors/darks on the screen.

I upped my bandwidth/upstream and the quality still seemed poor. I was disheartened, but I wondered why there were so many good reviews? You could chalk it up to user error/discovery.... Or just somewhat, non-so-immediately-intuitive features:

I discovered that, within XSplit at least, I could access an AVERmedia driver/properties window that allowed me to adjust the setting from "Low" up to "Ultra". For whatever reason, it was set to "Low" by default. Once I stumbled onto this and changed the setting, the stream was very clear. For those who may have run into this problem, here was my solution:

1. XSplit: In the current scene, if you're gameplay 'camera' is there, right click anywhere over the camera. There should be a 'Configure' button for the Avermedia.
2. Click on 'Configure'
3. Change the setting to "Ultra" (it wasn't even on 'Low', just a blank for me!)

RECentral software:
The RECentral software is for capturing video from the LGP to your PC and streaming without using another program like XSplit or OBS (Open Broadcaster Software), but I still use it to switch inputs whenI'm live streaming via Twitch and using XSplit.

For my tests, I have a WiiU & Xbox360 connected via HDMI and a PS3 connected via component (the LGP comes with a component (female) to AV-In (male). In order to switch between these inputs during a livestream, I have to use RECentral to switch input profiles. XSplit and/or the software doesn't like it when I switch from HDMI to Component on the fly, so I have to refresh the camera's properties from within XSplit, otherwise the visual (on the broadcaster, not the actual TV) is glitched/choppy.

Capture:
RECentral is serviceable.. I was able to capture 1080p 30fps video of Xbox360 gameplay just fine to my PC. I tried several minutes of capture and it seemed fine! It can save them as MP4s, but there is also the "timeshift" feature that exports the movies to a .TS format. I haven't delved into this so I can't say more about it.

Free-PC Capture:
I tried this, again with the 360. You still have to use the Free-PC Capture Utility (via USB hookup to your PC) to change the resolution and data-bitrate, but it works as described. Pushed the big button on the unit and it recorded clips without issue and without hooking it up to a PC. The LGP does NOT come included with an SD memory card. You'll want to provide your own Class 10 card, as it says on the label. Also, I couldn't bring up the LGP as a drive (in order to just copy the data off) - I had to take the SD card out and put it into an SD card reader. Could someone tell me if I'm doing it wrong? ;)

I give it a generous 4-stars because it's a compact unit that does deliver good results for what I need it to do. I took a star off due to the issues and the 'first impression' of just seeing poor streaming quality.

Also worth mentioning is that, over at the AVERmedia forums, tech support from the company seems non existent for a few weeks now.

I will update this review if anything comes up with the LGP, especially before livestreaming for a long time in November!

This screen protector set protects both the front and the back; the back piece wraps around the edges and corners as well.

The front piece was cut pretty well. It wasn't exactly perfect; the film was short by about a millimeter when the hole for the front-facing camera and top edge were perfectly aligned, and the cut-out for the home button wasn't centered properly. However, the left and right edges of the front piece were right on target.

The back piece, on the other hand was a bit more troublesome. When the cut-out for the microphone was centered, the bottom end of the piece is off by a few millimeters, leaving the bottom of the iPad mini not very well protected. A little stretching had to be done to protect the area around the volume buttons and orientation/mute switch as well. The small piece that's used to block the hole for the SIM card tray on WiFi-only models leaves a noticeable gap as well.

As mentioned, it offers side and corner protection. The back piece is cut such that there are four tails that can be wrapped around the corners. It's difficult to get them to adhere properly, especially when you have to re-adhere the main part of the piece a few times to get it all properly fitted. I would have preferred these tails to come as separate pieces instead; it would make them easier to manipulate/adjust.

The micro-bubbles for both sides went away a little quicker than with other films. Whether that has to do with the weather, the formulation of the spray they provide (which is nearly all water anyway), or the film itself, I couldn't say.

Overall, the protection is pretty good, the film protecting the screen is pretty transparent, and it doesn't feel tacky to the touc. That's all you can ask from protective films.

I'll keep my review short by only talking about the things I don't like about it (because I really like most things about it):    VOLUME CONTROL - there's no dial or control dedicated specifically to volume. This is a real inconvenience because I listen to music on this laptop.    HANDLING - you can not open the laptop with one hand.  It's built pretty sturdy (which is a great thing) but that is probably why the hinges don't release the top half of the laptop with one hand unless you hold the bottom half down with your other hand.    APPEARANCE - shiny exterior is appealing but scratches easily.  Also, why brown (even if it's dark brown)???    Again, I like this laptop a lot but the above are small annoyances I think of every single time I use it.

Another important thing is about the on-board wireless adapter. Some reviews say that the reception is bad, which, in my mind, is only half the truth. This is a wireless b/g/n router that can also act as a wireless bridge between two wired local area networks.  The bridge feature allows you to connect a device, such as a printer or a bluray player, that has an ethernet port, to a wi-fi network.  I bought it to enable the \\"BD Live\\" and \\"BonusView\\" features of my [[ASIN:B001V9LA44 Panasonic DMP-BD60 Blu-ray Disc Player, Black]]. First I plugged in the router into my laptop ethernet port and tried setting it up as a simple wireless router, following the User Manual instructions.  The instructions were easy to follow. I was able to log into the router and configure it without any problems.  However, configuring it as a bridge (\\"WISP mode\\") wasn't as simple.  I tried following the user manual instructions, with several variations, but without success.  After sending an email to Zyxel customer support, I was advised to put the LAN side of the new router on a different subnet from my primary router (e.g., primary lan address 192.168.1.xx, Zyxel lan 192.168.2.xx).  With this advice I was able to complete the configuration, connect the router/bridge to my bluray, and voila, my blueray was connected to the network.  Overall, very happy with the device, just wish for a little more detail on configuring the the WISP mode.

A testament to the longevity of the hard drive Western Digital put inside this drive. 3 Years of pretty solid hard use, and the drive still works. Unfortunately, I can't say the same for the case or electronics. Last night the drive quit working after booting up my computer. No coaxing would bring the drive back, front light worked, no drive spin up.

If you google disassemble WD 500Gb My Book, you'll find an instructions on how to remove this case. It's not hard to do, just tricky. Remove the paint or sticker over the screw on the side of the case, press in two tabs at the top and bottom, and the cover slides off (with a lot of coaxing).

Once I had the case open, it was pretty simple to free the WD Caviar drive from the housing. These are SATA drives. Open the computer case, connect power and the SATA cable, a brief driver self install, a reboot, and this drive has a second life as an internal drive.

I fully expect that this drive will last a good long time internally. Simple surgery and the drive has a whole new life.

By the way, this is actually a pretty noisy external drive. Although there is no fan, the drive makes a pretty decent noise while spun up. The reason you recognize it, after around 10 minutes if you don't use the drive, you hear a click, and a whining wind down noise.

These were decent drives at the time. The newer models are way less expensive.

The GoFlex is a neat idea.. I've bought all sorts of external hard drives, and it's a bit of a bummer to get stuck with an \\"old\\" technology.. whether it's USB 1.0, 2.0 or Firewire 400.. if you want USB 3.0, Firewire 800 or eSata you're outta luck. That's where the GoFlex comes in.

I've been a big fan of Seagate's portable drives lately as a backup tool.. the compact drives make it easy to keep multiple of them around. I have 8 Freeagent drives now (500GB each -- and 2 copies of each (so basically 500+500+500+500 and then a backup of all of that) for my music, photos, etc.. With the reports of these failing, I'm not at the trust level that I want to keep just 1 copy of everything yet. With that said, using the Freeagent GO and GoFlex drives from their initial launch.. no problems at all!

After building a collection (6) of Freeagent GO drives, I loved the style factor.. compact, had a nice dock, felt strong, even looked good with the \\"stars\\" that light up when plugged in. With the price of those now staying high while the GoFlex drives came down, I decided to give that a try for my next (2) drives. I've previously used the GoFlex Desk 2TB, but not these portable (USB-powered) drives.

These are just about the same size as the 500GB GO Drives, with the exception the connector dock end is rounded instead of flat.

I'm not a big fan of the super-glossy finish.. it leaves fingerprints all over it -- the freeagent go drives used a matte finish which didn't leave any marks. The material also feels much less secure (like if you drop it or even hold it too tightly it will easily crumble - the Go did not feel this way).

It uses the same mini USB connection as the GO - you can even use the dock from the GO with this one (although it's a bit tricky to line up). The included Seagate software is easy to use to configure the drive (sleep time, etc..) and can be removed without any problems (some of these require software on the drive to be used).

The dock for the GoFlex only has 1 USB plug - the Freeagent GO uses 2 plugs in case your USB connection is low-powered and requires extra power (since there is no AC adapter, all power and data are run through a single USB cable).

The \\"adapter\\" end (USB/Firewire/eSata) feels cheap and flimsy.. another part that you think might break even when just trying to plug it in.

Overall though - besides the design and possible build quality issues (I never dropped it - I can't say if it would actually break if I did), I think it's a good drive. It has some negatives compared to the GO, but the lower price point and flexibility to change connectors is very nice.he GoFlex only has 1 USB plug - the Freeagent GO uses 2 plugs in case your USB connection is low-powered and requires extra power (since there is no AC adapter, all power and data are run through a single USB cable). The \\"adapter\\" end (USB/Firewire/eSata) feels cheap and flimsy.. another part that you think might break even when just trying to plug it in. Overall though - besides the design and possible build quality issues (I never dropped it - I can't say if it would actually break if I did), I think it's a good drive. It has some negatives compared to the GO, but the lower price point and flexibility to change connectors is very nice.

I bought the 1.5 TB version on black Friday week at a very reasonable prize (amazon rocks!). However the drive was a horrible disappointment. I rarely return stuff I buy online but in this case I had no choice. The drive is just not reliable it disconnects every few minutes regardless of whether you are using the USB or the eSATAb cable sold separately. I really wanted to like this drive so initially I thought maybe it's an issue with Seagate software that comes with the drive so I formatted the drive (NTFS). I tested basic functionality (copied, deleted, created some folders, etc.) it started disconnecting randomly, after reconnecting the cable the drive worked for a few minutes then randomly disconnected again. Then I tried with other file systems (FAT32, exFat, etc.) and executed a couple of tests with a combination of USB/eSATAb connections and OSes Windows 7, MacOS X Snow Leopard and it disconnected several times from both of the computers, some of the those times I'd even lost the ability to access the files on the drive and had to re-format the drive again and again (fortunately I had the precaution of keeping the files save in another drive).   From this review I hope you figure the following if this drive is not reliable for simple functionality test within a few minutes, imagine the data loss catastrophe you could face in the long term even if the drive works for you for the first couple of hours.   When we are talking about nearly 1.5 TB of storage space you better get a reliable drive. This one is not worth it. The idea is great and hopefully Seagate will find a way to fix all of the issues by the time they release the next version of this drive and still offer a price much lower than the competiotion but for now I'd strongly recommend you to keep away from this one, even if like me you are able to find a reasonable price...

Pros:  + Rugged  + Great capacity  + Fast enough for normal usage    Cons:  - The outside rubber rings  - Minor quality issues with the labels    I bought the unit around Christmas 2007 to replace an old plastic 1GB unit that failed.  I carried a flash drive im my pocket so that I always have access to my data, but the old one just wasn't rugged enough to co-mingle with coins and keys.    I purchased this unit specifically because of it's claims to be rugged.  In that regard I have not been disappointed.  The rubber o-ring on the inside should provide good protection from moisture, but I haven't tried to see if it will float.      I carry the Corsair Flash Survivor on my keyring, which is usually in my pocket.  The outside of the aluminum case is showing a little wear from the keys, as I would expect, but drive itself is protected.    I have two issues with the flash drive.  First, one of the labels on the drive was not correctly applied in the factory and had to be removed the first week I had it to prevent it from sticking to other items.  This alone wouldn't have been enough to lower the rating if it wasn't for the second problem.    The quality and design of the rubber rings on the outside is an issue if you intend to carry this around like I do.  Both of them are loose, and the one attached to the flash drive itself spins freely.  It has even come detached a few times in my pocket, but so far I haven't lost it.    Overall, this a great product.  And if you don't plan to carry it everywhere, you might not experience this issue.

Seldom would you see military equipment used by civilians but during the past decade, we do see that untested even alien-like equipment come into the commercial market, just like in MIB. The Hummer is actually one of those military vehicles that have made it mainstream. Ideazon makes the claim that the ZNP-1000 Fang is one of those equipment tested by the military and declassified for civilian use. Talk about controlling weapons of mass destruction.

Packaging:

The Fang weighs around 1.5Lb (0.8Kg) it is package. It is protected by a thick box and a solid transparent plastic mold. Encased in its shell is the controller, a wrist rest, one CD containing the Zboard Z-Engine software and two manuals.

The Merchandise:

The Fang comprises of 41 keys which is functional as a regular keyboard. The standard keyboard has 105 keys so don't expect it to replace your regular keyboard. Remember that this is for fragging people away not for typing It has 6 massive keys in a shape of a butterfly, ASWD are part of keys we control our player, the Q & E can be used diagonally or for weapon selection, depending on the games. The buttons surrounding the direction keys are small Skittle-sized buttons. For big hands, this is not what I recommend, the fact big fingers may depress two buttons at one time is a big issue, there is ample space for your fingers but remember, when you game, game in comfort. For players with the right fit, selected Skits (Skittle Buttons) have dimples and some with concaves for identification. I did wish that the buttons could be easier to remember with embedded characters for finger tip reading like mahjong.

Continuing off the last batch of buttons would be the controversial thumb button which takes a little bit of getting used to. We often take for granted the large size of the Space Bar. Well things couldn't be worse when you find out that the Space Bar replacement is almost the size of a medicine capsule, I did mention controversial and I leave that up to you. During game play I did find myself forgetting that I had a thumb. Finally, the remaining 6 buttons would be the ones near the palm. Having three on both sides below the ring finger and index finger. It definitely takes a little getting used to, but it is useful nonetheless.

Looking at the bottom of the pad, rubberized feet and an option to slightly elevate the pad help make the gaming experience easier. It is important that I stress out proper gaming posture for your arm and hand which should be the same way as you were playing on a normal keyboard.

Aside from the norm, the Fang has multimedia keys to control your audio during game play and the an emblazoned Z-Board logo that glows white for that extra bling.

Software Support:

The package comes with a CD with the Z-Engine application. I would suggest you download the latest version so that you get an update profile. If you are running on dial up, install the software from the CD and update so it will download the latest profiles for you. The bad side of the Z-Engine, keys are customized for each game and you need to activate the key set of each game. Unfortunately, the Z-Engine software does not allow you to customize your own controls so for sports games and others on the list, they may need to wait. Over all the software work fine, unfortunately, I can't really give my full point of view since I have only tried it with Grand Theft Auto: San Andreas.

Recommendations:

If you are expecting that the gamer in you will come out with this gaming keyboard, it will provided that you practice. It will take time especially for those who are so used to the regular keyboard. Quality build, lots of buttons, military tested, there are so many things going right for this gaming keyboard but the thumb key may prove to be the Achilles heel of this marvelous product, then again, practice makes perfect.

Uppers:

* Dedicated gaming keypad with more than enough buttons

* Multimedia Controls

* Dimpled keys make identification easier

* Large ASWD buttons

* Ambidextrous

Downers:

* Transition to the Fang requires a learning curve when moving from a keyboard

* Thumb key will never replace the Space Bar

* Keys NOT YET customizable

* Not built for button mashing

* Not for everybody

Wish list:

* Add-on glow features for the keys for dark gaming environment

* Sticker Badge

* More dimples and dents on the keys for identification

* Game detection and auto key change

Alternatives:

* Logitech G15 Gaming Keyboard

* Belkin Nostromo Speedpad n52

* WolfKing Warrior Gaming Keyboard/>Uppers:

* Multimedia Controls

Downers:

The Wacom Graphire tablet is a mouse-pad like device that connects into the USB port (or serial port if you don't have USB.) A special electronic stylus comes with it and you can draw on the pad as you would on sketch paper. The Graphire tablet is for home use and is distinguished from other Wacom tablets in that it also has a cordless mouse. It comes in a choice of kid-pleasing colors (well, I like colors too, I must admit. I bought a clear purple keyboard recently, so who'm I kiddin'!) Now, this tablet-mouse pad is a darn clever idea. Both a graphics tablet and a mouse are \\"human interface devices\\" or pointing devices for the computer (how you move around and click on items on the screen.) So having a combination mouse/pen pad is nice as you can eliminate your regular mouse. And I can tell you, cordless mice are the way to go. Much more comfortable than mice with cords.

I prefer my Logitech cordless mouse to the mouse on the Graphire as it isn't as smooth as the Logitech, and I also use an ergonomic mouse pad to prevent wrist strain. You must use the Graphire mouse on the Graphire pad--that's how the electronic connection is made, through the tablet. Still, this is a wonderful interface especially if you have kids. They can draw and paint on the computer. What a great idea. And this is wonderful for creating digital art for your webpage. (ok, who'm I kidding! I'm the one who uses the pad and draws for the website and sends pictures to my mom in email.)

Many of the newer IC's and sensors on the market operate at 3.3v logic levels - and most Arduino applications default to the 5v level. If you're using newer modules or devices that integrate on protocols such as I2C, or you're trying to get those wonderfully time consuming sensor sketches and libraries you composed in the Arduino IDE to have some way to communicate with the Raspberry Pi, consider this model. Long story short is that if you're using mostly 3.3v sensors and communicating serial data from an Arduino unit elsewhere, this is a great board.

While the board does not come with pin headers, I simply soldered my own on so that it would fit neatly on my new and very large Elenco breadboard. This thing spans about the width of a standard breadboard, so you'd need two next to each other to wire it in. I would say the main advantage from my perspective is that I'm no longer worried about the wires falling out of my Arduino Uno as it's positioned tenuously at the edge of my prototype circuits. I can toss my breadboard down on the couch and not worry that parts will fly everywhere.

This board makes an excellent complement to the Adafruit modules running at 3.3v. I say 3.3v, but again, that's only the logic level. You can power this board with a standard 5v PSU or do the old 7805 IC, two caps, and a few jumpers on the breadboard to regulate voltage from your battery and/or \\"wall-wart.\\"

A few notes - an FTDI cable is necessary to program this board. No standard USB header. It also runs at 8 mhz because of the lower voltage, but I have heard around of some overclocking. I'll leave that to the others. Finally, if you do some \\"fritzing\\" what's great about a board without pin headers is that you can just drop your board onto your finished \\"Fritzing Fab\\" board when you've modeled your project on the breadboard!

Cheers to a good product!

Update as of 10/28/2012

Although this is a great board - there's more and more models on the market that are great as well. The issue of direct USB connectivity is one that is frustrating for me as an Arduino user. So if you want USB capability without the associated FTDI header or accessory FTDI chip, consider the headerless Arduino Leonardo on Amazon. Or if you're a real \\"Arduino Pro\\" just bootload an ATMEGA chip and run your sketches directly off a 28 pin DIP with the right crystal, the correct voltage, and a few capacitors and resistors (do a web search for \\"Arduino on a Breadboard\\"). My afterthought on purchasing this product is yeah, 3.3v is nice, but certainly I can just create my own bidirectional logic level converter or purchase one here on Amazon (3.3v/5v and vice-versa). After using this for a few weeks, I'll probably end up embedding this on a custom PCB for a specific application rather than using this for regular prototyping. Because of the convenience of direct-to-usb connectivity (and less connection issues) with the Leonardo, I'll probably do most of my coding and debugging on the Leonardo and drop the \\"Pro\\" into a finished product. So (1) great for a finished product - you can overlay the connectors onto your PCB CAD design after this has been programmed with your sketch and embed this as MCU \\"base station\\" on your project - but it's a little frustrating for day to day use because of the fact you need the FTDI cable or a second Arduino (or some other device) to program this board.nd more models on the market that are great as well. It's an awesome little laptop. The touchscreen works great, keyboard is nice, love the small form, and it has an amazing price point. The Celeron is more than capable of the menial tasks I was using it for, however there's one annoyance and one fatal flaw.

The annoyance: You can't turn off the adaptive display permanently. When darker colors fill the screen, the monitor dims. When lighter colors fill the screen, the monitor brightens. Smart idea to save power, if it wasn't annoying as hell. The settings seem to re-enable themselves every time you reboot, so you have to keep turning it off, over and over.

The flaw: Touchpad. It starts off working fine, you'll notice Synaptics lags a bit when you use the multitouch scrolling. Then you'll notice Synaptics eating CPU cycles when you're not even touching it, and eventually multi-touch will stop working. No more scrolling, no more tap to click. You'll have to use the physical button to click. Occasionally it flips out and the cursor will start flying all over the screen, clicking at random. Eventually it will just stop working, and not start working again until you shut down the computer completely, and start it back up.

I've tried every driver available for it, including some that were intended for other touchpads. I've tried updating the BIOS. I've tried uninstalling the drivers completely and have Windows think it's an old PS/2 mouse. The problem still persists after booting into Linux. It's impossible to get it working properly. You can use it for an hour or two before it starts happening, or ten minutes. It's sporadic, yet persistent.

I rarely return things, but unfortunately in this case, it's going back.

If anyone else is having the same issue, just Google "Inspiron 11 touchpad" without the quotes, and click on the first result. There are still people actively trying to solve the issue.

A couple of months ago I had to replace my dear old mouse. It had been having issues for a long time, but I had been putting off parting with it because it was the best mouse I ever owned -- wireless, fit my hand perfectly, and perfectly weighted. It was like an extension of my own body.

I could forgive it its inability to no longer right-click in its old age, but sometime this summer the poor old thing started left clicking and double clicking randomly all on its own. Rather than let it, and me, continue to suffer with the computer mouse equivalent of Parkinson's, I got a new one and pulled my long time friend's batteries for the last time.

The new one will never replace that special bond we had, but it does have something going for it that the old one never will -- a clutch! On the scroll wheel! Who knew something so simple could give so much joy?

I'm not ashamed to admit that I can spend minutes every day disengaging the gears, giving the wheel a big spin like I'm trying to win the showcase on The Price Is Right, and watching my Facebook friends' posts scroll on by at lightning speed. Why, on a good day I'll wind up staring at someone's post from last year by the time the wheel finally stops.

So Logitech, I salute you. At first what I thought was just pointless turns out to be the missing feature to revolutionize my procrastination.

=====

Other than that, this mouse is rather largish for a mobile mouse, which I like since I'm using it on my desktop. It is a bit heavy with two batteries in it, but I also like that. For my hand it's about 1\\" too short, but the curvature of the mouse is perfect. It's dead easy to set up and Windows automatically installs the correct driver. You only need to install the Logitech software if you want the extra features. The only downside is that, as others have noted, you probably want to keep the tiny receiver away from your WiFi router because it can cause interference that makes the mouse behavior erratic. My keyboard has an extra USB port in the rear so I plugged it in there and have had no problems. The battery life also appears to be as long as advertised. I've had it a couple of months now and have not noticed that the battery's charge has dropped one bit. However, the mouse does have an off/on switch on its bottom so I turn it off at night.

Thinking of getting a nice faux leather case for your Google Nexus 7? Well allow me to posit the following summary of events:
Imagine it's a nice sunny afternoon, and you've got a nice, icy cool glass of homemade lemonade. You decide to take your IVSO Slim Faux Leather Keyboard Case with your brand new Google Nexus 7 out to the deck for to compose a few emails, a little web surfing, and maybe to play a game or two. You set down your lemonade and open up the case, start typing away...it's awkward and cumbersome, and you aren't sure if you can power through it.
But that's the least of your worries, because you've just spilled your lemonade on yourself. The sugary-sour daisy-colored liquid becomes sticky and uncomfortable as it attempts to fuse your clothes to your skin. The lemon-scented goodness begins to permeate and attract a small swarm of yellow jackets begin to move in around you, buzzing and bouncing around against your skin, needling you with their pointy little feet and stingers. Filled with panic, you stand up suddenly, which triggers the \\"fight\\" response of the bees, and they attack full force, stinging every bit of your exposed skin. As your upper torso is met with a barrage of tiny stingers piercing your flesh, you realize that your legs had fallen asleep as you were sitting in the flimsy plastic chair, and they immediately become gelatin, causing you to hurtle towards your insufficiently attached deck railing.
As the weight of your healthy adult body is afforded no resistance as it drifts effortlessly through the pressure-treated railing that the contractor assured you was perfectly secure (even though it felt shoddy and wobbly), you can feel gravity take hold of you and pull you towards the Earth several feet below. Your instincts to feebly prevent injury by putting your hands out in front of you as you fell were met with a thud, several crunches, and then another thud as the rest of your body lands haplessly on the fallen deck railing in your backyard. You are given a slight relief from the pain as the adrenaline courses through your veins, until the angry yellow jackets catch up with your now-mangled body, angrier than ever. Your left leg has now fully gained circulation, but the deck railing has splintered, and that sharp stake has punctured straight through your thigh. Your throat is dry, because you never even got one sip of that delicious lemonade, so you can't even call for help, though you wouldn't be able to anyways, because your lungs are filling up with fluid.
After what seems to be a millenium, the gasping, the constant boring of yellow jacket stingers, the broken bones, the throbbing of chemical-treated wood wrapped in muscle tissue, and the dull pain of internal bleeding begin to fade as your internal organs start to shut down, your heart slows, your vision fades, and your mind starts to submit to the influence of dimethyltryptamine.
As you struggle to will your own eyelids to close before you walk into the light, one very blissful thought crosses your mind: \\"At least this is better than using the IVSO Slim Faux Leather Keyboard Case.\\"iling in your backyard. I didn't use my iPad Mini with retina outside of my house before I had this case, I was too worried about possible drops and water damage. The overall sturdiness and protection of ports on this case is fantastic, so I'm not worried any more, a big relief!

I like:

- positioning options
- ease of separating Mini from keyboard
- size and weight with or without keyboard attached - not too bulky to port around for a long time
- rugged yet sleek design - very cool looking!

I don't like (thus reducing my rating 1 point, to 4/5):

- unremovable screen protector
- tendency for Mini and keyboard to separate when making adjustments to create a "laptop" setup

Suggestions for improvement (I'd be willing to pay more for this case, up to double the current model's cost, if it had them all):

- removable screen protector so a scratched protector can be replaced
- better screen protector, maybe glass of some kind, that can show off retina display
- small locking feature to prevent a full separation of Mini and keyboard when adjusting positions
- place to store a stylus (I have and love the NT62B, also by New Trent) and a cleaning cloth for the screen
- ability to attach a carrying strap

I bought this in February, and by June, it was only working about half of the time. I made it last until July at which point I contacted Amazon and they refunded me the price and offered to pay for expedited shipping for a new one. I ordered a new one the same day, it arrived today and as soon as I plugged it in, I got the error message saying that this accessory doesn't work with this device. I have other cords that work just fine, so I know it's not the phone or the plug. I'm once again returning this item and will look for something more reliable.

After extensive review I settle on this keyboard.  Setup is easy, it works  well, the fit to the tablet is good. The appearance is professional and seems well made.  I was looking for a real leather cover with keyboard but for the price this is an acceptable substitute. The only negative is the strap that closes the cover. It is a tab that slides under a loop. Works ok now but my guess is after use it will stretch and I will at that point apply velcro

I got this item about a week ago, opened the box and I was a little disappointed. The LED connector was missing a pin (3 out of 4) and therefore couldn't work properly. I contacted Amazon for a replacement and just got it today. It works perfectly fine.

The item itself is an awesome decoration for your computer case. The colors are bright and clear. The strip is a little thick and sturdy to make sharp turn in a tight case but it seems to be built with high quality materials: smooth, shiny, and flexible plastic. This piece has several modes for you to play with, and you can manually mix colors to get your favorite one.

I caught this item for under $20, and for anywhere around that mark, this is definitely a great case. I rate it only 4/5 because the security straps inhibit external devices from conveniently connecting on the keyboard (i.e. power cable, SD memory, USB). The devices will still plug in, but you have to stretch the straps a bit to get them to fit. I'm afraid that this will lead to unnecessary wear and tear over time. In the end, it's only a minor inconvenience, but it's enough to keep my rating from 5/5.

Overall Pros:
-Looks Professional
-Decent protection for both the tablet and keyboard docking station
-Easy to separate tablet from keyboard while keeping the case on both components.
-Third flap has room for papers, business card, etc.

Overall Cons:
-The strap issue described above.
-Makes for a mediocre stand when using only the tablet (conversely, it does just fine when in \\"laptop\\" mode).

For the price this is a nice case (since its is 1/2 as much as other major brands that provide the same function).

Quality: 2.5/5
- The outside has a nice design with a texture in it, I don't mind it.
- The stitching around the outside is of what I consider low quality.
- What I mean is it is not a consistent distance from the edge all around the outside leaving a \\"low class\\" feel. But again, the price out weights this minor issue (its not that bad, I will upload a image later).
- Closing the case does not stay \\"closed\\". Without the strap holding it shut it does not stay nice and flat like a hardcover book when closed. This is a minor issue but would like to have had it stay flat closed without the strap.
- The area that the iPad slides into, the edging does not sit flush with the iPad. I can not describe this great so I will upload a picture at some point. This also may be way the case does not shut flat.

Functionality: 5/5
- Rotating function works great. I was was not sure if I would rotate to portrait but then I found a few Magazine applications that force iPad to be Portrait so I am happy I have the ability.
- Magnet \\"Smart cover\\" function: This works but not perfectly. What I mean is if you close the case and the magnet is not aligned right the iPad stays on. I have found you just need to close it right and put the strap around it and its fine. This goes back to my last statement in Quality, if it closed flat it would work perfectly.

Price: 5/5

Overall: 4/5
I would recommend this to a person that does not want to drop close to double the money for the [[ASIN:B004N62HZI Targus THZ045US Versavu 360 Degrees Rotating Stand Case for Apple iPad 2 (Black/Blue Interior)]] which does NOT have the magnet but I feel has a higher \\"quality\\" factor.

When I originally installed this product, it would not work. The software and drivers would load correctly, but the computer would never connect to the camera, even though it recognized that there was a VX-3000 webcam attached. Many other reviewers had this problem. The solution is on microsoft's support site for this product: if you have previously installed webcam drivers for a Logitech cam, this camera might not work unless you uninstall the Logitech drivers first. This solved the problem for me. Now that I can use my camera, though, I can say that the quality is not as good as the cams that are integrated in the iBooks. The image quality is decent if you stay still, but it gets choppy when you move around.

I bought the Sound Blaster PCMCIA card rather than cheaper models because I figured I would get a better sound quality and less problems than a simple USB plug in model and I needed it for my laptop, which has limited USB ports. I wasn't even looking for quality equivalent to my sound card. I simply needed sound from my Gateway laptop because the sound card was no longer working and I would have to replace the entire motherboard to fix it.

Unfortunately, I have been extremely disappointed with this product. First, I had to run it in \\"standard\\" rather than \\"advanced\\" mode to get it to work. Perhaps with more fiddling I could have gotten it to work in \\"advanced\\" mode, but for $100 I expect a plug-and-play. Secondly, even in \\"standard\\" mode, I sometimes get all kinds of pops, static and distortion (I tried multiple headphones and speakers, so its the card, not the speakers). There appears to be no rhyme or reason for when it decides to work and when it does not.

The biggest problem I've found is that if I bump the card, which is easy to do since it sticks out about an inch from the laptop, it sometimes causes the computer to crash (the computer is a 2004 Gateway 450RG laptop, running Windows XP Professional). Not just hang up, but a blue screen appears that tells you a fatal error has occurred and the computer promptly restarts so that you lose whatever you were working on in addition to the annoyance of having to restart. It would be one thing to have the Creative Labs software hang-up or crash, but there is no acceptable reason for a $100 hardware card to cause the computer to crash and restart.

I give it one star only because it does produce decent sound most of the time (in \\"standard\\" mode) - but what causes it to work poorly the rest of the time remains a mystery.

After some research we settleted on this Notebook as the best balance of price to performance.

Pro's - The screen is beautiful, it's fast, and feature rich. Batter life is pretty good. The 1 year free accidental damage warranty.

Con's - It's heavy, it has some pre-loaded bloatware. It only has a CD/DVD player/burner. It's a HD screen and has an HDMI out port, it would be nice to have a BluRay drive.

I would reccommend this computer for anyone who is looking for a good general use notebook.

This mouse has almost everything. Form, function, easy charging, wicked-cool scrolling. It's a beautiful piece of machinery in your hand and moves effortlessly across most all surfaces. So what's the issue? Battery life. I fully charged this mouse when it arrived and the battery was dead within 24 hours. I fully charged it again and it was dead within 24 hours once more. I'm not charging it again, it's being shipped back.

Too bad, that one flaw makes this thing a loser. Seriously, it's such a shame because this mouse is so gorgeous and its performance while in use is just amazing, but that battery just won't let it do what you need it to. After reading more about this mouse, it seems the Performance MX has been getting panned since day 1 due to poor battery life. However, if you can deal with the battery issue, you will love this mouse. I dislike sending it back, but I can't deal with it. This is the reason it has a 2 out of 5 stars rating. Fix the battery issue and you have a solid 4.5 or 5 star mouse. It really is amazing, but just unmanageable with a 24 hour battery life-cycle.
It satisfies the specifications.

If you're thinking about buying this card, don't. If you have this card and think it's just fine because it's just been in your digital camera and you're yet to take more than 1gb of pictures without downloading them to your computer--download and run a program called H2testw (Google it).

The program \\"writes\\" virtual data chunks to all the remaining storage sectors on the card, theoretically filling it up to its formatted storage capacity. After doing so, it tells you how many sectors it successfully wrote to, and how much data was lost. Below are the copy/pasted results of running H2testw on the memory chip I received after ordering this card from Blueproton:

Warning: Only 31370 of 31988 MByte tested.
The media is likely to be defective.
1.3 GByte OK (2825920 sectors)
29.2 GByte DATA LOST (61419840 sectors)
Details:0 KByte overwritten (0 sectors)
0 KByte slightly changed (< 8 bit/sector, 0 sectors)
29.2 GByte corrupted (61419840 sectors)
0 KByte aliased memory (0 sectors)
First error at offset: 0x00000000535c0000
Expected: 0x00000000535c0000
Found: 0x0000000000000000
H2testw version 1.4
Writing speed: 3.10 MByte/s
Reading speed: 8.02 MByte/s
H2testw v1.4

I had a ~640mb movie file on the card when I tested, H2testw managed to pack on another 1.3 gigs (for a grand total of 2 gigs), then every single byte it wrote after that disappeared into the land of fraudulent flash memory.

You won't get any error pop-ups when you try to write to your SD card, and any file manager you use will look at the metadata of all the files and tell you everything is hunky dory and that you have 22gb of data on the thing. But just try to access it.

If you MUST order this card, run H2testw immediately, before you go off to your sister's wedding and take tens of gigs of pictures that you'll never see.

Let me preface by saying that I am not a security expert. I am in the plastics industry. This product has a structural defect which causes the WPS button, also known as the Push \\"N\\" Connect button, to stick in the ON position. You can tell if yours is stuck if the blue LED in the button is flashing constantly.

The culprit isn't software. It's cheap injection molded parts. If you disassemble the router, the button looks like a flying saucer. Its loosley attached to the to the top of the inside of the router. It flexes when you push the \\"saucer\\" down, activating the WPS. It's a rather complicated flaw, having to do with poor injection mold design. The button is overly complicated. a simpler button would not have had this problem.

I discover it when I went to change my password and it wouldn't let me. It gave me a window that said something like \\"WPS in progress.\\" Now, it takes someone actively try and connect to your router for there to be a problem. All the same I highly recomend a more secure alternative.

The Lenovo Netbook ideapad S10-2 has great visual appeal and a nice ticket price, but when you dig a little deeper it's not as favorable.  The small size makes it very portable and easily handled, but because it's so miniature (0.44 lbs) there is no CD/DVD drive.  This can be frustrating when you want to download a CD onto iTunes or watch a DVD on your computer.  Watching videos on the internet can also be a problem because of the computer's slow speed. A short YouTube clip works fine, but a full movie will repeatedly stop and load. Pulling up your internet browser can take a while, and if you have too many tabs (approximately five) on the internet it will become unresponsive. The netbook is also too slow to have a Skype conversation, even though there is a camera built in.  The battery power in the computer is quite long lasting, although it takes around three hours to fully charge.  Even though the key board is smaller than a usual laptop's it doesn't feel it at all, but the keys tend to be sticky.   The mouse pad is a little hard to control.  The small screen (10.1\\") does give a nice, crisp picture. Something very important to any middle-schooler looking to buy a computer is how well the speakers project sound, and they are wonderful.  I can hear my song blasting from across the room.  The problems with this computer far outweigh its assets.

First, if you actually read this review please leave a comment.  I would be interested to know if my review were actually read since at the time I am writing this there are about 14k reviews.    I like the battery life but it represents the absolute maximum you might ever get.  I bought scrabble and use a case that has a pull out light and these two items must use up quite a bit of battery life.  As it is recommeneded, I turn off the 3g and wireless when not browsing/downloading.    I read a lot in bed.  With most traditional books the words go down all the way to the bottom of the page which is a problem if you want to pull up your blanket over your chest.  Since the kindle has the keyboard at the bottom the blanket dilemma has been solved.  I know this comment is a bit silly.    I have noticed that the bookstore browser is a bit slow.  I recommend using your computer to find the book you want to read next then just search for it on the kindle then download it.  I do not recommend browsing for books with the kindle.  Somewhat ironically, by the time you get back to your home screen your book is downloaded and ready to be read.      Somewhat interestingly, for your wish list items to appear on your kindle the kindle version of the product must be added to your wish list.  If you are like me, and you made good use of your wish lists before you get your kindle this may be disappointing.  I know there are technical reasons for this but I still wish this was not the case.    The six inch display is fine.  It might sound small but it is the size of most smaller paperbacks.    The screen quality is great.    I have a hunch that the page turn button on the side of the kindle will end up being the least durable part of the kindle but this is just a hunch.    One more thing, you can use your kindle with one hand as long as the kindle is resting on something.  Not needing two hands is nice for a few reasons.
Price it right and it works what more can I say?

I got this case the same day I bought my Kindle Fire at a local retailer. It has been an excellent case and has served me well. I've only had it for perhaps two months, so I haven't had it long enough to see if it withstands the \\"test of time\\", but it shows no sign of wearing out or developing any issues.

One feature that I absolutely love about this case, which I have not seen displayed in any of the pictures for it, is that it really has three landscape positions. The first two are displayed in pictures for the product, where you open the cover, lay it upside down on the table, and fold the Kindle over it to rest in one of the two grooves. The third position I have found is to fold the cover back and tuck it in behind the Kindle, which leaves it in a very secure position midway between the two grooves on the cover. I hope this makes sense. For me it's the perfect angle for playing a game in landscape, or even watching a video.

My one primary complaint, and the ONLY reason I am replacing it now (as well as the only reason I haven't given it a five star rating) is the issue others have mentioned. With the Kindle fully inserted into the case and in the landscape position, the bottom edge becomes difficult to access. I like a suggestion I just read from someone else here, to tuck something like a napkin inside to push the Kindle slightly out. I may go ahead and do that while I wait for my new cover to arrive.

All in all, it's a great cover that I've gotten a lot of use from. However, I'm looking forward to getting my new [[ASIN:B005KDYBIO Kindle Fire Genuine Leather Cover by Marware, Brown]]!

I am confirming that this dongle works on Windows 8.1 with the Sony playstation 4 Dualshock 4 Controller, including touchpad features.

-Windows 8.1 Update Bluetooth 4.0 drivers (this is a RECOMMENDED windows update, so if you only have required automatic updates set, you may have to manually download)
-XBOX360 drivers (may not need for all games)
-DS4Tool version 1.2.1
-Press & hold "Share" and while holding it press & hold "PS" button on DS4 controller

A note on the last point. I would've saved a couple hours of my life if I had just realized how to properly pair the PS4 controller.... Its not as simple as pairing the DS3 controller with the PS3. You have to press and hold 2 buttons (share & PS), and hold them longer than you might think.

The case is excellent when you are using the tablet as a "notebook". The kickstand holds it up securely but if you want to use the Kindle as a tablet the keyboard folds back but is not protected. You end up holding the exposed keyboard in your hands. If you are watching a movie in this way the keyboard is explosed to the surface you place it on. I like the wake up feature but the case is a bit flimsy-- wish it was just a little more secure. There is no danger of the Kindle slipping completely out but it will move within the case. Its hard to complain about a card I bought so cheap with a rebate but here we go...  CONs:  - Media Players (GOM, KMPlayer, Windows Media Player, etc) do not have control over the video playback. No aspect control and no control over placement of the video within its own window.   - The heat sinc seems to get very hot to the touch even without playing games or movies.  - Windows Index Experience elevated just a few points above the onboard video.   - The card could not take advantage of DirectX11 (even thought the Computer system has DX11). The card status shows DirectX10 for some reason.  - The card relies on the Chasis internal fan's air flow to reduce disapate its heat. Make sure your system has a good air flow system.  PROs:  - Very quiet. Not a sound. No fan.   - Easy to install.  - Low Profile card.  - Dirt Cheap especially with a rebate.  - Internet movie streaming improved  - Movie playing improved  COMMENTS:  I don't like the software. It does not have enough software control to set defaults like \\"allow Media players to maniputlate aspect controls\\" or resizing video. Software utilities could use a lot more sophistication even though the card is dirt cheap. Maybe it is there but I could not find it after several hours. And I could not get Windows Aero to work but it may be because my Windows 7 OS needs to be activated. I'm not a game player so no comment except my \\"game graphics\\" in Windows Experience Index moved up from 4.7 to 5.8.   [UPDATE]  I will update if anything changes. I bumped this up to 3 stars because the Aero feature may not be due to the card but my OS.

Over, an OK enclosure. The quality is acceptable, and it is very easy to load. The feet/stands flop around a bit, and barely keep the drive from tipping if you want it on it's side as shown in the photo (the photo doesn't show the feet extended.) Internally, the electronics are bare-minimum. No wires for connecting, the drive just slides into a fixed position.

One thing to consider, the chipset in this enclosure has some difficulty with some Linux configurations, causing a known bug with UAS. You can disable UAS on just that single UUID, but it still causes a lot of funny behavior on the system, including kernel OOPS. I would not recommend this drive for Linux users.

i am not a computer geek... er... not any more. i gave that up. i'm a born again USER that is sick of tech BS and just wants to get things done with my tools. However, i bought this thermal paste for my last computer build. That build was a disaster (replaced the motherboard several times, along with the memory, due to motherboard compatibility as the motherboard changed), but none of that disaster was caused by this thermal paste. The CPU was fine and is still fine. So the paste obviously does what it's supposed to do.

i do not over clock my machine. i have no idea if this paste is better or worse than any other thermal paste. i should give it a three star rating because i don't have any idea how i could honestly claim it to be better than average, but i decided that would be unfair to the product. A three star rating is middle of the road, average satisfaction, and may drag its overall rating down. Do i do that just because i don't know if this paste is better or ... less better... than any other thermal paste?

This is a mid range laptop from a mid range company. Toshiba is a great home laptop and not meant to be a "excellent" power laptop. You get a good affordable laptop. 8GB of memory is great and a 750GB hard drive is too. I have read reviews how it locks up and slow, I will agree with that. But the reason I found was the memory swap file was set to auto (let windows manage it) and it was using 1,7gb swap file. BIG NONO. Set it to a custom size and set it to 12GB to 20GB and whoohoo, it works much better. It has a little bloatware on it, I was able to remove the useless Wild Tangent games and a few other bloatware items and it runs well. Have been running it for a week now and no issues. I also own an HP quad core I7 with 16gb ram, a high end HP laptop and obviously you get what you pay for. Also looked at other similar laptops, but they were either more money or they could not expand beyond 8gb of memory. Having the option to expand up to 16gb is great. The battery life is low, but have not truly tested that out yet. For the price and its features, this is a good laptop. I have used all kinds and brands of laptops over the years, so I know what to look for and what works, I recommend the laptop.

I've been using this mouse for several days now, and so far I like it. Would I recommend it? It depends on how you use it.

* It requires a mouse pad. I tried it on a couple of plain desktop surfaces at home and at work. The thing was horrible without a pad. I've used some rinky-dink Microsoft optical mice without mousepads just fine. Not sure what's up with those one. I don't mind using a pad. It works wonderfully with one.

* As others have mentioned, that scroll wheel is a little tough to click. I don't click my scroll wheel often, so I like how I don't accidentally click the scroll wheel while scrolling as sometimes happens on other mice. But, for the few times that I use it, it's not too bad.

* The wheel does give some resistance when scrolling. I can see how some would not care for this. I like it, but it is different and it does take a little bit to get used to. After I increased the scroll speed in the Windows mouse settings, it seemed natural to me.

* The feel of the mouse is great. I like the contours and the weight is good. It feels solid.

* I've usually found side buttons on mice to be awkward. I generally don't use them. This one is in a good spot and feels good to click. It's a nice position for my thumb to reach, yet I don't find myself accidentally clicking it. It's going to be useful.

* The mouse buttons are very quiet. I can't stand loud clicky mice. Some people might miss the feedback.

* Scrolling the wheel is completely smooth and silent. You might prefer the little notches that you feel as you scroll on most other mice. I like the quiet and I don't miss the sensation that I'm scrolling over something that feels like rumble strips on the road.

* The price is great.

It's not perfect, but it has the nice comfortable feel that I was looking for without spending a lot of money.

This review comes from someone who has a 10 something year old version of these. The sub gave up the ghost awhile back, maybe a year ago, but the satellites still rocked. Decided I wanted to get some low end thump back and picked up another set last week.

Boy what a difference in quality of sound. The sub still brings it but the satellites just flat out suck. No amount of break in is going to alleviate the drop off in sound quality (though I'm going to give them a few more days before dealing with the after Christmas crowd). None. For folks that don't know what these used to bring to the table and find the sound adequate you don't know what you are missing. These puppies used to rock. In Point of fact my old sats make the new ones nothing more than desk top speakers that sound simply "ok". Again, you don't know what you are missing...

These used to be speakers that could get you into trouble with the neighbors (and my old ones still have that capacity). Very disappointed at this point. Really didn't want to go with a sub woofer but I "knew" I was going to get something familiar so I went for it. Not the case.

Some stuff sounds "okay" but it really doesn't even come close when making a direct comparison. I had to disconnect and reconnect several times to confirm...these sound horrible. Sorry folks, but they do. Maybe some others with previous experience have had better results but mine really just suck. Plain and simple. Not even two shades of white difference, this is black and white.

Kind of sad I had to write such a bad review...they used to be such a stellar product I would have fully endorsed and used to tell people about them all the time. I cannot recommend these at all other than "desktop" status. If that is all you are looking for then the price doesn't warrant the purchase.

I bought this so that my wife and I could share a printer (an HP Color LaserJet).  I installed it on my computer, and I could print.  I'm fairly happy fiddling around with computers, and pretty confident.  But I find the documentation dreadful, and can't make this work with two machines.    The next day my computer wouldn't print. It says 'printing', but nothing ever comes out.  I wanted to print something, so I thought I'd set it up on my wife's computer.  The documentation that comes with it assumes you are setting it up for the first time, each time you use it - it doesn't tell you how to install so a second computer can print.  I downloaded the drivers instead, ran them - it seems to work, it says that the printer is there, and can see it, but it can't install the printer - when I try, it says 'please connect your printer and make sure it is switched on'.  The network print server says that the printer is connected and ready.    So I turned off that computer, and went back to mine, to try again.  I try to connect, but it says that the printer driver is occupied by 'Computer 2', so I can't connect. Computer 2 is off!!!    Either I'm missing something obvious, or this has the world's worst documentation, or it just doesn't work.  Whichever it is, this seems like a waste of money to me.

I purchased this router in Nov of 2011 after reading several industry reviews stating that it was the best out there. I was impressed with the initial speed boosts on my network, but I have found that it is more trouble than it's worth to keep running. The router has frequent disconnects to the various machines around my home. I recently manually selected a broadcast channel instead of using 'auto', and that temporarily improved functionality. Low speeds and frequent disconnects have returned and it just won't play nice with some machines on my network (a Macbook Pro in particular). I replaced a Linksys WRT54G with DD-WRT with this router, and I think it's time to go back to what worked before.

The firmware notification feature in the router console is nice, and I have been keeping up with firmware releases. However, they don't seem to have addressed any of the issues that I'm seeing. If it's too late to return this router, I'll try putting an opensource firmware on it and will find out if it's a hardware or software issue. I'll report back with my findings if I do load an alternate firmware.

In summary, save your money and buy something else. This is the most I've ever forked over for a router and I had high expectations. It didn't even come close to comparing with the Linksys 54G wireless routers that you can get off of ebay for $40.

As much as i love my iPad, i make no excuses for the on-screen keyboard. It sucks. It just plain sucks. It's hard to type on for a zillion different reasons.

Until now, i've carried around a spare bluetooth keyboard for when i expect to have to jot down more than three words. I've done NaNoWriMo for a few years with that set-up. It works, but it's not elegant.

This... well, ok, 'elegant' may be going too far, but it's simple and easy. Built-in magnets hold the case closed when you're not using it, and hold the iPad up into laptop-screen-position when you are (look ma, no kickstand!). Further, the keyboard only powers up when the positioning magnets are engaged, so you have the on-screen keybaord when you need it, and you're not draining keyboard power unless you are positioned to type (or watch a movie...).

There are a lot of ads out there these days for two-in-ones that just look so dreadfully clunky, i'm at a loss for why someone who prefers to mac environment would get one of those instead of just getting this case.

And yes, it just about doubles the thickness and weight of your iPad. Because it's a case and a keyboard, not magic. And yes, it's a little on the small side. If you have plus-sized hands, you may have trouble with it. My hands are narrow, and i still occasionally hit the enter key instead of the ' key. And i can't find any way to see the current battery level of the keyboard.

But it's better than hauling around a laptop.
