I would have given him a 4 or even a 5, but there was some technical information withheld: it did not specify whether or not it had a manual/optical or digital zoom. Technical specs were very scarce, general and generic. Had I not been in a hurry and had more time to do research, I would have gone with a different option for the same price or for a few more dollars. That mistake would not have occurred, if a sufficient BASIC info was provided. But it appears, as if it was withheld intentionally. I needed something simple and cheap for a temporary situation, but the camera didn't even qualify for that. I AM USUALLY (ALMOST ALWAYS) VERY GENEROUS WITH MY REVIEWS — you can look them up, but here it is walking the thin line between ethical and unethical. It manages to stay honest and ethical, but, just like in the phrase "I swear to tell the truth, the whole truth, and nothing, but the truth", the seller dropped off the part that says "the WHOLE truth". It is a gimmick and it works on trusting people like me, but it makes me feel taken advantage of. I think this is my first negative review, and the more I write the angrier I get. So, I better stop. I will continue to hope that the seller will become a better person and start telling the whole truth.

I am an avid reader, my wife does not drive and I do not shop so I wait in the car and read. It is sturdier, and takes advantage of the new system to lock into the case, unlike this cover which relies on inconveniently located straps. This cover is a bit floppy (from the softness of the leather), and i prefer the bit of rigidity built into the Amazon cover.

Get the basic Amazon leather cover, which announces the Kindle on the front. This one, embossed with the Cole Haan brand, screams \\"pretentious overspender\\". Spend the extra $70 on content for your Kindle.

I purchased this for my wife as a birthday present.  I have not used it extensively myself but I did use it when I set it up for her so I know a bit about how it works.  This laptop is very light.  I have a competitor's convertible ultrabook and this is a lot lighter.  The keyboard is also much better than mine, and in fact you would be hard pressed to find a better keyboard.  The screen is smaller than mine but is very sharp.  On the other hand mine is just a tad larger and I think mine has a slightly better screen.  This computer is very fast booting in seconds as opposed to her previous laptop that took forever to boot.  She likes it so much that she's started to take it with her on occasions where she would have taken her iPad.  She hasn't used it much as a tablet yet but I think over time she will.  The bottom line though is that she seems to like it a lot.  The screen is smaller than the 15.6" she used to use but she says this is big enough.  I would say it comes very close to being the perfect convertible ultrabook.  So why did I give it a 4 out of 5 stars?  I was a bit upset over the setup of this laptop.  When I set this up for my wife the very first problem I had was setting up the Internet connection.  This is generally pretty easy but I could not get it to work.  I called Dell and ultimately it ended up that the driver for the WIFI card was not up to date.  Really? Then I had to download the updated driver on another laptop to a USB drive to try to load on this computer.  Guess what?  The USB port would not recognize the USB drive I put in the computer.  You guessed it, the driver for the USB port was not up to date.  Ultimately I was able to force the laptop to recognize the USB drive, download the WIFI driver and get onto the Internet.  From that point I could resolve all my other problems by downloading all the latest drivers.  Also, I did deal with a very helpful and friendly support person from Dell.  I know I've heard of people having issues with Dell support people but in this case I found a good one.  She stayed on the phone with me for as long as it took.  But my real question is, why would Dell release a laptop or any other computer to the general public that would not work as currently configured?  This is just clearly unacceptable and they need to change this.  I don't mind playing around with this kind of thing because that's what I was paid to do for years but if my wife had had to do this herself she would have been bald and probably committed before she figured it all out.  So Dell, you have to do better than this.  You can make all of the great hardware you want to but if someone can not plug this in, go through the step by step instructions and have something work, you're not going to sell a lot of product.
For the price the product is good it's does it suppose to do I would buy another if I had to again.

So I've had this motherboard Since July of 2012. For the most part, it's been okay. BIOS wasn't always the best, and it took them about a year before they released the UEFI update (which made things better.) UEFI made things better, boot times faster and definitely more pleasing. However, about 8 months ago, The BIOS started to randomly corrupt, going through a 3 minute shutdown, reboot process. I thought nothing of it, just updated the main BIOS to UEFI and continued. This kept happening every 3-4 weeks, at most, until it now no longer boots. Looks like it's dead. Save yourself the hassle, and just spend a little more on a better board.

I will start with the case.

The case itself is decent. It's a little cramped inside for space but considering the fact that it was intended to be a small PC form factor for a home theater setup or for a light weight, discrete home/office PC, it's not bad. If you don't install a disc drive inside, space won't be a concern. If I were able to give just the case a star review rating, I would give it a 3.5 out of 5 stars.

Now for the power supply.
This power supply was dead on arrival. The model of this power supply was an "Allied AL-8250SFX." Unfortunately, I should have read reviews from others about this power supply because most reviewers have been mostly negative about it. I tested it myself but for extra precaution, I took it to my local computer hardware store to confirm it was bad. The store confirmed it was dead and I had to return it. Although, I wasn't troubled with the case, I had to return the case as well with the bad supply. If I could give just this supply a star rating, I would give it 1 out of 5 stars because I couldn't use it.

Luckily, amazon's return system went really well and I received my refund quickly. To anyone looking at buying this item, I would recommend the case but invest in another PSU.

I ordered the Chromebook because my laptop crashed and I needed something to replace it for school. I don't have very much money but all I needed was something to write essays, do research and submit online assignments with.  -Touch pad is erratic and unreliable The first issue was that the touch pad is extremely sensitive. When I place one finger on the pad and stay as perfectly still as possible, the pointer jumps around in about a 3-inch area surrounding where I am trying to direct it. Sometimes it works better than others. But at times it has taken me up to 3 minutes to click on something, even after rebooting and troubleshooting the Chromebook. This makes it very difficult to get work done.  Some other drawbacks are that... -Netflix is not supported -You can only play video games supported by Google chrome -Google knows EVERYTHING you do -The integrated webcam sucks & most other webcams can't be used with the chromebook because google chrome doesn't support their software. -I have yet to find an alarm clock that will wake the system up from sleep -Microsoft word isn't supported  Perhaps my touch pad is defective. If this is the case then I'd recommend using Chromebook only as a second "computer".  I will say it's good at booting up quickly and surfing the web just as fast. It's a cool idea but it's not working for me. I recommend a tablet w/ attachable keyboard over this. You can find them for about the same price. I wish I'd done that.  Update: Luckily, Amazon Prime Warehouse has great customer service and a good return policy. I returned my presumably defective Chromebook for a full refund. They even paid return shipping. If you think yours might be defective, just return it and mark it as defective.

Just received the case today. It fits tightly around the iPad and looks like it'll provide adequate protection if one is careful. I did find one glaring "glitch". The Lightning connector works great if you're using a Lightning CABLE. If you're using an Apple Lightning to 30-pin ADAPTER then the opening is far too narrow and it simply will not fit. The iPad has to be removed from the case to use the adapter. This will certainly cause stress on the corners that keep the case tight and will likely, over time, cause them to crack. I rated it OK because of this. The problem can be fixed with a few minutes work using a Dremel tool. If not for this, it's a 5-star product.

Bought this higher capacity battery hoping it would give me more time on my laptop.  However, it runs the same time as the OEM batter that has a lesser capacity.  I just now have a spare backup supply.

Hardware:
The design of the iPad is exceptional with smooth curved edges and elegant textures of soft-touch metal. One problem that is apparent and has been stated multiple times is the weight of the device. It is too heavy to hold comfortably with one hand and the wrist may feel sore or achy after long periods of use. At the time of release, the screen was good enough for the average person to use. However, now with HD screens on devices less than half the size, the iPad's screen is seeming to pale in comparison. In addition, the battery life is quite exceptional. It lasts for weeks in Standby mode and also for long duration while reading or watching movies. Another point is that the cameras on the device are extremely poor, the resulting pictures looking too pixelated to view. You can forget about low-light shooting, because of a lack of flash and a poor image sensor.
Software:
iOS has always been a novel user interface, not for the unlimited functions, but for the extremely easy to use USER INTERFACE. Heck, I have seen kids not even 2 years old who know how to unlock and play their favorite games on the devices. The app store offers an abundance of games, and \\"productivity\\" apps. However, these productivity apps are not that easy to use. Lots of fonts supported by Microsoft Word do not work on these apps and the formatting is often completely messed up when transitioning from my laptop to the iPad. Apple needs to get Microsoft to build a preloaded app that will be accessible from other places in the OS.

Overall:
It's hard to recommend a product which is primarily limited to games, but if you're looking for an entertainment device, I would recommend the iPad 3 or 4 which have better graphics, a better processor, and a better screen. For the price, this is a good buy.

This review is for the Nextbook Premium 7SE tablet, running Android 4.0 with a Cortex A8 processor.

First off, the specs:

7 inch Capacitive touch screen
800x480 pixel resolution
RK2918 A8 Cortex chipset/processor, 1 GHz
512 MB ram DDR3
Over the air update capable
4 GB memory
0.44 inch thin
MicroSD compatible, easy setup
GetJar app market (NOT Google Play compatible, however it IS compatible with Amazon's appstore)
2 MP frontal camera
Preloaded Barnes & Noble bookstore and eBook reader
Includes speakers, headphone port and microphone on the back
Adobe Flash capable and bundled
Includes AC adapter, USB cable and a \\"protective\\" pouch (translation: cheap, fabric bag)

As you can see, not too shabby for a budget tablet. I WOULD have bought the Kindle Fire, but I just use tablets for reading and the occasional Angry Birds boredom session, so the tradeoff is fair enough for me. Now for the pros:

-Excellent screen quality. Images are clear, video playback and streaming so far works great and transitions are near-flawless with the occasional hiccup.
-Super thin and light. This tablet is very easy to carry and almost weightless, which is a nice bonus for people who don't like heavy things. I prefer them to be a bit heavier (they feel more secure) but I didn't mind the size here.
-Runs graphics heavy apps like Angry Birds Space perfectly, and most apps work great.
-Its default browser is surprisingly capable in my opinion and offers competition against Dolphin HD. Haven't had one issue with it.
-WiFi connection is easy to set up and the start up wizard is competent.
-If I'm correct, you can use this as a webcam on your computer, but I have yet to try this function.
-Unlike what most reviews in other product pages say, this product IS compatible with a USB keyboard and mouse. Last I heard (I have yet to try it, will update when I do so), it'sa matter of:

1) Go to Settings
2) USB Connection
3) Change to Host Mode and try plugging in the Keyboard

That's it. It has to pick it up.

Now for the cons, most of which are surprisingly minor:

-Speaker quality is decent but could be better. Audio comes out tinny at times. For what I use it, it works, but I'd prefer using headphones. Their location as well is cumbersome and makes my hands cover them unconsciously.
-Lack of a dedicated menu button and other standard buttons. How they were not included is beyond me. This might cause issues with apps like Kindle (latest version) where the Menu icon is strangely gone, making the Menu and settings inaccessible. However, you can install Kindle for 2.1 Android and you'll have no problems.
-Kobo's bookstore compatibility is absolutely non-existent. No books ever download, and this reader IS compatible with .epub format- it brought 25 books bundled in, courtesy of the Gutenberg Project. Why Kobo refuses to work here is beyond me.
-The Android version on this thing is severely restricted and locked down. You'll see what I mean. Depending on who you ask, you might have to root it. I, however, haven't seen the need to do so.
-Awkward plug placement, like Headphone jack and power jack.
-No Bluetooth functionality. It's to be expected, and I didn't mind, but the lack of the option is... well, annoying.
-Reset button is located RIGHT WHERE THE MICROPHONE IS LOCATED. And it's so small, you need either a paper clip or a mechanical pencil to press the Reset button if the tablet freezes... which will be very rare, if not never.
-You can't charge this with the USB cable- you can only charge it with its included AC adapter. Wat. :|
-The camera quality is... horrendous. Use it either as a backup (this despite it being 2 MP) or as a makeshift webcam. Then again, that's not what I bought it for.
-\\"Protective pouch\\" included is simply inexcusable. This was a major gripe with me. Its cheap quality is so cheap, I can't even close the bag right! They should have at least included a folio case or something.

Final verdict: Despite this being sold as a \\"budget tablet\\", I have to say that this rivals the Kindle Fire or even the Nexus at least. This is NOT an iPad, or even a Galaxy Tab, despite it being so functional. But for what you pay, the tradeoff and value are amazing! If you need a good tablet but don't want to waste a lot of money, go with this one. It's a very nice deal with incredible value for the money. I've had it for about a week now, and I haven't had any problems.

The XBOX 360 chat cable didn't work out of the box. I registered my product on their web site and sent in an online support ticket for a replacement part. I got no feedback from Tritton for 2 weeks. I emailed my request in after waiting 2 weeks and received a reply that the replacement part would ship. 4 weeks later I still didn't have it so I called in. There was no record of my trouble ticket or my email. I made a verbal request for a replacement part over the phone and was told that I would receive a replacement cable within 2 weeks. 2 Weeks went by and no replacement. I have since made 2 more phone calls to Tritton at 1-week intervals trying to get a replacement part and each time I call I am told the part is either back-ordered, or has already shipped and I should receive it in a week.    Don't buy anything from these people. If their products fail they will not honor their warranty. I am giving them one more week before pursing a resolution with the San Diego better business bureau.

1) the constant ad's. I know I can pay to have this feature removed but I don't feel I should have to pay an additional fee for an ad free screen.

2) That the screen saver is either blank or an ad. There are no settings in which to use a saved and treasured picture as screen saver.

3) lastly, that there isn't a settings feature to set "desk top" preferences.

Overall the quality is great. I would not have paid more than what I did at the promo price of $159. I guess I had hoped it had more features that fall in line with a tablet. Now I just have one more item to fit in my already heavy bag.

Great purchase as long as you fully understand what you are getting. I'd be content if there were no ad's and settings options.

I wanted to replace a Microsoft Wireless Desktop 6000 with this one, because some of the keys on my old keyboard are worn out and sometimes get stuck, especially the space and Ctrl keys. The Wireless Desktop 2000 does not live up to my expectations. I am a programmer of 25 years and while not a formally trained typist, I can get things done with a good keyboard. I am really struggling with this one. The biggest issues:

- The layout is cramped: the numeric and cursor blocks are adjacent to the main keyboard without any space in between. I sometimes miss the space between the backspace and insert keys, and the right Ctrl and the cursor left keys. The keyboard feels a bit tight and I make a lot of typing errors. This is the most frustrating issue.
- The F(unction) keys are tiny, are slightly more to the right than usual, and difficult to find without looking. The F labels are small and difficult to read. On the other hand, the multimedia keys above the F keys are gigantic in comparison, and I hardly ever use them.
- The wireless transmitter does not sit on the desktop like the old one, but is plugged directly into the USB port of the computer under the desk. Sometimes keys are swallowed, even though the batteries are new and I replaced them once, just to be sure. Other reviewers seem to observe this problem as well. The battery status LED on the keyboard sometimes lights up even with new batteries. Maybe this is related.
- There is no mute button for the speakers. I can turn the volume down all the way, of course, but most other keyboards have a separate mute button.
- The general tactile feel of the keys is of lower quality.

I have no issues with the mouse. It feels solid.

I am having real productivity issues with this keyboard and will pass it on to another family member or maybe a media PC. I will switch back to my old keyboard while I look for a better replacement.r />I am having real productivity issues with this keyboard and will pass it on to another family member or maybe a media PC. I will switch back to my old keyboard while I look for a better replacement.

Can't beat it for the price. It works and does exactly what the original one from Apple does but with a smaller price tag. Its like buying Kirkland water compared to Fiji. You guys know what I'm talking about.

The good part is that it does extend your network \\"reach\\" after you jump through the hoops configuring it for your wireless network.

The bad part is that it often needs to be rebooted. Sometimes I have to reboot just so my wireless devices can \\"see\\" the extender. If they don't see the extender they try to connect to the primary router which is usually too far away and low (if any) signal strength (that's why you are looking at buying this thing in the first place).

For the times when my devices DO connect to the extender, it seems to work find for about 8 hours or so. That sounds like a lot, but after running for 8 hours the throughput is horrible. Pages load slow, some services can't be found, and other assorted problems start to appear. Unplug the extender and plug it back in... 3 minutes later everything is \\"good as new\\". For another 8 hours.

That really sucks. That means I have to unplug/plug-in the extender in the morning to check email before work, again when I get home from work, and again in the evening if I'm online before bed. What a huge PAIN.

Initial impression of this adapter was positive. Easy installation with XP 32bit and both 32 and 64 bit versions of Windows 7. Upgraded my home network with gigabit ethernet and Wireless N, so this card made a huge difference in performance when I needed to transfer large files such as DVD movies. However, after about a month of use, it started having thermal issues. It was a slow onset with Windows XP where it would warm up over a couple hours of use and eventually lock up. I would have to remove the card and would use a wireless N adapter while this card cooled off. It progressively got worse over a couple of months. I upgraded to Windows 7 and had no problem at all with the install and it seemed to have improved somewhat in that it was taking longer before it got hot enough and stopped working. But, it slowly deteriorated in performance and would overheat a bit faster each time I used it. It finally started having performance issues and would overheat in less than an hour and stop working. Eventually stopped using it, as it was very frustrating having it overheat in less than half an hours use. The locking mechanism eventually wore out and it was difficult to get it to stay seated in the slot. I think it may still be under warranty. I used it in an HP Pavilion dx6650us Centrino Duo laptop. Good luck if you decide to purchase this card!

I bought this backpack with the intention of carrying a laptop (obviously), swayed by the leather bottom that is suppose to make it durable. \\"Fits up to 17-inch laptops\\" it claims. What a bunch of baloney. I see the picture shows a laptop and files and a mouse and all this stuff just jammed in there. Well i got news for you, you COULD jam all that in there, but it sure as hell won't hold up. The stitching on the bottom starts to come off, and the interior pockets are separated by a thin fabric that WILL tear (i got a hole on the inside top of it that i use instead of the front zipper now). Even the strap is beginning to come apart. And this was all within a year. Its about to be a full two years with this backpack (in a couple months), so its held up for quite awhile, but the fact that it tore within the first year is a bit unsettling in my opinion. I would assume it would be better quality.

GETTING TO THE POINT:
Don't get me wrong, its a good backpack, but if you're looking for a long term backpack that is durable, do not even consider this. I wouldn't even recommend carrying a laptop in this. But it is a nice, casual short term backpack if you're interested in it (although for 30 bucks, who would be?)

I've had this card with me on shoots for 4 years now and I am impressed with the reliability of it. I am sure it doesn't see the use like a sports photographer would use it, but it has worked on several weddings, countless portrait sessions, engagement photo sessions, a couple senior prom sessions and it has also been with me on many trips and vacations. Through it all this card captured many memories, and stored them reliably.

Back when I got this it was considered a huge storage device, and I figured for my Canon EOS 30D it would be more than enough. I wasn't let down, it still allows me to shoot almost endlessly on my EOS 30D, yet now looking at the 1Ds mk III or the 5D mk II (both 21MP cameras) this card is on the low end of the card sizes. Still, I am confident this card will record reliably the memories to come with my future purchase.

Now I just need to get more of these, and being as reliable as they have been (I also own a 4GB and two 2GB Lexar Pro cards) I can rest assured I'll get what I paid for... maybe more.

Love my new Amazon Kindle Fire HDX 8.9. From the reviews, I see there are no exceptional solutions to the cover problem. So I thought I’d save time and order three different ones and then choose the best. Unfortunately, it’s choosing the best of the losers. I purchased the Amazon Standing Leather Origami case (this is leather?), the Fintie Folio case, and the ProCase Flip Stand Leather Folio Cover with stylus pen (I do like using the stylus).
The Fintie says it’s made from durable synthetic leather, which must be pleather because that’s what it feels like. So it’s a cheaper non-leather version ($15) of the non-leather ProCase Folio ($23) which uses premium synthesized leather and at least looks and feels like leather. So out of these two, the ProCase wins. The ProCase comes with a stylus pen although the Fintie does have a loop if you purchase your own stylus. They both operate/fold in the same way. However, I was hoping the ProCase would be my keeper because of the elastic hand strap. I thought this would be my ticket to solving the issue some many have written about in holding the Kindle while ready in bed. It’s not. The weight of the Kindle causes floppiness and so the front flap (with Kindle in it) and back flap (with hand in it) can’t meet and be together as one. Also, it’s not that comfortable because your hand would have to be angled like when one is actually reading a book, it’s not perfectly horizontal.
So I’m choosing the Origami ($70!) because it does stand well on a table both vertically and horizontally and it’s slim. I like all the other features other reviewers have mentioned. It does nothing to solve the reading in bed or anywhere else problem, that isn’t a table or desk. It also will not be a protective case. I hope some new choices become available soon.

I'm just your average person who has photos and other data that I don't want to lose. From that perspective this is a pretty cool device.  It has very large storage capacity that I can't imagine ever filling up, and it was easy to set up and do my first back up. I followed the quick start guide and it all happened pretty quickly. I just checked and all my data is there and easily accessible. I obviously can't speak to its longevity since I have only been using it for a few weeks but I was recently told by and IT guy that all hard drives WILL fail at some point. I just experienced this with our old external hard drive and its a horrible feeling.  I had to pay a RIDICULOUS amount of money to have all our lost photos etc  retrieved and am very wary about the whole idea of putting all my eggs in only one back up location again. Seriously! How many places should precious data be stored before a person can feel confident it won't be lost inexplicably and with no warning? I obviously need to back up my back ups to some form of online service in addition to the drive, but where does it end? But I digress. This device seems perfectly fine. Does what it says on the box. Looks good on the desk. It's quite large and weighs a couple of pounds so it doesn't qualify as a portable device in my opinion.

On the positive side, the over all build quality was very satisfactory! This is a very powerful machine compared to most of the competition, though a lil pricy. Couldn't complain about the hardware in the least (ok, after 3 months of use there was a minor creak in the case, nothing to cry about though)

As for negatives:

The ambient light sensor is in a very poor location (top left besel, as can be seen in the photo) This causes the screen to randomly dim if you place your hand wrong. Placing the brightness on manual takes care of this.

Windows 7 is not touch screen friendly whatsoever! But that can be fixed with an update to 8.

Also, Samsung's crapware is atrocious! It serves no useful function, except eat up precious hard drive space. Once again, an update to 8 fixes this.

Over all, though, I've been extremely pleased with this machine, both in school and at home on the couch. It's now outdated, but i wouldnt think twice about springing for a newer model by Samsung!

Logitech has interesting features on their web cams, but the software that supports it has serious problems. First of all, the Logitech software significantly slows down your computer. The device drivers and other associated software runs continuously--even when the web cam is not in use! To see this for yourself (if you have one), open up Task Manager (or download Process Explorer from Microsoft) and watch the CPU usage of their applications. In addition to occupying the computer's CPU for no reason, when the software is running (doing nothing) it is forcing other applications that you ARE using to be kicked out of the CPU's cache--the high-speed memory that is inside the CPU. This means that the other programs have to wait to be reloaded from main memory back into the CPU when they do finally get to run.    Second, the software has a large memory footprint. In other words, it is a memory hog. It occupies 32MB of memory when the camera is not in use. This is a totally ridiculous waste of memory.    Finally, their software is buggy. It has caused multiple \\"Blue Screens of Death\\" on my computer. That is, the BSoD screen actually lists the Logitech driver as the cause of the crash.    All in all, the hardware is nice, but it is totally worthless without software that works without totally destroying all computing power, especially when the camera is not being used.    I recommend AGAINST using not only this specific web camera, but ANY web camera from Logitech as their software has common components, so you are likely to see problems in other web cam drivers from them.

No one device will fit everyone's needs, and most of the heavily negative comments I've heard about the Fire are of the \\"it should have come with ...\\" nature. Many of the more vitriolic appear not to have done any pre-purchase research, as they're stunned to find a feature missing when they try to use it. With a few exceptions the Fire does what it says it will, and does it well. The key is making sure it will do what you're looking for in a small tablet.  As far as features the Fire does not have which others have criticized it for, I personally have no need for 3G, cameras, GPS, or parental controls of any sort. Bluetooth might have been neat, but the lack wasn't a deal breaker for me. What came closest to making it a no-buy for me was the lack of an SD card slot. There are ways around the relatively limited memory (shuffling files between the Fire, a computer, and the cloud, etc.) but with the very large number of .MP3s I have alone it would have been far more convenient to carry a couple of SD cards and swap on the fly (and that doesn't begin to touch on video). I won't go into the reasons why Amazon should/should not add/not add any given feature, as those are being discussed to death already. As I note above, research your purchase and see if it has the features you consider `must-haves' before buying, since what is critical to you may mean nothing at all to someone else.  Speaking of what it does have, there are a few flaws in the Fire's implementation of things. First and foremost is the lack of ability to create collections for ebooks. All your books show up in one contiguous bookcase with no ability to categorize or segregate. Also, there is no ability to read the book description and customer reviews from within the book or bookcase ; you must go back into the store and look up the title. Since I've been on a free book binge for a while now I have several hundred titles in my To Be Read pile, and while the Fire does show covers, the inability to quickly look up a description makes the Fire a clear secondary choice to my Kindle Keyboard as a reading device. This is something many are hoping will be addressed in a future software patch.  Also, while Amazon touted cloud storage space when trying to lessen the impact of the Fire's small(ish) on-board storage space, apart from music the cloud operates more as off site storage than a streaming content source. Pictures and other files can be stored on the cloud, but to effectively be used you need to download them to the Fire in one of a few different ways. Given how seamless the integration of .MP3s is (even .MP3s not purchased from Amazon) it's quite surprising that the non-.MP3 integration is so clunky. Again, something that it is hoped will be addressed in a future patch.  There have been reports of owners having other issues which I've never come across : difficulty connected to a WiFi network, blank/missing pages in some titles, fast battery run down, etc. I can't speak to those as those problems never arose for me. Given the huge number of units sold it's no surprise that there will be rough spots here and there.  In the end I decided to return the Fire, not for any flaw in the unit itself, but that it ended up not filling a need. It did pretty much exactly what I was expecting to, and did most of that exceedingly well, but I found that it fell into a niche of `neat to have, not needed'. And this would hold true for any device in its class (e.g. the Lenovo A1, Nook tablet, etc.). I am a bit disappointed that I couldn't justify the purchase in the end, as it really is a wonderful little device, and the price/liberal return policy at Amazon is hard to beat.  Read what the device has and doesn't have, think about what you're going to want it to do and how you'd use it, and decide from there if the Fire fits. If it has the features you want then it is a very well built, well supported device.

I purchased this usb hub for my Mac Mini that only has two usb ports.

The dome looks pretty nice sitting next to the mac mini as it is silver and small.

When I first tried to plug in some usb cables, it was a little tricky since the hub is dome-shaped and you have to plug in the usb cables parallel to the base. It makes you want to plug in a cable downward towards the base instead of parallel to it. But once you figure it out, you get the hang of it. The cables don't come out on their own, they seem to stay in tact.

I was very excited to see that the hub came with a free fly light! It was the first thing I plugged in, but it didn't work! It only flickered on and off. I messed with it and disconnected other usb ports and still nothing. So, that was pretty upsetting.

The hub comes with a power adapter that is the size of a box of crayons, about 2.5\\" long, 3\\" tall, and 2\\" wide. So, you need to make more room on your power strip for that.

I plugged in three usb cables at once and they all work just dandy. The hub was plug and play so I didn't install any drivers. I did read, however, that the hub will disconnect certain ports if one port or more are drawing too much power. I connected my external hard drive, drawing tablet, digital camera cable, and printer/scanner. Worked good for me, nothing turned off.

The manual was a little bare. I wanted to read some more info on the lights on the front of the hub, but it didn't say much about anything in the manual.

There are seven lights on the front of the hub (one for each port). There are six usb ports on the backside of the hub and one usb port on top of the dome. It's very light, but doesn't move around much as it has little feet to keep it in place.

Overall, I think it's a great product especially for the price. Too bad the fly light didn't work though.

Original review: My husband and I love this mouse. Looks cool as well!  Update: I have two of these. They both broke within 8 months of purchase, and even less time of actual use.  The problem with both of these mice has been the scroll wheel. One of them has the most frustrating scroll wheel imaginable - it changes direction of the input rapidly while you're scrolling, making it effectively useless. This defect began to appear after maybe a few months of use, then continued to get worse. The other one simply randomly ceased to work after about six weeks of use. A working scroll wheel is pretty much a necessity for me, so these defects have rendered these mice almost entirely unusable for me.  I wanted to like this mouse, but it sucks. I didn't expect the world for $22, but I expected mice which could be used for more than a few months before either showing signs of wear or breaking entirely. After going through multiple cheap mice in the past year or so, next time I will absolutely invest the extra money into a decent mouse. It pays off in the long run. Up until last year, I had used a Logitech MX518 exclusively for the best part of 5 years - now THAT was ~$40 well spent!  The only reason I didn't give this a 1-star rating is because it looks cool.

Okay, I would like to start by saying I personally did not buy these, a friend of mine bought them for me as a gift.

Now, for starters, the headset itself is good. The sound is clear and smooth, and it feels comfortable after wearing for a couple hours. The mic quality is solid from what people I've talked to on Skype say, and the overall use of the headset is top notch.

However, there are a few things that I had gripes with. The first being that the sound quality is NOT surround sound like advertised. It has a strong base and no way to control that, so listening to music with heavy bass can be a bit ear splitting if you don't turn the volume down. The second and most important grip, is that the headset I received was NOT a "VIPstore" brand, but rather a "SADES" brand. The headset is identical in every way to another product you can find here on Amazon (I won't link to it for courtesy to this seller), and the only different in the images given is that the "SADES" logo was removed from the sides of the headset and USB connector. However, the box that it came in was labeled "SADES", it was in Chinese, and logos that are not in the image, are there.

Overall, the product is a good one and I'd buy it again, but not from this seller, who is clearly selling a different headset than the one listed here, probably at a profit.

Update: December 5, 2010 - I just installed a 120 GB Intel SSD into my laptop computer and what an amazing improvement! It boots up with Windows 7 64-bit OS in a mere 29 seconds. This is just further proof that the Seagate hybrid disk that I received is indeed defective. Now I have enough evidence to return this defective part to Seagate. Original review below:
-------------------------------------------------------------
I did not purchase this drive from Amazon, but I would have if it had been in stock. I installed this 500 GB drive into a relatively new HP laptop computer that came with Windows 7 OS and cost more than $1000. I wrote down the Windows Experience Numbers with the original Fujitsu 5400 RPM hard drive prior to making the swap. Also, I measured the power up and power down times for comparison. I used Acronis Easy Migrate to clone the Seagate Hybrid drive. Before cloning the hard drive, I cleaned the registry and triple defragmented the hard drive to make sure everything was optimized. The system powered up perfectly after swapping the hard drives. I powered up and down several times to give the SSD portion of the hard drive a chance to learn from my usage. I expected Windows 7 to power up faster because my old drive was 5400 RPM and the new one is 7200 RPM. To my surprise, the boot up time was exactly the same as with the 5400 RPM drive! I tested it several more times just to be certain and it was consistent. Well, that was disappointing. So, I reran the Windows Experience test to determine if that was any better. I got the exact same numbers as with the 5400 RPM drive. I double checked to make sure the Seagate drive model number was correct and it was. So theoretically, I do have the correct disk drive in my laptop computer. I cleaned the registry again and I defragmented again. No change in performance.

I am a fairly accomplished electrical engineer and I build my own high end over clocked Intel i7 systems, so I think I know what I am doing. I checked back over at Newegg's reviews and some people had the same experience as I did. And then there are others who say they are getting fantastic improvements. I don't get it. It is as if my Seagate Hybrid drive's SSD section isn't working. I do not know how to test the SSD section since it is buried inside the drive. At least my hybrid drive is very quiet and doesn't vibrate like several people experienced on Newegg. The only parameter that is faster with this new Seagate Hybrid SSD drive is the power down time. Power down is about 15 seconds faster. So at least something is faster.

There was no documentation or installation disk of any kind accompanying this disk drive. I opened the box and there was only the disk drive in an antistatic bag and nothing else. Of course, now Amazon apparently has this disk drive in stock. I am tempted to buy another one from Amazon to see if there is any difference. I have considered returning my hybrid drive to Newegg, but I cannot prove it is defective. After all, it does work -- just no better than my 5400 RPM Fujitsu OEM disk drive. I am clearly disappointed with this disk drive.

UPDATE: July 28, 2010

Today I installed this hybrid SSD based disk drive into a Vista-64 desktop computer versus my new HP laptop computer. Again, there was no improvement in speed whatsoever. This time I took time to measure numerous before and after benchmarks on different applications, and everything was exactly the same as with the original 7200 RPM SATA Seagate disk drive I removed. I opened and closed the applications many times to give the Seagate algorithm opportunity to learn from my usage. I think the SSD portion of the drive is either not working or completely missing. There is no way to determine if it is working or not except by actual usage. I think there is a quality control problem at Seagate and they are shoving these things out of the door without adequate testing. NewEgg customers also have this same experience. I'm going to leave this disk drive in this old desktop computer because it is too much trouble to try to return since I am in Shanghai, China. I will wait for the next version to come out before trying this product again.

This time I used HDClone Version 3.9 software to clone the old drive. Originally I used Acronis. (HDClone costs $44 for a download version. But it is clearly superior to Acronis. The feature I like most about HDClone is disk defragmentation on the fly. This way you are guaranteed to have perfect defragmentation as the new disk is being written. Also, it allows you numerous more options on partition sizing and partition to disk copying. But it is more complicated to use.)

I think this Seagate SSD hybrid drive is hit or miss. Either you get one that works or you don't. I firmly believe the disk I received has a non-functioning SSD. About the only benefit from this exercise has been that I have become a near expert in cloning disk drives.his same experience. Verified Purchase(What's this?)
This review is from: AAC-X4 Desktop Computer - 3.8GHz Quad Core Processor (Bulldozer) 8GB DDR3 RAM 1,000GB (1TB) HDD (Personal Computers)
Mixed feelings over this product. For it's price, the specifications are outstanding. But I'm not sure of the component quality and I'm less than happy with the much touted 3 year warranty.

Within a few months of purchase, the sound system started acting buggy. The PC is connected to a TV via HDMI. In order for the audio to pass to the TV, the TV had to be turned on for a few minutes prior to the PC being powered on. Checked the cable, TV HDMI input by using another PC and it is definitely something to do this product. Emailed support and was met with a "never heard of this before, did you try a different cable? Type of response. Decided to just always turn in the TV first as a work around.

About 1.5 years along, the HDMI has gone out all together and a fan sounds like its about to die. Did all the normal trouble shooting. - ie changing cable, different HDMI input choice, different PC, etc and it's definitely this machine. Opened it up to see if I could just replace HDMI - nope, it's part of either the mother board or card. Not sure as I didn't dig around as I didn't want to void the warranty and I'm not a computer whiz so none of this is instinctive.

Contacted support and was told to use an air can to blow out the fan as that's usually the problem with fan issues. And for the HDMI problem, Aaron told me that I'd have to reformat the entire machine since it's probably a bad driver. When I responded with, "no, that's not normal process for a corrupted driver." Aaron insists that I have to reformat the entire machine first.

Um, no.

So, if you need a cheap no name PC that works decently for 1.5 years, this will be fine. I'll use it as a backup machine until it dies as the VGA connection works fine.

For HTPC (always on and used 16 hours a day) it didnt work for us.

I was looking for a specific board that had 6x SATA 6gb/s ports, and 4 RAM slots. This board fit the bill. I was weary though looking at reviews on newegg. Apparently this board had BIOS issues for a little while. I can't say that I've seen any of the issues they're seen.

The board itself is well made with a rather thick PCB. It is thicker than cheaper boards. ASUS usually makes quality boards. RAM, CPU install and installation into my case were trouble free. I have 6 SATA drives and a 380w PSU driving this board and it hasn't complained one bit.

The only gripe is the On-board NIC - Realtek is a cheap chip-set and would have preferred an Intel chip-set for the gigabit ethernet. Luckily the 8111G has been around long enough for Linux support.

WOW! As awesome as this thing was and how excited as it was when I first installed it, I am blown away how something with so many useful features could be such a piece of garbage! But, that's just a result of no quality control. First time I booted my PC up after installing, no audio devices would work, except the headphone port in the "Media Dashboard", the Realtek audio manager showed that both mic and headphone jacks on the unit had something plugged into them, when they most certainly did NOT. No big deal though, just unplugged front panel audio, it's not like I ever use it anyway and my mic is built into my webcam. USB ports worked fine and felt really secure and sturdy, which I liked, but when I tested the card reader it said every Micro SD HC/XC card I tried was "Write Protected", but blowing out the card slots fixed that and all was good, which is weird enough. I then proceeded to test the IDE/SATA ports, (hard drives used: Maxtor MaxLine III, 250GB, SATA 1, Seagate Barracuda 7200.7, 40GB, IDE/ATA), the first time I plugged the drives in, (not at the same time, of course) they worked like a charm, Windows picked them both up as soon as they initialized, read/write speeds were great, and it seemed like a really cool little gadget, it also looked really good in my case!
Later that day... I went to go pull some data off the 40GB before it was to be formatted and its Operating System reinstalled on the PC it belonged to, I plugged the IDE cable into the drive and unit, plugged the power cord into the unit, then into the hard drive, but as soon as I flipped the switch to turn on the power to the hard drive, smoke came off the circuit board on the hard drive, filled the room with "magic" smoke (Hey! You let the magic smoke out, idiot!) and that familiar smell that lets you know "you're f*cked", my PC also instantly shut off as the power supply's short circuit protection kicked in. (Thank God for that!)
I immediately unplugged the hard drive, took it out of its caddy and found the baked circuit. I then unplugged my PC from everything and removed the unit, wishing I could smash it as I removed it, (too bad you have to return the unit in one piece for a refund! Erg!) I'm just glad my PC still boots and everything still works, thanks to that short circuit protection! Oh, it also fried the unit as I plugged it into a device that converts a wall adapter to a molex adapter and NO lights would come on, but when I first received the unit I tested it using the same adapter and it worked fine, so it's not the adapter's problem, and there weren't any pins touching metal, or the PCB of the hard drive touching any metal either, that would make it completely my fault, when it is, indeed the unit's fault.
To wrap it all up, don't buy this unit unless you want to risk the life/health of your PC and any hard drives you plug into it, I'm also concerned if it damaged any of the Micro SD HC/XC cards I put into the card reader (SanDisk 32GB Class 10/UHS-1, PNY 64GB Class 10/UHS-1)
I'm glad to say I got my refund almost as soon as I shipped it back, but what about the hard drive and data it took along with it? Which I mentioned to them!
Thank you for reading, I am glad to share my experience with anyone who plans to buy this so they don't experience what I experienced, one reviewer also claimed that it took out their motherboard AND power supply and caused a fire! WOW!
-Austin Cox, Des Moines, IA.

This review is being done after the second Zalman mic has died. I say died because the first one acquired a problem just after the mic to pc adapter causing no sound other than static during use. Now the second replacement for that mic has succumbed to the same fate, the mic jack has developed the same problem. I know what you're thinking, what about your setup? The microphone is plugged in the rear of my PC tower, and has nothing but gravity pulling on the cord. No trauma could have caused this issue due to the use of a cord manager.
The sound quality prior to this inevitable problem was decent and served it's purpose quite well.

To start off with, I would like to have given the Kindle Fire HD 5 stars, but
for the problem I encountered connecting it to my Sony Bravia HDTV.

The issue is that Amazon does not say anything about the type of Micro-HDMI
cable to use. I assumed that the one that I had purchased a year ago for my
Android phone would work. It did not...

After talking with customer support (they were very responsive, but not helpful),
I thought I would try buying an expensive cable at Staples. This one did not work
either. Amazon then sent me a new Kindle.

I decided to check out cables listed on Amazon, read the reviews, and found one
that people said they found worked. I purchased it quickly and tried it
on my original Fire HD. It worked!!! I returned the replacement Kindle.

The moral of the story is: Not all Micro-HDMI cables are created equally :(

This one does work:
Mediabridge Flex Series - High Speed Micro-HDMI to HDMI Cable with Ethernet (6 Feet)

I hope Amamzon support and their documentation will be updated to prevent
future customers from having this problem.

Happy now, but frustrated.

P.S. This cable does not cost that much. It would help if Amazon included
it in their Kindle package.
P.S.S. After getting this to work via direct connect to my TV, I tried connecting
through my Yamaha 6.1 Amp with HDMI switching... works great.

Ok - so I received this from VINE and really hate to complain but I'm not about to \\"sugar coat\\" something just because it was free.

It arrived quickly and I'm ready to open it. The item wasn't in a bag or any protective sleeve and when they packaged it, the adhesive from the box stuck to the finish of the case. I didn't rip and tear and after gently pulling, tugging the cardboard came loose with patches of faux leather. Ok, so that's number one to aggravate me because a brand new product looks like it was chewed by the family pet.

So I put the Kindle into it and it really does look and feel impressive and will guard the book just fine. I decide now I'm going to try out the features. Standing and tilting, etc. Well let me tell ya - that velcro they use could secure a small car to a helicopter for aerial transport (and for a damn good distance too!) What the velcro did for me ? Frustrated me till I was ready to throw the thing in the trash. There's velcro all over it and it's a pain in the arse and sticks to other parts - even parts you don't want it attached to at the time.

I have a Kindle Fire and the jack goes into the \\"short\\" side - on this model the jack goes into a long side and that's the side that sits on the table when charging. I don't believe you should charge it when you're working on it. The charger sticks out the bottom and if you want to tip it up and work on it, it's resting on the charger plug. So two things can happen. One, it could damage the plug or the HD's internal slot and two, you could damage your Kindle because the HD tips back and forth because it's not sitting securely when the plug is in.

Personally I'd go with one of the book cover types. I have that type on two others and they work to protect the item and really, the convenience of a smaller, lighter Kindle is for ease in handling and they're portable. I don't require a cover that will frustrate the hell out of me just to prop upthe item and usually I'm holding it when working on it - so why pay for that option.

Overall - it wasn't packaged well enough to protect the finish, you need to be a puzzle master to flip it around and get it in place. All in all, I'm not impressed with this case and probably wouldn't be with any other made like it.

I have photos to post and will do so asap.

I needed a cheap, simple cloner for a laptop drive. I have not tested the USB connect capability.
Pros:
Once I figured out that it was cloning, it duplicated the drive perfectly.
Cons:
1. The included instructions were translated poorly to English. I relied on other reviewer suggestions to start the cloning process.
2. The LED indicators are poorly designed. It was impossible for me to determine progress as the LEDs appeared to flash 75% progress during duplication. I could tell from drive vibration that the copying was occurring.

For the price, I can accept the indication issues. It duplicated a 160Gb drive in less than an hour.

The first one I got did not work at all.  Amazon rocks when it comes to returns/exchanges.  Very easy and got new one in a couple days. Got item to work but loses signal easily.  IOGear's technical support is not good at all.

This case doesn't even fit a 13" macbook pro, it's too small... which is weird because 13" is the smallest macbook pros are made.  The whole set up is pretty flimsy in general too, you'll be better off investing in something a little better.

It's an average USB 3.0 portable 1 TB Hard Drive. You never know when a drive will fail, but it could be years, so reviewers really can't make that kind of determination until it's too late for most people.

I'd say the build quality is average, a little on the cheap side. It's fairly cheap molded plastic. I've had real WD (Western Digital) branded hard drives that seem to have nicer manufacturing specs, even though they have plastic enclosures. I'd say we should do everything possible to encourage higher build quality in computer components. For instance, a drive with an aluminum enclose costs only a fraction more to manufacture, but is much nicer in many ways. Nevertheless, I don't downgrade my review because of that. I'd just say this is average, and that's fine, as long as you can get it on sale or for an otherwise low price. I trust it will function and hold up to my standards for the foreseeable future. If I think of it, I will update this review after I use the drive a bit more.

Very good tool to learn the concepts of microcontrollers and for designing and understanding basic circuits commonly controlled by them.  I found the examples provided very easy to construct and follow.  It leverages the code examples found of the Arduino website.  The code was very helpful and well commented so you could understand how each procedure actually works.  I bought this kit for my niece this summer who just completed her first semester studying electrical and computer engineering.  She knew basically nothing about microcontrollers but has taken to it right away.  She struggled her first semester in labs understanding basic analog and digital board designs and C++ programming.  After working with the Arduino, she now feels she will have a bit of advantage on the other students.  I have a degree in electrical and computer engineering myself and wish I would have had something like this as a student.

Hey, I get it. It's a Galaxy and it "SHOULD" be just as great as their cell phones. I have owned a Galaxy S3 for a couple of years and it has NEVER failed me and it's a dynamite product. But a tablet is NOT a phone.

Y'see, I own a Kindle Fire HD. It's a great product and I have had NO issues with it, but I hate the restrictions to the Google Store that it imposes on you. So, I decided to shop for a tablet that doesn't have these restrictions. I settled on the Galaxy Tab. Well, I was NOT impressed with it's performance. My 2-year-old Kindle HD 7 Fire out performs it. Here are some of the things that forced me to return this product:

1. The real estate on the web browsers was an annoyance. I couldn't invoke the FULL-SCREEN mode on any of the browsers that I downloaded. Even though the SETTINGS for that feature was checked.

2. The tiny, tiny, itty bitty, speaker. I was so used to the two-speaker stereo sound that my Kindle Fire HD had, that listening to music or watching Netflix was not enjoyable.

3. The storage issue!! Daily I received the OUT OF STORAGE SPACE alert even though I had a 32 GB external SD Card installed. I was forced to CLEAR the cache on the thing daily just to avoid those annoying alerts.

4. The performance of the web browsers. I'm a GEOCACHER and I like to use my tablet to display maps.This tablet's browsers would hang and lag and just get on my nerves whenever I tried to enlarge or scroll. Kindle's browsers never gave me that problem.

Those are the reasons I decided to continue my search for a non-Google Store-restricted tablet.

I acquired my Kindle HD Fire with miles and have spent a week figuring out how it operates...my first device of this sort. The interface operates extremely well and the screen looks great. Most technology is not particularly intuitive to me, but I think I've learned most of what I need to know to use the Kindle. That said, what I can do is limited, since 1) I can barely read some Web site pages, and enlarging them doesn't always help since not all online pages are designed to be enlarged for a 7\\" screen; and 2) the apps are thus far pretty dumb. The only two games I play are not available for android (so far...I emailed one and begged them to please develop their android version, and they said it's coming). And the New York Times crossword puzzle, which I've done for 50 years and online for years as well, is not at all ready for android, just iPads, and they didn't want to hear about making one for the Kindle. (Lost income opportunity there, NYT.) And these are the only reasons I rated my Kindle 3 stars...all personal to me. The Kindle pluses for me: great for reading books, lots of stuff available free when you have Prime, and you can figure out the interface quickly. In the meantime, I am going to wait for the ideal small, light ultrabook, since that will have everything I need to do the fun things I've been doing on a heavy laptop all this time...The ultrabook will probably be from Microsoft, since I have never entered Apple World and I think it's a bit late now after 26 years on Microsoft software.

I'm an instrumentation repair technician for a large environmental laboratory. The IT department replaced one of these switches because it had terrible packet loss(the metal shell type) and i snagged it up. The more i can learn about hardware failure modes, even on something as cheap as a network switch, the better i can perform my job.  I disassembled the switch to discover that it has what is commonly known as \\"capacitor plague\\" so this one did not teach me anything. That's right, the packet loss is due to defective capacitors. Assuming you have capacitors and proper tools, you can repair one of these switches in about five minutes.  I gave a three star review because I really don't have much experience with the device, all that i know is that it was in service for about 2 years in a very, very rough environment and now i have a spare gb switch.

I bought the NETGEAR XAVB101 Powerline AV Ethernet Adapter Kit based on the reviews here, and my desire to use a hard connection to my iMac to replace the wireless 802.11n I've been using so far. The proported speed of 200 Mbps of the kit tracks very nicely with the maximum speed of 802.11n, and it would eliminate any wireless interference issues I might have.    Set up was very easy - just plug one Adapter in a power outlet near the router (make sure you don't plug the adapter into a surge suppressor), plug the other Adapter into a power outlet close to your PC/game console, connect both with the supplied ethernet cables, and away you go! Without any prior set up of software, drivers, etc., both Adapters immediately recognized each other and began to send and receive data! If only other computer peripheral installations were so easy.    There are 3 lights on each Adapter showing the status of the unit. There's a Power light that shows if the unit is receiving power or setting up security protocols, an Ethernet light that shows if the Adapter is linked and if it is sending data, and a Powerline light that shows if the Adapter is connected to the Powerline network, and the approximate Link Rate. Since the XAVB101 version of Netgear's Powerline Adapters should have a maximum transfer rate of 200 Mbps, I was dismayed that the Powerline light glowed RED, signifying a Link Rate of < 50 Mbps. I thought that possibly this status might not be right, so I performed several data-intensive operations, such as adding album art to Apple Lossless music tracks on my ReadyNAS music server. Much to my chagrin, the speed was no better than my wireless 802.11n connection. When I ran an ethernet cable directly from my router to my iMac and performed the same tasks, they ran lightning-fast. Not a true scientific test, but the comparison was dramatic - from just minutes to complete to TENS of minutes.    I tried other power outlets in our house, but they all showed RED for the Link Rate.It may be the wiring in our 50 year old home, but I don't have anywhere else to test the Adapters. In any case, where I NEED to use the Adapters, the throughput is dismal.    So, anyone looking for an easy connection to their network and is not worried about the speed of the connection, then by all means get the NETGEAR XAVB101 Powerline AV Ethernet Adapter Kit. But if you're like me, you need a FAST connection, look to other solutions.

I ordered this laptop from a different site - however thought of writing the review here.    NOTE:- I ordered it fully loaded with i7 4900MQ processor, 16 Gb RAM, 2Gb Graphics card and 1.5Tb HDD    This is a great laptop, is very fast and can handle any APP and can run multipl APPs at a time with out any time lag or hassel    However there are couple of things one must know before taking the decision  1) This laptop is much much heavier than I expected  2) There is quite a good flex in the keyboard on the left side (the ASDF keys)  3) The keyboards response is random, sometimes it chooses not to accept a key press and if you type fast then be prepared to miss out on some letters - and get into the habit of going back and fixing them regularly  4) The mouse touch pad is large and sensitive - however sometimes it just decides not to respond, you click or double click - its just dead - then it jumps back to life again :)  5) I opted for a bluRay burner, if you leave your system ON for a long time like a couple of days - the Optical drive does not recognize even the most ordinary disc, you need to re-start your system for the disc to be recognized  6) The screen is not very thin - as expected - its as ordinarily thick as of any other laptop, but yeah the display is awesome    If you are using this laptop for regular stuff - it never gets HOT - its very quite and is lovely to work with.    The reason I give 4 starts is it does the job that i bought it for, true it has some glitches and flaws - but is still a great machine    I hope this review would be help full to you all      UPDATE    after about two month of hands-on with this laptop here are the set of Problems I've been facing    1) Extremely bad keyboard - if you are a fast typing person then be prepared for correcting and re-correcting your text. The keyboard tends to skip some letters while you are typing, i lose a lot of time going back and correcting the words and typing in the missing letters. too much flex in the keyboard    2) Mouse pad acts whacky, twice dring the last week it decided not to respond to any clicks, it detects the movement and hovers the pointer all over the screen but does not respond to a single or a double click.(had to roll back the drivers and re-install them)    3) the touch screen decided not to work - (had to roll back the drivers and reinstall them)    Hence if you are a TECHY and you know how to fix such problems that creep up every now and then; then go ahead and pick this beast - else pick something which is hassle free.    I would rate the laptop 3 stars for these nasty troubles that keep coming up.

All in all, I am very pleased with my Kindle 3.     The positive stuff:    The Kindle is designed to do one thing, and do that one thing very well. If what you want to do is read books, a dedicated reader is the way to go. Here is why:    READABILITY: The electronic ink used in the Kindle (and some other readers) has a much higher resolution than a TFT (transistor) display. It really does look like high quality printed text, not like the pixelated characters to which you are accustomed on a cell phone, laptop, or computer screen. As you have doubtless already heard, you can read the e-ink displays in bright sunlight, just like you can a book.    WEIGHT: You know how much a traditional laptop weighs. You probably have or had one. Netbooks are lighter, comparable to a college textbook, but not exactly handy for reading. When the Apple iPad hit the market, there was plenty of chatter on the Internet about it killing the Kindle. Well, I've had an iPad in my hands, and it is a cool device, but it is still too heavy to hold in your hands for a long period, the way you would hold a book or magazine. I can hold the Kindle in one hand for long periods, just as I would hold a paperback.    BATTERY LIFE: My various laptops will run for somewhere between 2 and 4 hours. The batteries on an iPad will keep it going significantly longer, but still not for more than part of a day. The Kindle will go for a week on a single charge, and if you turn off the wireless, except when you wish to order something, it will go for much longer.    Let's say you are sold on the idea of a dedicated reader. Why the Kindle? There are other readers which also use electronic ink, and some which use TFT displays. The Sony readers I looked at in the past suffered from a major design flaw -- too many buttons. You may or may not like the iPad, iPhone, or iPods, but think about what sets them apart from the also-rans -- their simplicity, their no-compromise single-button perfectionism. When I see some touchscreen phone which is a belated attempt to catch up with the iPhone, where the designers could not resist adding a handful of buttons, I just shake my head because they don't get it. A phone, or a reader, which has buttons like your TV remote control, is something you are going to be challenged to learn how to use. The Kindle designers \\"get it\\". The newer Sony readers are getting better, but they are still playing catch-up.     The issues:    PAGING BUTTONS: The Kindle 3 has a smaller frame than the previous versions, for the same sized display, meaning there is less room around the display for buttons. As a result, the buttons on the sides for paging forward and backward really are ON the sides. My hands are big enough for me to cradle the Kindle in a palm, with my fingers wrapping around an edge, where it is easy for me to inadvertently squeeze a button. As a result, I want to instead hold it below the screen, pinched between a thumb and fingertips, but the keyboard buttons below the screen get in the way of doing that. In short, I find it a bit tricky to hold onto with one hand, but I do manage.    PAGING BUTTONS: In order to make the device equally usable if held in the left or right hand, both sides have two paging buttons, for paging forward or backward. The button for paging forward is vertically near the middle, and about twice as large as the button above it for paging backward. So far so good. But when I hold the Kindle in BOTH hands, I find myself instinctively wanting to use the big button on the left side to page backward, and the big button on the right to page forward. But both page forward, so often when I try to back up to re-read a passage, I end up paging forward instead. It is a hard habit to break. I would like to be able to reassign the buttons. Maybe it can be done, but if so, I have not stumbled across how to do it.    NO TOUCH SCREEN: After having an iPod Touch for only a short time, which I use mainly for listening to music, I find myselfwanting to page back and forth on the Kindle by swiping my screen with a finger. It is almost irresistible. Whether a touch screen is compatible with an e-ink display I do not know. How much additional battery drain it might cause, taking away a major Kindle advantage, I don't know either. Whether the fingerprints would make the screen look bad I do not know. But I do know that I would really, really, like a touch screen for navigation. There are other readers which have them, but check to see if those are using TFT screen or e-ink. I would not trade away the e-ink for a touch screen. But sooner or later somebody is going to give me everything in one package.    NO DEDICATED NUMBER BUTTONS: The QWERTY-arranged buttons are in 4 rows. With this iteration of the Kindle, there is no top row containing the number buttons. To enter a numeric character, you must click the Sym button and move the cursor over the digit, and then click the enter button. This is a pain. A row of number buttons at the top (which previous versions actually did have) would be much appreciated. There is enough room for the row, so I don't know why it was taken away.

I previously had the JoyPen - this mouse feels much more sleek and comfortable, but I ended up noticing that it was more stress on my hands to use it - I think I just held it more tightly in my wrist due to it being more smooth and slick. It works great, and no major grips/complaints (great price, especially for ergonomic mouse), tracks well, and feels good in your hand, but if you have man sized hands like me (not huge, but larger than my wife's hands) the Joypen is probably a better option.

What makes a good mouse is a pretty personal set of criteria.  For me, this mouse has two fatal flaws.  I tend to grip my mouse as if my hand was a claw, meaning that I use the tip of my thumb on one side and pinky on the other, and click with my index and middle fingers.  With this mouse, however, the claw approach doesnt work.  For one, the sides of it are too slick, which makes gripping it difficult.  Secondly, the mouse buttons dont extend all the way to the front of the mouse, so if you have long fingers, you find yourself trying to click where there is no button.    My other compaint is the wheel doesn't have very good tactile feedback.

I got this to replace an extremely old (10+ years) bluetooth USB dongle because I was only getting about a 10 ft range and it would break up constantly. My device (Android LG Nexus 4) has BT 4.0 support so I got this specifically because it was the latest bluetooth version at a reasonable price.  I use several bluetooth devices including 2 cars, a portable bluetooth speaker and this USB dongle I am reviewing. With the bluetooth speaker, I can have my phone in one room and walk 3/4 away across the house transmitting through 4+ walls and it won't even get static. I have a high-powered 3 antenna AC router where my desktop computer is that transmits at the same 2.4gh frequency as device. I can put the speaker at the precise location where this dongle is seated in my computer, then walk half way across the house with the router directly blocking the line of sight between the phone and the speaker and the speaker never has a hiccup or breaks up until I practically get outside the house. The 2 cars have an even better range with the same phone. My wife has dropped me off in our driveway and driven to the mailboxes 100+ft away and the music in my phone is still broadcasting to her car without dropping the connection.  All that being said, out of all the bluetooth devices I have, this is by far the worst performing and most troublesome. I can have my phone resting on my desk less than 3 feet away from the dongle, and I will get massive static occasionally and have to slide my phone a few inches to get it to clear up (as though I were adjusting bunny ears on a TV). If I take my phone into the bathroom literally 4-6 feet away through one wall (with no metal in it), the audio breaks up so much its not even worth using it.  If I didn't use it with so many other bluetooth devices, I might think my phone is at fault or the location. But I have tested positioning my phone / bluetooth speaker in the exact same locations. I am actually work at a tech support call center troubleshooting all smart phones available on the USA market including bluetooth issues. I have tried unpairing the phone and computer (removed the device completely from both the computer and the phone) then repairing. I have gone so far as to change channels on my router and even have tried turning off the router. I have uninstalled/reinstalled the drivers. I tried to look online for an update, but this company has HORRIBLE support (or complete lack thereof). They don't have USB drivers or even a support tab on their website. I tried to change USB ports to my front ports (which I use 10+ other devices without issue) and this piece of junk won't even work on any of them after reinstalling the drivers / power cycling my computer.  I have also tried switching to USB 3.0 ports on the back of my computer.  I also tried connecting my old iPhone 4 to this. I get better range (maybe 50% more) and less static but get massive lag when trying to pause/play the music (I press pause and it takes 5+ seconds to pause) and the audio stream speeds up (music sounds high pitched / chipmunk voices) or slows down (deep voices / slow motion voice).  All this may be excusable if there was better support or some way to update the drivers. I am very organized when it comes to driver discs (which are going completely out of style and will disappear in the next 10 years) so I was able to find the disc in my CD binder when I came back to troubleshoot this again. When I plug it in, it does not automatically find the drivers on my Windows 7 64 bit computer. So what if I were to lose the disc for this?  The only reason I give it 2 stars is because I happen to be in a situation where I can place my phone within 2 feet of the dongle with little inconvenience, find a sweet spot, and have only very occasional static. But I originally intended this to have the same range as my other bluetooth devices so I could walk around the house with my wireless headset with the phone in my pocket listening to music or evenaccepting phone calls through my headset.  Edit: I started futzing with this again so I returned to this product's Amazon page to see if I could find some better drivers. I see that 5-6 people are taking the time to mark all the 5 star reviews helpful and any negative review unhelpful. Whoever is selling this product is taking the time to mark my highly detailed review as unhelpful but can't provide any comment or troubleshooting tips. I am lowering my rating to a 1 but wish I could make it lower somehow. I really hate companies who manipulate Amazon reviews.

This is my first experience with a Chromebook. And, as expected it takes some getting used to. Especially if you're used to a laptop.

First, all the good stuff about ASUS. This Chromebook is really very well built. Looks very nice, is light yet fells strong, very good keyboard and track pad. In fact I'm typing this review on the Chromebook! Although I just realized there's no delete, home or end keys! Still the keyboard is not bad. The other features include built-in webcam, HDMI output, SD card slot, USB slot, earphone/mic jack. The battery life is amazing. I charged the battery the first time (and it was quite quick) a few days ago. And with light usage (about an hour each day) I've been running on battery ever since, almost a week now! In short, ASUS did an excellent job with this Chromebook.

But are you ready for a Chromebook to begin with? That's the bigger question. You can read a lot on the web about the differences between the following:
1) Laptop: Most expensive. Heaviest. Most versatile with software, apps, productivity.
2) Chromebook: About the cheapest. Light. Least amount of apps (can only download for Chromebook. Note: Chromebook does not run Android OS).
3) Tablet: Cost is somewhere between Chromebook and Laptop. Runs Android OS (or IOS for Apple tablets).
4) SmartPhone: This is a different category, but should be considered since a Smartphone starts to perform almost all the functions a laptop can perform. It's the lightest of all, and either runs Android OS or IOS for iPhone.

So here's my first impression with the Chromebook.
Web browsing: Very fast. That's primarily what a Chromebook was built for - fast web browsing using Chrome. But note - you cannot download Firefox or Internet Explorer. Still, the speed with which pages open up and the navigation is very good and overall you're going to like browsing the internet with this Chromebook.
Apps: Not good. I have an Android phone and I'mused to the apps on Android. E.g. I can download Skype on my Android phone. But not on Chromebook. This was a big negative for me. You have to use Chromebook apps like hangout, etc. for the equivalent of Skype. Chromebook tries to overcome for this problem by making other apps that import your Skype contacts, etc. But they're not the real deal.
Productivity (like document editing, etc.): Okay. You can use Google docs. But remember that the Chromebook has limited hard drive space. They pretty much want you to use Google drive (cloud based storage). Which can be good or bad depending on your point of view.

Overall I don't think I'm ready to switch over to Chromebook. I still use my Laptop for Office email (Outlook), Skype and other software that can't be run on Chromebook. But I do use my Chromebook if all I want to do is browse the web. Still, I can do that on my phone as well! Maybe as I play some more with Chromebook (and as they add more apps) I might change my mind. And I hope it does change one day soon!

So if you're familiar with Chromebook and know its limitations, I'd recommend this ASUS one, it's great. But if you're not sure about Chromebook versus a tablet or a laptop, I'd probably wait or go with something other than a Chromebook. Hope this helps. Good luck!
