This is a very slim backpack for all your electronics.

PROS:
- This is a slim and sleek backpack.
- It has designated pockets for your mouse, power cords, micro sd, laptop, tablets, etc. They even have the logos on the pockets to show you what goes where.
- It has a sternum strap lock to keep the weight distributed and air meshes to get some kind of airflow.
- You can tie your shoes or whatever to the ring on the front if you want, which is pretty cool.

(workable) CONS:
The only downside side is that this backpack feels compact. It could probably only hold 2 books and all your electronics. If you put two sets of cloths, it can get pretty tight. But you can fit everything nicely if you just pack one set of cloths in it (shorts or pants/shirt/socks/belt) or one thick book.

OVERALL:
The material is pretty nice. I like the shape of it. This is a minimalist backpack for all your electronics. If you use it for anything else, you'll have to be pretty creative in packing things before it starts to feel very compacted and tight.

I would recommend this to people who pack light and who need to always bring their electronics with them.

First let me say this is my third Mac.  I have been a loyal fan since 2006 when I purchaced my first Macbook.  That Mac has been to Iraq twice and still runs like a champ!! The down arrow key fell off.  Normally not a huge thing but with the current operating system it is required to scroll through websites.  Because my computer is 13 months old, exactly one month out of warranty I have to pay to have it repaired.  Also, what I thought was a blown speaker was actually the bearings going out of the coolling fan.  Grand total for a new keyboard and fan with labor $426!!  I even called Apple to see if I could get a little customer appreciation to no avail.  Stated it was normal wear and tear.  I'm writting this on my 06 model so I don't think that is the case or shouldn't be the case for a $1200 computer.  I am terribly disappointed in today's Apple.  Before making the leap, please research the repair issues I've stated, I am not the only one.  The internet is full of these same issues and the same response from Apple.  I will now be going back to PC where I can get a junk computer for half the price of the garbage Apple now pedals.  Good bye Mac!

Several months ago, I bought the older Logitech quickcam pro for notebooks and it was great, except it didn't have manual focus on it. Logitech improved that feature and more with this newer version of the same camera that came out in July. I was excited to see that they had changed that among other things! Just like my original quickcam pro, this one has the stand, which is good for sitting your cam when you aren't using it to clip on the top of your notebook. I have a toshiba 17\\" laptop, and this cam fits perfectly on the top of it. Have dark rooms? No problem... the low light technology on this webcam is the best I've seen. Over the course of 5 years, I have bought about 4 webcams and this cam by far is the best in dark room settings. The previous quickcam pro I have works great too... I use this cam to talk to friends on aim, and they have ichat. Works great. They can't believe all I have on my desk is one lamp on the low setting and they can see me perfectly clear, when they have to turn on all the lights in their room so I can see them! Another thing too is the 2 megapixel video .. it's pretty awesome. And you can take photos in 8 megepixels! There aren't many webcams out there that do that. If you buy a webcam with a 1 megapixel video or lower, you get what you pay for and it's going to look awful.

One thing about this camera, which I just asked the logitech customer support on their message boards about, is about the frame rate. It's supposed to be up to 30 frames, yet this one seems a bit slow. My other quickcam pro didn't seem to have any problems with the frame rate, yet this one does for some reason. It's almost a ghostly effect when you move. Which really isn't that big of a deal, but it would be nice if it didn't have that or you could adjust how fast it picks up the images it captures. Or maybe it's just a problem on my computer's end. Other than that this camera works great and I would recommend it to everyone.

Card reader arrived, inserted a 4GB SD card, plugged into Windows 7 64-bit computer, Got \\"device not recognized\\" message. The interesting part is that on the box is printed \\"Free tech support\\" with a stylized person icon and \\"One-Step Solution\\" with an email icon but nowhere on or in the box, or on the device itself, is there any information about the manufacturer or how it might be reached. No email address, no web site and no physical address. The box only contained the reader itself so no pamphlet or driver disk. I tried several web searches but only found sites selling card readers.

I was using a USB port on the case front, connected to a header on the motherboard and I checked to verify it works with other devices. However, when I connected the card reader to a back port on the motherboard it was recognized and started working. The device works so I'll give it 3 stars but I take off 2 for not having any support information at all.

This was suggested for the [[ASIN:B0047Q4F40 Coby 7-Inch 1080p HD Video MP3 Player with 4 GB Flash Memory]].  Bad suggestion.    No matter which way you orient it, the (not adjustable) clamps cover/push some of the control buttons.  If you put it in lengthwise, you can push \\"Volume\\" down equally, and set it via the remote.  Barely.    The mounting system is marginally acceptable, but initial setup is hard, it works by a lock camming over, so you have to arrange both and engage the locks for it to stay. There is no lock for the vise with the media player, so it will often come loose - or when you try and put it on later, will knock the locks off.    After that is set up, it's apt to fall of if adjusted, but so far, no problems once you finagle the media player in, manage not to hit any of the buttons, and then proceed - after that it's been acceptable.    Since it's \\"universal\\", you'll need to be sure that the device has no buttons on the side where the clamps go, or device a shim to clamp it where the buttons aren't.

Bought this June 24, 2013, and had trouble getting it to work, keep switching and unplugging and suddenly it just started to work (spent time on phone with Apple).

Fast forward to Jan. 19, 2014, shut Mac down to install a PCI card and second monitor (using the HDE adaptor) did not work upon rebooting. To make a long story short, spent 7 hours of my Sunday troubleshooting by myself, with Apple Tech, finally went to apple store at 4 PM and they discovered the HDE Mini DisplayPort to VGA adaptor was bad. Replaced with Apple adaptor, and everything works perfectly.

The lesson? I try to save money when I can ($9 for the HDE vs. $29 for the Apple), but in this case it bit me in the tookis, and ruined my Sunday. I will probably continue to use inexpensive cables and adaptors (Monoprice is terrific), but occasionally you pay a high price for frugality. C'est la vie.

I've tried two dual core AOD257 models, aquamarine and white. Keep in mind the white doesn't look attractive at all, more like a plastic toy. Both have the bad habbit of freezing while transfering files over my home network, downloading files from internet or streaming a Netflix video. Once they freeze, you have to restart them from the power button. It seems to be some problem with the wireless network card/configuration. I've seen reviews about freezing also with the Happy2 line of Acer.  I finally bought a purple Gateway LT2804u which is the dual core Gateway equivalent of AOD257. Gateway was bought by Acer so they have very similar specifications but the Getway doesn't freeze. It is very responsive and works perfectly while networking. It is also very quiet and much more attractive than the AOD257 models.

If this board had dual channel ram it would be a grand slam home run. As it is, it is sorta like a triple. It works well, it is low powered, it works with Windoze and Linux, it is inexpensive, it is very easy to set up, it does not generate heat, it can play HD video easily. It is just about perfect. If you want a board strictly for web browsing or use as a media center, this is your board. You will be delighted. If you sometimes transcode video or audio files, as I do, then you will miss dual channel ram. I realize that many people do not transcode files, and, for those people, I highly recommend this board. Also, you won't be satisfied if you like to play 3d games. This board can play basic ones, but would choke on newer games.

My power cord for my Vostro 1500 crapped out on me as they always do, so I frantically ordered this product.

Pros: Unlike most other after-market power cords, this one is 90W so it's perfect for the Vostro 1500 and I do not get any error messages. It has been about 2 weeks since I ordered this, and it seems to work smoothly with my computer, and for the price, I would definitely order this again! I might stock up considering how quickly I go through power cords (I bend them, the plastic breaks, wires break = no more power). Finally, I paid for UPS Ground shipping to get it faster, and the seller took over 24 hours processing time, but I got it quickly.

Downsides: it is a bit short, wish the seller would put the length in the description, I'd say 5-6 feet long which isn't much for a good cord. Also the adapter label does not say it is 90W, so you have to remember for next time. Finally, the connection seems to fit fairly well and hold well in my computer, but it still pops out easily. But that is true even for Dell cords. And the cord itself seems thinner than the Dell cords, I'm not sure if that is good or bad.

Verdict: I would definitely order another! I can't believe I paid $80+ last year for a Dell cord that only lasted me 1 year (they are more expensive and unavailable now from Dell's website), when this one costs $7 + shipping and works well.

My hard drive failed about a week ago and I took it into the computer shop where they confirmed it was hard drive failure. I called Toshiba and they recommended that I pay for a box at $25.94 which would have instructions and all material including mailing label for me to send in the computer. I paid for the box and today it arrived. There weren't any instructions in the box and only one small piece of foam so that the computer would be moving around in the box and more than likely end up broken. I decided to look up complaints on Toshiba and found an astounding number of complaints about Toshiba and their customer service.Many people were complaining that they were supposed to receive a box to return their computer in but never received anything. They didn't mention being forced to pay $25.94 like I had to do. I guess the payment for the box is new and expensive. I also found complaints about hard drives failing in short periods of time. I have only had my computer for 3 months and I bought it new.There were also complaints about the year long warranty not being honored for the full year. I received an email from Toshiba saying that I must return the computer by a date in June or they won't fix it and yet my warranty is good for a year.

I called Toshiba and they said they will send me yet another box. However they did not send me an email confirming this as they did the first time. This leads me to suspect that I may not get a box as people have been complaining about on the internet. I am going to call them on Monday and ask for an email about the box. Should the box not arrive in two working days as the first box did then I will file a complaint with my state attorney generals office and also complain about the June deadline they gave me for getting the computer there. I think I actually will complain to the attorney general office anyway. Why should I have a deadline to send it to them? I only bought this computer because I bought a Toshiba lap top about 5 years ago and never had problems with it. I was supposed to get a free upgrade to Windows 7 for this older computer and sent in the request for it. I contacted them the day after the deadline to send it in and they said they never received it and wouldn't give me my upgrade. It was apparently a mistake to buy a Toshiba again. I thought they still made good quality computers although I knew their customer service was bad. Reading the complaints about all the hard drive failure leads me to think Toshiba does not make quality products any more also.

After reading the glowing reviews, I got this camera for my XP Service Pack 2 system (btw, an ASUS A7NX8-E Deluxe motherboard). Following the instructions, I attempted to install the software before plugging the camera in. In fact, I downloaded the latest software (v 8.4.6 build 1016A) from the Logitech website first. The initial attempt to install failed during the process to install the drivers. It loaded several files and then attempted to \\"Uninstall Device\\" (?!!?). The Logitech program it tried to run, DELDEV.EXE, died, generating a system warning (ie. \\"Device Removal Module Died! Send Report To Microsoft ?\\"). It then retries, dies, retries, dies, forever. Had to finally kill the install process in the Task Manager. Nice.

In looking on the Logitech Support website, they recommend doing a \\"Clean Boot Process\\" prior to install. This involves running the utility, MSCONFIG, and doing a \\"selective startup\\", turning off all Windows configuration files and all Windows Services and rebooting the machine. Jeez, I've never had to do this with any other software installation -- ever! Seems excessive and burdensome, especially for a USB device. But, I tried it. I had the same installation failure. I tried doing this again, but clearing out all temp files first (another suggestion). No go.

I've spent hours pouring over the Logitech Knowledge Base and User Discussion Groups. I haven't found a good solution. But I've seen lots of discussion of folks having problems with XP Service Pack 2. Some folks report success with XP SP2, but there are also a lot of folks having a frustrating time. Looks like the QuickCam software is not completely stable/reliable under XP Service Pack 2. Waiting to hear back from Logitech Tech Support -- but I'm not holding my breath for a speedy resolution.

I've just about given up. I went into the Control Panel/Add-Remove Programs utility to clean up the *partially* installed QuickCam software. The Uninstall program for the QuickCam software dies with an exception in SetupDLL/SetupDLL.cpp(454) (ie. line 454 of the C++ code for SetupDLL). So I've got this crappy, half-installed software I can't clear out of my system. Gosh, thanks Logitech.

I know people are using this camera successfully and getting great results. But I can't get past the initial software install (haven't even plugged the camera in the USB port yet). I would recommend that anyone considering purchasing this camera for XP Service Pack 2 first visit the Logitech support website, and search through the Knowledge Base and the User Discussion Groups.

I have had this computer for over a year now and here are my thoughts:    Lets get this straight from the beginning: I love this computer. So why the 3 stars? Well it is because of these 3 factors:  1) This computer as it is out of the box is best suited for very basic operation, as its internal graphics are flimsy.   2) It is difficult to upgrade as there is little space under the lid to fit in new parts. I would suggest not trying to stick a two port graphics card into this machine. It can be done however.   3) Most Importantly I got this machine for $300 dollars less at Office Max. That was a steal. This is about average.    I would not recomend this computer to someone who is timid about throwing in new parts. I would however highly recommend this computer to people who are not afraid of getting their hands dirty. What makes this computer great is that it is an excelent base to build upon with it having a 750 Gig harddrive and 8 gigs of ram. After getting a new power supply, a new (single port) graphics card, and two monitors, this computer was transformed into a beast which I can play the latest games at the highest settings and do heavy 3D work. ( I'm a beginning 3D game designer.)    I highly recommend this computer to the techie who can find this at a better price.

This flash drive is a USB 2.0 drive, which by today's 3.0 standards, is pretty slow. Still, it holds a large 32GB of data, and it has a nice swivel design to protect the drive pins, without requiring a cap which can be lost. There isn't much to say about things like hammers, batteries or flash drives. They either work or they don't work. In my case, the drive seems to be working fine. I have done some test copies of data to the drive, and transferred the files over to other computers with no problem, and the speed is decent for a USB 2.0 device, but nothing special, below are the results from Crystal Disk Mark 3.0.2
-----------------------------------------------------------------------
Sequential Read : 22.387 MB/s
Sequential Write : 4.989 MB/s
Random Read 512KB : 22.172 MB/s
Random Write 512KB : 0.498 MB/s
Random Read 4KB (QD=1) : 4.023 MB/s [ 982.1 IOPS]
Random Write 4KB (QD=1) : 1.084 MB/s [ 264.6 IOPS]
Random Read 4KB (QD=32) : 3.742 MB/s [ 913.7 IOPS]
Random Write 4KB (QD=32) : 0.314 MB/s [ 76.7 IOPS]
-----------------------------------------------------------------------

Worked great for three days, then the spacebar stopped working on the right half,(stuck down), just the left half rising up enough to register, causing continual errors and go-back-and-fix run on words. Keys have to be very distinctly and deliberately pushed to register, not a keyboard for a touch typist!  After just a month now the backlit keys are fading, the sensor that turns them on when you hover is sporadic and hit-n-miss when they come on, even plugged in! I leave it plugged in now because the battery seems to die in 2 days.  Very frustrating.  Would not buy again.

I have had a number of Asus products over the years and all worked well. Not so with this product. When everything was set up, the system booted up as expected, the problem was that if you let the machine go to sleep or shut down via the software shut down in windows 7, it would never wake up until you removed power from the motherboard. This was done by turning the power supply switch off for a few seconds and then back on. At this point it would boot normally and repeat the same problem.

Here is when the larger problem began. I contacted Asus tech support (this turned out to be the most disappointing experience) and they had me do several checks, even suggesting the power supply was bad (it worked fine on another Mfr's motherboard and it is more than adequate at 750W). After several emails back an forth they ran out of dumb ideas and suggested sending it in for repair to there facility in Jeffersonville, IN. They issued an RMA number and to ship it to them at my cost of $22 . I sent it off and approximately 2 weeks later, the same board was returned to me. After installing the same components that were previously connected to the motherboard, it now failed to boot at all! It had a momentary red LED light flash indicating a problem with the processor so I re-seated it, same light flashed when trying to start the machine and then nothing except for a green LED on the board that lights up when power is applied from the power supply. I again tried the processor in another manufacture's motherboard and again it worked fine. I'm sure they never tested the board or they would have found the same issue.

The real insult that was most aggravating was the call to tech support to advise them of the failed "repair" and then they suggested that I pay $10 non refundable processing fee along with a credit card number (to insure I returned the failed motherboard) and they would ship me a different "repaired" motherboard. The $180 charge to my credit card would be refunded when I returned my original piece of junk.

My advice to you, if it doesn't work send it back to Amazon immediately and either get you money back or an exchange. In a moment of weakness I bought a Fuji S5200 camera that can only use XD memory (even though I had heard horror stories about corrupted XD cards etc.)

The very first time I tried to download my pictures using one of the above `type M' high capacity cards, I lost every single image on the card.

To put this in context, I have owned more than a dozen digital cameras over the years, and have NEVER lost a single image on a Compact Flash or SD memory card, but have had 512 Megs to a full Gigabyte of images irrecoverably disappear several times on XD cards.

I had seen `picture recovery' software before, but UNTIL I got this Fuji camera with XD memory, I wondered why folks would ever need such a thing.

Of course there are some folks who feel some kind of evangelical need to promote XD as the ultimate in digital image storage after choosing a camera that uses this worthless format (It must be the best! I picked it after all, didn't I?).

XD is definitely best, if you definition of best includes:

- Very high rates of corrupted and lost images

- Short life (one XD card I purchased only worked about three times then died and this seems to have happened to others as well)

- Double or triple the cost (and this is getting even worse as SD memory is heavily discounted due to competition).

Of course XD cards are so cute and tiny and that counts for something right? Sorry, mini/micro SD cards are MUCH smaller, won't TRASH your images, and come with this snazzy adaptor that let's you also use them in full sized SD devices as well.

To make matters worse, XD seems to be going the way of BETA video tapes (with even the idiots who thought it up abandoning it).

If you are fortunate enough to have a camera that can also use an alternative memory format like CF or SD (as is the case with some Fuji and Olympus offerings), then I HIGHLY recommend thatyou used them and stay away from XD, and if you are considering a new camera purchase, I would warn you NOT to purchase a model which can only use XD memory (I certainly never will).

For the benefit of those that ARE stuck with XD, here are some tips:

- Go slow when changing to another capacity card (256k to 512k or 1G)

- Go slow when changing to another vendor (Fuji vs. Olympus)

- Go slow when changing to another type (M vs. H)

- Go slow when trying to use external card readers (probably better NOT to use them at all)

With the definition of \\"Go slow\\" above being that you should not shoot any pictures that you actually care about until you have done enough test shots to make sure you are not going to loose everything you shoot (because every one of the above issues can cause trouble).

I have never given a \\"1\\" rating to ANYTHING on Amazon, but the only reason XD doesn't rate a ZERO is Amazon's ratings do not go that low.

The lame justification used by the Fuji/Olympus cartel for monopolizing the manufacture of these cards was so they could insure compatibility and control quality, but the reality is that it was just about ripping off consumers with much higher prices (because, as far as I can tell, XD cards seem to have MORE compatibility issues and other `lost picture' problems than ANY other type of memory storage card).

As much as I despise frivolous litigation, I would love to see a bunch of XD card users who have lost all their irreplaceable vacation photo's (from say, Europe or Africa), get together in a class action and SUE Fuji (NOT just for the cost of a replacement card, but for the full cost of their vacations).

I wanted to connect two printers for my PC and a Linux portable I usually connect with wireless.  Netgear's instructions only include Windows, but documentation shows Win 2000 and XP connects via lpr, so it should work for Linux and Mac, no?  Trick is the queues are \\"L1\\" and \\"L2\\", not \\"LPT1\\" and \\"LPT2\\"--or \\"P1\\" and \\"P2\\", as the Windows connection would indicate.  Once I found that (from someone's web page, not Netgear's site) my Deskjet 812C works fine from both, without having to have the Windows PC turned on for the portable to print through.  Now I just need to see if my little Samsung laser printer works as well, and I'll be good.    And the four-port switch built in means you can turn off wireless and use it as a wired print server, and that you could connect several computers with only wired NICs to your wireless network.    Just a few hoops to jump through to get started, and you shouldn't need to do that more than once.

After a relative's crazy pet Chihuahua chewed up my laptop's original charger, bought this particular 65W PWR+ charger mid-October 2013 which worked great right out of the box. Fast forward to early April 2014 and discovered that one of the three metal prongs inside the power brick port, where you plug in the AC cord, had broken off and was now stuck inside the connection plug of the AC cord. Surprisingly, the break point wasn't a clean fatigue-like snap like most breaks in small metal parts. Rather, it was rough and uneven, as if a (possibly pre-existing) crack had formed in the metal prong itself, and had eventually grown enough for the prong to give way and break off completely, giving the impression that very brittle metal was used in its manufacturing.

Was about ready to share my views about this on Amazon, when I noticed that PWR+ has an 18 month warranty for their chargers sold on Amazon, and decided to put that warranty to the test. Viewing other negative reviews here at Amazon showed that PWR+ often commented on these reviews, wishing to get in touch with the negative reviewers and posting their Customer Service contact info so the reviewer could do so. Contacted PWR+ using this info, stated my problem, and received a very quick response asking me to send in the charger, and they would immediately send a replacement. Was pretty impressed with this response and sent in the broken charger using pricier yet trackable Priority Mail, as suggested by both their email response and their official product website. Received my replacement charger within 4 days and would have been very happy about it, except right out of the box there was a problem. After a few minutes of trying to get the charger to power my laptop without success, I decided to switch the AC cord that plugs into the power brick with an AC cord from another laptop as a test, and sure enough the laptop began charging. Switched back to the replacement charger's AC cord and again, no charge.

After having one PWR+ charger essentially break apart after 6 months and it's replacement charger having a bad AC cord right out of the box, I can't wholly recommend PWR+ products to anybody considering them. The fact that I wasn't reimbursed on return shipping costs for the first busted charger doesn't help any, even though previous reviewers who have dealt with PWR+ customer service apparently were (look for a review posted on February 5, 2014 and another on November 7, 2013 for examples). Which is too bad, because the original charger worked great for the brief time that it did. And Customer Service was very friendly and seemed interested in resolving my problem almost immediately. But after the first one went bust and its replacement arrived with a problem of its own, it's obvious they just aren't built to last, and good customer service can't save that.r />

Update 9/23/10 - I returned the Samsung due to poor color and black-level performance and bought the ASUS MT276HE, which I have found to be excellent.[[ASIN:B0034626ZY ASUS MT276HE - 27\\" Wide LCD Monitors - Black]]

Since most reviews have covered the basics of this monitor, I do not want to rehash the same info. This is what you need to know if you are an EXTREMELY fussy buyer, like me:

Gray-Scale:
While the gray-scale is very good, it CLIPS all data below and above standard RGB profiles. If you need an extremely accurate monitor for photo or video editing, move on, you will not be satisfied. However, if you can get away with a monitor that is \\"good enough\\", then you should seriously consider the 2370.

Color Profile Setup:
I initially started setup of the monitor with DVE Blu-ray 1080p using PowerDVD Ultra Mark II, which leads back to the gray-scale. While the monitor performs well, it does have some artifacting and skews to red on the scale. It took considerable tweaking of the OSD, which is very good, to START to CALIBRATE the monitor. However, I also needed to run Samsung's freely available \\"NATURAL COLOR PRO\\" app to get a correct blue hue, and tame those reds.

Brightness and Contrast:
Unfortunately, the brightness control does not control the gray-scale. It controls the AMPLITUDE. This is the primary reason why the monitor is so difficult to calibrate. Also, this is an extremely bright monitor, and you will be spending time trying to find the correct brightness vs. contrast ratio without affecting true blacks.

Bottom Line:
I wanted a solid monitor for gaming, non-professional photo and video editing, and productivity work. Overall, it is highly unlikely you will find a monitor this decent at this price point. If you need better color accuracy and a near-perfect gray-scale, you will want to look at the Dell Ultrasharp 24\\" IPS; however, the monitor is $600. I am waiting for wider availability of 120Hz monitors, so this is an excellent choice to hold me until then.

I hope that helps the \\"picky\\" customers, like me, to determine if this monitor suits your needs. One final note, I am using an EVGA 470 GTX card, and I found that DVI-D was the best way to go. Depending on your card, your mileage will vary.hold me until then. I hope that helps the \\"picky\\" customers, like me, to determine if this monitor suits your needs. I have been using this interface for home recording with Cubase since years and it worked extreamly well.
- great sound quality
- 2 quality mono inputs + stereo line
- configurable outputs: stereo to sourround
When I planned to upgrade to Windows8 I checked compatibility and the Terratc site claimed the product to be compatible.
However, after almost a year Terratec is not able to provide an ASIO driver with less than 40ms recording latency. Even ASIO4all is better here (20ms) but this is still not sufficient for live recording.
Conclusion:
Very good product but the advertised Win8 compatibility is misleading customers.
Therfore only 2 stars.

If you find yourself running out of CHA FAN ports on your motherboard, or want to run liquid cooling radiators in push-pull configuration (with the same RPM for both fans), or simply don't have many PUS connectors to spare, then the StarTech 12-inch 4 Pin Fan Power Splitter Cable works well as it allows two fans to be plugged into a single motherboard port or PSU connector (which it is designed for).

Pros
--------

Allows two fans to share a single motherboard port/PSU connector.

The \\"12 cable length offers extra space for more cable management options.

Cons
--------

This splitter has two tachometer leads, which means RPM monitoring software may not return an accurate result if they are plugged into the motherboard.

The bright color scheme stands out against the rest of the internal computer components, making them somewhat difficult to conceal.

Conclusion
--------

I use two of these splitters to pair my 4 front 120 mm fans, so they have the same RPM for optimal air flow through my case. I had to clip one of the tachometer leads on each one so that the fan controller software could accurately report their RPM (as this brand's splitter is designed primarily to plug into PSU connectors, not motherboard ports). When looking through the clear plastic on the side panel of my case, both of these splitters also instantly stand out against my black interior illuminated by blue and white LEDs, making them an eye sore. I recommend them, though, if you simply want to plug your fans into a single shared PSU connector. 4/5

NOTE: if you want to plug your fans into a motherboard port, I recommend using a brand's splitter with the second tachometer lead already disconnected and the leads discreetly concealed (such as [[ASIN:B00B46XKKQ Silverstone Tek Sleeved PWM Fan Splitter Cable (CPF01)]]).

I've had this monitor for two weeks and so far it has been great. Colors and sharpness are acceptable. However, there are some things that buyers need to be aware of:    1. Some people have complained about the constant \\"ViewSonics\\" logo that comes up. You can keep this from happening by un-selecting the \\"auto power off\\" feature in the set-up menu. This lets the power savings function kick in after a short period of time, instead of shutting off the monitor power completely, thus avoiding the logo.    2. The main drawback to this monitor is that it only has VGA and DVI connections and does not have a HDMI connection. VGA connections, which are of moderate sharpness, will be out of use in a year or so. DVI connections - which are supposed to be a little better - will be out of use in about three years, and will be totally replaced by HDMI, which is in use now. And HDMI is supposed to be much sharper than DVI. Soooo, if you plan to use this monitor for many years, or you want the sharpest monitor you can find, pass this up and get one with a HDMI connection.    Jack

I have had this router for over a year now and feel I can write an honest and knowledgeable review. For starters, this would have exceeded five stars for me if it would not have gotten lost in the mail. Yes, I know this is a \\"product\\" review, but I think the sellers who make the product, not Amazon, choose how they ship their products and if you pick the cheapest shipping for this, they will deliver it via post office and not ups. This resulted in my package getting hung up in Atlanta. After a week or so, I called Amazon to make them aware of this, and they said that I had to wait over a month for it to be considered lost in the mail and for a replacement to be shipped. I was VERY disappointed since the router I was replacing only put out a 15 foot signal. After the torturous waiting period, I called Amazon again to let them know that I still had not received my router. They promptly sent me a replacement and it arrived (still via the post office) in a few days. My husband was confused on how to set it up, but I got it up and running without a hitch the next morning. I think my husband tried installing it with the disc, but it is easier to follow the directions and hook it up over the internet. Here's the kicker... I have multiple wireless devices and have counted at least 8 devices running on this router at one time with little to no lag. My house is a smaller to average size at just under 1500 square feet all on one story. Also, my kindle fire picks up a signal anywhere in my yard which is about a quarter acre. This being said, the router definitely met my expectations. What happened to the first router I ordered? Well, of course, it came to my house a few days after I received my replacement router. I called Amazon to tell them this, but instead of returning it, I was so impressed that I just had them charge me for it so I could give it to my mother since she didn't have a wireless router. She doesn't have many wireless devices, but I wanted her to have one in case I brought my Kindle or my son brought his laptop to her house. Again, easy to set up and works beautifully. Finally, the computers at my work kept getting kicked off line and had a lot of problems communicating to each other (there are eight computers in our network). I told my boss that the old g router was probably the problem and recommended this router. She is a prime member (I have become one since), and received her router within two days. As soon as I switched routers, all of the computers picked right up on the signal, except the main server. I called customer service and, though they were nice, they couldn't help me with my problem and said that it was probably because our cinder block walls were too thick. Since the computer three feet away and in the same room as the main server was working fine, I didn't see how that was the problem. I called our I.T. guy, and he fixed the problem right away. It was a security issue and had nothing to do with the routers signal strength at all. Since we have been using this router, there have not been ANY issues like there were with the old g router.

I highly recommend this router. I also highly recommend that you spend a little more money on shipping (if you are not a prime member) to avoid the problem I had. Five stars on the product itself, but three stars on total customer experience.se I brought my Kindle or my son brought his laptop to her house. Again, easy to set up and works beautifully. Finally, the computers at my work kept getting kicked off line and had a lot of problems communicating to each other (there are eight computers in our network). I told my boss that the old g router was probably the problem and recommended this router. She is a prime member (I have become one since), and received her router within two days. I called customer service and, though they were nice, they couldn't help me with my problem and said that it was probably because our cinder block walls were too thick. It was a security issue and had nothing to do with the routers signal strength at all. Since we have been using this router, there have not been ANY issues like there were with the old g router.

I highly recommend this router. I also highly recommend that you spend a little more money on shipping (if you are not a prime member) to avoid the problem I had. Five stars on the product itself, but three stars on total customer experience.

I wish the user interface had more information. It's clear that this was NOT designed by the same people who made the RT-N66U router. Some improvements that could/should be made:

1. You cannot put in a static IP address in Repeater Mode. From a management standpoint, this is a big detractor. It will only get a DHCP address for itself. Should that address change, you have to use their Discovery Tool to find the IP address.

2. Want to see performance numbers (i.e. throughput, packet loss, etc.)? So would I. Unfortunately this doesn't offer it.

3. You should be able to operate this in dual-band mode. NOTE: Asus is very clear that this only operates in EITHER 2.4GHz OR 5 GHz - NOT BOTH at the same time. Having said that, they can do it in the RT-N66U so why not in the N450?

4. Did I mention that the interface is very poor?

Despite the above, I still give it 4 Stars:

1. Performance is very good (as best I can tell without having any statistics).

2. Very flexible. Can be an Access Point, a Wireless Router, or a Wireless Extender. All work well.

3. Very small. I was surprised how small it is.

4. Very cool looking. I particularly like how you can simply look at it from a distance and tell how good your signal quality is (it uses the LED lights - which are very easy to see from afar to tell signal strength).

5. Is easy to mount.

The adapter is easy to set up if you have a WPS-enabled router or have some tech knowledge and can configure it by hooking it up to your computer. I connected it to my non-WPS router with WPA2 in about 5 minutes.  I wasn't able to maintain connectivity, however. It would connect for about 10 seconds, then go down for 5, and repeat. I tried replacing the included network cable, and that fixed the issue. The included cable is pretty thing and flimsy, it's not your standard shielded Cat5 cable. If your adapter is connecting but the connecting is going up and down, try replacing the network cable with a standard Cat5 cable if you have one lying around before RMAing it.   It works great and it's small, and I was able to troubleshoot the broken cable, so I can't give it 5 stars.

This adapter has served me fairly well over the past year. We have been using 2 of them on Windows 2000 machines in the same room with little difficulty. However, there are some quirks of which you should be aware before purchasing. First, there is no channel selection option in the software unless you are using Peer-to-Peer networking. In Peer-to-Peer, the channel option becomes available. Also, the reception quality seems heavily dependent (indoors) on which direction the adapter is pointed. This would at first seem to be a non-issue, except that the cord is quite a bit heavier than the adapter. Therefore, when placing it on a desk, you have to very careful to place it in such a way that the cord does not pull it onto the floor. My suggestion: once a good signal direction is found, tape the power cord to the back of the desk, or consider a D-Link adapter instead.

I bought my wife a Kindle 2 about a month and a half ago -- it generally worked well, and she loved it, until the other day when it slipped out of her hand and fell about 2 1/2 feet onto the floor.  Don't be fooled by that \\"drop test\\" video -- her screen broke as a result of the fall, and it's now inoperative.  No problem, we have a one-year warranty, right?  Well, no; I did not buy the \\"extended\\" 2-year warranty, and it turns out that I should have read the fine print.  The 1-year warranty does NOT cover damages for dropping the Kindle, while the \\"extended\\" warranty covers one free replacement for drop damage.  Had I known that, and had I known it was so fragile, I would definitely have sprung for the $65 for the extended warranty.  Instead, the best Amazon is willing to do is replace the damaged Kindle for $200 (!!!).  So, bottom line, if you want to buy a Kindle 2, (1) buy the extended warranty and/or (2) DON'T DROP IT (or make sure it's encased in bubble wrap when you're moving it).  Otherwise, you are almost certainly going to end up \\"dropping\\" $135.

I saw this mouse here at Amazon, and at less than $4, I couldn't resist the offer. Besides, I like the looks of it. At 17 days, shipping must be by oxcart. It was wrapped oddly, too. Custom inspectors?

I like the \\"racing stripe\\" around the sides but I wish I could have it in another color. When I popped in a double-A battery, the mouse lit up even though the power-switch was in the Off position. I cycled the switch once, and it began normal On/Off operation. Some reviewers have mentioned a second version of this mouse with a blue laser LED. Mine is red. I inserted the USB transmitter (stored in the bottom of the mouse and easily overlooked, by the way), and my older back-up computer running Windows XP Home SP3, recognized it immediately.

Most mice are shaped a bit like a bar of soap, with a hunchback contour. This one is flatter and I find myself wishing it had just a little more height in the middle. Still, my overall impression is favorable. It looks nice, and has a nice texture, more silky smooth rubber, than sticky plastic.
The buttons have a pleasant \\"click\\" to them, and are not too loud or, well...mousy.
The mouse has the usual Left-Right buttons as well as a scroll-wheel with also depresses down to a mouse-click. I have not tried the DPI switch, which I gather stands for Dots Per Inch. I always adjust my mouse from the control panel menu. This worked fine.

I found the mouse works very well with my 23 inch LCD screen. Neither too sensitive nor too sluggish. The overall operation is smooth and positive. I had expected this mouse to feel like a cheap, flimsy piece of plastic, but to my pleasant surprise it has a rather nice feel of quality. It slides smoothly over my mouse pad and the buttons feel just right to me.

In conclusion, I think this mouse is a real value. I intend to buy another soon as a back-up, and if it proves durable, I may get two.

The reason for an average review is the price and availability of e-books. Kindle is an incredible machine for comfortable reading of available books with the exception of images and story-related maps. This flaw prevents one from easily flipping to the 'map' page and relating story to location. Perhaps the Dx is better for fine images and maps but then one loses convenience of size and portability. The built-in and easily interactive Dictionary function is very convenient! The \\"Go to\\" function is as good as 'you know exactly where you are going for exactly what you are searching for.' The Menu experimental function that includes a rudimentary Web Browser, MP3 and Text-to-Speech, is interesting. The Browser is not currently worth the effort.  The Text-to-Speech is available only if the Publisher allows. My 1st Kindle was flawed but Amazon customer service rallied and my perfect Kindle arrived the very next day. There are some things to like about this case and some things not to.

Pros:
* It holds the iPad REALLY well
* Keyboard is very light weight, removable, and quiet
* Magnets hold the latches well
* Seems to be of decent (good) overall quality
* Built-in stand

Cons:
* The soft silicone keyboard takes some getting use to. I didn't like it very much. This was my biggest disappointment.
* It adds considerable bulk to the iPad mini.

I can see how this case might have people who like it more than I did - those who want a keyboard and who like the feel of it (being soft silicon) and those who don't mind the added bulk. It wasn't for me though, as I found the soft, small keyboard too difficult and unproductive to use and I didn't like the bulk that it adds.

Overall 3 stars.

I've had this for two days so these are my initial observations
The reasons why it's not a 5 star case:
It has a vertical crease running top to bottom on the front cover. I know this is like this because it's designed to fold back when using it as a stand, but since this case is first and foremost a case and secondarily a stand, the vertical crease takes away from the rigidity of the case and it sort of buckles out when the case is closed so that the front is not flat, but making a slight outward bend at the crease. As a result, i think this lessens the efficacy of the magnets that help keep it closed.

Additionally, to expand on the magnetic closure, the bottom magnet does it's job but the one on the top seems much weaker.

The stand feature is adequate but it's flimsy. When using it, its best to place it on a flat, solid surface that doesn't move. I don't really like the stand feature but it does work, just not very well.

I do want to try the tablet out with a capacitive stylus and I noticed when buying this case, it came with a pen holder. It's very small and will only fit a pencil or skinny pen. I do not think the stylus I bought will fit in it.

Now for the pros:
The material that it is made out of looks and feels great and maybe more importantly, doesn't smell at all. The stitching on my case looks very good and I didn't notice any stitiching coming loose. The tablet is secured tightly on the right hand inside flap. It slides in towards the right edge of the flap and there is a tab that tucks behind the tablet on the left side of the tablet to secure it from sliding out. So far, it has stayed in place.

The magnets feature an auto sleep on/off feature when you open and close the case. And it works very well. Pretty intuitive and despite claims of some nexus 7 cases putting the tablet to sleep when folding the case back to hold in one hand, this doesn't happen with the poetic case.

Thecase doesn't fold back flat because of the case spine on the left side. However, it doesn't really take away from the usability of the case in that respect. There is a vertical elastic strap on the inside left flap that you can slip your hand into for extra security when holding the tablet with the case folded backwards. Time will tell if it holds it's elasticity. But so far, it's nice to use.

I also like the credit card/ business card holders on the inside left flap. I took some index cards and cut them down to size to fit in there for pencil and paper note keeping if I need to. There's also a pocket behind the business card holders that you can slip papers, receipts or whatever you need to temporarily. Additionally, you can use the space behind the tablet as a place to store some papers. It's very tight though and you may risk stretching it out if you do put stuff behind the tablet.

I'm guessing I'll need to eventually use an elastic band or something to keep it shut when the magnets fail. it just doesn't seem to have a strong attraction. But you know what, it's okay because I only spent 12 bucks on it. As long as it protects the tab from a fall or two, keeps the screen clean when not in use and looks good while doing so, I won't complain.

I wouldn't spend more than 15 bucks on this product. But it's worth purchasing.

My only complaint is the cooler on this thing. Im a cooling enthusiast and this just ran too hot and too loud for my liking. There is only a copper cored aluminum fin cooling block on the gpu, no extra cooling is made for the ram or vrm's, so if you plan to overclock, i would look elsewhere. I ended up returning this for the sapphire 7950 oc edition which comes with a much beefire heatsink and fan.

So far it looks like a whole lotta overkill for my needs. It has all the features of my dedicated web server that I pay $200/mo. for, but with no suitable network connection (Time Warner Turbo only) it's not worth using any of the web server plugins. In addition, the Replicator 3 does not look like it can back up a system drive, only user files...if that's true that's pretty whacky. Even my old dying Acer Aspire 340 running WHS can do that! The only reason I'm giving it 3 stars is that it runs on Linux and it seems quite responsive as compared to my old Acer, which takes 3 minutes just to log in. The real killer was the additional $55 licensing PER CAMERA on the video surveillance app. I just got this thing today and so far I'm not very impressed. Don't plan on doing much with iPhone sharing either.

PRO's
Runs on Linus
Seems fast
Did I say Runs on Linux?

CON's
Too many apps that I'll never even consider using on a NAS. I have dedicated web servers for that.
Additional licensing or monthly fees required for some apps.
Can't back up a complete Windows 7 system disk (including the SYSTEM RESERVED) partition.
PC backup is awkward at best.

Maybe I'm missing something here, but this one may have to go back. I'd settle for another Synology product with less fluff and stuffing. Just need reliable, fast backups. No mobile sharing.

I have used and am still using the USB 2.0 version of this 1.5 tb portable go flex drive, and I cannot say enough about how pleased I have been with its performance. However, I am not sure what Seagate did to the USB 3.0 version of this drive. The USB 3.0 version is just disappointing. The copying or synchronization of a small number of files worked well, but below the expected speed of even USB 2.0, leave away that of USB 3.0. However, the copying of a large number of files (either through File Explorer or through a Synchronization Software) would invariably freeze up my computer, often for hours at a time. And, once that freezing occurred, my computer wouldn't even respond to restarting the windows operating system. And, my computer is nice and powerful - it has a Core-i7 processor, 8 GB RAM and has a high-speed internal hard drive. So, the computer hardware was not the thing that can be blamed for these freezing up issues. All, I could do to shut down the computer was to hold the power button down and \\"hard\\" shut down the OS. This freezing happened at least 3-4 times. And, finally yesterday (just after 3 weeks of use), all the data on this drive just got corrupt.

I used to be a huge fan of Seagate. But, going forward, I am going to be more circumspect of Seagate and will also give other brands a chance.

This drive was only able to read 2 of 10 blu-rays I owned. I returned it for a refund and purchased the Samsung SE-506BB/TSBD 6X USB2.0 External Slim Blu-ray Writer Drive (Black) instead which works flawlessly with my MacBook Pro.

Now it would not be right of me to shun the monitor for late shipping, and it did happen to come on the same day as my laptop so I didn't have to wait. The problem with it is, it has a dead pixel in the middle of the screen. This also wouldn't be something to complain about but I'm a graphic designer and avid MMO player, so it's unfortunate for me. I admit it's an Android and that excited me, but after having it for 2 months now, I can say this:

-I have WIFI problems, when I sleep (turn off scren) and then turn he screen back on the wifi connection is lost. I have to turn off wifi and then turn it back on... It takes time. Annoying.

- It's a very slow device, some apps run very slowly and the animations lack 'animation'.

- I had to go through a lot to be able to install the Android Market. Plus, the device isn't even recognized by all developers so the options to download apps are fairly limited. For example, Skype is not an option. I have to download tons of APKs na dinstall them manually.

- Some apps don't run properly due to the limitations of the equipment. The camera is very poor so Skype works only on voice, not video.

- I accept Facebook and Twitter work normally most of the time. But they're slow.

- WHat bugs me more is that sometimes when I start it the wifi connection is completely disabled. Only rebooting will put it back on, and sometimes I had to reboot twice. Plus, sometimes, out of the blue, it reboots by itself for NO REASON.

For its price it's a nice device, but if you're planning to use it intensively, like for going to college and using it during class or to work with it, you'll be completely dissapointed and upset.

You better look at other options if you'd like to enjoy a tablet.

If your main use is for reading, I do not recommend this product. It is virtually impossible to see in any bright light, and there is a lot of glare.  It is also too heavy for comfortable reading.  As a tablet, it is quite functional i.e.. for Skype, email, games etc. It's wireless receiver is quite sensitive and it will hook up where other devices fail to get a signal

This works. Another reviewer complained about looseness of the connection on the Samsung tablet and yes, it is a tiny bit loose, but there is no connection problem and it does not fall out. I rarely use it mostly because I don't need to but it feels really good to know that I can use my tablet and recharge it in the car.
Can't really say how this holds up because it was a gift. But it looks nice when I received it.

Corsair 450D Case Review

I have built several computers in the past and have used exclusively Lian-Li cases. From recent reviews, it seems that they have decreased in quality. Because of that, I looked at Corsair cases. They are a reputable brand in the computer component industry and I’ve never had a product of theirs I didn’t like. I listed the components of my build with this case at the bottom. This review contains my initial impression after building my computer yesterday. Hopefully you will find it helpful to sift through the multitude of cases available on the market today.

Overall, this is a very nice case. It is pleasing aesthetically and the brushed aluminum finish on the front is a nice touch. It houses a lot computer in a nicely sized mid-tower case. It has tool-free SSD, hard drive, and optical drive installation. It has 165mm of room for a CPU cooler which will fit my favorite fan and heat sink, the Hyper 212 Evo. The lack of room for cable management behind the motherboard is the main reason I give it 4 instead of 5 stars. Proper cable management is critical when building a computer and though possible, it was difficult to achieve with this case. That being said, the pros definitely outweigh the cons. I would recommend it to a friend with the caveat that it will take them a long time to route the cables properly.

Pros:

-Lightweight nicely sized mid-case.

-Great airflow, especially with the 3.5” HDD cage removed. This was important for my hot overclocking build. There is room for 240mm radiator in the front with a nice and cool push/pull fan setup.

-2 SSD slots behind the motherboard. This is a great feature and I expect lots of case manufacturers will begin to use this location for SSDs. It allows the removal of front hard drive cages and locates the SSD drives and cables out of sight.

-Magnetic dust filters on bottom and top. This will keep the case cleaner no matter where you mount your intake fans (unless you reverse the rear case fan). Front removable panel has filter in front of the intake fans.

-Plenty of room for 2 large GPU cards in SLI

-Large window on side (if you want to see your setup).

-Comes with decent, quiet Corsair fans (2x-140mm, 1x-120mm). I replaced my two front fans with Corsair Air Series AF140 LED Quiet Edition High Airflow Fan - Red (CO-9050017-RLED) fans and couldn’t be happier with their silent operation. I changed them only because I wanted Red LEDs in my front fans.

-Bottom Mount Power Supply. This allows the PSU to pull air from and vent to the outside of the case adding minimal heat load to your system. (Admittedly common anymore, but it is still nice to keep the PSU cooling system separate from the case).

Cons:

-Needs more room for cable routing or at least a vertical channel that protrudes into the case for the large ATX Board wires. It only needs an additional half-inch either way. I would be willing to take a reduction in internal case or desk space for this.

-2 SSD slots behind the motherboard do not have room for the Corsair multiple SATA connector power cables unless you use the very end of the cable. I couldn’t get the mid-cable connections to fit behind the case cover with the other cables. It bulges the case side slightly, but not enough to permanently deform it.

- When an Optical Drive is installed, it leaves and awkward recess in the smooth brushed aluminum fascia. This is a disparity in this otherwise great looking case. I think Corsair should supply an adapter plate that matches the fascia to fill in the recess around the drive. I’ll post pictures.

-Hard drive cage is flimsy and came warped. I was able to square it with just a little pressure from my hands. To me, this shows a lack of quality assurance. It belongs in a $30 case and not in a $120 case. I’m not using it, so it’s nota big deal for me.

-The sides of the case are a little flimsy. There are cases in the same price range that have sturdier sides. The sides are flimsy enough that they are hard to mount to the case. When you attempt to seat it and slide it forward you get tabs that won’t catch. The window side is better because the plastic window actually stiffens the side up.

-The front panel contains a dust filter and is pretty sturdy, but the plastic latches that hold it in seem very weak.

As I said above, I really like the case overall and I’m sure it will provide me years of nice, quiet, cool computing.

I plugged this riser into a setup that had been running fine for weeks without issue.  When I powered on the power supply, there were sparks and a few popping noises.  Smoke began to rise from the end of the riser that was attached to my video card.  I immediately turned off the power, but the damage was done.  Luckily, my high end video card was fine, but my motherboard could not be salvaged.  The seller (Urban Source) informed me that they would gladly refund the $25 riser, but they could not do anything about my $100 motherboard.  The quality of risers on the market right now seems to be sub-par due to the high demand.  I would advise being very careful who you buy from and what brand it is.  I have decided to abandon risers all together and figure out a different way to keep my cards cool.

I thought that this flash drive was above average in performance. Works well between a Macintosh and a PC. I liked the feature--missing from my last flash drive--of easily emptying the drive after use without having to some fancy erasing techniques. In other words, the PNY worked like a real hard drive. I would like the manufacuters to explain in detail how to attach the tread to the laniard. It took me a while to figure it out.

This case fits the WD My Passord SE 750 GB/ 1TB edition well, with some extra space to spare. It has two pockets which can be used for either the hard drive or the cable. The picture was accurate and showed this quite well.

The shell is quite hard, and offers excellent protection from pressure and moderate bumps (not sure how it would hold up with drops...). There is a little extra space for one or two additional cables of similar size to the one that comes with the hard drive. Given that, everything is still extremely secure in both pockets.

The zipper is shielded from the inside of the case to avoid scratching - a good design technique.

My largest criticism for this case is that there isn't much padding. There is a very thin protective layer that composes the orange material, but it's about 1 millimeter thick and doesn't act well as padding. Because of this, I wouldn't count on exemplary drop protection. Also, there is minimal padding protection between the two sides. I could see sharp objects (especially cable heads) from the screened pocket scratching a hard drive. Also, the fit for the hard drive a little tight in either pocket, making it a wee bit difficult to remove or insert. On the other hand this does offer a very secure fit. Because of the fitting issues, but mostly for the lack of a more protective divider inside the case, I don't think this case quite deserves 5-stars.

WD offers a case (which has been criticized as being more accurately represented as a sleeve) that is softer and smaller, but it doesn't offer the same level of crush/pressure protection that this one does. Because the Amazon case is larger, it's doesn't fit an average size pocket well. As a size comparison: the WD case fits inside the Amazon case with the hard drive and USB cable present inside itself. The fit is tight though and I wouldn't doing this recommend this for practical use.

Bottom line: this case does what isadvertised to do.

Personally, I prefer the WD edition. I'm still satisfied with this edition - the WD case just better suits my needs (the small size of the WD case is really nice). I'd recommend this case for anyone looking for the extra protection. The 4 stars are well earned. I'd give 4.25 stars if possible.

Ordered this bluetooth adapter with the intention of using it in my vehicle to stream my Google Music library and other internet radio options from my phone through my car stereo speakers. Since I have an auxilary input option with RCA inputs in my console/arm rest with a 2nd power outlet placed right next to them, a bluetooth adapter such as this seems like the ideal option for wireless connectivity. I did need to purchase a power adapter since it only comes with an AC wall option out of the box, but fully expected that going into the purchase. Sound was great and and even though I did purchase a RCA cable with a ground loop isolator in anticipation of that being an issue, it was almost negligible using Monster Cables without any filter. Was barely noticeable under nearly all situations which was very surprising from past attempts I've made at using this same auxilary input for other playback sources in conjuction with the power supply in the console.

Sadly, I decided to return this item because of a couple of factors:

1) This COULD be more an issue with my phone (Samsung Galaxy Nexus) than the adapter itself, but each time you turn off the car and subsequently the power supply to the adapter, when you start the car back up, the adapter is on and ready to be connected to, but I would have to toggle the bluetooth on my phone off and back on for it to automatically re-connect. Slightly annoying when you're on a LONG road trip with fewer stops and long stretches of listening in between. But for just normal daily driving and much shorter listening periods this just made it not worth it. Again, this could have been my phone but I didn't exactly do a lot of \\"testing\\" to rule out that it was the adaptor either. I did also have a couple of instances where it would seem to re-connect (you hear a little beep through the car speakers each time it re-connects) but for whatever reason the sound wouldn't play at all....track times would be elapsingbut you wouldn't hear anything through the car speakers or the phone speakers, unless you turned bluetooth badk off. And even turning bluetooth on the phone back on didn't seem to fix it. Each time this occurred it would just \\"magically\\" start playing again, wasn't able to determine exactly what I might have done to get it to work correctly. And again, I didn't spend a ton of time/effort trying to diagnose the actual issue.

2) The physical size of the adapter, while not huge by any means, was large enough it took up a bit of space in my console. Granted, the console in my '07 Infiniti G35 isn't exactly gargantuan like something you might find in an SUV, but I still like to make use of it for other things and not have this adapter taking up nearly all of that space.
Do not buy this adapter. I would have rated it a zero if I could. It lasted one week. Spend more cash for something that will work.

Battery arrived within ~ 4 days of my order and in good condition. It fits my Dell Inspiron 1545, and I estimate that it holds a charge for ~ 6+ hours. The downsides: It's a little heavier and bigger than the original battery, so it extends ~ 3/4" out the back of the computer, rather than fitting flush as the original did. It still fits in my laptop sleeve, though, and it can be a helpful "handle" when wrangling the machine in and out of bags.  All in all, this was a good deal. The added weight & bulk is a minimal inconvenience for a much more functional computer, and this relatively inexpensive battery seems a more sensible choice than buying something sleek and expensive for an old, already heavy computer.

I think it's also stretched out a little bit over the first week of use, so that it now fits more or less perfectly... at the beginning, it was coming loose on one end because it was a fraction of a millimeter too short.

Overall, a good buy-- I don't know if you'll find a less obtrusive keyboard protector. And I really like being able to wash this thing off every few days, since I work in a healthcare setting.

Only qualm-- it does leave a bit of smudge on my screen. I'm guessing the best way to avoid that is to clean it more frequently so that it doesn't accumulate grease.

It feels a little bit flimsy on the IDE connection, but the work to get the files out of the old HDD gets done. I wrote this in other reviews I did of camera bags, I used to be a full-time hobbyist who loved to go out shooting, but my interests and commitment have changed since becoming a parent. I downsized from a DSLR setup to a Mirrorless and have since had my needs in a camera bag change. Prior to having kids I would pack the usual camera gear for enthusiasts (filters, tripod, on occassion flashes, OCF supplies, etc). Now my bag is half camera equipment and half kid gear. You're as likely to find a sippy cup or extra snacks or diapers in my bag as you would a spare battery or memory card wallet. If I had no kids, this bag would get 5 stars from me, it just packs a massive amount of gear.

As I write this review Im in the middle of a 2 night, 3 day trip on D.C. and just spent the day at the National Zoo. I had with me the Sony a6000, 16-70 f/4, the 24 f/1.8, and the 70-200 f/4. All fits in this bag with room to spare. think tank lists that you can fit the 70-200 f/4 in the bottom left pouch, and you can, but with the hood reversed and the tripod collar off. I had it setup with the a6000 and the 16-70 attached in the top left, the 24 and the 20 pancake in the top right pouch, and the 70-200 in the bottom left pouch. The others were left empty.

Pros
- again, a lot of space for lenses and other gear. Can fit a laptop and tablet. Can fit a 70-200 f/4. I could've had room for 3-4 other lenses, and a lot of other camera equipment.
- included rain cover. Seems trivial, but with my other main bag, the Mindshift Gear Panorama, which is more expensive than this one ($199) and made by the same parent company it's a $20 option.
- lots of extra pockets for more storage of small items like caps, filters, card holders, etc.
- opens up nicely to allow more gear placed on the bottom without having a flap come over like a lot of other backpacks such as the TT Streetwalker.
- zippers are top notch, shoulder straps are nicely padded.

Cons
- Again for me who has to carry kid stuff, a lot of which may get wet (sippy cups, juice boxes, etc), having no isolated section is a negative. This is the main reason why Im keeping my rotation 180 as my go to backpack. I can keep my kids things in the top section, my camera gear in the belt section, and have access to both easily. Can also ask my wife or someone else with me to just zip open the top and take what they need out without me having to remove the bag.

- Having so much room might lead one to overpack. I'll be honest I got this bag simply because it said it could hold a 70-200 f/4 in the bag. It can but storing/removing is a lot of work. Have to remove the tripod collar, reverse the hood, zip the bag wide open, etc.

- Being able to store all this gear doesn't help with accessibility. Still have to take the bag off to remove the camera/change lenses. At that point you end up carrying the camera on a strap around your shoulder most of the time, then the bag ends up just being a lens storage system and you have this larger bag on your back with a lot of empty space.

- Waist belt seems cheap and useless. It's funny how much different it is on this vs the rotation 180. Obviously the rotation 180's one needs to be nicely made because it's the main part of that bag, but that one just screams quality vs this one which seems like an afterthought.

- Pack is comfortable for the most part. Maybe it's just me, but any pack, regardless of how it's made will start to wear on you sooner or later. I love reading reviews of other bags where the reviewer says that they're able to carry it for hours and hours and not feel a thing. I mean you're carrying 10-20 lbs on your back, how could it not weight you down. But this bag seems less comfortable than my mindshift bag. I'm sitting here with sore shoulders and discomfort in my upper back.

Again, if you're strictly a shooter and can carry your camera gear and only that and want a bag that can fit a lot of gear for a Mirrorless system, this is the bag for you. I thought that it would be the ideal bag for me. And 2 years ago it would be. But now for present me, the one who has small kids, this isn't it. I'll be sticking with my rotation 180 bag for the foreseeable future.

I bought this to replace a 10-year-old iMac DV that had kept our music collection networked for many years until it died recently. I knew I wanted to get an NAS with mirrored RAID because the thought of having to rip so many CDs again was not pleasant. We are an all-Mac household as well, so we needed something that did not require a PC for initial setup (I'm looking at you, HP Media Vault).    What's good:  -Very fast reads and writes to the ReadyNAS Duo. I now keep my iTunes Music folder on the NAS and the iTunes Library file on my Macbook Pro, and the performance is great.  -Fast network speeds using AFP (the standard network protocol for a Mac).  -Fairly easy to setup the basics using their wizard.  -Lots of advanced options if you need it (password-protected accounts, Internet access).  -Easy printer sharing. Just plug in your USB printer! (And no Mac limitations like the Synology.)  -Recognized my APC-brand UPS; it can monitor the UPS and automatically shut down during a power outage when the battery drains to a certain level (you can set the remaining battery level to your liking).  -Built-in backup software allows you to backup to an external USB drive at the push of a button (though I haven't tested this yet).  -iTunes streaming server works very well; it's very fast over the local network. It shows up in iTunes under the \\"Shared\\" section as \\"Itunes Server.\\"  -Small and quiet.  -Uses less energy than the old iMac.  -Adding a second hard drive (like I did) gives you peace of mind with data redundancy.  -Solid construction.  -Hot-swappable drives on trays (you can also purchase extra trays to rotate drives).  -Easy to expand the storage by swapping in larger hard drives one at a time (though I haven't tested this).  -Great widget for the Mac to monitor the Duo (available capacity, temperature, UPS condition, fan speed).  -Configuration is done through a web browser.    What's bad:  -The UPnP streaming is really poor. Previously I used Connect360 on the old iMac to stream music and movies to an Xbox 360, and the iMac was many, many times faster than the Duo. It can take 20 seconds or so for the Xbox 360 to fully load any one of the music lists (Albums, Artists, etc.). By comparison, if I turn on Connect360 on my Macbook Pro and stream the same 93GB iTunes Library from the Duo, the performance is great! (Then again, the Videos folder on the Duo does not have a lot of subfolders and it loads fairly quickly.) Obviously I'm not an expert on UPnP servers, but if streaming media is your absolute top priority, this might not be the box for you.  -The documentation is really light. You'll need to go to the ReadyNAS forums to get answers at some point. As far as forums go, they are very helpful.  -You will need some knowledge of networking terms. Not hard to learn, but the software was clearly not written by anyone from Apple.  -Expect to spend at least 30 minutes with the initial setup, not including any file copying that needs to be done.  -Too little RAM. I upgraded to 1GB (available through Amazon).  -Small list of approved hardware upgrades, including RAM, UPS and hard drives. There also seems to be a lag in approving new items.  -Not all brands of UPS are supported.  -Approved hard drives are server-grade, not consumer desktop models. Expect to pay about 50% more (but theoretically they should be more reliable). I purchased a second hard drive from Amazon from the approved list (a Western Digital 500GB) for ~$90.  -Not the cheapest NAS out there.    What's needed:  -Better UPnP streaming. I'm not sure if this is a software limitation or a processor limitation.   -More base RAM.    To sum it up: My only real knock against it is the UPnP streaming. As an NAS, it offers reliable and redundant storage combined with fast network speeds; works with different operating systems (and works very well with Macs); and it's very energy efficient. Unless media streaming is at the absolute top of your list, the ReadyNAS Duo offers great performance for the price.     For added research, check out the charts at [...]  There's a great feature to sort by Price vs. Performance. Highly recommended!
