I had high hopes for this unit. The specs look great, the capacity is huge, and it comes with NovaBackup and access online through a buffalo website and phone app.
Now, after ordering, exchanging, and returning 2 of these units, I am wiser and able to, I hope, save another unsuspecting customer from the aggravation and subsequent disillusionment that this product caused me.
Specs and software sound good until it arrives, you plug it in, and you install the software. The first thing you notice is the slow firmware interface. For a product that boasts a 1.6Ghz internal processor, a lag of plus or minus 5 seconds is long and feels longer every time you access it. Want to log in to the firmware? That's an extra 10 to 15 seconds. Flipping through the various pages of firmware settings? 5 seconds of wait coming your way. I didn't actually measure it but is a long enough delay that the programmers added a loading animation to make sure you didn't think it a bug. Every page people. After comparing the performance to my netgear router, it came away looking pretty pathetic, and my router isn't packing the kind of hardware found in this NAS.
Then there's the update issues. My first unit prompted me to update virtually the instant I plugged it in. That's how it should be you say; At least until you get the error message about the DTCP-IP protocol not being able to update. Yeah, the firmware update is broken into 2 distinct parts. For those not familiar with it, the DTCP-IP protocol is a function connected to DLNA, the standard file sharing software, that allows the unit to work with copyrighted media. Apparently, one of the 'perks' that the company fails to mention in it's marketing material is a bug in the update algorithm for DTCP-IP that prevents it from updating. I thought it might be teething troubles, so I checked the buffalo forums. They had questions and complaints about this particular issue going back to January of this year. When I contacted tech support and asked about it, I was told this was a known issue and that a fix was on it's way. When, I asked? No idea, they said. Lovely.
I decided that I would deal with it as DLNA still worked with non-copyright stuff and the unit was still pretty speedy on storage and retrieval.
Then I installed the NovaBackup software. There's an upgrade, I was told. Click here! So I clicked. A page on the NovaBackup site came up. Special Deal! Buffalo customers can update free! ($20 handling charge). Excuse me? So now let me get this straight... I can upgrade the pack-in software, trumpeted on all the marketing material as free, with a $260 product, only to find that the free upgrade has a $20 handling charge for the incredibly laborious backend action associated with me clicking on the download button?! The website helpfully stated that those with a license key could click on the download button for really for real free. So I looked for the key on the installed app. What a surprise that the key info panel was blank. So, I emailed Buffalo, expressing my distaste for this rather obvious attempt to bilk me of an extra $20. You're welcome to use the version included with the unit, was the terse reply. Gee, thanks. Anyone out there old enough to remember shareware? I'm here to tell you, it ain't dead; It shacked up with Buffalo, Inc.
Then there was the webaccess feature. I have an android phone. They have an android app named WebAccess. Sweet I thought. Access through phone. What could go wrong? Enabled it through the unit firmware. Downloaded app. Started app with big grin on my face. App states it would love to work; all it needs is for me to turn off SSL because the app doesn't support it. Face loses grin. Emailed tech support to inquire just what kind of insane company produces an android app intended to stream an individual's personal data to one of the most insecure technological inventions yet devised by man, a smartphone, that does not allow encryption of said dataBY DESIGN.
Fine, I thought, me being of the eternally generous (some would say gullible) disposition. I still have a decent, if slightly hobbled, NAS solution. Until a week later, when the unit started clicking loudly every 5 minutes. Now I'm a semi-pro computer tech and I know that sound. It said 'bad hard drive controller' very loudly whilst running across my desk stark naked with a sign that screamed 'dead duck' in big, ugly letters. So I emailed tech support. They told me to RMA it.
Sigh.
Unit number 2 arrived a week later. Plugged it in and it said nothing about an update for firmware, despite the very obvious fact that the version was obsolete. Nothing a could do would get this thing to even acknowledge it needed to update.
It was a moot point as it happened, since this unit sounded like a box of crickets the instant I turned it on. Cue desk streaker with annoying voice and ugly placard. RMA numero dos. This time I got my money back.
Do yourself a favor and get a Synology NAS. The DS112j is pretty sweet...

Light-weight

Comes with a DVD burner (being an audiophile I cannot do without a burner, secondly I am a Linux junkie so I keep testing new distros all the time besides burning them for friends and family)

Matte screen (I cannot stand glossy screens as they give me headaches with the glare)

Large storage which is speedy

Great battery life

Well built with metallised case

Good keyboard and trackpad

The answer was - Samsung Series 5 Ultrabook

It is very different from all those IBM Thinkpads I used all these years (I went through 5 of them in last 15 years)

I updated most of the software, as well as windows updates. After registering it with Samsung they also gave me 3 extra months of warranty.

Out of the box the default settings were all Samsung optimized so it was a balance between power and extended battery life. I put it in high performance mode and this is when this thing was blazingly fast, The trade-off was battery lasting 4 instead of 7 hours, still not bad.

What I really liked:

Speed
Hard drive capacity
Screen and graphics
Sound better than I expected from the speakers considering it is and ultra thin and light laptop
Good wifi connectivity, locks in and does not drop the connection.

Fit and finish is excellent for the price but not really built like a tank which was standard for the Thinkpads. (Thinkpads also costs more for the sake of argument)
Not much bloat-ware, although I did delete a few programs which I would not use

Samsung software updates worked like a charm, it not only updated all the software and patches but also updated the bios without any hassle. The laptop is eligible for free Windows 8 upgrade.

Full recovery disk came with the package plus hidden partition of Samsung for factory reset, I tested it and it took only 11 minutes to restore. Back in the 90's a factory restore on my first IBM laptop took 6 hours

4 GB ram in single bank and bank 2 empty so upgrading is not wasteful and I can simply drop a 4 GB mem stick in the empty one for a total of 8 GB on-board. A 4 GB stick on Amazon is for $24. I have seen other laptops with 2 GB in each slot or a stick of 4 in fixed and 2 in user replaceable slot which means in order to upgrade your 2 GB stick is rendered useless for which you have paid.

Plenty of ports for all kinds of connections including a vga port (I am surprised they managed it on this one, many ultra-books do not sport one).

What I did not like:

The keyboard: my IBM laptop was too good, no comparison here, the tactile feedback is nowhere near the IBM one. It was generally said about IBM keyboards that they were the best, now I understand why they said so. However the keyboard on this machine is much better than most out there today.

Keyboard is not back-lit or illuminated, I sorely miss this. I use my laptop at night in bed and the illumination was very useful.

The A/C cord length is not as long as I would have liked.

All in all it was a good decision to go for it. I have been playing around with it for good two weeks and I have to say it is giving very good service and I am beginning to like it more and more.

Disclaimer: I did not buy it on Amazon but from my workplace as I was eligible for an employee discount.

Updated: January 14, 2013

It was very important that I update this review after having used the computerfor sometime now. In the middle of December after just 29 days of using the laptop, it died on me. I was unable to get it to start, only the power light was on and the other lights would not come on. I contacted Samsung over the phone and after going through the routine with the tech support they finally asked me to send it for repairs. A return label was emailed to me and I sent the laptop off to them. after about two weeks in early January I received it back from Samsung who informed me that the motherboard and the battery were replaced. All this work was covered under the warranty.

I was slightly dissapointed in a way that I was left without a laptop for 15 days and in my opinion Samsung should have given me a new one promptly. Nevertheless, I was very satisfied in the sense that they did not touch the hard drive or reformatted it but sent it back in the same condition, intact with all the changes I had done in terms of updating the existing system, installing software of my choice and customizing it. By leaving it intact it saved me a lot of hassle of going through the routine again.

I also noticed that the laptop was returned in same condition as I had shipped it to them which looked practically brand new and scratchless.

I was very disappointed with this motherboard. The package is great, the cables are there, the doc's that come with it and the stickers are great, but the motherboard is dead. Unpacking the board from the bag and turning it upside down, I saw traces of soldering all over the board. I confirm that this was the work of the Chinese manufacturers, since only they can leave capacitors half soldered and soldering solution spread all over the board. In plain words, the back of the board was covered in a sticky solution that I had to wash off with alcohol (this is what they were supposed to do). In theory it doesn't cause any serious malfunction, but come on, this is Intel we are talking about!
I plugged the board and it was starting on it's own and shutting down whenever it wanted. I later discovered, that the power button was soldered and either it was the soldering solution or the button malfunction. Each time I tried to figure out the cause of the problem, I caught my self on a thought that this is not supposed to be my concern! I payed for a working motherboard and I received cheap Chinese quality!
When powering on, the board kept giving me a code 21 error no mater the memory configuration. In other words, the board is completely screwed!
Since I do not live in the US, I can't return the product, because it would cost me half the price just to send it back.
I really wanted to like this board! I was so excited about it and now I am completely heart broken! Thanks for nothing Intel.
My advice, stick with ASUS and Google each board carefully with the key word \\"problems\\". I bought an ASUS to replace this board and it works like a charm.

The Case Logic MLM-111 11-inch laptop and iPad Messenger Case is about what you would expect from Case Logic. It's a nice little bag and by that I mean it is nice - and it is little. It does not hold much. It is advertised to hold \\"a 11'' laptop, daily notebook, headphones or other accessories\\" but I am not really seeing the \\"Spacious organization compartment\\" that supposedly \\"accommodates a charger, pens and small accessories.\\" If by accessories they mean that set of headphones, you're golden. Otherwise, it will bulge and the flap will not stay closed.

The clap doesn't snap you see. It is just held down by its weight, which is a magnet located in the little part you see that folds over the left side in the image. So sure, put your 11\\" notebook in there, or your iPad or Kindle but don't expect to fit a lot else inside. You might be able to cram in the advertised \\"map, magazine, snack or ticket inside the back panel pocket\\" but don't go crazy on the snack.

It is great for its intended purpose, though the unsecured flap concerns me a bit. Personally, I would not pay $40 for this bag and if I had paid $40 I would be disappointed. The three stars I gave it reflect both the price and my concerns with the flap, more than the limited storage capacity, because I did not have high hopes going in. This is, I suppose, the sort of bag we will see popping up more frequently as our technology gets smaller but I'm one of those people who never feels quite ready without a paper notebook and pen. And gods forbid you decide to bring an honest-to-goodness paperback with you in addition to your technology.

First of all, let me say that the router is pretty good for the average 1300sqft home if you put it in a well centralized location. I don't usually like to write reviews but this one got me, not for the obvious reasons. The router works great, has many user friendly settings, it’s a dual band and even has the guest network. Let me advise you, and I strong recommend it, use the CD that comes with the router to set it up. It's a breeze. What I wanted to warn you though, beware if you have any computers running Vista, in my case 32Bit. I had a Linksys E1000 that did the job before, I have 3 laptops, 2 iPads, 2 kindles and three iPods, not all running at the same time of course, Plus I have Netgear switch feeding two 3 DVRs, PlayStation, a surround sound, smartv, a DVD player and a roku. I know I have a lot of stuff, but I had to change my router ONLY because my wifi kept dropping. This router is nice looking and does the job so far. However, back to my vista laptop. My son, who is a Minecraft fanatic, loves his laptop so he can play. After I connected the new router, everything worked flawlessly, EXCEPT the laptop that has vista, which is my son's. I could connect to the router no problem, but there was no internet access at all, only unidentifiable network. The ONLY resolution I could find was that the laptop could only connect to WEP encryption, and not the WPA which the N capability works on, not the WEP. So it as a major bummer to accept this because now I had to change this one setting so all my other devices connects to accommodate this one laptop. I did some research and found two articles. My current wireless adapter Atheros 5007 was running a driver version of 7.x.something. I came across this one article that this one guy shared the SAME ISSUE and all he did was update his driver. Let me advise you that you won’t be able to find the updated driver by finding the network device in the device manager and updating the driver. You must download it. The update driver feature will say that the driver is up to date. I found a link, which I hope I can post, that took me to a HP website (my laptop is a HP) to download the driver and it had the hp assistant. Once it downloaded, and I installed it, my network connection restarted and BAMMMMM! My new network driver version is 9.2.0.427. I was able to connect to the wireless network using WPA rather than WEP, shortly after I changed the security type from another computer. Overall, that little hiccup set me back, but I'm sure I'll be more than happy with my new router. Better range, and better transfer speeds. Hope this helps!!
Article
http://www.bleepingcomputer.com/forums/t/457095/cant-connect-wi-fi-with-wpa-on-vista/

Driver
http://h10025.www1.hp.com/ewfrf/wc/softwareDownloadIndex?softwareitem=ob-108903-1&cc=us&dlc=en&lc=en&jumpid=reg_r1002_usen_c-001_title_r0001

My Girlfriend was sweet enough to buy me a tablet for christmas and I couldnt have been more excited. The tablet is very nice looking and didnt appear flimsy... Then I turned it on!!! Immediately I noticed the screen is next to impossible to use with your finger so we found a stylus from a old blackberry. Im not a weak man and Im rather large but the screen took a rediculous amount of effort to get it to react and if you tried using the onscreen keyboard the letter you select is 2 letters away from the one the tablet selected. I even calibrated the screen a few times to see if that was the issue. Even if the screen wasnt flawed it wouldnt have been long with the amount of pressure needed to make it react. So that was frustrating but I figured for the price it would take some getting used to. Then.... The screen started blinking at me??? What was going on? I did only charge it for a few minutes so I figured I would let it sit on the charger over night and try it again in the morning. Worked for about 10 minutes before the screen would start blinking again then went blank completely. I shut it off even did a reset a few times finally after a dozen or so times I gave up and said this has to be returned! Dont purchase this tablet! If you want a tablet save your money! This isnt a case of you get what you pay for, this is a case of poor manufacturing trying to cheap out.  ONE MORE THING! ONLY PURCHASE FROM AMAZON DIRECTLY!!! NEVER THE OTHER SELLERS! Ive had a such horrible luck so far but Amazon direct has always been the best online company Ive ever dealt with! Pay extra to always make sure your item is not being shipped directly from a foreign distributer. I finally had to have my credit card company get my money back because they denied receiving it even though I had a tracking number and they signed for it! Good Luck Shoppers!

This never really worked with Apple iMac Time Machine. It was easy enough to set up (if you've set up LAN-based devices before) and Time Machine worked great the first day. Then I started getting failure messages daily indicating the drive had a \\"username or password\\" problem and Time Machine could not back up my work.

Re-entering the password would make it work once, then it would fail again the next day. I searched widely for a solution (others had the problem but not the fix), and I put up with the problem for about a year -- I even wiped/reinstalled the drive -- before I gave up on it and got a different brand.

Here's the error message:
\\"Time Machine could not complete the backup. The network backup disk could not be accessed because there was a problem with the network username or password. Open Time Machine preferences to select the network backup disk and re-enter the correct username and password.\\"

Do not buy any of the Pogo devices. This is not a NAS, it is a device that you have to have a software license for each machine that connects to it and you have to use an Internet connection to be able to use it. For about $100 you can buy a real NAS that looks like another machine on the network, has 1TB of space (for slightly more, you can get an NAS with 2TB), can be accessed by Windows (XP and above), old (PowerPC) and new (Intel) Mac with OSX of 10.3.9 or later, or Linux (using Samba), and requires no extra software license (it supports Windows Networking directly), and it works whether or not you have an Internet connection.

I know because I have both one of these and a Buffalo NAS with built-in hard drive, I have Windows machines and an old Mac, and the Buffalo \\"just works\\" with all of them, and will be cheaper when you realize this is just a sharing device (that requires a per-machine license) and does not include any hard drives, you have to connect them to it and install a software driver on each machine you want to connect to it.

The \\"True HD 1080p\\" is probably this display's main selling point. The only HD source I had handy was an Xbox 360 with VGA output and a copy of Halo 3. The image quality was excellent and edege-to-edge with no black bars or image distortion. As an added bonus, the HD resolution requires a very sharp .248 dot pitch -- perfect for day to day use with text. The downside of True HD 16:9 is that the viewable height is only 10 and 5/8 (the shortest of any 22' LCD I've looked at) as opposed to a full 11 inches or more for viewing a two-page layout WYSIWYG.    The monitor installs easily and is automatically recognized by XP as a Plug and Play Monitor. The only advantage to installing Viewsonic's driver package (that I could tell) was the addition of a color-calibrated profile -- which didn't seem to make any difference.    Like most modern LCDs, its stand has only a tilt adjust and no height adjustment. I guess the assumption is that with a wide viewing angle, height adjustment is less critical.    I like that the screen has a matte, non-glare finish. I wish I could say the same about the bezel. The high gloss attracts fingerprints and dust like... well you fill in your own colorful analogy.    Button placement, on the lower right, is a poor choice for placing two displays side by side and flush. You can barely read the button labels against the piano black bezel, and the status indicator is far too big and bright. But I like how input source switching (VGA or DVI) can be achieved with a single button press.    The OSD has its share of quirks. Why did Viewsonic think the end user would enjoy being nagged about setting the display to 1920x1080 for optimal performance? Thankfully, this can be disabled. But it should never have been in the software in the first place.    As so many others have noted, the sound quality of the built-in rear-firing 2x2W speakers are truly abysmal -- completely without bass response of any kind and adequate for only the most basic of computer beeps.    The different ECO modes are an interesting concept and might be helpful if you plan on leaving the display on 24/7 without a screen saver -- to monitor a dynamic website for example. The most conservative setting (50% reduction in brightness) seems a bit too dark at first, but I was surprised at how quickly my eyes adapted.     In contrast (pun intended) the dynamic contrast feature worked poorly, often rendering video that was simply too dark. Also, ECO shouldn't be used with dynamic contrast and it would be good user interface design to automatically shut off the one when the other is selected. It would also be more useful if it were easier to access. I need to press nine buttons every time I want to change ECO settings. I'd love to see all 4 buttons replaced with a pushable scroll-wheel like on an HTC Mogul phone.     Rather than dynamic contrast, I would much rather have a dynamic ECO feature -- turning down the brightness during periods of less redrawing activity. Or better yet -- have some ability to sense ambient light levels and adjust brightness accordingly.    Bottom line: This is an excellent display for gaming, watching movies, and everyday use so long as you BYOS (bring your own speakers). Graphics professionals will want to look elsewhere.

I ordered my kindle Fire HD with the aspirations of using it as my main weapon of choice for conquering my classes at school. I was going to use it mainly for keeping books and documents on my device and as a medical study tool. I am an avid Google user, so naturally I was torn between the new Nexus 7 FDH and this. Because of an amazing deal that Amazon ordered I decided to go with the kindle. I was excited. Once I received my device, the hidden disappointments began to roll in. Carousel; is pointless and rather aggravating to use. It becomes an endless list that's annoying to continually delete programs from. My other disappointment is how shallow the app base is for the kindle. Very controlling; almost like Apple but without the massive app resources. I can't use Google chrome, google docs (side note: amazon does have their own versions of cloud storage, but I prefer the seamless browsing that google provides) or any google play apps or even Itunes apps; only amazon apps (mainly consisting of paid apps). The tablet is a beautify made and the screen is crisp and responsive. The real power of the kindle comes from the massive Amazon prime account. So if you're not into that, you're pretty much missing out on the true point of this tablet; a media devouring machine. This thing has potential, but Amazon put's limits of what could be an amazing device. Despite it's beautiful screen, the adds, the limited app store, the need to get an amazon prime account to get real use out of it, the useless Carousel option, the lack of support for google made it a no for me. I ended up sending it back and getting a Nexus 7 FDH instead, which is what I should have done in the first place.

This a nice general purpose board. However it has VERY limited expansion possibilities at this time. There are only 4 internal sata connectors (2 sata iii-2 sata ii). This might be okay for a micro atx installation, but this is a full atx motherboard with provisions for the latest Intel processors.  One would think that you might want to do a little more with the build than a $399 bargain store machine.  The MAJOR point here is if you wanted to add additional sata ports--like a raid controller card--YOU WILL NOT BE ABLE to do this at this point in time (Have upgraded the bios to Intel,s latest). Have tried LSI, Highpoint, 3Ware (Pcie-x1  and Pcie-x4) all of which worked flawlessly on Boxed Intel Desktop Board Extreme Series ATX Form Factor for Second Generation Intel Core Family Processors BOXDP67BGB3--NONE work on the Intel Desktop Motherboard LGA1155 DDR3 1600 ATX - BOXDH77KC. Even tried a cheap PCI silicon chipset based card--PROBLEMS.  Not sure if its the change from sandy bridge to this newer 3rd generation. One reviewer states that it is a no frills board--that is okay, BUT you should be able to add SOME frills (it has the necessary slots on the motherboard). Also tried an old Promise PCI non raid sata card--NO LUCK--basically the computer, if it \\"sees\\" the card at all will just sit on the Intel logo screen. I did get it to boot without any hard drives attached to the add on cards. Went thru the whole process of booting without hard drives attached (have several WD Caviar Black 1 Terrabyte units that have worked with the above listed raid cards on the BOXDP67BGB3 BUT NOT with the raid cards on the BOXDH77KC--Even got them to work with these raid cards on an older Supermicro core 2 duo board with Pcie slots) AND then attached and created raid--NO BOOT--sits on the Intel logo screen.  I even noticed 1 person on that auction site selling his new BOXDH77KC with the same basic comments concerning the use of add on raid cards (he just wanted to build an inexpensivehome server). Have not tried other Pcie add on cards EXCEPT the SAPPHIRE AMD Radeon HD 6870 1GB GDDR5 PCIE Graphics Card which works flawlessly on this motherboard.  Maybe Intel will address this issue in a further bios update.  It seems that any add on card that may have a \\"bios\\" on it (as raid cards do) have a problem with this motherboard. Again, I did not expect many \\"frills\\", BUT you should be able to ADD some (the motherboard has the slots). That is the reason for the 3 stars.

Don't buy HP laptops! The firm I work for has 4 elitebooks and they are the most unreliable laptops I have ever run across. I told them that it was extremely important to have these problems fixed ASAP so they said that they would send out a tech with the parts to replace them. Later that afternoon I received the quote from HP for the parts and labor to fix the machine that was still under the parts warranty and it came out to $2400. That's right $2400 to fix a $2300 machine! Needless to say the appointment with the tech was canceled, and it is now four days later and HP has still not come up with a reasonable fix to my problem. After having the livescribe pulse pen 2GB for several years, the battery is completely dead. The battery has under 50 cycles on it, but is ~3yrs old. I used the pen on a Monday evening for an hour meeting, at the end of the meeting the remaining charge was almost full. I placed the pen in the cradle, went to upload the meeting to the computer and the Livescribe Desktop software told me there was an update to it and a firmware update to the pen. I ran the updates, as I have in the past and continued to upload the meeting to the computer. Had the continuation of the meeting the next morning and when removing the pen from the cradle it had a full charge. There was about 20 minutes of non business chatter prior to the meeting, and after these 20 minutes, the pen was dead. Kaput!  I went to the support site, and there were suggestions on re-flashing the pen. I did. No fix, in the morning removed the pen from the cradle with an indicated full charge. After 20 minutes it'st dead after another full evening of charging (plugged into a computer that does NOT go to sleep).   Here's the real bummer. Livescribe/Pulse offers no battery replacement. They offer no discount or upgrade path over what you can get for yourself online. The end result is you're buying a pen that will be dead sooner or later, and there is no guarantee after the first year. This is an expensive luxury that I may have to abandon.

The screen protector came in an envelope tucked in the bottom of an Amazon box with multiple other items from my order. I immediately noticed that the protector for the top of the tablet was creased.

I knew it was going to be a water install, which didn't phase me because I have installed many Zagg products in the past. What I didn't realize was that it didn't come with the solution. My own ability to put a reasonable amount of liquid on the protector and the device was seriously miscalculated. My review might be slightly better if it had come with a spritz bottle (like Zagg ones do) rather than instructions to make my own solution.

Anyway, there was so much liquid in my install that it was difficult to squeegee it out fully while keeping the protector in place. I also was unimpressed with the squeegee itself. It was a small piece of cardboard (as opposed to the rubber one Zagg provides) that was fully capable of scratching the protector in the process of squeegeeing!

Once I got as many bubbles out as I could and had everything perfectly aligned, I left it alone for a while. When I came back there were new bubbles and lots of 'em! At that point the protector was stuck on enough that they couldn't be worked out without ruining it. I just had to wait longer and hope they disappeared. Which they did, mostly.

The next day when I wanted to start using my computer again I was disappointed to find that the screen protector had a sticky texture to it. The areas that are heavily touched, such as scrolling areas, began to feel less tacky fairly quickly. Overall though, the cover has enough tack to make swipes stick a bit. It definitely doesn't feel like glass.

After a few days with it on, I noticed that the keyboard for the T100A presses on the protector. If you leave it shut for a while, the screen protector will have a dent/scratch that doesn't go away in a reasonable amount of time. It's right in the middle of the screen and very distracting.

I'm pretty disappointed with this product overall. It is easily scratched (as evidenced by multiple scratches caused my the squeegee), it feels tacky and was terribly hard to put on without a solution spray provided. Had it come with a spray, I likely would not have scratched it while squeegeeing as I wouldn't have had so much liquid to remove.

Luckily the price was good at least. I would never have bought this if it were selling for full price. $10 with Prime is my limit.

The 3rd Generation Kindle reader is the first eBook reader that I have ever owned.  While it's not perfect, there are many more things that I like about the Kindle than things I dislike.  Consequently, I feel confident in recommending it to most users, and in particular to users, like me, who enjoy discovering new books, have run out of space to store physical books, and have a bright indoor space to read in.      For me, reading on the Kindle was not \\"love at first sight\\".  Unlike a physical book, the Kindle features a large screen, prominently located in the middle of the device.  This would be fine except that the screen's location is precisely where I put my thumbs while reading!  Like most issues with the Kindle, however, this one is easily remedied:  A Kindle cover, such as M-Edge's excellent Go! cover solves this problem nicely, allowing you to hold the Kindle as just you would a physical book, without putting your thumbs on the screen.    The second problem I had with the Kindle was just getting used to reading on it.  I have read hardcover and paperback books all my life, from the time I was 2 years old to today - over 25 years.  The Kindle simply feels different than a paper book.  Besides being much lighter than most books, the Kindle has roughly equal weight distribution, with slightly more weight located in the lower half of the device (where I'd assume the battery is).  The Kindle's 3 built-in fonts (Regular, Condensed, and Sans Serif) are all excellent - when they're properly used by the book publishers.  Reading the Kindle is as easy as reading a paper book, provided you have adequate lighting.  \\"Adequate\\" in my experience, is light that you can comfortably read a paper book by.  As the Kindle is a passive (as opposed to backlit) reading device, you will require a source of light.  Having said that, it reads excellently in direct sunlight based on my experience.    Instead of pages, the Kindle uses \\"locations\\", and this takes some getting used to.  My one-thousand (1,000) page paperback copy of War & Peace has over twenty-six thousand (26,000) locations on the Kindle.  Were it not for the Bookmark function, this would make finding my place in the book rather difficult!  Fortunately, the Kindle lets me easily bookmark, annotate, and highlight passages of interest while I am reading.  These features, combined with the linking feature, make reading even more of a pleasure than with traditional books.  For example, I love history books, and on the Kindle I can click to a numbered footnote link, read the footnote, and simply press the \\"Back\\" key on the Kindle to return to where I am reading.  Before getting the Kindle, I used a combination of sticky notes and my fingers to do this.  With the Kindle, navigating my favorite books is both simpler and easier.    Overall Impression:  While it took some getting used to (I was physically uncomfortable with the Kindle for about 2 weeks until I learned how to hold it comfortably) I am now a Kindle convert.  Because it's so easy to download book samples, I've downloaded about a dozen books that interest me, and purchased a half a dozen more.  Also, I know how to make the Kindle work for me:  Fonts, number of words per line, and line spacing are all easily adjustable.  The built-in dictionary - the New Oxford American Dictionary - is superb, and lets me quickly and easily find definitions to new words without interrupting my reading experience.  And though there is currently no equally good dictionary in French (my second language), I expect that it's only a matter of time before one is made available through the Kindle store.  And that's the beauty of the Kindle:  It's a functional, highly useful eBook reader now, whose capabilities will continue to evolve with time.  In short, it's worth buying now, and will only get better with time.  4/5

I have a hard time understanding why this is so popular. Once again I made the mistake of ordering whatever was reviewed most/highest and have been let down! I've had a lot of different speaker sets and have been building home and car audio setups for years. I would consider myself an audiophile, and cannot stand when you buy something such as this that is supposed to be fairly high end, and it sounds horrible.

What I didn't like:
1) Most importantly, the mids and highs are horrible! There is no crispness here at all, and some tones don't come across at all. Maybe I'm rating too hard, this is after all a fairly cheap system. Bass was not that clean either and seemed to focus around a very tight frequency range.
2) The left and right speakers have specialized connectors, meaning there is no way to extend them, they are tethered to the sub (which is typical, however these are very short and did not allow me enough length to setup my desk the way I wanted)
3) Poor construction and quality control... The connector for the left speaker at the sub/amp was very loose. I actually could not tell if it was making a connection and felt it may actually fall out on it's own. In addition, there was very audible static while doing anything with the right speaker (where controls are). If I just touched (not pressing) the power button it made all kinds of noise! The input cable that came with the system had a short as well and I had to replace it right away or every time it was touched there would be very loud sounds!
4) Very susceptible to interference. If the cable going to the right speaker is anywhere near a power source you will hear lots of background noise!

What I did like:
1) It powered on and played sound... Plenty of power, volume, and bass.
2) No, that's actually all I liked about this system.

I agree with a few of the other reviewers, those who are saying this system sounds wonderful are either deaf or have not had a chance to compare directly with anything better!

Decent headset. The sound quality is a bit better than average $10 earphones. Comfort wise they're good, fit my head perfectly, and no pain after hours of wearing. The mic isn't the best, if you make it loud enough for people to hear you clearly then you'll get that faint buzzing noise in the background(a problem many low cost headsets have). The only thing this headset does really well is in it's capability of producing that nice bass. These have a real nice bass that can be overpowering to some. Surround sound is good, and having the option to adjust the ranges with the equalizer is a nice aspect. Overall these headsets are worth the money you pay for. They seem to be of high quality with the braided wire and the material its made of seems sturdy enough to last longer than my previous headsets. I'd give it a better rating if the sound quality was better, but these will do fine for a casual gamer. If you like LED's, and a loud bass, then i'd suggest these, otherwise these don't do anything too special.

To start off I already broke the little pressure tab at the edge of the lid for this device, I had no way of knowing where to pry it open since the manual just says, "open the drive insert your HDD then close it and connect it to your computer". Useless information. Another thing is (don't know why) is that the SATA to USB controller gives a very slow throughput. This of course is not isolated to this drive only, other USB 3.0 2.5" enclosures have the same issue such as Ultra Products which gave me slightly faster throughput but not significant. I did a benchmark between these 2.5 inch enclosures and a 3.5" enclosure from NexStar which is USB 3.0 as well. With a Sandisk Ultra SSD inside both the Sabrent and then the Ultra Products I barely got around 90MB's read / write average. The NexStar-HX enclosure has a 3.5 inch 5400 rpm 4 terrabyte HDD connected to the same USB 3.0 hub on my PC; it measured 150 MB read and 125 MB write. I thought the problem was with the Sandisk since I refused to believe its speed sucked, but then I connected it to my PC via a SATA 2 connection and it measured Read/Write 247/214. I don't know if both Sabrent and Ultra Products buy their controller from the same manufacturer but these results were conclusive to me and disappointing.

First purchased this item in September as my macbook battery was barely holding a charge. I received a 4100mAh, 42Wh battery rather than the high capacity one listed on this site. I contacted customer support and was told it was most likely a mistake in shipment. They refunded the charge and I returned the battery.
I again ordered this item in October as by now my original battery was completely dead. Again I received a 41mAh 42Wh battery instead of the 51WH battery advertised. I rated the seller 1 star and informed Amazon of the false advertising. They removed Bavvo Electronics as a from the item page for a few days while they looked into the problem. They informed me that I could again return the item for a refund but by this time I was left with no choice but to keep it as my old battery was dead.
About a week later I get an email from Bavvo Electronics saying they are sorry and asked if I would like to return the product or receive a refund of 20% in lieu of removing the 1 star rating I gave them. I replied back asking if they would please send me a true 51Wh batter as advertised rather than offer me a partial refund. I also informed them that they had done this on two occasions so it was hard to believe this was just a mistake where the wrong item was shipped.
After about 4 battery cycles the design capacity of the battery went from 4100mAh down to 3800mAh. Another 3 cycles of the battery and now the maximum capacity reads 3453mAh and a design capacity of 3800mAh. Not only are they misrepresenting the item on the site but they are also sending mislabeled products. I will update this review if I ever hear back from their customer service department.

It was time to replace my 2GB Lexar Lightning Jumpdrive. Back when I when I obtained it the Lexar Jumpdrive was fast. Maybe still is compared to a number of flash drives. But there are also much better flash drives available now.  The SuperTalent Express 3.0 is currently the only 3.0 flash drive available other then the SuperCrypt also by SuperTalent. The SuperCrypt is supposed to be even faster then the Express and comes with built in encryption software. However the SuperCrypt is even bigger and bulkier and nearly twice as expensive. Since I don't need encryption software, I got the Express version. I sprung for the SuperTalent Express 3.0 even though I don't currently have a motherboard that supports usb 3.0. It is backwards compatible and works just fine plugged into a usb 2.0 port. It is supposed to be faster reading and writing then any 2.0 flash drive even when used at 2.0 speeds.   I have only been able to use the drive at 2.0 speeds and it is still far faster then any other drive I have owned. A folder full of almost 4,000 word documents took less then a minute to copy to the Express drive. A folder full of almost 400 songs also took less then a minute to copy. Individual video files copied in 1-3 seconds. It is indeed a speedy drive. A blue light flashes on the end of the drive when it is in use. A turbo program comes installed on the drive which is supposed to make using the drive faster. You don't have to turn it on, but why wouldn't you?     The express drive is made of black metal and feels solidly built, however it is not without its faults. The drive casing is a bit bulky, not as much as the SuperCrypt, but enough that I had to unplug the usb port next to it in order to allow it to fit. Depending how your usb ports are spaced you may have to unplug one or even two slots to use this flash drive.  Worse, the metal casing on the drive drive gets very hot when the drive is in use. I mean almost burn your fingers hot. Heat and electronics do not mix well.This makes me question the long term durability of the drive. I was thinking about leaving this drive plugged into my TV usb port to access pics, vids and music. The heat issue nixed that idea, I wouldn't recommend leaving this plugged into any device when not needed. A firmware update was supposed to fix that issue, but I have not been able to test it yet.  Also the design of the drive is nothing to get excited about. The cap pops off and is easy to lose. There are no innovative design features to keep the cap attached, or the end protected that you can find on a number of cheaper drives. The drive has no rubber coating and/or special shock or waterproof protections. It also comes in cheap packaging, the kind you would find if you bought a cheap flash drive off the rack at a Best Buy.  If you search online you can find discount codes to get the Express 3.0 drives at bargain prices. The 16GB version can be had for less then $50 and the 32GB version for less then $85.    Still Depending on your needs there are a number of 2.0 drives available that may better suit you. The fastest 2.0 drive is the Corsair Voyager GTR. The 32GB version of the Voyager GTR can be had for about the same price as the 32GB version of the Express 3.0. The Voyager drives also comes with a durable rubber coating and some water and shockproof capabilities the Express lacks.  Other very fast 2.0 drives include the OCZ Rally 2, the Corsair Voyager GT, the Patriot Xporter XT, and the A-DATA Xupreme. There are some other fast drives as well.    In addition you may need to consider whether you need a flash drive at all. External hard drives have gotten so cheap they are not much more then a good flash drive. The are light and portable, though you will need a usb cord as well, and obviously they do not fit in your pocket like a flash drive. However you can get the Western digital My Book 3.0 1TB version for around $120. That's an entire TB of space at 3.0 USB speed. If you do not have a motherboardsupporting usb 3.0 the My Book works just fine with a 2.0 connection. But it also comes with a PCI card you can install in your computer to use the drive at 3.0 speed. Considering the amount of space your are getting for your money, its a much better buy then a flash drive if you don't really don't need the pocket portability.

I desperately needed a portable/external CD/DVD drive to install Windows on a separate partition of my MacBook AIR (no optical drive). I had absolutely no desire to deal with the nearest Apple Store, so I swung by a competitor and took a chance on this drive.     Fortunately, it was recognized by the AIR and Mac OS and I was able to successfully install Windows. Unfortunately, burning isn't supported under OS X.I knew that there was a chance that this drive wouldn't work at all on my Mac and the retail packaging explicitly states that it's only supported by Windows XP/VISTA & Ubuntu, so I'm not deducting any stars for that.     The only cons, aside from the lack of Mac burning support, were that the tray sometimes gets stuck on eject. For the price, it would have also been nice if they included a power supply instead of making us purchase it off of their website.    The drive served its purpose, though I'll still likely be purchasing the Apple external drive.       P.S. It plays DVDs just fine under OS X, if that was a  concern of yours.

Pros
- Great form factor. Easy to carry and hold in one hand for extended periods of time.
- Excellent resolution for reading newspapers/books, listening to podcasts or watching downloaded movies.
- Battery charge is great - gives me about 6 hours of reading time.

Neutral
- Samsung's Kies application is a good first attempt to access your tablet from a browser on your PC - similar to how you control IPad through ITunes. One big limitation is it does not let you manage your apps (add, delete, move screens, etc).
- Pairs nicely with other samsung products - Blue Ray player, TV - but works mostly as a remote.

Cons
- You can spend money and buy an SD-Card but you can't really use it with this tablet. There is no way to move apps from internal memory to SD-Card, download videos directly on your tab to the external SD-Card. What's the point of the Lobotomized SD-Card then? Nice design decision, Samsung. Kudos to the product manager.

Recommendations to Samsung
- Allow the external SD-Card to be used as an extension of internal storage.
- Allow watching whatever is on your screen on the tablet on TV or Blue Ray player. Extend the interaction between the products. Will be great if that's done as an app/firmware update on Samsung devices - wishful thinking?

I got eight months out of this machine before it finally gave up the ghost (I am writing this review on another laptop as I sit and watch the Toshiba try, try, try to boot up one last time).  For the first four or five months, things were quite good.  The machine worked well, I could surf the net easily, no problems.  Around month six it got a virus (I had McAfee loaded and totally up to date) and I reimaged the machine.  That seemed to do the trick, and then the trackpad left click button broke.  The machine wasn't dropped, wasn't misused, and had only had light usage (about an hour and a half of use a day).  I soldiered on with the trackpad, and the machine started to get slower and slower and slower.  Constant checks for viruses turned up nothing, and it was getting to the point that it took 30 or 40 seconds to load a webpage.  Going through the reimaging process is a hell of a pain, and while this thing is still under warranty it's just a dog with fleas.  My wife hates it and refuses to use it.  I paid $499, and a reasonable person might say that $499 for 8 months usage is a fair deal.  Perhaps.  I hope yours works out better, but I really would urge you to spend the extra money and get an Apple.  That's what I'm going to do.

The concept of the Kindle Fire is excellent as well as its price point. However, the customer service supporting the KF is terrible. I bought three Kindle Fire's (the third one from Sam's Club before it worked properly. Clearly, Amazon rushed this product to market in order to compete with the iPad and Barnes and Noble's tablets. The Kindle Fire is best for e reading especially at night because it is backlit. You can watch movies but streaming them is slow. The aps are limited for KF. I recently bought Plants v. Zombies game ap and it crashes EVERY TIME I try to engage it. I read Spanish books on the Kindle Fire. I bought the Merriam-Webster Spanish to English dictionary from Amazon. It fails to translate English to Spanish words -- you have to buy a separate dictionary for this! However, Amazon doesn't tell you this. You must discover it for yourself... when you try to look up a word in English there is no option to translate the word to Spanish. You must buy ANOTHER dictionary for this purpose. Rip off! Finally, the battery does not last more than a few hours if you are surfing the Internet and then read books. Let the buyer beware! Amazon can do better and must if it is to survive the tablet wars.

[[ASIN:B004SD22PQ Amazon Kindle Touch Leather Cover, Black]]
The cover is beautiful and provides protection. So that is good. What could be better is that it is not too comfortable too hold as the textile covers that have an option to put your hand through a connection

The good, the battery works.

The bad, well it is not machined to the same specs as the factory battery. The center screw could not be used, upon further review the access hole was not the same thickness as the original. This battery does not last nearly as long. Two hours under heavy use, such as streaming video, and 4-6 hours under light usage, such as web browsing. My original battery had bubbled up and was dead so I had to swap it out. Since my MacBook Air is an early 2008 and not upgradable to latest OS, this battery is fine. If you are looking for a battery to give you back your "new" laptop life disconnected from the cord, this is NOT your choice. This battery is for the, I do not want to spend any more money than necessary on my legacy laptop that is still functional choice.

This is my 8th or 9th Mac since 1990. I have owned this MacBook for a year this week.

My primary Mac presently is a 3 year old+ iMac that I am still very satisfied with. I bought this white MacBook so I could write and surf the internet in a variety of places around the house. I purposely did not install or download much software, believing the less stuff clogging this little notebook, the faster and better it would run.

The little color wheel that spins but quickly disappears on my iMac will spin for a full minute or more on this MacBook under the same circumstances, maddeningly. It is much slower to load internet pages than my 2002 PowerBook or my iMac, interesting due to the iMac being absolutely crammed with powerful software, such as Adobe CS5 Suite, and dozens more not installed on the MacBook. This MacBook is the slowest computer for surfing the internet I have owned since before I dumped AOL in 1996.

The greatest INSULT, however, is the CORD, which despite the Macbook remaining mostly stationary on my work station, has failed me twice, at a replacement cost of $160+.

Many people have complained about these flimsy, fragile cords, leading me to believe that Apple would quickly improve them. They absolutely have not, and I interpret any company's lack of attention to an egregious flaw in its product as insulting to its customers. I wouldn't be surprised if the dorks at the Genius Bar referred to the rest of us as Muppets.

I absolutely would not recommend the MacBook. The MacBook Pro Models use the same style cord, so if you buy any MacBook, be prepared to have its portabilty grossly compromised by the fact the cord has to be babied so much. As it stands, my happiness at thinking I'd be taking this everywhere I went has been thwarted, since I don't feel at ease even moving it around the house.

Update: Three power cords, all genuine Apple products, have failed now. Go to the Amazon reviews for thereplacement cord and feel the rage of the masses. The fact Apple thinks we should spend $100 annual FEE to replace these defective producst is the height of hubris. The cords' flaws make this computer useless, so I am lowering my rating to one star because Amazon doesn't allow ZERO stars. No power cord = no computer.

A very cute laptop that is all looks and no substance.  In the 1.5 years I have owned this laptop, it has been moderately functional for 2 months.  The service is some of the worst I have ever encountered, and I can say with certainty I will never again buy from Gateway.  Apparently this computer has \\"known\\" issues, including a problem with the hard drive connector cable-- this is why so many of these laptops inexplicably shut down randomly.  For about 4 months when the laptop was in partial-working condition, it was shutting down every 45 seconds.  DO NOT BUY THIS LAPTOP.  In fact, DO NOT BUY GATEWAY.

I bought this as a gift for my mother, when she told me it didn't quite fit right i just assumes she was up to her regular non technical hijinks...
However when I finally got my hands on this product I was APPALLED. It looks so terrible and like it is so poorly constructed that it belongs at the dollar store, IN THE CLEARANCE BIN.

You will need a reading light if you read in a dark place (ie:night time in bed). This one simply clips on. I haven't tried any others. This one lights up the full screen. I do wish the clip was a little more narrow though. All in all, it works.

I am on my third macbook cover and none of these POS's fit!  By the time I print out a shipping label and pay for shipping it's more trouble than it's worth to return the damn thing!  Don't buy this if you have a 15\\" MacBook Pro because it sure as hell won't fit.  I should have listened to the other bad review - that's what I get

After using a regular Kindle for several years, I decided to try your new Paperwhite. I love reading on it and the touch screen is nice. However, I have a couple of things that I detest. One, the only power cord is for USB not electricity. Now, how often do I read at my PC? And what if I am in a place where all the re-charge access I have is an electrical outlet. Two, the Paperwhite has cloud capability, but I have no access to Wi-Fi so it is useless to me. Third, the ability to put books in collections and thereby removing them from the initial menu screen is causing me much frustration. I realize that you can see which have been read by the black dotted lines under the title, but I don't want to see them listed as though they were never read. Four, I use the Million Word Crossword Dictionary every day. but dictionaries don't show up in a collection or on the home page, you must go to the end of the entries to find it. 'Dictionaries' is not considered a 'collection'. I would prefer my crossword dictionary to display on page 1.
Would I buy another one? I doubt it, if the only real advantage I have for it is a touch screen.

I bought this because of the reviews I've read on here, but when I got it, it wasn't worth the time or money spent.

I had more and better sound out of the items I connected it too then I did with it.

Don't waste your money on it!!!

I have the \\"basic\\" Kindle with SO and I´m really happy with its construction, its pretty easy to hold it and the battery life is amazing. The only drawback is not having a sleeve for it but I'm reluctant to pay US$60 for it... not yet...

I have 2.2 GHz dual core processor with the minimum recommended GPU and it can't keep up with the compression. Be sure to check out the system requirements on Display Link's website if you are going to use this for full motion HD video.

However it does work very well with static images and that is why I purchased it.

Huge oversight by Amazon on this to not be able to sign out of the Goodreads app and add your own information.

I loved the product on my first ipad.  Yes, it was a bit difficult to install, but if it was a bit crooked (which it ended up being), no big deal.  With the ipad 2, since there are two holes that have to be aligned perfectly (one for the home button, and one for the front camera), it is nearly impossible to align correctly.  I kept having to peel it off, and redo it.  Eventually, after repeating this process 5 times, one of the sticky corners folded over and touched another area on the sticky side.....and that was that.  40 bucks down the drain.  When I tried to unstick it from itself, it just got worse, and stuck in other areas.  I ended up with a wadded up ball of clear plastic.  I didn't even bother with trying to install the back side...what was the point?  I think the product is great, just too difficult to install.  One suggestion that I would make for those of you that purchase the front cover and the back cover is to install the back side first (which I should have done).  This way you can at least have some practice before you try to install it on the front side.

It keeps the keys from making marks on the screen in the event you put the squeeze just the wrong way on your MacBook Pro.  Also not a bad cloth for wiping the keys or screen. Installed onto a 42" wall-mounted flat screen in about 20 minutes. I ran the strip horizontally just above the wall mount bracket then down about 6 inches on both sides. Needed to cut the last 6 inches from the end. Trim locations are clearly marked.

**** UPDATE: After having this tablet for four months, I thought I noticed a corner of the screen coming loose this morning. I updated this review from one star to three; I have no problems with performance but the color remains as washed-out and faded as ever. :( Leaving my original comments in case someone else has the same issue. ****      I'm thinking either all these other reviews are fake, or I got a lemon. I have a Kindle and was getting frustrated with charging issues. I needed a tablet for internet browsing only. Not looking for bells and whistles, storage space for apps, etc. Just wanted a decent compact tablet that connected to the Internet.    I am deeply disappointed in this product. Like I said, I've used tablets before. With normal use by me and my kids both, my Kindle never had so much as a scratch. After three or four days with this tablet the screen was absolutely covered in scratches, some of them deep. Even worse, the display is very, very poor and weak. Colors are totally washed out. Image disappears if the screen is at an angle.    I had the most basic expectations for this product and it completely failed to meet them. If I could afford another one I'd return it in a heartbeat.

The Dell Inspiron 15R i15RM-2658sLV 15.6-Inch Laptop (1.8 GHz Core i5-3337U) is a good product.  The style is modern; I like the finish.  I'm getting accustomed to the side numbers on the keyboard. I like the platform--Windows 7 Professional; it has many good features and I did NOT want Windows 8 because so many were having difficulty in learning this latest platform. I had to purchase Microsoft Office 2013 because it did not come installed with the product. I'm enjoying this, as well. All in all, I would recommend this computer.

I'll keep it simple. Read the rest of the reviews on the issues this product has, mine has had them all. Save yourself the frustratin and just by an iPad until someone else can come up with something competetive.

I suppose it should come as no surprise that the Sony name will cost a little more.  This Sony Vaio CR420 laptop combines a new Intel T8100 processor with attractive style multiplexed with all the accoutrements of a modern laptop and maybe more considering it has the not yet agreed upon N-wireless 802.11.  Aside from enumerating all the other features, you go ahead and read for yourself the fairly detailed Amazon description.    Although it does not contain a separate graphics card it's nvidia graphics chip does provide enough power to turn on all the Vista Aero features I know.    My major gripe with this pretty laptop is that when  I compare it to the HP dv2810US it doesn't deliver me anything more (of what I need).  Note that the HP Pavilion's CPU is AMD TL-60.  While I have heard AMD is getting their butt kicked with T8100 (Penryn) I just don't see it here.    Without going to great detail I considered drive size/speed, memory, weight, screen size (Sony is a noticeably brighter screen btw),Bluetooth (pretty sure both stereo -a2dp),battery life, optical drive, speakers, touchpad, and overall quality of build.  The HP performs well in all aspects.  Note,  I say \\"performs\\" instead of compare to differentiate my real world experience versus marketing specs.  I do think the Sony is prettier. Note: I got the blue case b/c it uses a silver keyboard I preferred, most if not all these Vaio's have black keys.  The Pavilion has black keys also.    Overall,  I think a case could be made for choosing the Sony over the much cheaper Pavilion, however, for my station in life and value of a dollar, I chose the Pavilion dv2810us.    Things (of note) I did while I possessed both aforementioned laptops...  connected both wirelessly and wired to my home network (and ultimately Comcast broadband), signed in wirelesly at coffee house to web surf, downloaded and installed updates to Vista, streamed audio/video from Windows Media Server, installed VMWare Server GSX and then multiple OS's within -very slow to start on both laptops(slower than my previous Lifebook S Pentium M 1.6Gz w/ 2MB RAM running XP home).    I contacted both vendor's customer service departments about \\"downgrading\\" to XP Pro from the Vista Premium and it turns out to be not so easy.  In the case of HP, while they highly recommend against downgrading the Web Chat HP guy said he could point me to some of the drivers on the web... but could not say if all the XP - flavored drivers were available.  I didn't get into a discussion with Sony as much but got the same indication.    Hope this helps someone.    PS I like the Sony battery adapter more, it plugs into the laptop from the back with an \\"L\\" shape, the HP plugs from the side and sticks out approx 2\\".  Also the Vaio has what  I consider and annoying light emanating from under the touchpad -I dislike stray light-sources like that and not sure if it has a reason for it.

Love the device, not sure why they put the power button on the bottom where your thumb naturally wants to go to hold it.  It's the little design cues like that which leaves me using it less than I otherwise would.

This is a decent keyboard. It seems to be well built, and it just started working for me right out of the box. As other reviews have mentioned it feels much like a laptop keyboard. However I was never able to type on it as fast as I do either on laptop  or on normal PC keyboard. The reason seems to be combination of short travel and very light resistance for keys. Keys just don't resist your touch enough, and don't bounce back under your fingers. It could be a great keyboard, but at the moment it seems to me mis-calibrated a bit.     Another slight downside is absence of any kind of indicator keys for caps lock, number lock and such. Unlike HP, I think these indicators have their use in life.      I've since moved on to Logitech Illuminated Keyboard. I think its excellent.
Screws were absolute s***. One scratched and started stripping with a fingernail. Also did not sit in the case very well at all. You get what you pay for and this was not worth the money.

I had problems with firewire (ie it wouldn't work) immediately--I attributed this to my flaky firewire card. It worked well under USB, but there were weird problems with my computer (Outlook would hang)--these resolved whenever the drive was off.

I attempted to use this drive with my laptop today, first via firewire then by usb. It got about halfway through a big file copy when the drive went offline and I haven't been able to get it back since.

This is just too flaky, a HDD for backups needs to be johny on the spot and work. I will not use Lacie again, not even for a doorstop.

I've bought exclusively HP laptops for the last 5 years.   I'm very disappointed with this model.  I've bought at least 10 laptops over the years and this is BY FAR the worst ergonomics I've ever seen on a laptop.     The mouse pad is VERY poorly designed - the sensitive area is completely smooth and has no edges that you can feel so it's very easy to lose the the position of the mouse pad;  your fingers need something you can feel to know they are positioned correctly.   The mouse pad button is incredibly STIFF and again, completely smooth so you have no idea where it is by touch or where the left and right mouse buttons are.   If I use these buttons for more than a few minutes my thumb starts to  hurt because you have to push VERY HARD to get the button to activate.     Anything that requires press-hold is very difficult to do and is sure to cause a thumb RSI injury if you used it all day.    The keyboard button feel is actually pretty good, except HP has inexplicably added an extra row of buttons along the left edge of the keyboard.   This shifts the place you need to place your fingers about an inch to the right.   However, they kept the ESC key in the top left, so that means it's in the wrong place for a touch typist.   The control key, normally in the bottom left of a keyboard is in the wrong place.       They also put the hard drive light in the wrong place.  It's on the LEFT side of the chassis so the only way you can see it is to lean your head two feet to the left.   I've never seen a laptop before that you couldn't see the hard drive light from your normal head position.    Seems like whoever designed this laptop has never used a laptop before, and certainly they didn't actually test this design with human beings.   Unbelievable HP could come up with such an awful  ergonomics after making laptops for so long.        Battery life is nothing special - you might get 2.5 hours out of it.   I recently received an Samsung Galaxy Tab 10.1 Android tablet - the battery lasts at least 10 hours - and the device weighs 1.2 lbs - 1/4th the weight of this laptop.   Microsoft/Intel/AMD better get their act together because 2.5 hours just doesn't cut it anymore when there's tablet devices that can last 10 hours.

This computer is a fair price for the inexperienced user. Once you get past learning how to use the poorly designed Windows 8 Set-Up you may feel frustrated. Everything you would want to do on your new computer requires new accounts on Microsoft. After that annoying fact pops up every fifteen minutes, then you get to experience the terribly slow operating speed and the glitches. I have had a seven year old laptop that moves faster than this one. Plus, it constantly freezes on the home screen. I often have to restart my computer multiple times to get it un-frozen. Yet more problems I have seen are as follows: you cannot play DVDs on this computer, the web cam is sub-par at best, any iPhone or Apple product will not cooperate with this laptop, downloading pictures is a long and infuriating task, the battery never holds a charge for longer than three hours, you cannot watch movies (as the screen will turn black), and the speakers are very quiet at its loudest. I highly recommend shelling out the cash for a better product such as a Mac.

This was the first router I bought and it was recommended by the Best Buy employee I talked to. The installation was pretty easy and for a month this router worked excellent. I had great range and it was reliable. Then one day (about a month after I bought it) my wireless internet connection didn't work. I didn't know what the problem was, but after resetting the settings, I had decent connection again. Unfortunately this problem keeps reoccuring and about once week I lose my wireless connection causing me to reset the settings each time. Its kind of annoying to be honest.

Overall this is a good router when right, but outside of a month it hasn't been reliable for me. I guess I would look for an alternative router if I were you.
Too slow freezes

I agree with several other reviews when I say \\"I really wanted to like the Kindle Fire.\\"  But how do you start with a Google Android Operating System and leave out core functionality and Gmail integration?  So far I have been unable to sync Gmail Contacts or Calendars.  There is a Contact App, but no apparent way of syncing Contacts.  There's not even a Calendar App.  Yes, you can always view contacts and calendars through the Web Browser, but there is no integration between that and the Email app on the Kindle Fire.  You should also be aware that there is no apparent support for Exchange Active Sync.  An Exchange Account should work if you have POP or IMAP access, but not traditional Exchange connectivity.  I believe I had reasonable exceptions (it is a $200 device), but shame on me for not doing more research.  My Droid phone has the Kindle app, what I got here was a larger screen with less functionality.  What it does, it does well, but skipping contacts and calendars this is an oversight that keeps it from being a fully functional tablet.  I like being reminded of an appointment when I'm reading on my phone, but that won't happen on the Kindle Fire.  If you want to read books and watch movies, this is a great device.  One other minor flaw is the location of the power button.  So far I have inadvertently shut down the device 4 times while reading (I just got it today).  I tend to hold it against me while I read.  If I hold it right-side up it presses against the power button (and shuts off).  So I have to hold it upside down (which covers the speakers).  Not ideal.  I will be happy to update my review with 5 starts if or when we get full calendar and contact sync.
In less than 1 year, when the hard disk on this goes bad, they will make you pay to ship it to them for repair.

I have set up many wireless networks for myself, friends and office. But this little device has me flummoxed. I can set it up as a router -- no problem. But for the life of me I cannot get it to set up as a wireless extender for an existing router.

I followed the directions in the Installation Guide. However, I never found a way to access the check box that says \\"Extend my current wireless router's range\\".

Then I downloaded the full manual for the device from Netgear's web site. Still could not find a way to get this fundamental setting to show up.

So I searched Netgear's website. No dice.

I read the Amazon reviews. No dice.

Then I contacted support via e-mail. Not working yet. It has been about 5 hours of messing about with a totally fruitless situation.

I don't get the same screens shown on the Installation Guide, the Owner's Manual or the web site.

A very frustrating experience.

UPDATE: Netgear tells me that the unit is defective and needs to be returned to the reseller -- no problem, the reseller is in store only and 85 miles away -- the fuel cost to drive there and back is more than the unit cost on sale (it was just $17.00 at the seller). However, I bought 2 of these units and decided to try connecting the second unit just in case there was something other than a defective unit going on. The second unit immediately gave me the screen I had been missing with the first unit. I suppose I am lucky that one out of two units apparently worked, but one unit was for me to travel with and the second was to be a gift for a friend who needs the extension capability for their weak network.

FURTHER UPDATE: Netgear customer service provided me with a return number so I can mail in the defective item for replacement. A nice help for me. Since the second unit works and the setup with it was a breeze, I have changed my overall star rating. Still unhappy about lost hours of messing with a defective unit, but Netgear is trying to remedy the situation and I have always had prior good experiences with Netgear products.y the situation and I have always had prior good experiences with Netgear products.

**update**  I'm very disappointed in this tablet and currently looking to buy my daughter something else. She can only keep a few games/books/apps on there before it says it's out of memory!  What a waste of money!  I wanted her to have a kindle because my older 2 already have them, but I wasn't expecting this problem Bought this last week for my youngest daughter because I was sick of her constantly using mine. I have the 8.9" fire HD  2012 model I believe. Also, my 2 older daughters have the 7" 2012 model, so I can kind of go off of my experience with those when judging this new one.The screen quality is really nice on this new model. And I really like that they moved the power button away from the volume button because that was a big inconvenience. It's quite small, but sufficient for a child or for someone who likes to carry it with them often. But there are a few things I noticed that I don't like so much... The main thing is that, for whatever reason, there are apps and games that my daughter was using regularly on my kindle that she cannot use on this one. And some of these were not free! When I check the cloud on all of our other devices, those apps show up, but they will not show up on the new kindle! They don't even show up when I search for them in the app store. So I bought this device for her so she won't have to use mine all the time, but she's still going to use it because there are things that she likes to play and apps that I have paid for that she can't access on her kindle. VERY annoying! I hope this is something that Amazon fixes very soon. It also seems like the volume doesn't go up very high at all. I guess I will have to asses more with further use. I also noticed that for a brand new device, it can be pretty laggy, it gets very hot, and the battery seems to drain a lot faster than the other kindles we own. Overall it seems like a good value for the price though.

The rubber used to grip the tablet works if there is no panning. On the contrary, it works well with my Note 3. It's more of a smart phone mount than a tab mount.

Easily the worst laptop I've ever had.
1) Fans ard obnoxiously loud at times. When I'm in class this is very embarrassing and I have to completely shut down the computer.
2) The trackpad is SO bad. I have trouble scrolling with two fingers. It's nearly impossible to highlight text. It randomly changes which side is a right click and which side is a left click.
3) Touch screen constantly stops working whenever you start using the pen.
4) It starts to get VERY slow when I barely have any apps open.
5) Microphone is practically unusable. It is setup right next to the very loud fan. I use Rosetta Stone and part of it is you have to say certain phrases. Rosetta Stone cannot understand a word I say so what should take me 15 minutes takes me an hour.
6) Keyboard constantly stops working for no reason. It just shuts off and the only thing to do is reset it. The other day, it completely died and I was unable to get it to work again.
7) All browsers "stop working" at least 5 times a day. The only way to get them back is by going to task manager because just exiting the application does nothing. This may just be an OS problem, but it is very frustrating nonetheless.
8) Worst wifi I've ever had on my device. I can stand 15 feet from my router and I'd be struggling to get signal. My phone's wifi is at LEAST twice as strong as it. I can only use the device in one room in my house. What a joke.
9) Have already sent the laptop in 4 times within the 6 months I've had it.
