I purchased the Archer C& because of some reviews. It worked out of the box ... but soon realized that it was dropping connection often. This was on a laptop, and a desktop that is about 15' line of site from the router. Then made sure the firmware was up-to-date and it was. recycled it a few times which brought it back on-line, but at some point would drop again. Frustrating.
Next, the range was not sufficient to reach the living room where out smart TV is. It would barely get there, but was so week that the TV would only rarely connect. The C7 was to replace an ASUS AC-66U that we have had about 2 years. It reached the TV and never dropped. Would still have it too ... but a lightning strike took it out.
So we returned this one(TP-Link Archer C7) and bought an ASUS AC68U. It is now working flawlessly with almost lost-less speed even next to the TV. VERY happy with it so far (about a week). Range is WAY better, thru-put is WAY, WAY better. So worth the $60 more.

This is my first Asus product, and, unfortunately, I am not at all impressed. This is one of the most disappointing computers I have ever used. While the specs and pictures look nice on the box, this computer fails to live up to expectations. One of the biggest problems I had with this computer was the track pad; I found it to be slow and even a little buggy. I also found the speakers to be substandard. Even with the volume turned all the way up, it is still hard to hear from a few feet away. They keyboard is also one of the biggest drawbacks; cheap manufacturing has slowed my typing speed a lot. The battery does not last anywhere near ten hours; the longest I have gotten out of it is four, maybe five, hours. This computer is incredibly heavy and certainly not worth the extra weight. I tried this product in hopes of finding an affordable pc laptop, but it looks like I will be sticking to my macbook. I would definitely test this product before purchasing it.

It worked pretty well at first. Had some trouble with facebook related connections, but I thought nothing of it. It was a new model, I assumed it would resolve itself.

I've had it 2 and a half months and the problems with it just continue to escalate. It frequently drops internet and won't reconnect without being rebooted first. This was a minor annoyance compared to the big issue now however.

Now it won't charge. This device doesn't come with an adapter, just a USB cord that charges it. I've tried plugging it into a laptop, a desktop computer, and even a USB-to-wall-outlet converter, and it constantly dies. It will claim to charge for a little bit, bit the percentages just continue to drop until the device is forced to shut down.

I get frequent "insufficent charger current" warnings no matter how I'm attempting to charge it. And just the other day I got "thermal event" warning. There is clearly something defective about this device, and I will certainly not buy from Toshiba again.

I have used this case since a year ago and it functions perfectly. The auto off/on lid works every time. The case is very durable and is very low profile, not bulky. Here's the big BUT........ STMbags.com has put a very thin over-molding rubber over the entire outside surfaces probably to improve hand grip. Within a couple weeks of normal usage this rubber starts peeling off in small flakes getting everywhere... in my bed, on the night stand, in my car, on my desk at work, on my clothes... etc. I would be happy just peeling off all of the rubber coating but it doesn't come off easily in its entirety. Just consistent bits and pieces the size of grains of rice day after day, month after month.

I love this case, but I have to give all of you the strong recommendation NOT to buy this product.... If it did not have the rubber problem I would give this five stars.

FYI, I have submitted a request for return to STMbags.com and haven't heard anything back yet. I will update this post when I find out more from their customer service department.

Kind Regards, Ken

I bought four of these units from two different vendors. The first two were taking forever to arrive and upon checking the status of the shipment I discovered they were being shipped from Hong Kong. If I had known that I would have never ordered them. It was not obvious that this was where they would be shipping from. Since I needed them right away and they were so inexpensive I ordered two more, this time making sure to purchase from a vendor in America. This shipment arrived promptly and I also received the first shipment around the same time (nearly) and I noticed obvious differences. One set was black and chrome, the other was black and white. The black and white units from Eforcity which shipped from the USA were of much better quality and work great. The black and chrome units which I unknowingly ordered from C-Teck in Hong Kong are made of very cheap material and hang every time I try to copy data to or from the inserted hard drive. In short they are junk. So be very careful who you order from as Amazon alternate these vendors for the same listing. Buyer beware.

I have always been an avid fan of good pens, both fountain and rollerball or gel pens. Recently, I have been moving to an iPad as my computer and wanted to begin the transition to a stylus for note taking and navigation, since I won't be handling a mouse much longer.

I searched around for a Mont Blanc stylus thinking by now, a pen manufacturer like Mont Blanc would have already created a stylus for using with an iPad, but alas, I couldn't find one, and when I did google Mont Blanc stylus, the Hard Candy stylus came up as about the only top line type stylus that still looked like a fountain pen or at least a very nice gel or rollerball pen.

I took awhile to commit to the Hard Candy, but I liked its look and read enough positive reviews that I thought I would like it a lot. Ordered through Amazon Prime, I got the stylus in fast order and was excited to put it to work with my iPad Air. Now let me say right off that the Hard Candy stylus has the best tip that I have used, though I have not bought many. I have a Bamboo that came highly recommended, and I like its grip better than the Hard Candy, though it is slim and the stylus tip is not as sensitive to the iPad screen.

The Hard Candy stylus is very sensitive and gives me much better control. I also like the pen end of the Hard Candy. I write in blue ink and so when I got the Hard Candy stylus, I immediately exchanged the black ink for a Parker Jotter Gel refill. The shape of the refill fits perfectly into the Hard Candy barrel without any problems at all. With the hefty weight and fullness of the barrel, it feels just like a well made pen when I write with it. So with the sensitivity of the stylus and the versatility of the pen when refilling the ink, the Hand Candy worked perfectly. That's the good news.

I gave the Hard Candy stylus only 3 stars because I was dismayed by the caps on either end of the tool. Neither end has a place to go when you take them off. They are not like a fountain pen where you can attach the top to the butt of the barrel while writing. This is a small but significant concern to me, one I have an issue with, but also something I could live with, if that was the only issue. Also, I know many have reviewed this flaw, so I wanted to bring it to the attention of Hard Candy. But...

My main issue is with the barrel itself. I love the brushed chrome and the contour of the barrel on both ends; however, I am not comfortable at all with the sharp ridge that is exposed when you take either cap off the stylus. When using the stylus, my fingers lay uncomfortably over the sharp edge where the cap usually sits, and I find myself thinking about where my fingers are positioned rather than concentrating on my work.

When I am using the pen end of the stylus tool, my fingers again worry about the sharp ridge along the barrel where the cap rests. I do not like to hold my pen close to the tip. I enjoy a pen that I can "lean back on" along the barrel. I am a professional writer that switches back and forth from hard copy to computer, and a pen and its comfort is very important to me. So when I tried to use the Hard Candy stylus and pen, I loved what I was potentially holding, but it seemed too flawed for me to want to use it as it is now designed. So here is what I did.

I redesigned the Hard Candy stylus, and made it work for me. I took two non-slip rubber finger grips off cheap G-2 Pilot disposable gel pens and slid them onto either end of the Hard Candy barrel, so I would have a firm grip. The rubber sleeves fit perfectly against the sharp edge of the cap base, so I no longer have to worry about the sharp ridge that was so uncomfortable on either end of the barrel. All that has made for a perfect tool to use with my iPad Air and any writing that I do on paper.

Of course, my alterations have made the caps for either end useless. They no longer fit the barrel. So I began looking around at what was in my house and really couldn't find anything that matched or came close to keeping the aesthetics of the pen intact. What I ended up using (forgive me Pelican Pens) is the top off of one of my Pelican fountain pens with silver accents to cover the gel pen end of the tool. For the stylus, I am using a pencil eraser that fits very comfortably over the stylus. It's goofy looking and I want to find something to replace the eraser soon. Mostly I leave off the eraser, but when I travel or carry the stylus with me, I cover the rubber tip so it won't get damaged.

So I am giving the Hard Candy stylus only 3 stars because I had to basically redesign the ergonomics of the pen to fit my need and to remove what I think are terrible flaws in this tool. It could be the top of its class with more thought being put into the ergonomic elements of style and design. I am not yet finished with my design yet. I am still looking for good caps to replace the silver bullet covers. I don't want to use my Pelican cap for very long simply because it comes off a very expensive fountain pen, but I want this Hard Candy stylus to work out. I really love the design, the weight and girth of the pen. It feels great in my hand (with the alterations) and I feel I am writing and touch screening with a top quality tool. Perhaps the designers this tool need more input from those who use quality pens and are looking for the same in a stylus.

So here's the down and dirty. I love the idea of this stylus. I love it now that I have corrected the flaws. Would I buy another? Well, if I can find good looking caps that match the design, then yes, I would buy another and refit it just like I did the first. But I am also looking to Mont Blanc, Waterman, and Acme pens to see if and when one of these fine writing instrument companies will take the plunge and make a stylus with the flair and style of a fountain pen. Maybe it's already outthere, I don't know. If anyone does know, please respond here, so I can look it up.

If Hard Candy gets this design right, I'll stick with them. I keep allegiances when I like a product, but I won't stay with it if I find a tool that is just as precise in the stylus but with more comfort and ergonomic design. I have taken too much time to make this particular product work for me. Fix it, please, so I can write another review of a great redesigned stylus.

I have been using this product for a few weeks now (purchased for my Raspberry Pi) and this is what I have found:

I've tested the keyboard on a Mac, a PC, an XBox, and a Raspberry Pi. It is a straightforward plug and play device. None of these devices have had any trouble recognizing the keyboard. The keys are fairly small, but not small enough to pose much of a problem. The small USB receiver is hidden nicely in the keyboard itself until ready to use.

The trackpad works better than I expected and is comfortable to use. The keyboard is a nice two handed sized device and is great on-the-go.

The problem with the keyboard is that many of the keys are sticky. Not physically or literally sticky, but when I press the \\"S\\" or \\"O\\" keys once, for example, the keyboard will output multiple characters of the same letter. For example, one press of the \\"O\\" key will yield \\"OOOOOOOOOOOOOO\\".

This makes the device fairly impractical and frustrating to use. The only thing that I can consistently use it for without frustration is Powerpoint Presentations. This works well because I only need a working space bar and the nifty laser pointer.

In summation, the product's main function is supposed to be typing, yet it cannot even accomplish this appropriately. Shovel out the few extra bucks for a better brand because this is not worth the price and the hassle.
NP

Description says \\"2TB 7200RPM Serial ATA Hard Drive\\" but this is not the case.  It's two 1TB HDDs.  So instead of three open expansion bays I've got two.  Somewhat disappointing.    Also, when it says \\"Intel GMA 950 Graphics\\" be clear that it has no graphics port at all; you need to use client connector software to set it up and then (I think) I'll be able to remote desktop to it.  Fine by me, but potentially confusing as described in the tech specs.

This computer was purchased to replace a relatively new, fairly expensive Lenovo laptop, which was falling apart (physically).  Since it seems to be impossible to buy anything in the technology arena that lasts very long, I decided to go cheap this time.  In the future, I will use my desktop for my more sophisticated computer needs and use this one, essentially, as an internet device.  For that, it is sufficient.  It is sometimes slow to reconnect to my wifi and to my personal cloud.  The color is every bit as hideous as it looks in the picture.  It almost kept me from buying the computer.  Had I realized that it was not possible to remove the recovery drive, I would have most likely not purchased it.  The available memory is simply too small.  I use a 128 gb SD card for memory and have only loaded minimal software and I am down to about 6gb.  After researching removing the recovery drive I am hesitant to do so.  Some of my research indicates that its removal  can cause the computer to not work correctly, since the system uses some of the files.  I have no idea if this is true, but am not chancing it for now.  It is light weight and should travel well.  It is about what I expected.  Update:  It is actually less than I expected.  I have, without adding any additional apps or software, begun to get notice that my memory is critically low.  The usable memory on this computer makes it of little value for anything except surfing the web.  Although I didn't expect much more, I did expect to be able to put a few basic apps on it and use them.  I have a 128 gb card to store all of my documents, photos, etc.  No data or documents are stored on the device.  It is simply too limited.  In addition, the track pad has begun to right click everywhere I hit it, except for the far left hand corner.  Very annoying.  I will be replacing it with another lower end laptop

I purchased this to combine a router and phone adapter (to get rid of the Motorola PA that I got when I signed up for Vonage in July 2004). After 3 weeks I got the case escalated to their tier 3 team (the only ones who know anything at all) and with careful troubleshooting he saw that the MTU size is what was causing me to not be able to connect outgoing calls. After wrestling with my ISP thinking it was their fault, we re-registered my old phone adapter with Vonage, removed this router and all was working again.

So I bought another pair and after a year, the plug in the left ear that charges the headset would not function or charge the set. I received another set for Christmas, and yet again, the plastic has broken on the headset, this time it's the plastic around the ears pieces that swivels. I just gently took them off one day and the plastic cracked! I am thoroughly disappointed with this product as it is highly rated, and I loved the fact you could still use the product while it was still charging, you just couldn't go wireless with it while it charged. I loved the fact that it was affordable, but I guess you truly get what you pay for!!

I have had nothing but trouble with the My Book Essential line of external hard drives. The first one I bought, [[ASIN:B000VZCEUI Western Digital My Book Essential 1 TB USB 2.0 Desktop External Hard Drive WDH1U10000N]], never installed on my Mac and after countless attempts at formatting it the best advice Western Digital text support could give me was \\"take it back and buy something different.\\"

Thus it was with some trepidation that I tried this version of the My Book Essential, the \\"Western Digital My Book Essential 1 TB USB 2.0 Desktop External Hard Drive WDBAAF0010HBK-NESN.\\" Fortunately, this one formatted just fine, but unfortunately, it decided to jam a bunch of software on my computer and start backing-up my files automatically.

I suppose it is all about what you are looking for in an external hard drive. Personally, I want the extra space. Nothing more, nothing less. I don't want a \\"time machine,\\" I don't want an automatic back-up of my files. I just want a magical little chamber where I can pack in movie files and other things that take up space on my home computer, but things that won't destroy me when the drive eventually fails.

Fortunately, I found what I was looking for in my third Wester Digital My Book, the [[ASIN:B002JSS2NS Western Digital My Book Elite 1 TB USB 2.0 Desktop External Hard Drive WDBAAH0010HCH-NESN]]. Easy to install. Easy to use. That is the one for me. I am glad I finally found the prince, but sorry I had to kiss so many frogs first.

Short and sweet, I just returned this netbook because of three things that were deal-breakers for me:    1. The trackpad is the same texture as the soft plastic around it on the palm rest. It is the worst touch surface I have ever felt for a trackpad. Compared to my office Mac Book Pro and my wife's Sony laptop -- which both provide a nice slightly rough tactile response -- I just couldn't stand to use the slick soft plastic of the 311.    2. The cursor jumps all over the place when typing. I'm not sure if it because the trackpad is so sensitive or something else, but this is very annoying. I couldn't find a simple way to turn off the trackpad (a function key would have been nice).    3. The Atom processor is dog slow in this model. I had used an MSI Wind U100 netbook last year which seemed a bit faster (much more so when overclocked). Loading the browser on this Mini takes forever. It just goes to show that I needed a faster computer.    There are several small notebooks hitting the market now, much faster than netbooks but within two hundred dollars of this one. I'll be doing some more research to find one that is right for me. If you can live with the above caveats, then this might be a nice light travel solution. If not, keep looking.

I bought two of these for a Corsair H100i because the fans it came with were pretty loud. I have to say I had high hopes since most people rave about these fans being really quiet. As a silent PC fanatic I can say that these fans are far from quiet at full speed. I turned the fans down a bit and they became acceptable at best. The fan also produces more noise when mounted horizontally vs vertically. It seems they also vibrate a bit and could benefit from rubber mounting pins or gaskets. They do push a good amount of air though and for those looking for strong performance these would probably be better than some of the other choices out there.

If I didn't have to mount these horizontally I would probably have gone with Scythe's Slipstream fans. Although they have sleeve bearings they are incredibly quiet. I'll be trying the Kama Flow fans next since these GTs have to go.

UPDATE: I've since replaced my Typhoons with Kama Flow SP1225FDB12M. They are much quieter but of course don't move as much air. I moved the Typhoons to my NAS in the living room thinking I wouldn't hear them in the living room but they make enough noise that I can always hear them. Ended up ordering even more Kama Flows so I could replace the Typhoons.

I would've loved the Typhoons some time ago when I was all about performance but these days I look for low noise from my components and the Kama Flow SP1225FDB12M wins because this. If you don't mind a little noise the Typhoons do move a good amount of air without sounding like jet turbines but I don't think they deserve the silent or even quiet description that they so often get.

Every time a company sales you a drive inside an \\"sealed\\" enclosure like this one, rest assure, you will have to pay hundreds of dollars to Seagate to recover your data. It would be less fraudulent if the drives were sold for $20 a piece but they are sold at regular prices. On the other hand, if you buy a bare drive (yes, even from Seagate) and place it inside your own third party enclosure, you would never have to worry about that issue. The reason for this is that more often than not, the drive did not fail but the enclosure alone did, meaning, your drive and your data are intact but you simply can never get to it on your own. There are unscrupulous companies out there that make thousands of dollars retrieving data for people that have been fooled by an enclosure like this one (Western Digital Books are notoriously infamous as well). Don't trust terabytes of information to a flaky enclosure which you can't open without voiding a warranty, it is a fool's trap.

I thought I'd share my experience with this router. I bought it based on the overwhelming positive reviews. As everyone else I wanted to eliminate the monthly rental fee I pay ($8 per month). I am with Comcast. I installed it and it did successfully install via the online enrollment. Initially I got great speed - ~28 mbps. However, I couldn't get speeds over 1 mbps after the first minute...literally. I called Comcast and they said it never completed enrollment properly and set it up for me. To be fair, they were cordial and stayed with me until I was connected. I hung up happy but guess what? One minute later I was back to 1 mbps. UGH!!!! I called back and they were not able to diagnose. They could see the modem but had no option for resolving the slow connection. The next day I decided to try again before I giving up. I connected again and this time I had fair connection speeds. It wasn't overly consistent compared to my rented modem (~25-27 mbps) but I was getting anywhere from 14 to 28.

Next step, connecting to my router (was hard wired to computer to this point). Here is where I threw in the towel. I just couldn't get it to connect to my Cisco E3200. The rented modem (Arris WBM760) had no problems. I tried every combination of power off the cable modem, power on, power off router, power on and so on and so on. At this point I felt this was just too much trouble and was concerned about long term reliability even if I eventually could get it to work with my router. I returned it.

I was hopeful for this product but for me it just didn't work out. I have since purchased the SB6121 and without the need for Comcast intervention I am connected and it's working well with my router. I have found my connection speed is on par if not a bit faster than the rented one.

Relative to inconsistent connection speeds I can't say for sure if the issue is the SB6141 or Comcast. 2 star rating though is because it shouldn't have had trouble playing well with my router. I've had a dsl router and now two cable modems working fine. Maybe I just got a defective one?

The casing is made of plastic as expected, and it feels like plastic, but it doesn't look like plastic. My iPad Air 2 (white) looks great in it and I love the look. Macbook owners would be pleased. In fact, a friend of mine even thought I bought a new laptop/netbook when she initially saw me using it.  Now here comes the BUT...    Typing on it sucks, especially when you use it for as much typing as I do. Let me list the ways: 1. The spacebar doesn't space when you need it to. I tend to (almost always) press the far right side of the spacebar with my right thumb when typing with both hands. Well, it only spaces when you press so hard that you're practically banging on it, and even then it may not work. This holds true for the left side as well. It spaces fine when you press close to the center, however. 2. The lock key is placed right above the delete key; it gets quite annoying when you reach for that delete key with your pinky, but it lands on the lock key instead and turns your iPad off. 3. Same thing with the right shift key, which is placed immediately to the right of the up arrow key. My pinky ends up landing on that up arrow key and words start appearing where it shouldn't. Then, you go to delete, but end up turning off your iPad instead.  Furthermore, the hinge that connects the case and the keyboard doubles as a groove in which to place your iPad. Well, the groove was so tight, I couldn't get my iPad in. My boyfriend tried and same thing; it just didn't fit. I definitely got a dud. Wanting my iPad to magically fit into this beautiful keyboard case, I asked him if he could possibly loosen up the groove for me, which of course he couldn't. So back to the store it will go! But then.. he tried one last time before I wrapped it back up. And somehow.. he got it in!  Too bad the keys suck.  I hope my review is helpful to you. Thanks for reading.  By the way, I do not have these typing issues with my detached Logitech Keys-To-Go keyboard, which I love (link providedbelow). The only problem with that keyboard was I tended not to use it since it wasn't attached.  Logitech Keys-To-Go http://www.bestbuy.com/site/logitech-keys-to-go-portable-keyboard-for-apple-ipad-air-2-black/9483417.p?id=1219418200796&skuId=9483417 http://www.amazon.com/s/ref=nb_sb_noss?url=search-alias%3Daps&field-keywords=logitech+keys-to-go&rh=i%3Aaps%2Ck%3Alogitech+keys-to-go

I would like to preface my negative review by saying that I'm a die-hard apple freak and apple stockholder, so I'm not some random PC shill here to bash without reason... That being said, I could summarize my experience with AppleTV by saying: The interface is stunning, and it will impress the masses, but it has a number of fatal flaws that will make a Mac Mini or laptop a better (and more costly) option for the high-end, professional type discriminating user like myself. So this review is here for nitpicking, high end users with high expectations. The rest of you probably won't care...    Let me get what I like out of the way first: The interface is way nicer looking than Front Row. Totally slick. It is a killer way to browse the music library of a remote computer, for instance the one 30 feet away in your office that has an external 500 GB drive full of music and video.     What I don't like...    1. The treatment of images (photos) is totally \\"tuned for the test drive\\" as they say in the auto business. This machine excels at making very low-res images, such as album art, look amazing. HOWEVER, load it up with hi-resolution photos from your own slideshow, and they will come out totally softened. This thing obviously does not have the guts to handle hi-res. It's a little known but true fact that there is a threshold (possibly multiple thresholds) within iPhoto that scale the animation textures of Ken Burns effect photos to different qualities depending on the amount of VRAM and quality of graphic chip in the given mac. This is automatic, and there's nothing you can do about it. I'm postulating that the AppleTV has a very weak graphics processor relative to any other recent Mac, and that would be why the pics are so freaking soft. I bought this thing expressly for slideshows, so it's getting returned to the store tomorrow for this reason alone. Considering that the Apple website currently says \\"your photos will appear in high definition,\\" this one is a big letdown.I guess by high definition they mean 720p.     2. The wireless sync is very slow. It seems to be running at about 8 Megabits, or often less, on a 802.11g network with a full signal strength... not remotely approaching network capacity.     3. The USB port can't be used for external storage. That is a no brainer that Apple blocked out for obvious profiteering reasons. The salesman at Fry's told me that you could use external storage, which illustrates the quality of employee training at Fry's. It was obvious at the time that he was just telling me what I wanted to here, so I risked it. 50/50, right?     4. Slideshow settings are global to all slideshows rather than to individual folders of images. In short, not as configurable as iPhoto.     5. It does not do 1080p. I just bought a 1080p set, so I'm very disappointed. I get 1080p out of my Powerbook when it connects to external Apple Cinema Displays, so I'm confident that once I get the right cable, I will have 1080p coming out of my Powerbook to this new HDTV... no thanks to AppleTV.     Conclusion: If you care about image quality, configurabilty, and the right to plug something useful into the USB port, you need a real Mac and not this AppleTV thing. I have not yet tested the Mac Mini to see if it has superior photo slideshow (Ken Burns animation textures) resolution), but that is my next project... Otherwise, PowerBook will be spending a lot of time docked at my new TV set.

This fits pretty well. The fit is not perfect, i.e the camera hole is a little off, but not enough to be in the way of the camera's view, and the headphone hole is a little off, but my Apple earphones' jack fits okay. The buttons that are covered work fine, and feel almost the same as without a cover. I am able to insert the standard Apple Lightning cable that came with the iPad Mini with no problem.

It also offers good protection, covering everything that doesn't need to be a hole.

It has a pleasant surface texture to hold on to, not sticky/grippy like some soft polyurethane covers. The surface is hard enough that it won't scratch easily and dust and hair doesn't stick to it. It does not collect fingerprints.

THE PROBLEM: When the case is installed there is a continuous ridge that extends in front of the bezel of the iPad Mini, all the way around. This is part of the protection and is welcome for that purpose. However, it prevents the Apple Smart Cover from laying flat against the glass and interferes with the magnetic closure of the Smart Cover, which is just barely strong enough to keep itself closed on a naked iPad Mini. With the iBlason back cover installed the Smart Cover does not have enough magnetic force to stay closed and won't even lay flat. If I put my iPad Mini in a bag, any movement causes the magnetic sleep switch to trigger repeatedly. This is a deal killer and disappointing.

I bought this battery because the one that came with my laptop stopped holding charge after three years of use.

As the directions that came with this new battery said, I gave it a couple of full discharge cycles before making any judgments on it. It gets 1 hours and 30 minutes from a full charge to drained on power saver mode. If I'm not using the internet (i.e taking notes in class and just using Microsoft word) I can get just under two hours out of it.

I downloaded BatteryCare which is a program which tells you exactly how much time you have left and it also estimates the amount of discharge cycles (discharging battery to less than 40%) you can get. A normal hp battery claims to get 200 cycles. This battery will only get 30!

I was disappointed but willing to deal with the battery life of only 1-2 hours because I rarely use the battery more than that without having the ability to use the power cord. But when I saw that I will only get 30 cycles out of it, I was very disappointed. I have had the battery for less than two months, so I estimate it will last me 3-4 months.

And just a side note, the price of this item went down 7 dollars since I ordered it. If you are considering buying it, watch the price for a couple weeks and buy it when it's at it's lowest.

I will not be buying another one of these batteries. Next time I will just dish out the 100 bucks or so to get a brand name battery because my experience with this one has been disappointing.

I bought one of these in 2008. It was pretty good - LOTS of compartments, which I make full use of, well-designed, strong and useful carrying handle, and very comfortable even when loaded chock-full of stuff thanks to the shoulder and waist straps distributing weight well. The only minor complaint was that the bungee closure on the front flap quickly gave way, but then I was putting far too much stuff in there anyway.

After three years of heavy use (and abuse), the zips on the middle compartment started to show some strain. One side of the zip started to tear out of the fabric a little. But the other side still functioned, and the bag held on despite still very heavy use for another couple of years. Finally, the other side of the zip gave way as well, rendering the bag unusable after five years.

So overall, not perfect, but pretty good.

HOWEVER - I ordered a replacement when the previous one died. Exact same product name and model number. Product came, looked as good as before, but with one crucial change - NO WAIST STRAP. (On re-reading some other reviews, a few of them did warn against this - well, it's true. There's no more waist strap. There are, however, still the zippered side compartments.) Considering how much heavy stuff I can and do put into the backpack and how long I carry it around for, I find the waist strap crucial and the removal of it inexplicable. Plus, doing that without changing the model number (not even adding an 'A' or '-2' or something to the end) to be sheer incompetence.

Sadly, then, going to return this and get another one.

That said, if you don't use waist straps / don't put as much weight in your backpacks as I do, then it's still a pretty good product.

I'm determined after my latest laptop failure to work out a better backup solution for my household.  The Hawking HNAS1 Networked Attached Storage Center seemed to be a good solution for this.  I had an extra 3.5\\" disk drive in a drawer, so I bought this unit, inserted the disk drive, set it to Master, attached cables, screwed in 4 screws, and put the case back together.  Voila!  Network Attached Storage.    Configuring this unit was not as much fun.  It does not use DHCP to find a good IP address, and its default 192.168.1.1 is the same as the default Linksys router address.  If you simply plug this unit into a Linksys or other router which is already configured with this IP address, then the Hawking and the router fight it out over who responds to this address.  After several rebootings I got the Hawking unit to win this race, I logged into the web interface from a PC and quickly changed the IP address to one that isn't used by any other device.  Operation became more predictable after this.    The firmware version shipped in my unit (1.01) has a bug in setting the time zone via the web interface.  There is a firmware download (version 1.02) at [...] which will correct this.  Download the file (about 3MB), then use the Hawking web browser interface to upload the firmware into the Hawking device.  It takes several minutes to upgrade.  Unfortunately, I found that the login password was changed after the upgrade and I had to hold the Reset button on the back of the unit for over 5 seconds to reset all accounts and passwords on the unit back to their defaults.  Unfortunately, this also reset the IP address back to the same value as the Linksys router.  Sigh.  Rebooting the Linksys router helped me to somehow log into the unit to change the IP address to a safe value outside the DHCP range again.  Phew!  Using the 1.02 firmware release the time settings appear to stick, though you have to check \\"Use Time Server\\" and supply a good server address - I'd replace the default (a server in Germany) with \\"pool.ntp.org\\".    You need to format your disk via the web browser interface (it uses EXT3 format for the Linux operating system inside the box).  You also need to create one or more shares, and you may want to change the user accounts and passwords.  If you give the \\"guest\\" account a blank password and supervisor priveleges, then you can connect to the share from \\"My Network Places\\" by just double clicking on it.  If you want to use accounts and passwords, then users will need to map the share to a Windows drive letter and supply the appropriate login credentials.    Now that the HNAS1 is up and running I'm happier.  My biggest complaint, aside from the lack of DHCP and need to upgrade the firmware, is that the fan is annoyingly loud.  My office currently has 4 computers running, and the Hawking is louder than the rest combined.  I can't easily relocate the device to another room, so I end up powering this down when I don't need it.  Unfortunately, this defeats my original intent to run this 24x7 with regular automated backups from all machines.  On the other hand, given that \\"real\\" Network Attached Storage devices used to cost several thousands of dollars, this unit is amazingly cost effective.

I got this as a gift from my wife to house 2 Western Digital green hard drives (one 2.0 TB and the other 2.5 TB) that were previously in independent enclosures. I use these drives to store my digital content which serves my Apple TV's via my 2011 Mac Mini. Yes, I know the 2011 Mini is USB 2.0 but, the description clearly says it works with 2.0 and I wanted to be "future proof" for when I got a 2012 or newer Mini with USB 3.0.

1st problem: After installing my hard drives, as individual drive configuration, the Mac Mini immediately wanted to reformat them as the partitions weren't readable. Disk Utility saw both disks perfectly fine. I pulled each drive back out and retested with the individual enclosures and they worked. At this point I was ticked so backed up both drives, put them back into this enclosure, reformatted both drives, then copied all my content back to each drive.

2nd problem: As I previously stated I use these drives to host my digital content. After I got all my content restored I went on with some other business. Later that day, I went to watch a movie and got an error. Puzzled, I went to the Mac Mini and saw an error that both drives were improperly ejected. I went to enclosure and only the power and hard drive 1 lights were on. I turned the unit off and back on. It worked and now I could watch my movie. But the next time I went to watch a movie the exact same thing happened.

Thinking maybe it was the USB cable, I got a new cable and experienced the same issues. I then tried a different USB port on my Mini and again the same thing. I called Vantec Support and they were puzzled too, so asked if they could call back in a little bit. I said sure but, never got a call back after 2 days.

Enough is enough. I had my wife call Amazon to request a full refund. I ordered a different brand enclosure which will be here tomorrow. Sure hope I have better luck with that one. Stay away from this enclosure. I not want someone else to go through all that I did.

Third problem is the 6.0 data transfer rate does not work on either WD or Seagate 6.0 drives.  The board is fast, but I would not recommend this board to anyone.  This board is not up to ASUS standards.

I also thought being able to rotate it to portrait view would be ideal, and if the stand were thought out a little better, that might have been the case. Unfortunately, the grooves that are supposed to stand the iPad up are too shallow, causing it to fall the moment you touch the screen. Since I do a considerable amount of work on my iPad and don't just use it as an ereader, I have to have a stand that can handle a lot of screen contact without letting the iPad fall. So I just unboxed my brand new pair of these headphones today and plugged them in, and while I was doing the setup, I realized the left surround speaker wasn't working. While the headphones sounded good when I tested them out with 5.1 surround audio from a Blu-ray, the fact that they were already broken when they were brand new doesn't speak well for the quality of this headset. As other reviewers have noted, the construction of the headphones isn't durable, and while they seem to have good audio, they don't seem durable enough to justify the investment, if they were working.

I simply can't recommend this product, and after having a chance to try this headset, I definitely won't be buying any other Turtle Bay products after this.

The case itself is extremely flimsy as opposed to the actual leather one that my fiance has - the case bends and creases which wouldn't be a problem except it will not stay shut. I cannot close my case because immediately it pops open which then defeats the purpose of the sleep/wake fuction which doesn't work on mine obviously as it won't close.

There is also the fact some of the vinyl seems to be coming apart which is evidence of how cheaply made it appears to be.

I would recommend sticking to the simple colors if you're going to order from this company. If you choose to go with the designs, just beware what you might actually get. In the meantime, I'll be returning mine sadly and probably look for another company to order my case from.

They fool us. They create these kindergarten little \\"Assistant\\" applications that have absolutely no useful content and pop up every time you boot your PC. What you really need is a company that will act like they are one of Microsoft's biggest customers, and tell Microsoft that their operating system has critical deficiencies, and that they need to fix it, instead of telling their customers that their PC user's agreement that they had to accept to use the machine, specifically exempts HP from supporting the machine \\"for any specific purpose\\", or supporting \\"any external devices\\" including their own! In other words... You're screwed! I've been trying to get my laptop to install a printer as a network printer. If I plug it directly into the laptop, it automatically searches, finds, and installs the driver and prints like a dream. But I bought a wireless laptop because I don't want to drag a printer around with it everywhere in the house! Windows 7's network printer wizard will search for the driver too, but can't find it! And I asked HP where the driver went that installed when I plugged the printer in directly, and I was told that they \\"do not support external devices\\", and that I should contact the printer manufacturer. The printer manufacturer has handed all of their legacy drivers over to Microsoft and only supports their newest products, so the issue, which IS a Windows 7 issue, should be covered as a Windows 7 issue. Since HP purchases Microsoft operating systems as an OEM (Origional Equipment Manufacturer), HP agrees to support the operating system. However, the only support they provide is telling you how to reinstall your operating system if it has become corrupted. Any other issues with the operating system that require someone to show you how to work around an operating system bug, will elicit an instruction, from the HP representative, to contact Microsoft or PAY HP to place a technician on the phone with you! They know that Microsoft will refer you backto the OEM (HP in this case) or purchase technical assistance as well.  Then there's that Kindergarten help and assistance \\"software\\" they put on the machine that is completely useless to anyone familiar with using a PC. I used to be able to search it to find out how to disable it, but now my search only returns the following:  1. Opening and moving Tablet PC Input Panel [This almost sounds a little relevant, but regards the touch screen of a tablet and this ain't one!]  2. How to Power your HP Notebook PC from an Automobile or Airplane  3. Turn User Account Control on or off  4. Purchase an HP Notebook PC Battery  5. Getting started with Internet Explorer 9  6. Purchase an HP Notebook PC AC Adapter  7. Make the keyboard easier to use  8. Understanding HP Notebook PC Batteries  9. Show or hide the menu bar in Windows Media Player  10. Enabling the Wireless Adapter  11. Add or delete desktop icons  12. HP Battery Check: frequently asked questions  13. Internet Explorer 9 keyboard shortcuts  14. Troubleshooting Short Battery Life  15. Type without using the keyboard (On-Screen Keyboard)  16. When and How to Calibrate the Battery  17. What's new with the Windows desktop?  18. HP Power and Battery Learning Center  19. Make items on the screen appear bigger (Magnifier)  20. Removing and Replacing the Battery  21. What's new with the Windows 7 taskbar?  etc.  So if the above list is pretty much all you're looking for in PC support, then this is the product for you! But if you're actually fairly skilled in using computers... Good friggin' LUCK!

Oct. 31: I purchased a Kindle Fire and a ZAGG screen protector. It seemed like an outrageously high price for just one, but the salesman said it was guaranteed for the life of the device. He also offered to install it for me, but the installation charge would have almost doubled the total price.

The salesman told me to register the screen protector as soon as I got home, in order to begin its lifetime warranty. When I did, I was relieved that I didn't have to create and remember yet another password. The registration was based solely on my email address.

When I got it all home, I discovered that installing a ZAGG is way more complicated than any I had encountered before. (One of the instructions I really did not like was the one that says not to turn the device on FOR 12 TO 24 HOURS AFTER INSTALLING THE SCREEN PROTECTOR, but that's a setback for the buyer regardless of who is doing the installation.) The process involves a special solution (included) and instructions on how to wet your fingertips to avoid getting prints on the screen. I decided to save myself the frustration.

Nov. 1: I returned to the store and paid the exorbitant price to have this installed. With sales tax, this screen protector now cost close to forty dollars.

As the salesman tried to put it on, he discovered it was scratched, so he took a second one off the rack and installed that instead. When he finished, I asked about the scratches (yes, the second one was also scratched) and he said they should \\"work themselves out\\" over the next day or so.

Nov. 2: The scratches, of course, did not \\"work themselves out.\\" I returned to the store and the salesman installed a third ZAGG screen protector. When he finished, I noticed that the scratches on this third one were worse than the first two. He said the store clearly had a bad batch, and I should contact ZAGG, explain the problem, and have them ship me a replacement.

I went back to the ZAGG website and was given two options to start the replacement process: sign in WITH PASSWORD, which I don't have because the original registration process did not ask for, or issue a password; or, the second option was to register my product (which I had already done). That was the first hangup.

The second hangup was the cost of shipping. You have to pay to ship the bad screen to ZAGG, but you also have to provide a credit card number because there's a shipping and handling fee for the replacement. That's right. They won't just charge you shipping, they'll also charge you for the time it takes them to put the screen in the envelope ... and they DON'T TELL YOU how much that shipping and handling charge is going to be.

Nov. 3: I took the screen protector and both receipts (the one for the protector, and the one for the installation) back to the store, and it got a little ugly for a few minutes. They wanted to refund the cost of the ZAGG but not the cost of the installation. I told them their alternative was to waste every sealed, scratched ZAGG on their rack until they were all gone, or they could refund both charges.

They chose to refund both charges rather than have an empty ZAGG rack. In other words, they chose to continue to sell scratched ZAGGs to unsuspecting customers.

I finally got out of there with my money, and came back to Amazon where I ordered a highly-rated competitor's screen protector. It's a set of two protectors that cost about twenty percent of what ZAGG charges for this one.

CONCLUSION: This might be the best screen protector ever made. Who knows? I would have to try one that wasn't scratched, which this particular store couldn't deliver on. Aside from this one store's unfortunate batch of defective screens, the problems with ZAGG's \\"lifetime guarantee\\" were twofold:

1. Their \\"Who are you?\\" attitude when it came time to log on to their site in order to deal with the problem (i.e., asking me for a password when there was no password involved in the original registration process).

2. Their practice of pre-charging an unspecified shipping and handling fee. Not only do I not know how much that charge will eventually be, I also don't know how many times I would have to return the product (and get dinged for the shipping and handling fee) until they get it right.

The rack is good looking and nicely constructed. The mounting bracket says it's patterned for 16" studs, but the holes are actually a little off 16", and the holes that are that width are not centered on the mounting plate, so the rack mounts either a few inches left or right (your choice) of the centerline between the studs. That's really odd and seems like they could have done better with that. If you need to center over studs, I recommend you install plywood over the studs, then affix the rack to the plywood. Also, since the rack has some weight and you know some weight will get added to it, you'll be tempted to use lag bolts to affix the mounting plate. Unfortunately, the way the rack and the mounting plate mate for installation, it can't clear a big head on a lag bolt--you need to use something that has a fairly flat head. Seems like this is something they could have done better at, as well. It makes me wonder if they've tried installing their own rack. Still, once it's up, it looks great and does its job. Other minor gripes: the left and right side panels are not hinged, so the first time you remove them, hold on to the panel as you remove it--when you pop the latch, you may expect it to swing out as if hinged, but it will actually fall out and drop to the floor (with possible damage). The front door is removable, but if you remove it, there are two little plastic sleeves that center the hinge pins in their holes that can (will) quietly drop off and go... somewhere... where you spend... seemingly hours... on the floor... looking for it... and if you don't find them, the door won't sit straight or close smoothly. Those little sleeves should be SNAP in, not DROP in. After my first bad experience, I started tacking them into the rack with clear caulk, and I also put a warning label inside the door at the hinge pins as a future reminder/warning to watch out for and hold on to these important little parts when removing the door.

A few days ago I got my Kindle DX in the mail.  Great!  Just in time for a 2 month trip to Europe.  Three days into the trip it died.  We have been big Kindle users for the last year, despite the reliability issues.  We are currently on our 3rd original kindle in one year, we have family members who are both on their second.  We had high hopes for an improvement in this area with the DX but it is just more of the same.  The bigger issue is that Amazon refuses to ship the replacement overseas leaving me with a $500 paper weight.  My only options are to ship it back to a friend in the US, then get Amazon to ship the kindle to my friend, then have the friend ship it back here.      While I loved the device for the 3 days it worked, I am furious at the reliability issues.  The big reason to have this is to travel with but the reliability is just not at a point where you can count on in working for you.  Amazon is a great company, and the kindle and kindle store is a great concept, but I think Amazon should have left the consumer electronics business to the pro's and teamed up with Sony.  I am sure I will not like the e-reader one tenth as much as the kindle but at least it will turn on.

I then bought the KENSIGNTON K72337US ORBIT TRACKBALL WITH SCROLL RING for PC or Mac.  FAR SUPERIOR!  First of all, there's no software to install - you plug into your USB and you're ready to go, just like a regular mouse.  Then, the SCROLL RING is fantastic - it's even better than the scroll wheel on a regular mouse.  It gives you better control and a greater scrolling range than the scroll wheel on a regular mouse.  Also, the Kensington is not as bulky as the Logitech.    I returned the Logitech and am happily using the Kensington for over 2 months now. I guess first and foremost, I got this mouse after my last one's scroll wheel finally died.  I perused the choices, saw there was a 'new' technology, and chose to give it a shot.  It works much like any other mouse out there, but with a noticeably greater sensitivity which can be good and bad.  Good if you're doing something precise (like when I touch up photos in photoshop), bad when it catches you by surprise and the over sensitive scroll wheel suddenly makes a page scroll when you middle click.  I have never had this issue in all my years using clickable scroll wheels.  That is more of a minor annoyance.  The great surprise since then has been my left click button developing a nasty 'rusty spring' sound.  It's been under 2 months, and already it's squealing??  I'd give the next generation a shot to see if MS can fix this issue, if you can hold out that long I'd recommend waiting.

I am writing this review just to inform people with Verizon wireless service, using the Verizon USB720 (Novatel U720) modem to be aware of possibly compatibility problems. The situation is pretty simple. When my modem is plugged directly into my laptop, it works almost 100% of the time. When I plug it into the KR1 router, it freezes up every few minutes. When this happens, there is no connection or IP address listed on the \\"status\\" page. This freezing occurs until I unplug the router or sometimes after 5 to 10 minutes it fixes itself. It is just not usable this way. Kyocera replaced the router under warranty and the problem is exactly the same. I did upgrade the firmware on both routers. This matter was escalated to D-Link support and they were unable to fix the problem. They are now looking into getting me a different model of router to resolve this. The U720 modem is new, so hopefully they will work the bugs out, but I wanted to make sure this information was available to other buyers. Both Kyocera and Verizon assured me the two units were compatible before I purchased them. I am now locked into a contract with Verizon without a working router and I wouldn't have done that if I'd known of this situation.

This Synology unit is probably a five star from a features and functionality perspective, but the documentation and set up deserve about two stars. As a non computer geek, but a smart person, I found the set up to be frustrating, and continue to have difficulty using the unit as anything more than a basic back-up for our MACS (using time machine). Since I cannot use the EZ Internet provided software to set up my Verizon Actiontec router with the DiskStation, the skimpy Synology documentation isn't enough for me to obtain remote access to the Synology DiskStation. In addition to using the DiskStation as backup, I had hoped to use the provided software to allow easy remote access to my photo albums (for family), and to have remote access to my music library. Contrary to other reviews this is neither intuitive, nor simple.

On the positive side, this works perfectly with Time Machine.

I should not be FORCED to use a third party in order to use the livescribe pen in the way it was meant.

I will never - ever - recommend this pen to anyone again.

ps. make sure you read the return policy! You're limited... in my opinion, you're not given enough time to evaluate the pen with the third party - Evernote. AND, nowhere does it say that you get a "full" version of evernote but the advertising leads you to believe that you do. IT'S NOT TRUE! You get the generic free version which only allows a few uploads/syncs.

My old Netgear WNDR4500 bit the dust after about two years. I bought this router due to the fairly good reviews, the cool look of it, and the pretty nice technical specs. I wasn't worried about making a router \\"work\\" because I am in IT Networking, so a home network is much more simple. I was wrong.

On to the review:

The good:
* The router sets up very easily. It takes some time to figure out their interface, but after you do, it does make sense. Just not very intuitive.
* The router looks good.
* The USB sharing function (attached USB disk drive) works much better than my old Netgear.
* The Range is better than my old Netgear.

The bad:
* Documentation is little or non existent. It wasn't a big deal for me because of my background, but I can see how some people who are not familiar with networking could be confused without it.
* Almost immediately, I had issues with my smart TV's and Satellite systems connecting (and staying connected) to the new router. These devices included Samsung SmartTVs, iPad, HP Touchpad, Samsung Galaxy phones, HP laptops, Dell Desktops. So, there's NOTHING in common between ANY of the issues except the router.
* Direct connections (non wireless) would hang; the router would just freeze and would not even be accessible by direct connection to 192.168.0.1. The connection would time out.

The Ugly:
Support. Good luck getting through. On the last day before my 30 days post-purchase return with Amazon ended, I was on hold for 50 minutes before I spoke to someone. I outlined my issues and she didn't know what to do so she put me on old to talk with her support. When she finally returned she told me that the issue I am having is related to the way the router loses track of IP's that have been assigned causing conflicts (this is a KNOWN ISSUE that the F/W 1.01 upgrade was supposed to fix -- guess it did not).

To explain a little more, there isan issue with the router keeping track of the IP addresses on the network. Apparently this is only with DSL and dynamic connections. Quite amazing if you ask me since the router should be smart enough to keep track of the MAC addresses, assign leases on IP's, and re-assign if needed. She told me that I'd have to call my ISP and get a login so that we could establish a PPoE connection. I told her, \\"No thanks. This is nuts.\\" Needless to say, I have returned the router. I really wanted this router to work because honestly, I HATE returning items, but in this case, I had to. I am really disappointed in the quality of this router and the lack of DLink Support. I probably won't buy another DLink device again.

Hello, let me first off say that I had purchested the kindle when my previous gen had broke. Now, it wasn't my fault that it broke, but it was a known issue to Amazon at the time. The charging port was bad, and it simply wouldn't let me charge it. When I had contacted Amazon, they knew about the problem... But had insisted that I buy another one (the kindle fire HDX7"). They would not send me a new one, even though my warenty wasn't up. They instead gave me a discount. Which I was reluctant to take. So I ordered the new kindle. Everything was fine for about a few months... Then one day I dropped it from about two feet. At first, the damage wasn't terrible, it had some cracks on the side of it. When I turned it on, to my dismay, I found that where the cracks had been the touch screen wouldn't respond. I did do some research and found out that unlike other tablets, the kindle fire HDX 7" had the glass and touch pads under it, fused together. So that when a coach would happen, it would go through the glass and ruin the touch pads underneath. An iPad from Apple does not have this problem because the glass isn't fused or directly touching the touch pads/sensors. So me being a very clumsy person, dropped it again from about a foot onto carpet. It cracked again. The crack was a shallow one, but still it rendered the screen where it cracked useless. So now, I'm unable to use it. Because I can only access 1/4th of the screen. I had to shell out more money to buy an iPad mini. Which I'm very happy with, and with the whole kindle fire HDX 7" incident, I proceeded to buy a case for the iPad. The kindle fire would have had five stars, if not that. The interface is great and the whole experience was great, from a technological standpoint. If Amazon would have tested it just that extra bit and dropped it from two - three feet on the corner, they probably would have caught the problem. But they unfortunately released a device that had a major problem. My advice to anyone that wants a "cheap" tablet, this is a good choice. But be careful with it...e that wants a "cheap" tablet, this is a good choice. But be careful with it...

Well,

I just bought a new KF and wanted to protect it as well as have some other functionalities such as setting it at an angle for viewing etc. I was also concerned with such things as screen areas being interferred with buy edges of case and closure methods etc.

I had narrowed my list down to a possible 5-6 to pick from and was also trying to keep the price under $20-25. I was nearly ready to place an order and I saw the YooMee leather case for $5.00 measly bucks! I thought what they hey, if it isn't perfect I'm not out much and it's worth the risk with free shipping right?

So I just got my case/cover and when I put it on the center clips that you slide the Kindle under were tight (which is a good thing) except that the top center clip must have a very sharp edge up under where you cannot see and it actually gouged a sliver of the Kindles plastic edge off which now makes it less than perfect which is the main reason I purchased the case to start with, its a minor thing to some people but to me, I care very well for my electronics and this really bothers me.

But wait that's not all; the case may fit tight under the two center clips (top and bottom) but it is very vague on fitting into all four corners so really the only thing keeping it from falling out are the two center clips ( one top one bottom). The worst part though is that the fixed clasp that is made to hold the cover shut, doesn't work! It barely closes far enough to stay shut and the least about of pressure and it just pops open. I might as well not have a clip to hold the cover shut. It is either to loose or too short or both but either way, it's a design flaw and to make matters worse the cover has already started to develop a slight bowe which I'm sure will make the clasp completely useless in a very short time. No matter what the clasp is just a waste and would never protect it if you dropped it because it would flip open mid air. Lastly the leather stitching on the edge has a place that is coming loose or rather never was sewn well to start with.

So, is it worth $5.00 bucks? Well if you didn't care that the case scratched the Kindles edge, and all you have to spend in the world is $5.00 on a case then I guess it's worth it.
For me, it was NOT worth it! I've dameged my beautiful new Kindle and wasted time fooling with this.

This is really too bad because I like the feel of the case, if it just fit better and closed well it would be an awesome deal even at $20. But there are so many options under $20. this one just failed!

If you order this I wish you better luck than I've had. Maybe I got a bad case, but really? do you think that another one could be much different.

You make the value judgement, as for me, I'm back in the market for a good case again.
