Slow shipping, and after installed the ipad is not as sensitive as it should be, have to keep turning it to get it to work..

I have had the third Kindle crap out on me, I practically wrap it in silk to protect it, it has a thick, leather case. It's in my Truck bunk when I am not using it ... I plugged it in to charge and now I'm looking at a recharge shadow. An expensive paperweight ... not impressed.
everything is ok

I ordered the Z-Mate Flash memory drive because I wanted portable storage which I could put on my keyring (so I wouldn't lose it).

The pen drive functions fine but the weak little keyring attachment broke off within about 30 minutes of me attaching it to my keyring :(. So much for that idea....

My Intel SSD 520 Series 240GB drive does not fit in this case.  The end near the SATA connector is not high enough, so the drive does not slide in far enough for the case to close.  Perhaps most 2.5\\" HDDs do fit, but I purchased it for my SSD, so it is being returned.

After installing this in my case (as intake), the back of the fan was rubbing against the case making a scraping noise. I removed the fan for closer inspection and it turns out the center of the fan where the motor is housed is a little loose. I can push it in, but it springs back out, which is why it is rubbing against the case. Instead of going through the hassle of sending it back and waiting for another one, I switched locations with another fan where the fan mount allows the fan to sit away from the case a little more. So it's working now with no rubbing. However I'm worried about how long it might last. It's doing the job it's supposed to do for now, so we'll see how it goes. The blue lights are pretty cool, though.
I took it back because the screen didn't light up and i couldn't see the screen...i have the kindle fire 7 and 6 so I'm cool

I bought this to do regular backups of my mac, but after 10 months, backups started to fail.

The first sign of problems stared when the disk kept making beeping noises whenever I booted up
my mac. I ignored the beeps for about two days, but shortly afterwards, the Time Machine backups kept failing.

Time Machine reported that the backup disk was bad, and even after I attempted to do a disk
repair using the disk utility, which at times indicated that the problem was fixed, the backups just kept failing.

It got so bad that mac started reporting that the WD My Passport disk ejected, which happened on its own
without me doing anything to eject it.

I am really disappointed as I expected this purchase to be a robust backup solution.

I've contacted Logitech Support and they couldn't solve my problem.  The touch scroll would work consistently on some applications but won't work most of the time on others.  Especially on browsers such as Firefox and Chrome.  If it wasn't for this issue, the mouse would be great.  I had to return it and chose the Microsoft Explorer Touch Mouse which works fantastic for the same  price.  Just not as cool looking as the Logitech.

First of all I bear no I'll will towards the seller, very good service. Second don't waste your time with this, the first drop, you're controller is useless. After my son dropped it earlier we thought nothing of it. Later this evening the shoulder button started getting caught. So in conclusion. Cool idea, but it's cheap garbage.
I had this one , and is't very very bad plastic cooling pad, it's amazingly bad one. It's chip but u can spend 15$ more and buy really good pads
My power button got rushed in and I can't turn it on. .
Software issues after 9 months. have not been able to use it because I COULD NOT AFFORD TO SEND IT BACK. So I have a tablet here that does not work.

My previous (cheap) keyboard broke and I picked up this keyboard at Walmart because it was the cheapest, thinking that this would tide me over until I finally had the money to splurge on a mechanical keyboard. However, this keyboard is the worst. It takes a really long time to (sync? whatever it does with my computer on start up), so that even when the computer is booted up, I have to wait for the keyboard to start working before I can type in my password and log in. It's annoying, but wouldn't be a deal breaker. The real issue is that it doesn't pick up keystrokes half the time, so unless you prefer your sentences without vowels, I would spend the extra $10 on something slightly nicer. [Corsair Vengeance K90, here I come.]

I use this memory card for my gopro.  It works well, but my TV does not recognize it when I plug it in with a card reader.  My other SD memory cards work fine in my TV, so I don't know what the issue is.  I haven't tested it with my computer yet, so far my smart TV doesn't like it.

This keyboard is probably the best design for laptop-like use. Other keyboards have better casing to protect your iPad and may have just as good of a feel (like one of the Brookstone ones), but no other keyboard at the time of this review offers the comfort of a real on your lap like laptop feeling as this one. So, I do not think this is a waste of money, and I brought it second hand here on Amazon so I didn't pay full price.

The PROs
+ excellent real keyboard feel
+ can be placed on laptop or various surfaces
+ keyboard is also a case
+ instant connection via Bluetooth
+ keyboard lasts a long time between charges

The CONs
- case does not protect back of iPad if that is a concern
- case edges include a foam filling to hug the iPad into place, unfortunately after just 1 month, that foam is losing it's shape
- due to its durability issues, not ideal for heavy use as a case
- BIGGEST con, as a case, the ipad can not be placed inside the case with the screen facing out! Sometimes I don't need the screen, but have limited space, I have to put the case aside.

That last con is why I only use the keyboard at home, it's no so much an issue with durability yet, but I see signs of wear in just a month, but I often take my iPad the gym for reading while I'm on the elliptical. I place the iPad on the stand, but if I bring the keyboard, I can't place the case on the back of the iPad, I have really no place to put the case when I dont need a keyboard since it can't sit neatly inside. That was a primary reason that caused me to own both a keyboard case and a regular iPad dust cover. For this reason, I also recommend some Brookstone keyboards which solve my cons above, but add bulk which I didn't want.

UPDATE: Nearly 2 years later, I barely use this keyboard now because of the inconvenience of not having a place to put the case, and also the iPad was new to me then, I no longer find typing on screen any bit of a challenge. The keyboard can synch with other Bluetooth items as well, such as your phone by the way. Neat little find if useful at all.g on screen any bit of a challenge. The keyboard can synch with other Bluetooth items as well, such as your phone by the way. Neat little find if useful at all.

I bought this drive with the advice from my father who has bought several LaCie's for his company. He's always had good luck with them.

The first thing that I noticed when I opened the box was that there was a gap between the case and the faceplate. I called LaCie customer service and they sent me instructions on how to open the case and also noted my serial number so that I wouldn't void my warranty. The problem was that there were 2 screws that hold the faceplate onto the internal chassis who were not even tighted (as if they started the screws and didn't tighten them).

By the way... the actual HD inside the case is a Maxtor. If I had know that prior to purchase, I would not have bought the LaCie.

I fixed the problem with the case and turned it on.. only to be hit with a high pitched winning sound coming from the HD. This noise will drive me crazy and is not \\"Ultra Quiet\\" as noted in the description. I'm sending it back to Amazon for a refund.

I received this item, performed a backup of my macbook pro, and it stopped working within 3 days!  The drive just DIED.  I called WD.  After talking to 3 techs, I was told that the drive had failed.  The drive just stopped being recognized on any computer it was attached to.  I will never purchase another item from WD again.

Unbelievably slow.  Support is absurd.  Spent 15 minutes getting a person on the phone just to told \\"a technician will call you back when available\\".  Documentation does not even mention some required fields that make no sense.  I've configured hundreds of routers and this one is crap.  Port forwarding issues abound and after many months on the market Linksys(Cisco) has failed to address the problems.

I received this item, hooked it up and....nothing. Called the number for assistance and an hour later got it working....somewhat. She gave me 2 networks, one for distance and one for speed. I have a very small house and whenever we take the laptop anywhere, we have to change the network. The connection is constantIy dropping and to top it off the tech support tried to sell me an extended warranty for $30!!! Who does that?????????  am so frustrated and the thought of being on the phone for an hour again, for a new product, drives me mad!!!

Slower than promised. Which was a bit of a let down.

I think it is still very fast, but real world testing shows nothing else but a lot of wait.

Having several wireless/cell providers in our area, we never thought to check the \\"coverage area\\" of the provider of wireless services for the Kindle.  We could not download from our home 2 miles from town, nor in town, was it a strong signal.  So, before buying check that out.

This is the second attempt at buying an HP all-in-one and within 2 days I have had problems again.  The first one was a refurbished model and it had major problems.  This time it was minor, but still I just bought it and who knows what problems might appear down the road.  It also seemed to freeze up at times.  I wasn't sure if it was the computer or the my service.  I really wasn't too impressed with how it ran.  I just bought it!!  I would not recommend this model.
This works,  however the space bar key feels flimsy like it's going to pop out.  I think I'm going to end up buying another set of keyboard from a different manufacturer.

Based on the many great reviews for this item I went ahead and purchased it. The instructions for setup were easy, and the auto-setup found my D-Link DIR-655 wireless router with no problem. I entered the password for the network and applied it. After about a minute I got a message that my \\"settings were not correct\\", and that I should correct them. I spent about an hour resetting the device, trying other settings, etc. with no success; it just wouldn't connect with my network. The documentation online and with the product is minimal, and apparently there was nothing left to do so I returned the item. I'll buy a different brand.
Way too big for the XPS 13

Only 4x? One of the slowest I've used even at 4x speed. Pextor's PX-712a or Nec's latest 3500a write much faster and consistent(12x for the plexy, 16 x for nec). They both support more formats(Nec=all known formats, Plextor=all except dual layer write).Plus cdr/cdrw is much much faster at 48x, about 2 min tops for any cdr. I don't know how they justify the price of this drive as you can get more than double the performance for less. Nec's can be had for under $100, do a search.

I have a 13" lenovo yoga laptop and the case was so tight that it took two of us to get it back out without damaging the case or the computer. It is also really lightweight and flimsy for the price. I probably would have kept it if the computer had fit better, but would not have felt good about the price. I'm returning it.

Top piece seems fine. Bottom piece of mine is tricky. It does not fit perfectly. It is too big!
Every time I lift up my mac, bottom cover slips or gets fallen off from the mac.
I do not recommend.

Do not buy this product. After warranty went away, all this hard drive does is making loud clicking sounds and take for ever for it to load stuff. Horrible. Its about to die already .. right after the warranty...
The black case is Great quality, but the Miami Heat insert was WAY TO CHEAP
Plugged in and never worked at all, wouldn't even register on my PC.  I bought another card at the same time (different brand) and it worked perfect.  This one is cheap, but no good...
It worked for a while but then it started to break apart little by little on the edges. Lasted about a month.
The teams appear to be repaired, has much rust on the inside and issue a musty odor. Bad product, it is not offered, it is a scam and I lost my money.
AP kept disconnecting, this product is definitely more geared towards a professional environment.
Switch worked perfectly for thirteen months.  Then dropped one channel which terminated its usefulness.
But the computer was already toast the new part didn't help.

I bought this product in the hopes that it would approximate my old Logitech Trackman Marble FX M/N T-CJ12 P/N 804272-1000.  I need a trackball mouse to use with my left hand.  The Logitech Optical Marble Mouse caused stress on my hand within a couple of hours.  From a design point of view, the trackball is too small and requires at least twice the rotations in order to move the pointer across my monitors.  The shape of the mouse is too small for a man's hand to rest on.  I just can't understand why Logitech stopped production of the Trackman Marble FX which is still being sold continuously on Ebay.  So there is obviously a demand.

I had difficulty installing the driver so I called Netgear support and was told that this product was manufactured on Nov. 1, 2009.  Therefore it is over 4 years old.  Very disappointed that Amazon would sell such an old product. I will try to return it but I will not pay shipping for the return as that will probably cost more than I paid for the item.
Was very nice but I bought the wrong size for my 7" android, so I had to send it back.

I ordered this drive based on the excellent reviews....that was BEFORE Iomega decided not to support this drive under Snow Leopard due to \\"architectural changes\\".  I'm now outside of my 30 day return window, so Iomega effectively sold me an expensive paper weight.  This would have been my third Iomega drive, but they have now lost a customer.

This screen protector is just pure bull crap nonsense!!! The instructions are so hard to follow, and I absolutely hated the way the screen was wetted with that stinking solution and all. After 5 mins of trying, I just threw it into the dustbin and cleaned up my screen. I would rather have fingermarks all over the screen than to install this nonsense!!! This is a total waste of time, and I have wasted money on this product. Hope someone can come up with a dry version of a screen protector that is easy to install and is bubble-free.

I purchased my new SanDisk Ultra II 256 MB CF card in April for a trip to Italy in May.  I filled the card up with pictures (Canon Elf) and all seemed well.  I was able to review the pictures on the camera while in Rome fine.  When I returned to the States, the CF card was unreadable by any computer.  Even a Data Recovery company said it was corrupted beyond recovery. I seem to have lost about 80 pictures of a once in a lifetime trip to Rome Italy.  Thanks Sandisk.

It doesn't cool, the fans are a joke, and the thing is so flimsy that if you place a laptop computer on it, the plastic bends down and hits the fan so it makes a very loud noise.  Honestly, this is the kind of product that has me wondering who the hell runs Targus and who in hell thought that this was a product ready for distribution.  Truly an embarrassment.

I purchased this because the customer wanted it specifically to match their other computers - not because I was a big fan of it. It seems to work fine, but I'm NOT a fan of the AMD processors and this is another reason why. It's just plain SLOW to do anything. Of course I usually recommend customers get quad-core Intels with 3.0 GHz processors and 8 GB of ram, so I'm used to playing with faster machines. If you're looking for a machine on a budget - this would do you fine. If you want performance, keep shopping and don't try to spend less than $750 and you'll probably be OK.

It comes with a ton of games pre-installed that I had to remove, mostly stuff for little kids. When I booted it up it appeared to be geared towards a 10-year old, not an adult office worker.
I bought this to use my pc mic on my ps3 mic and It broke in a month and a half.It was 2/20/14 when I received this item and 4/16/14 when it broke.!!!!BUYER BEWARE!!!!!

I am completely dissatisfied with this product.    I bought this for my daughter to secure her laptop at college.  After I bought it I tried setting the combination and it seemed OK.  I reset the combination back to the factory default 0-0-0-0.  A few weeks later, the night before we were supposed to move her into her dorm, we tried setting the combination again, and the lock just wouldn't work.  After setting the combination we couldn't get it to lock.  After playing around a little it finally locked but then we had trouble getting it to unlock.  Finally we got it unlocked but then I couldn't reset the combination to a more secure combination.  The final straw cam when I discovered that all you had to do to unlock the lock is dial the first wheel of the combination.  The lock pops right open no matter where the other three number wheels are at.  I am going to try to return this and get something with better quality.  Rest assured I will not buy another Kensington product.

The USB is very short! Does not reach the end of my USB port to connect. Very disappointed with this.
The pen is thick. The only good thing about it is the laser pointer.

Bought two. Both have problems with the usb cable having to be held in a certain position before it can charge. Why in the world did they not use a standard micro usb cable? This has a very small barrel type plug on one end and hard to find a replacement cable. Puts out good light when it works.

I too purchased this monitor and absolutely loved it.  After 1 year and 3 months I had a 6 inch wide stripe of multi-colored vertical lines in the middle of the screen.  I called Gateway; Out of warranty; too bad for me.  Talked to gateway via live chat to get the phone number for their tech support operation in Texas.  Believe it or not I was told I could NOT have the phone number.  What incredibly bad service on a $1,700 product or any product.  Imagine not being able to call Tech support directly.  Instead i had to deal with a 3rd world supposed technician.  They told me to take it to a local technician for repair.     I took it to the Geek squad and they informed me that it would cost $1,700 to fix the monitor.  Way to go Gateway!!!!!     Gateway did not live up to their end of the sale when they told me it was a great monitor.  They sold me a defective product and now I am stuck holding the bag. This monitor is a piece of junk and that sums up my entire opinon of Gateway and their products.  Pure junk!  I would not buy one product from Gateway ever again!  Not a monitor, not a keyboard, not even an empty cardboard box.  Their customer support is one of the worst I have ever encountered.  If you want to be treated as a sap that bought a defective product and be ignored by Gateway as if they don't care that's your choice.  I for one will never buy a Gateway product again.

This unit works as advertised. It seems well made and sturdy. It does what it is supposed to.

Any problems I had with it turned out to be on my computer. But customer service immediately abandoned me when they couldn't answer a question about this product. The driver page is confusing as there are two drivers availavble with no description as to which one to use.

This thing is way overpriced, as you can get similar units on Amazon for less than half the price. I cannot find anything about this product to justify the high cost. Save your money and buy something cheaper. The phrase \\"you get what you pay for\\" doesn't seem to apply here.

Pros:
1) durable protective coating for my kids
2) Amazon replacement guarantee if it does get broken
3) parental controls seem good so far

Cons:
1) navigation is poor --Samsung and Apple have figured out that a physical Home button is the way to go and I certainly agree -- the Fire requires a swipe from the top or side to give access to the Home and Back buttons and it doesn't always catch the swipe
2) low customization -- Amazon wants the Fire to look and list things like Amazon wants them to look -- I'd prefer a simple home screen with only what I want on it and NOTHING Amazon determines should be on there
3) screen quality is unimpressive
4) power button and volume buttons are really small
I guess I was not expecting this bag to be as heavy and bulky as it is.  Not happy with it and would never have bought it.
Didn't work :(

I used to love my old-school MS Natural keyboard, but I think now I'm used to the quiet, easy-to-press buttons of a laptop. Others have said it multiple times, but the space bar is just ridiculously difficult to press when you're typing quickly. Just as importantly, it's so loud that I feel self-conscious in a shared office space even now typing this review (even with the office music up kinda loud). I really wish I hadn't recycled the box the same day I received it, or I'd be sending it back for sure. At this point, I'm back on Amazon looking for a silent, soft, more laptop-like keyboard.

The damn thing MELTED in my computer, damaging my laptop and burning my hand.

Will be seeking compensation from the manufacturer.
lost it in a week ..
Didn't work out of the box as many don't (read up about the headaches). Returned it and bought the Linksys N300+ Wi-Fi Wireless Router instead and it's been great since.

The space key in the keyboard is extremely hard to push, as others pointed out. As a result it's very hard to type, noisy and typing speed suffers considerably. I've had several ergonomic keyboards before and this one is the worst by far.

I got this case at Christmas, held up pretty well until around march. The magnets on the side would come out of the slots and wouldn't go back in. I would use my case all day opening and closing the magnets. Also the same side under the volume buttons would crack. Currently half of the side is broken off. I would not recommend This case for someone who is going to open the case 24/7 like me.
This item is a waste of money and does not work. Do not buy it. Not a single port worked for neither my Playstation or computer. Junk.
It says it is compatible with my HP Pavilion DV7, but it is a few inches bigger then my battery slot. Waste of money.

I have had this case for exactly one year and just wanted to let future buyers know that it is not durable. It's very pretty and I have gotten lots of compliments on it. But the resting notches you use when the case is open are not deep enough to hold my ipad, so I have never been able to set my ipad on the second notch or it will slide out and collapse. Within just a few months the outside cover of the case had begun to peel off on the corners and sides. The plastic corners that hold the ipad are breaking off and this causes the ipad to move around in the case. If you want a case for pretty looks than this fits the bill. But if you want one that will last, I would recommend looking elsewhere.
terrible product! Didn't even work. Waste of money!

purchased this as a travel item, could not use it: too heavy
there are other items of the same kind, for similar price, at the fraction of the weight

Not good because if you playing a game and high pitch sounds will temporarily mute the speakers. That suck. That defeats the purpose of using them. So every time I shoot my gun or a loud grenade bang, it will go mute or shut off but when every thing is low: it will act normal. Smh

I bought this card for my new cellphone so I could store and play my music library.
It came with both a SD adapter and a USB adapter, which was a plus.
It worked without problems for about a month, then died.
Given the short lifetime, I would not by this brand again.

This product is worth the 100 dollars including the memory chip, I bought this for my daughter (almost 3 yrs old), and she loves to play the games.  It seems like the android store doesn't have that large of a variety of free games for kids; both educational and fun.  The touch screen technology is ok at best and processor speed is average. Still all in all for a 3 year old it was worth it.

got it to play black ops 2 and the sound and mic work great it even came with an extra ear clip for lefties but it doesnt hold on to my ear very well. could just be me but for the price im still satisfied

My tab 2 would not stay in the slot period. Horizontal, vertical it was just too unstable for my wife's use. So I returned it.

All was not bad, not sure why I had a problem. AS I write this I'm returning a music holder for my tab that didn't seem to work either. I have a refurbished unit, maybe it's and early model and there has been some changes that this products assume. I don't know.

Cheers.

The case fit the tablet and offered protection from casual damage.  All of the buttons and accessories are available but the wrap-around closure for keeping the tablet in place is not tight enough to prevent the tablet from sliding a bit.  This makes some of the buttons on the lower part of the screen hard to reach.

I may have received a defective product because after only 2 weeks it's been showing serious issues. The charger worked fine for about 2 weeks...fast charge, doesn't overheat, etc. But then it started randomly turning off and turning off my laptop along with it. My screen would just completely go black. The first time this happened, the charger turned on again a minute later and my laptop restated. However, now it just happened again and the charger seems completely dead. I restarted my laptop with force turn on, but the actual charger is showing no response (it's plugged in but there's no green light). I'm going to try to contact the company tomorrow, but I'm very disappointed in this product--first time one of my many Amazon orders has been defective.

I received these on time.  And they are really comfortable. The only issue that I am concerned about is their packaging. When I received this product it came wrapped in plastic.  Tucked into a enveleope. This product looked brand new but not so sure why it came wrapped in plastic instead of a actual headphone container..?  Overall I like the headphones and the microphone works great.

Good product although I didn't know it was a stick onto my existing keyboard.  It was hard to peel off and put on perfect onto the existing keyboard.  I did have a couple of bubbles when I placed the product on.
Awful. Not even an on/off switch. Feels cheap, looks cheap, DOES NOT WORK.

It's great! Had a slow start because I thought it would be just like my regular Kindle - a big mistake.  After messing up everything, I spent some time on the phone and received great help from Amazon Help.  Now it's wonderful.
Died after almost a year.

Lasted 3 weeks, it makes WAY to much noise, I assumed wrongly that that it being listed as aluminum might be a little stronger. The USB hub only works for about a week then shut off. The cord to attach to the usb is to short and generally the whole thing is a poor design. I discovered that it shuts down when it gets to hot!!! there is no raisers on the thing so the lap top sets directly on the thing..Pass on this one boys and girls.

I juts received this table and once I open it both of the security seals are broke. This means that this item is not new. I think the seller is trying to sell a few refurnish as new.
I contacted amazon for a full refund, and they were cool with that. Just be careful buying from this seller.

The price on this unit is very good but as usual you get what you pay for. Instructions were sparse and there were too many connections. It would be nice if it was one USB connection for everything.  The video quality was pretty good though but only through a VCR. The tuner section never seemed to work as I could not pick up any channels even with cable tv decoder. It works but there are better options.

I have try this modem on 2 computers with xp and one with 2000 pro. I have updated drivers and it DOES NOT work. If it does dial up then it will just lock up my computer. I highly recommend you don't waste your time with this modem.

I recently bought this cable to charge my Bose wireless headphones which comes with a short USB cable. I wanted this extension cable to carry whenever I travel but this cable is not a compact one. I don't understand why Amazon made this cable so big in size and heavy in weight. No one is going to use this cable to pull their caravans while going around. So those who are planning to buy for travel purpose I sincerely advice them to think about its size.

Apart from this I don't have any issues with this cable.

I was looking forward to having an extra power adapter for my Toshiba A305 laptop, but unfortunately this charger worked intermittently for a few days and then died.  When it worked, it ran fairly hot to the touch.  I returned it to Amazon for a refund.
It doesn't work well need some thing better
did not work to convert DVI to a VGA signal. on thin client  system.
This cable does not work with Droid X. The description does not specify. So I hope this help someone else.
Not really a rating. Works like it should. Nothing special about it. Good buy for the money
Stopped working before I could use it!

[[ASIN:B0083OXSBS MoKo Apple iPad Mini with Retina Display Case - Ultra Slim Smart shell for Mini 2 (2013) and Mini 1 (2012 Edition), BLACK (With Smart Cover Auto Wake / Sleep)]]
It's overall an okay case and stand, but my problem is that the cover attaching onto the mini is attracting dust. I got a shock when I opened it after placing it in the case, the screen was filled with little dust particles. They also wouldn't come off! Tried using store bought \\"Lens cleaning wipes\\" but didn't work. Not a big problem now days since they show only in the sun in a slight angle. Also magnets are iffy and sometimes don't stick, wasting battery power. Mediocre case overall

I had to buy this directly from Thermene's site because it was unavailable here. The fact that it claimed to have graphene seemed promising. The product is really poor. It seems like an undeveloped backyard job. Perhaps with proper development of the paste in theory could be good. Too many hypotheticals. It is super runny. Like pouring cream or ketchup. I put a test bead on my desk and ran an Apple Black Stick through it (pointy end) and the run mark closed up. That is how runny it is. I ran multiple tests on a Mac mini and found it ran just slightly warmer (i.e. worse) than Tuniq TX-4. This suggests it is reasonable to run close to TX-4. But they clearly advertise it is far better than TX-4. Anyway I had to take it off the Mac as it ran. Too risky despite the investment. I made a complaint to Thermene and they did not reply. Poor product and non-existent customer service.

I waited 2 1/2 weeks for the thing to show up and was disappointed with the everything about the case.  The cheap cardboard materials, color texture, and bamboo tray.  But the deciding factor on wanting to return the case happened after 2 days of light usage.  The decorative Dodocase sticker started peeling and sticking to my hand.  I took it off because the cheap adhesive wouldn’t re-adhere to the case.  The rubber edge protector on the bamboo tray also peeled off.  The paper mache cover stained with fingerprints like a sponge soaked in oil.  It didn’t look, feel, and hold up to $80 worth of product.  It’s a cheaply made, overpriced cardboard and I wasn’t interested in seeing how it held up against wear if it was already falling apart after 2 days.    I sent an email requesting a refund and sent photos of my defective case in a follow-up email.  I never received a reply after that.  After a week I sent another email for an update.  3 weeks after sending those photos there was still no response.  Their low morale directly correlates with their poorly made cases.  They boast about their quality bookcase-like covers but don’t follow through with repairs, exchanges/returns in response to customer dissatisfaction by completely ignoring your emails.  They didn’t even AT LEAST offer to repair the defective case when I asked for a refund.  This company is under the mindset that if they ignore you, you’ll go away and your voice will be buried underneath their expensive marketing and advertising.    If you care at all about your health (because they’ll make you a really angry customer with their blatant disregard for your satisfaction) and quality products at appropriate prices, don’t waste your money on this s***.

I recently purchased the WRT600N N-series to replace a D-link g-series wireless router. I wanted a Cisco product (quality) to avoid the random connection issues I had experienced with prior products. This WRT600N has both 2.4 and 5GHZ bands to operate simultaneously. I also purchased the WPC600N notebook adapter that was specifically designed to work with the router. My wife and I depend on a strong signal so we can actually do work and not play wireless connection debug. I am running Vista and she has XP. I specifically went for the 5GHz product, which I expected to have a greater signal strength farther from the router.
Impressions:
1)The 5GHz signal is weaker than the 2.4Ghz signal far from the router where it is supposed to be stronger.
2) The router install program did not work. Just use 192.168.1.1 directly to configure it.
3) I don't feel it was worth the extra expense since the 5ghz signal is NOT stronger.
Recommendation: By a 2.4 GHz product and use the wireless adapters built into your laptop.

The original Incase product I wanted I saw at the apple store, and thought I was getting a good deal finding it here on Amazon for a price cut down to $35. I even checked Incase's website to make sure I was getting the right product, and that this was the appropriate case for my MacBook Pro 15\\" RETINA DISPLAY. This was the only product listed on the Incase website from what I could see, so I ordered it.

The case itself seems fine (and I'm sure it's a terrific case for the older MacBook Pro), but I guess it was my fault for not noticing that the apple store sells the DELUXE version of this bag. The Deluxe version is more custom made for the thinner retina display MacBook Pro, it has an extra zipper so you can charge the MacBook pro while it's in the case, and it has an extra pocket inside to hold your iPad. They look \\"almost\\" identical, so this is really my own mistake for not noticing I was getting the wrong bag. I also discovered the deluxe version is ONLY being sold to the Apple store, from Apple (in store or online from apple.com). I couldn't find the deluxe version of this bag on Amazon.

As I said, I'm sure this is a fine bag (I eventually just threw down the extra money and got the deluxe version, and it's a really great bag so far), and the mistake is entirely my own fault, but I'm writing this review just to help stop others from making the same mistake I made. Will this bag still carry the MacBook Pro retina display? Of course, just like any other laptop bag will. Just expect it to have a bit more \\"wiggle room\\" for the thinner retina display item.

I bought this "personal cloud drive" with the understanding that I would be able to access it remotely over the internet.  Well, sort of.  It is set up so that there is a "Public Folder" on it, and you can set up individual, password-protected personal folders as well.  The problem is that only the public folder is accessible over the internet.  It is also accessible to anybody who can log onto your home wifi.  So the choices are, put your files where anybody you give access to your network in your home can read them, or put them in a personal folder where you can't even get them yourself unless you're on the home network.  Which pretty much defeats the purpose of being able to access them over the web.  Plus, there isn't an easy way to move stuff around between private and public folders.  For a lot less money, I could have just bought a regular external drive and plugged it into my router, and gotten all the same functionality, with a simpler interface.

As a desktop replacement, this computer works fine.  For basic internet browsing, email, word processing, iTunes playlist management, etc., it works fine.  Still, away from the charger, this computer is basically useless, it's often slow, and shut-down takes an eternity.    People compliment its sleek look, but I wouldn't buy this system again.  The battery life is inexcusable, and SONY customer support was quick to tell me that they cannot and do not warrant battery performance.    The sleek aesthetic comes at the expense of performance.

The case is really nice with several major caveats:  The GPIO pins are not accessible with my cable due to interference with the case's boss location and it will probably be impossible to access the camera and display connectors for similar reasons. If you carefully remove the insulator on individual pin cables, the wire can be bent sharply enough to clear the case and exit the bottom  If you just plan to go without external accessories, the case is elegant and the cooling solution is likely to be overkill for most applications.  My example had the bosses properly tapped for the provided screws, unlike an earlier reviewer.  The micro SD ram must be inserted AFTER the case is assembled as it protrudes far enough to interfere with assembling the case bottom.  Otherwise, the case is starkly attractive silver and black and has a very solid feel to it when assembled.  It would be great for a media application where the small size and cool, quiet operation are an asset.

When it is running, it works quite well with the idiosyncrasies others have reviewed. The problem I am having is that it goes to sleep and never wakes up. The Finder looks and returns empty to the search button. I have to power-cycle the unit to bring it back.

Also, the 50 degree C setting to start the fan caused my 1st-gen Seagate 1TB disks to get so hot the disks actually burned my hand when I took them out. The fan start temperature should be user adjustable to keeps the disk cooler. I bought WD Green disks that run WAY cooler. I would not mind if the fan ran at its slowest speed all the time.

Because it is only available part of the time (sleeping all the other time), I need to power cycle to get it back and the fan starts at too high of a temperature, I can only give the KD20 2-stars. Reliability is extremely important for data storage and the flaws I have stated do not make for a reliable unit.

The case snapped on, fits well, and seems secure. Takes the sleek beauty of the macbook down a notch, but that was expected when slapping some clear plastic over it, and it's not bad. The plastic is molded into a harsh corner that's actually a little bit rough. It would have been much better had that plastic edge been rounded. It bothers my husband and I both enough that I'm going to look for a different kind of case. Other than that, we'd have no complaints about it.

Edit: Also want to add this: The part of the case that's cut away on the side to allow the USB/thunderbolt/power plug to plug in isn't quite low enough for the thunderbolt, at least on our case. We'd been having trouble keeping the thunderbolt cable plugged in - we would walk on eggshells when backing up the laptop to an external hard drive because the slightest little jostle and the thunderbolt cable would disconnect from the computer (not physically knock it out of the port but disconnect from the standpoint of data transfer so we'd get that scolding message from the computer). We thought it was a problem with the thunderbolt port being loose, but we eventually figured out that the case was pushing up the thunderbolt plug ever so slightly - barely visible unless we looked for it, but enough to decrease how securely the thunderbolt plug held in the port.

I picked this up elsewhere last week. The physical device works fine. The copy protection and authorization problems with the lone compatible UHD & HDR retailer (M-Go) is very faulty. Do an Internet search for some long forum threads of all the customers not able to get things to work on their 2015 and 2014 Samsung TVs. It is a terrible customer experience. After many lost hours I was able to get things to work partially. The problem then becomes that the only compatible retailer (M-Go) heavily throttles the download speed for UHD movies. It takes 20+ hours to download no matter how fast your Internet connection. And downloads sometimes fail at 92% or so and you have to start all over. There are more problems but by now you probably get the point.

On the bright side, if you are one of the lucky ones and able to authorize and view compatible UHD HDR content, you will be very pleased. The quality of colors and light are unlike anything we have ever seen before. It is not that exciting to go from HD to UHD. By comparison, it is amazing to go from non-HDR anything to UHD HDR. The images in movies are just beautiful and it reveals a new level of lifelike presentation previously not available in the consumer living room.

My advice is beware. Don't by this unless you can withstand the pain of making it work or perhaps waiting weeks or months until firmware or M-Go app updates fix all the problems. It works better with M-Go than the similar Samsung UHD pack but it does not work well for most consumers. In time there will be more providers and more authorized retailer options to download the UHD 4K content which is visually just as good as the future 4K blu-ray content will be. Average file size of movies with this device is 85 gb or so. This is the same data size that 4K blu-ray will use.

1. Does not work as advertised - doesn't work on all surfaces (for example, my blanket or carpets) - whereas laser mice (such as my Apple Magic Mouse or my new Lenovo N700 do).

2. Also I don't like the loudness of and how the button clicks sound. Less of an issue yet still annoying, but I'm "spoiled" with how the Apple Magic Mouse's button clicks sound (muffled and low pitched). The N700's though are even worse, they're quite loud and high pitched (maybe I can muffle them somehow...). I just press a lot of mouse buttons and I like a quiet environment, so loud and high pitched mouse clicks get annoying very fast.

If the mouse wouldn't have the above flaws and would be a laser (or possibly have both, laser and existing sensor) mouse and if it would reconnect like the N700 does (heck, I can do with a mouse button press!), it'd be my favorite mouse, due to its shape and, once configured and set to the minimum value with the windows app for the MS Arc Touch mouse, I like the vibrating feedback when scrolling, which the N700 doesn't do. Also that middle area needs to be wider and perhaps slightly arched, so you can feel immediately where to go with your finger to scroll. Can't be that difficult to implement, right?

So now I'm deciding on returning it - I don't need 3 bluetooth mice laying around! The issue though is that Amazon is wanting to charge me almost 1/4 of the price for return shipping (UPS drop-off) and almost 1/2 of its price if UPS picks it up... that's ridiculous, considering that I'm already paying for Prime. It also took them one more day to ship even though I paid extra for 1-day shipping. All in all, this purchase has been a huge disappointment :(

So I guess I'll keep it and maybe find use for it somehow - maybe the reconnect issue will be fixed in the future with a software update on how the computer's bluetooth interface looks for new devices... who knows.or Prime. This is my first wireless-n and gigabit router. So far the speeds are awesome, way better than my AirPort Express. But thats where it ends.

CONS:
-Set up with a static IP (which I had no idea I had) from basic Comcast cable internet service was annoying. Not plug and play or easy by any means. Apple AirPort, you just plug it in and it works.
-Wireless has cut out now a few times. I reset the router and it is back up and running.
-WPA works on my Macs, WEP works on my Linux machines, but I cannot for the life of me get them both working on either WPA or WEP together. Again, my little dead AirPort Express did this just fine.
-This thing is huge. The biggest waste of space I have seen in a 4 port router in a long time. With its size you should have about 12 ethernet ports in the back and still have room.

PRO:
-Its fast
-Web based admin is nice in that its platform independent. Though, this is the same crap interface from my last netgear from 5 years ago.
-The status lights on the front are nice, the useless ones at the top are just that. Wish it was a load indicator or activity or something.
-The price is pretty decent

All in all, I might not buy it again. I like it enough to keep it for now (12 hours in) but probably will stay clear next time and most likely not buy a netgear again. I can't believe I would say it but I will take the overly locked down, proprietary software/hardware, Mac requiring, overpriced Apple product over a netgear for simple ease of use and reliability.

EDIT:
The router no longer works and only did for the first 36 hours. Returning this pile and getting a router that of course costs twice as much, but then again, you get what you pay for.

This review is for the Scroll X1 2400dpi version of this mouse. I am not sure how this mouse has such good reviews. I think that some of these 5 star reviews must be fake because this mouse isn't at all a proper gaming mouse.

I bought this mouse to use with a budget gaming system I built and I was lured by the fact that it is advertised as having an Avago 5050 optical sensor, and Omron switches. I thought that the low price of this mouse was simply due to the fact that it wasn't from a major name brand gaming mouse manufacturer. Unfortunately I was wrong. The mouse arrived today and after plugging it in, I sat there for a minute moving it around to see how well it tracks. Sadly, the sensor in this mouse is either not an authentic Avago 5050 or it is somehow defective. When moving the mouse at any DPI higher than the lowest setting of 800, the mouse pointer is jumpy and feels like the mouse is applying some kind of artificial acceleration. It felt exactly as if you were to max out the mouse pointer speed in the Windows mouse settings so that the pointer jumps multiple pixels at a time and cannot move precisely at all. This happened at 6/10 pointer speed in Windows 7 and without "Enhance pointer precision" enabled.

The second issue I noticed right away was the tracking when quickly whipping the mouse across the mousepad like you'd do when playing an FPS and need to turn around 180 degrees very quickly. In this case, the mouse pointer would simply stutter around in place when applying too much sudden physical acceleration to the mouse across the surface. I have a basic Logitech optical non-gaming mouse that I use with a Linux machine that does this exact thing when moving it too quickly.

Both issues I mentioned above happen regardless of the surface the mouse is on. I tried it on a Kingston HyperX "Control" hard mousepad, a SteelSeries QcK cloth pad, and on my bare desk with the same results.

Things I like about the mouse are that the shape and design are pretty good and feel comfortable in my average-sized male hands. I did not have any problems with the scroll wheel like some of the negative reviewers mentioned, and the buttons all felt pretty good for such a cheap mouse. It's too bad because I really wanted to like this mouse. I guess this is a classic example of "you get what you pay for."

I received the 64 GB Transcend Jetflash on Jan 31 2013 and have been using it since then.  On 5/28/2013 it was invisible to Explorer when I attempted to access it on 3 different computers (running OS's from Win XP to Win7), even though it was listed on Device Manager, so there was no way to access the data on the drive. First, in a tower case the fans have to be located below the motherboard and power supply since that's where the expansion slots are.  Heat rises, and the intake on these fans isn't strong enough to pull it back down and push it out.  That means you can catch the heat from other expansion cards (like video cards), but the hottest parts of the computer get a very limited cooling effect.      If you have your tower in a desk enclosure it's worse.  The fan slots can't be angled to blow the air out of the enclosure.  That puts all the hot air around the back of case, which heats both the air back there and also heats up the wood or metal in back of the desk enclosure, so most of the heat gets pulled right back inside the case again.  Using two (or more) of these helps a little by creating a better, stronger, air flow.  Using them with a conventional add-on case and/or power supply fan (like the Nexus Real Silent Case fan) helps much more.  Just don't expect that adding only one of these by itself is going to make a whole lot of difference overall.

I hate to be one of those "this thing doesn't work" people, but my experience with this item falls just south of a root canal sans novacaine. The reason I bought a hub was to, well, hub things. I had enough USB devices to merit it, and after installation, I thought my troubles were over. No more plugging and unplugging. My bad. Each of the 4 ports had it's own personality. One didn't like the tablet, but loved the SmartMedia reader. It was ambivalent towards the scanner. Another happily took the visor but shunned the scanner.Getting each peripheral to work together at the same time was impossible. In some cases, powering up a device would shut the hub down entirely, necessitating unplugging it. Granted, some USB devices don't like to share, like the Nomad Docking station and the printer, but it makes me wonder about how a person could possible link 127 devices at the same time. I had a heck of a time with 3.

As the old saying goes, you get what you pay for.
To get to the point, this is a good tablet but it has some shortcomings.

Pros- Screen resolution, Battery

The resolution is by far the best feature of this tablet. I bought this to be used mainly as an ereader
and so far the screen resolution is amazing. I'd say it's equal to or even better than tablets in the $500-600 range.
Battery is above average.

Cons- Screen responsitivity, screen sensitivity (screen feels kinda rough), slow and laggy, crashes.

The touch and feel of the screen is horrible, especially when typing. I wish someone told me this before buying. It's very important to me how the screen feels. But I'm willing to deal with it. The screen is also slow in responding to the user's inputs. It's not that slow....but it is noticeable. I am typing this review on it and can definitely notice it. The speed is an issue I didn't expect. It definitely doesn't feel like a quad core processor. My phone with a 1.5ghz dual core processor and 1gb of ram is much faster. If you have a lot of tabs open you can notice the speed suffer, that shouldn't be happening with 2gb of ram and a quad core processor. It also crashed within the 2nd day I got it. It froze and even the power button wasn't able to turn it off haha. In all seriousness, this is a cause for worry and I hope it doesn't happen again.

Basically, if you want this as an ereader like me go for it. It will also work fine for browising the web and watching videos. But if you're looking for a general purpose tablet I would recommend something more expensive.

Bottom line up front: the seller lied and rather than a new drive for your XBox360, you're paying for a used one which was poorly refurbed at some point. That's ok-ish because you don't need the circuit board anyway--you've done your homework and you're going to pull it out and replace with the one from your old failed drive...right? (Disregard my comments if you're doing a software flash and expect plug and play reliability. In that case, steer clear. Your drive might be OK, but my solder joints were bad.)

That said, I hate being lied to. Seller is intentionally misleading--this condition is no accident. Drive is sold as new with anti-tamper stickers on the case. It's specifically targeted at home Xbox repair, where buyers will open it up. Upon opening the case (making it non-returnable I'm sure), there's dust inside the drive. Worse, the PCB was apparently soldered by my 9-year old or a monkey on meth (not necessarily mutually exclusive). See photos of the globs of solder & burned wires.

Thankfully, I didn't need that ratty PCB anyway, though clean wires would have been nice. Mechanically, the drive seems to be sound and has worked for the past few hours as my kids play their games on DVD. However, I paid for new, not poorly refurbed. Again, I hate being lied to.

If your plan is to buy this card, attach it to a laptop, and then attach it to a GoFlex USB 3 Hard Drive, prepared to be disappointed. This card does not provide enough power on its own to run USB hard drives. Although it comes with a cord that allows for additional power to be provided to the card from a spare USB port on your laptop, something about the power output causes the drive to simply stop working after a while. I initially thought it was my supplemental USB port turning off power, so I tried an external power source that I knew would not turn off and had the same result. Tested the same drive using USB 2.0 directly, and no issues.

This appears to be an OEM card that has multiple brands, and is based on the Renesas USB chip, so I suspect any of the cards that look exactly like this one and use the same driver will have the same result. Works for probably 5-10 minutes, then stops. Very disappointing.

I own two of these drives, having purchased the second when the first one failed. This seemed to be a very nice drive. Nice appearance and very fast, especially when using the firewire 800 connection. However, a hard drive is something that can't be nice just when it works, which is the case with this drive. Now that I own two of these with no real solutions to get them to work all the time I am on the verge of trashing both of them. The amount of time I have spent trying to determine what is wrong with these drives is totally unaccceptable. The LaCie tech support people are all very nice, but I still have 2 LaCie drives that do not work. The problems started shortly after purchase of each. Even though the older of the two drives has had the same problems unresolved now for over a year, I was told by LaCie tech support last week that they will have to charge me to repair that drive. That simply adds insult to injury. I have four other external hard drives from different manufacturers and have had no problems with any of them. Having had a major problem with both LaCie drives seems to indicate an intrinsic problem with these drives. There is also the problem of firmware updates. They had an update for the drives to be used with Windows XP service pack 2, yet did not send out any notice to customers even though they have customers name and email addresses. I only found the update by accident when checking the LaCie site. This is another catch-22: YOu need the firmware update for the drives to work with service pack 2 but the update must be done on a computer without the service pack installed. I tried to do the update as the LaCie tech recommended, but it failed on both hard drives. Essentially I have two large drives that are only recognized by Windows occassionally. If you don't mind a hard drive that only works a little bit of the time, then this is a good drive and will look nice. But if you happen to need a reliable hard drive that you can depend on, then stay away from these LaCie drives at all costs.

Bought this for daily use to the office, and business trips. I've used it for two trips so far, and daily use since it arrived.

Likes:
(1) Plenty of room; the pockets all expand nicely, with a good selection of sizes. (2) The edge padding around the laptop portion of it is great. (3) It is very well made, with no huge quality issues to speak of. (4) It is light for a bag its size.

Dislikes:
(1) The shoulder strap being mounted on different sides on each end. For me, this makes it slide off my shoulder much easier while I'm trying to move through the airport or whatever. (2) THE ZIPPERS! (this is almost a quality issue, but not quite). If they have hardly any tension on them at all from the pockets being full, they pull a part when you try and zip them anyway. Then you have to try and get the zipper back the other way, etc... This is very frustrating. For a bag this well made, better zippers would've been great. (3) The two carry handles have no way to fasten them together so they can stay together. So if you want to pull it off your shoulder, you either have to set it down and then grab the handles from each side individually, or, just grab one while it's on your shoulder and then try and grab the other while the bag is hanging from the first one. It's kind of like trying to comb your hair with your off-hand and a one-tooth comb. You can do it, but it's not as easy. However, the last two dislikes would keep me from buying another one.

Overall, I would give it a 5 out of a 10. A very well made bag (minus the zippers), for the price. It just needs some revisions here and there to make it more user friendly...in my opinion.

I think this is a perfectly average wrist rest. Not too squishy or too firm. Keeps my wrists off the hard desk which is what I wanted it to do.

It's pretty thin, so it doesn't sit up above the level of the front edge of my keyboard (which is the standard Dell keyboard with number pad). It also is almost exactly the same length of my keyboard. The edges where the bottom & top material are glued together (which is about 1/4\\" thick) is the only part wider than my keyboard.

The front edge has a sort of wave shape with the back edge straight across. The front is widest at each end, scalloping inwards about 1/2\\" right where the \\"enter\\" key on my keyboard is (maybe 2/3 the way across the front from the left). The \\"top\\" (edge closest to the keyboard) is slightly higher than the \\"front\\" (edge closed to you) and it feels like there is a subtle swell in the middle. So across the top surface it's sloped slightly with a divot where my palms seem to hit. Typing on it feels pretty comfortable.

The top is covered in a black, semi-shiny fabric; the bottom of the rest is a rubbery material and so far hasn't slipped on my desk at all. In fact it's very grippy; I can't make it slide on my desk if I'm putting pressure from the top.

It doesn't seem extremely durable, but so far has worked just fine for it's intended purpose. I can't imagine this not lasting for quite a while with normal daily use, but moving it around a lot of picking it up off the desk a lot might cause the bottom material to separate from the fabric & gel.

Bought this refurbed router last September and it worked great until last week. It let me set up a main network and guest network easily and I had plenty of signal strength throughout my 1 bedroom apartment. Last week through it crapped out on me. I've tried resetting it, unplugging it, everything. It still shows up as a network, but there is no internet. It doesn't pass the internet through the ethernet ports either. Buyer Beware.

The camera is blurry, the speakers are on the back so if it lays down flat you can't hear them. It's made of a cheap feeling plastic. That being said, it was a great bargain and has provided hours of fun with the Android games and apps.

Aside from the quickly-broken scroll wheel, it's generally a good and useful mouse. Variable DPI is useful, the 2 thumb buttons are mappable to whatever game, and has nice blue LEDs.

However, it still has a broken component 3 months into use, so not very good quality. Also does not appear to be easily openable to attempt to repair the scroll wheel problem as there are no visible screws anywhere that I have found.
I bought this for my 11.5 cromebook and It doesn't fit. If your computer is over 11 inches, try something bigger.

I have owned this drive for 6 months, running on a 2.4G MacBook. It worked OK for awhile, but then started faltering and losing directory info. Disk Warrior was able to fix it once, but a second time I had to use Data Rescue to salvage what I could. Like a fool, I reformatted and tried again, using Seagate's updated firmware. This last month it crashed again. I had backed up, luckily. Disk Utilities tells me to save what I can, and reformat. But I am not about to try again.

Do yourself a favor. Get on Seagate's website, and read the forum entries for this drive. Even firmware updates are not fixing the problems. Your data is valuable. Yeah, you may be one of the lucky ones who does not have problems. Are you feeling lucky, punk? Well....are you?

My granddaughter was disappointed with this product.  The material started falling apart and ripping.  When I contacted the seller about a refund, I was told it was over thirty (30 days) and no refund would be processed. .

I have an older Logitech wireless headset for my TV, so I figured these new, updated ones would work great for my PC. Well, they're wireless. They run on the same 2.4Ghz frequency that wifi and a plethora of other wireless devices do. That means the signal cuts out frequently, especially while online gaming. Secondly, the battery doesn't hold a charge. It worked just fine for the first week, but now after you unplug them, they'll stay on for maybe five seconds before powering down. Charge light works showing it's charging, but the battery doesn't seem to care.

While you can still use the headset while it's plugged in to charge, it's still operating over that 2.4Ghz wireless connection, so you're still subjected to interruptions when there are large data bursts on your wifi network.

When the headset does manage to work, the sound isn't bad at all, the on-ear volume controls are nice, as well as the hot keys and mic mute button. Sounds great for Skype and gaming, but with the other issues I've listed above, they're not very useful for either. I'd recommend avoiding these and getting the cheaper, wired version.
It's a case but can only stand in one position. Should have bought the other one.

The functionality and ability to manage my kids usage of the device is great.  The set back is there is not enough space on the device at only 8 gig of internal storage, and there is not an expandable memory slot for a micro sd card.  This has made things difficult for the kids.  When the memory fills up, there are different varying issues that arise.  One has been unable to connect to my home network, another has been unable to play any videos and another issue was unable to download any apps.  The inability to download anything is understandable, but it does not tell you that the memory is full, and it appears as if it is downloading.  When it is complete it just will not show up in the list, and no error to go with it.  I would not recommend this device for kids age 8 and up, as they will fill the memory too fast with pictures and videos.  Hopefully amazon will address this issue.

Bought those a while ago from Amazon for my office. I guess I'm used to a high quality system in the living room, so I was a bit put off when I first heard them :-) Basically it's kind of a muddy mess. But then again - those are computer speakers for my office not an audiophile setup, so, after adjusting my expectations - here's what I think:    Pros:  - Reasonably detailed (for computer speakers)  - Loud (Not sure if that's a pro, but for my - relatively small office - those are very loud - I can do parties there now)    Cons:  - No off switch  - Don't get me started on the blue neon light, I'm constantly fighting urges to take it out with a shotgun  - The bass     And this is my main issue with those speakers - is blown out of any proportions. And it's not even a good punchy bass - it's just a mess of a low-mid frequency noise really. Even when turned all the way down with the Bass knob it is still way overpronounced. So, I took a bunch of toilet paper and stuffed it into the peer ports on top of the speakers. That helped.    Bottom line:  - If you want something for a dorm room - those are OK, although I bet you can find something with a punchier bass.   - If you want to listen to jazz/blues/anything highs-mids rich really - skip this one.   - If you need those for listening to windows startup sounds, Voip, youtube and online training sessions - OK, but be prepared to stuff the peers full of paper and turn the bass all the way down.

This is a really excellent router.  I did not have a single issue setting it up and have had no issues using it.  Because of the WPS flaw (google WPS flaw)  and the fact that the feature in the GUI to disable WPS is broken, any moron can run Reaver to break into this router in 4 to 6 hours.  Linksys 4 weeks after being notified by the US-CERT has failed to provide a simple firmware fix that would enable a user to actually disable WPS.  SHAME ON YOU LINKSYS.  Also with the current firmware (which is months old now), the USB port is basically broken.  If you flash to Tomato or DD-WRT to get rid of WPS you will loose other router functionality.   If you get the V2 model right now, you're going to loose the ability to flash Tomato or DD-WRT.  If you get a V1 you can flash to Tomato or DD-WRT but you're are going to LOOSE functionality (SSH, the USB port an antenna, etc).  You also have to be really careful to avoid bricking the E4200.  It's a very touchy router in this regard.  The WPS issue actually applies to every router Linksys makes.  All they have to do is fix the 'disable WPS' option so it works.  One month later they haven't even made a statement about it.  Your next door neighbors 10 year old can figure out how to launch the Reaver WPS attack after 15 minutes of reading and will be in your network within 6 hours.    Again:  SHAME ON YOU LINKSYS!

I do not leave reviews. Ever. And if I can change the star rating when this problem is rectified, I will. But for now, wow...

The USB port on the back of the drive shifted in shipping (I'm guessing in shipping) so the drive was almost impossible to plug in. When I did get the drive plugged in, I read through the setup for Mac and ran the cache settings then partitioned. In utility, the drive read as a 3TB, as it should, but I couldn't transfer the 1.2TB I had on another drive to it (Error - disk volume not large enough)... I thought that maybe I had made a mistake running the partition or something but then I noticed that the box said 3TB on the side and 1TB on the top. The drive still reads as a 3TB but will not allow more than 1TB...

Sending it back. We will see what happens when I try round two.

Update...

Still don't know what size this drive is as it still says 3TB but will only allow a transfer of 1TB, and the box has BOTH markings. I did change the star rating from 1 to 2 though because the drive is VERY fast. I know because I have formatted and tested by transferring 1TB of data about 5 times trying to make the thing work. The 1TB this \\"3TB\\" drive will take, gets there fast... So there is that.

Yup... Edit again. SAME ISSUE!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! If no stars were an option......

1TB on the top of the box, 3TB on the side. Functioning as a 1TB.

Works great, unless you let your computer just sit for an extended period of time. If your computer goes to sleep on its own all the fans will turn off, but for whatever reason the graphics card must still be doing something. It ends up heating up quite a bit. When you come back to your computer and wake it up, everything will look fine at first. However, when you fire up a game you will get this awful red tint over everything. This happens in every game. I don't know why this is happening, but it is very annoying as my computer becomes unusable for games. The way I found to get rid of the red tint is switch the slot on the motherboard that the graphics card is plugged into. There needs to be a driver update to fix this asap!

I bought one of these to give to my Little Sister (Big Brothers Big Sisters - find your local one and volunteer, it's great!) so she could connect to her home wifi network. Before giving it to her, I set it up on my daughter's Windows 7 machine, and it has not worked very well. In fact, it worked so poorly that I was unable to download updated drivers using this adapter. When I looked at my wifi logs, the adapter was repeatedly disconnecting itself. I ended up tethering her PC to my phone to download updated drivers. The Realtek web site barely worked to download the drivers, and the ones that ultimately worked were for a different model of USB wifi chip than the ones on the included CD, which might explain why they weren't working.

Even with the right drivers, that PC keeps randomly disconnecting from the network for a few seconds to a minute before it re-establishes a connection. I've ordered a couple new Atheros based USB wifi adapters for my daughter and my Little Sister. Hopefully they will work better. I didn't bother trying the out-of-tree Linux drivers, because I really didn't care that much.

Update two years later: I dug this out of a drawer and stuck it in my Raspberry Pi. Seems to work great there under Raspian, Pidora, and OpenELEC, so I'd say Linux support is good these days. Who knows, maybe the Windows drivers got fixed, too. I'm not going to waste my time finding out.

***Update April 2014***
The router gave me the blinking lights of death today. Power light blinking and internet (orange) light blinking. It's done this a few other times-maybe once a month or so, but I assumed it was my cable modem as is usually the case. I called to have that issue addressed and discovered it was the router this time. I tried all the trouble shooting methods I know of-no solutions. I went online and tried a few of those and was instructed to update firmware. How can I do that if I can't connect my computer to the internet? I was on the phone-on hold mostly-with tech support for a total of 65 minutes and only talked to the rep for about 5 when she told me I'd have to pay extra for tech support because it's outside the warranty time (hasn't been a year) She instructed me to go online and download firmware-which I tried already and if that didn't work then I'd have to buy a new one. She tried to tell me also that I maybe damaged the router so that could be the issue-not at all true. Then said well sometimes they (routers) just malfunction and they don't really know why-HUH? I asked do they replace it if it's still within the one year warranty and she said no. At some point in the long 5 min. call she hung up on me and my only resolution was to uninstall everything and reinstall and manually search for updated firmware on the new install. 2 hours later it was working! I purchased this so I didn't have to keep doing things like I was but it looks like spending nearly $100 for better equipment means nothing. Regretting this purchase now and waiting for more issues to begin.
Down grading the review rating because the tech support sucks and while the router works great, if it's not going to work all the time it's worthless so I need to search for a replacement already.

Purchased this a few months ago and wished I had done so years ago. Our wireless cable internet was crap to the max and we are stuck with it since we live in a newer subdivision. I was resetting the modem or wireless router or reconfiguring settings once a week. At the recommendation of the head of IT at my job I purchased one of these and connected it to a regular cable modem and haven't had to do a thing (besides shorten my daughter internet time) since.
Set up took less than 10 minutes (I'm good with tech but the instructions were VERY simple).
Lots of controls like having a guest wireless access point with a separate password, parental controls, adding a printer and optional cloud storage and more I haven't played around with yet.
We have a about 7 wireless devices including gaming systems and TV on the router and haven't had any major issues. I will say that a few time three devices, one being the DTV box, was streaming movies and everyone ran a little slow but that's to be expected with the service I have here.
We can connect from all over the house, in fact I pick up my wifi when I'm pulling in the garage and sitting on my back patio and the router is at the front of the house.
Wish it were cheaper, but for now it's well worth the money.

Immediately after a quick and painless installation the router performs beautifully - with signal strength and range that allows me to disconnect my existing 2 other dual-band access points. The entire family is overjoyed with the wonderful performance until...

After a day or two of great service the router's ability to perform DNS lookups becomes unstable and then fails altogether. It even intercepts and discards DNS lookups to outside servers like Google's 8.8.8.8, so manually changing the router or computer's DNS settings does not help. However, any sites that happen to be in your computer's or browser's DNS cache work great - with no seeming performance degradation on the local or Internet connections.

A release/renew on the WAN port does nothing to fix the problem. The only resolution seems to be rebooting the device.

Netgear has some lemon firmware here - running the latest v1.0.0.22_1.0.10

Until Netgear fixes the firmware I would recommend steering clear. If I keep the device long enough to get good firmware, I will upgrade this review appropriately.

Update: I just spent over an hour with tech support. The support engineer had many great troubleshooting ideas for my problem - that I had already run through when my router was malfunctioning - and coming to the diagnosis that the router has DNS stability prolems. However, immediately after reboot the problems disappear for a day or two, so everything appears perfect and no amount of troubleshooting will find the problem (because there isn't one until it becomes unstable again).

After repeatedly explaining that the problem was intermittent (every day or so), the tech kept asking me to perform standard troubleshooting processes that didn't find any problem (of course) - and that I had already performed when the router wasn't working and rebooted it as a work-around. Still the tech refused to focus on the root cause and kept looking for a configuration issue.

I then requested a transfer to a supervisor. After putting me on hold for 5 minutes and then asking me 5 more questions \\"for the supervisor\\" I insisted that he transfer me. Then told me that he couldn't transfer me and that I would receive a call back immediately after hanging up with him. 30 minutes later and still no call.

It looks sleek in the picture, but it is rather inconvenient in practical use. As other reviewers have noted, the four ports being at opposite ends of the device mean that it is nearly impossible to organize your cables all in a row. One or two cables have to be sticking out in an odd direction.

Consider the layout of your USB devices before purchasing this. If you can picture cables coming in from four directions, then this hub should be nearly perfect. If you want everything going out the back of your workstation, then this hub will only get in the way. The cable that connects the hub to the computer is depressingly short as well, which increases the hindrance that the shape of the hub makes.

Last week I purchased the Kraken AMS case for the new Apple iPad in the black-on-black color. I was excited when I read about a new and improved Kraken that was made specifically for the new iPad, as Trident set the bar high in regards to the Kraken that was available for the original iPad and iPad 2 and offered unbeatable protection. After getting the Kraken AMS in the mail and using it for about a week, I find several glaring issues that should Trident should have fixed before sending the Kraken AMS to market. The AMS case consists of a soft silicon sleeve that wraps around the iPad for protection, and two outer layers that snap around the silicon sleeve for added `shell' protection. The old Kraken case had two plastic clips and hinges that were, admittedly ugly, but VERY functional. The new AMS case's plastic outer shell simply snaps together without the use of any type of secure fasteners. This leaves the entire iPad (case and all) to have a very low level of protection in a drop or fall. The two outer plastic shell pieces on my AMS case barley stay secured in simple daily use - I'd hate to think of what might happen to my expensive iPad3 if I was to drop it! The other major issue that the new Kraken AMS case has is the poor design of the silicon `plugs' for the earphone port and charger/syncing port. The inner soft silicon case for the AMS has two plugs of material that serve to cover the two ports on the new iPad. While the idea is sound, I find that when using the iPad in landscape mode, my hands constantly pop the silicon charger/syncing plug out of place. This is due to a poor design, and Trident should be ashamed that they have allowed their newest, `prized' ultra-rugged case to have such major flaws. For $60, there are several cases that would be a much better choice to protect your $500+ iPad3 investment, and I urge those considering this case to keep looking.
