This is a nice looking case with USB 3.0 at a decent price, but keep a few things in mind.

Pros:
Very spacious with a multitude of vents for large fans. Nice screw-less system for mounting DVD drives and hard drives. Acceptable build quality, but a little tipsy until you install the bottom-mounted PSU.

USB 3.0, The motherboard for this build hasn't arrived yet, so I haven't tested its functionality yet, but I like how they point straight up. I must say that they do flex down a little when a USB device is plugged into them and I wish they were sturdier.

The wire management is nice, but not groundbreaking.

Cons:
The latch that pegs into and holds the DVD/CD drives has a tendency to pop out at its hinge before the correct end snaps free. Not a serious issue since it doesn't actually break (just keep this in mind while opening it) and because most people will only need to open/close this once in the case's lifetime.

The side panels, although secured by convenient thumb screws (read: screwdriver not required), they are thin, flimsy and the way they lock into the front end of the case sucks. You have to lay the whole thing down on its side to ensure that they are properly inserted. Again, not a major issue since most people will not open the sides unless they are upgrading/replacing a part.

The tabs on the back for expansion devices snap off (by design), so be SURE of which ones you need to take off for video/sound/network cards because you can't securely put them back in.

The orange 140mm fan that was pictured, but not mentioned in the description, is NOT included! Seriously bummed about this one. The description was disappointingly brief I don't like being mislead.

I haven't had a chance to test it yet, but I'm not very optimistic about the air filter's ability to keep out dust. It's really just a flimsy piece of finely-perforated plastic that clips into the bottom of the case. Another filter, white and apparently non-removable, is stuck behind the front grille for aesthetic purposes. Since all the other vents are left open, it would appear that the builder is supposed to install separately-purchased case fans in all 8 vents, all in an exhaust orientation to pull fresh air through the poorly conceived filters. This is a case that you could conceivably spend more money by plugging all the vents with fans than you did on the case itself. Don't get me wrong, doing that would turn this thing into a chilly wind tunnel, but very few people have a need for that kind of air flow and those that do will not choose this case. Since I am NOT going to drop $80 in fans into this, I foresee the unused vents creating a serious dust problem over time.

Bottom Line:
Comparable cases made by Xigmatek's competitors, such as the Antec 300, come with several fans, more robust mounting systems, nifty removable side panels that swing on a hinge and superior air filters. It's not that I *wouldn't* recommend this case, it's that there are so many better cases out there in the same price range.

When I have my keyboard plugged into this hub, my typing ends up on the screen slightly delayed (it's slight, but it's noticeable) and will occasionally pause every couple of minutes. When it comes back from the pause, one letter will repeat 10-20 times on the screen and I'll have to go back and delete it. For someone who makes a living typing copious amounts of text every day--software developer, here--this is a major pain point.

I bought this hub so that I could cobble together something similar to a KVM for switching between my Mac and PC for development, so I need to be able to plug everything into this hub in order to avoid having to muck around with more cables every time.

I sent an email to support, but never heard back.

EDIT 1: Shortly after posting this review, I got a call from a support team member about my issue. Evidently there are some corporate machinations that caused my first email to support to get lost. She was more than happy to send me a replacement hub, but unfortunately it exhibits the same issue. I have since discovered that the hub seems to work fine if it's plugged into a USB 2.0 port, but given that it's a 3.0 hub I am somewhat disappointed that I can't plug it into a USB 3.0 port and have it behave properly. However, since I have found a way to make it WORK (even if not how I'd prefer), I've updated my rating to three stars.

As far as read speeds, everything is pretty fantastic. Benchmarking reaches about 470MB/s. Windows boots so fast that the Windows logo doesn't even get to finish forming before the next screen and the Windows startup sound is cut short as the computer blazes through load screens. Programs load very fast even upon first time runs...like they were already loaded into memory and then some.

But when I used CrystalDiskBenchmark, my write speed was only about 80MB/s. Sure enough, I tried copying a large folder from one area of the drive to the other and Win 7 showed a consistent write speed of about 80MB/s. I called tech support which is of course out of the country (Costa Rica) and unable to do anything but read from a script. They told me I needed to use a benchmarking tool that uses compressible data. So I did, and of course the MAX write speed on one out of a dozen tests that were performed reached about 500MB/s write speed. That's cool and all, but obviously that's not the type of data being used by Win 7 for normal tasks, so why is that data used to advertise Intel's write speeds? Oh, because it's like 6X what the drive will actually be performing at in your computer. I thought this was pretty shady, and since I actually do copy large files fairly often, I had to take off two stars for poor performance and really useless tech support.

TECH SUPPORT + UPDATE: They are so useless that they didn't even suggest I update my SATA controller by downloading and installing the latest Intel Rapid Storage Technology driver. This is different than the drive's firmware. This seems to have increased my write speeds to hovering right about 100MB/s. Still about 400MB/s under what the box claims I should expect. Oh well, I guess.

For $2000, I would expect more from Sony. I would buy this computer instantly w/ no complaints if Sony addresses these minor gripes.

- Include Core 2 Extreme Processor QX6700 - 2.66 GHz
- Include High Definition Optical Drive - Blue-Ray Drive
- Include Internal / Built-in ATSC HD TV tuner
- Include HDMI & Component Video Inputs
- Include Built-in IR receiver
- Include Vista Business Edition / Media Center PC Edition

If not including these features, at least allow the consumers to have some say in the final configuration of the unit. I do realize Sony intention for its all-in-one desktop to never upgrade, but the next edition should be provided w/ an accessible bay in the back, so that consumers don't have to deal w/ their lame customer service support if there is a problem w/ the optical drive or the hard drive.

Sony, addresses these concern & I'll be the 1st to buy. Otherwise, this model would fall gravely short of Sony's selling motto \\"When space is at a premium, power is a necessity, & beauty is a must.\\"

Sony has always been a leader in pricing for products against similar competition. Thus, it only makes sense that we expect Sony to incorporate the right features at the right price, with the competition in mind please.

In regard to comparable products:

-- Apple iMac (24-inch):
1st of all it has a 24\\" Cinema display == Larger & Brighter screen
Display supports up to 1920-by-1600 Resolution == That's 1080p folks
Sony's 1680 X 1050 Resolution == Short of 1080p standard
Intel Core 2 Duo T7600 == Much better than Sony's T5600
Can Run both Mac OS X & Window XP via Boot Camp Beta
500 GB Hard drive == Twice the size of Sony's hard drive
nVidia GeForce 7600 GT Graphics card == Better than Sony's 7400 GT

Apple iMac 24-inch offers much better features for the same exact price. So folks ask yourself how in the world can Sony expect someone to buy something like this for $2000. Perhaps this prior statement will not apply to those willing to doll out the money for just the stylish look of the LS25e.

Sony's Laptop & Desktop have been outfitted w/ Blue-Ray drive since summer 2006. Even WinBook Jiv Mini can integrate the IR receiver & TV tuner into the unit & also have DVI & Video component inputs. There is no excuse for Sony not being able to do these things that competitors can offer. Basically, there is only 1 conclusion: Sony Does have the Capability / but Does Not have the Will to do it. LS25E is at best a Semi-all-in-one desktop, not the true All-in-One Desktop that it should be at this time and age.

I got these speakers for Christmas. I wanted to use them to play music from my iPod in my room.

Pros:
Long cords that allow flexibility - I needed one satellite to be on one side of my bed and another to be on the other side of my bed w/ the subwoofer in the middle. I have a queen bed and the speakers reached with a little tweaking.

Acceptable sound quality - If there's one thing I hate in reviews, it's when people say \\"it doesn't have _____\\" or \\"This product isn't product x\\". While it's not the best, you're only paying $30... for that price range, these speakers produce sound quality that fits that range. I'd say that they are better than my Logitech Z313s that I have for my computer ($55).

Cons:
Too much bass - The bass coming out of the subwoofer is pounding. Good if you like it. For me, I find that the tonal balance gives too much bass. Side note, the satellites produce pretty low tones which is weird.

The control knob on the speaker is too heavy - hard to turn it without holding the speaker or having the speaker secured to whatever it's sitting on. Not a fan... for me, not being able to adjust volume with one hand is really annoying.

The line-in for the speakers feels cheap.

Overall:
For $30, it's a good product, but I wouldn't tell you to \\"buy it, buy it, buy it!\\". It's not a steal. However, it's a solid product that offers adequate sound quality for the price.

Would I buy it again?
No. For me, the amount of bass is an issue. I'd probably buy Logitech Z313s again if I didn't mind paying an extra Jackson for the speakers. If you put a gun to my head and gave me $35, I'd get these, I suppose. Maybe I'd find some way to disable the bass (this won't ruin the sound b/c the satellites put out some bass as well).

We purchased this tablet as a Christmas gift for our daughter. For the first month the tablet was great and my daughter loved it! The tablet was fast enough for our use, and was very user friendly. If we HAD to complain about something, it would only be that tablet takes 4+ hours to fully charge.
However, less than one month after having it, the screen on the tablet went completely blank. For the past week, we have been working with the customer service / IT department to figure out a resolution. They have asked us perform numerous tasks (ie. plug the table into our computer using a USB port for 6 hours, plug the tablet into the regular charger for 20 mins, take "pictures" of the problem - which is just a blank screen- etc), and then they require us to call back afterwards so that they can continue to help us. After speaking with them 5+ times, they finally agreed that we should return the tablet so it can be either repaired or replaced. They were to send us an e-mail, and asked that we fill it out and return it, so that they could send a shipping label. However, we had to call them 2x to request for them to send the e-mail because we hadn't yet received it. We finally received their email and are now awaiting a shipping label, however WE have to pay for the return shipping. They reps are very difficult to understand and they seem as though they couldn't care less about our issue. The older revision of this backpack was a definite 5 out of 5; this one, not so much. Differences include:

- The older version was bigger - the main book pouch was much larger (essential for any serious college student), and the side pouches were also larger (essential for carrying anything larger than an aspirin tablet in them).
- The Targus symbol on the front of the bag was a headphone jack pass-through, and was designed in such a way as to not let water in. The pass-through in the new version is just an X cut in a piece of rubber. Not good if you keep electronics in that pouch.
- There are other, smaller differences, such as a longer handle at the top of the bag (tougher to put the bag on a desk, esp. if you're short) and the zippers running different ways (affects water resistance).

The new revision is still a great bag (I gave one to my fiancee) but it can't hold a candle to the older model of the same name, especially if you pack a lot of stuff in it.

Bought this for audio recording about three weeks ago. Worked great-- totally silent, super fast, no issues whatsoever. Then yesterday, it was suddenly useless, appearing in Disk Utility with an unrecognizable name and an unmountable partition. I hadn't gotten around to reorganizing my backups since the purchase, so I may have just lost dozens of hours of work. Contacted Elgato, and they are offering to exchange it for me, but they offer no help or suggestions for data recovery. I understand that none of these companies accept responsibility for user data, and it was foolish to procrastinate on backups. Still, it was a brand new drive so I didn't feel like I was taking much of a risk. I'm looking into third party data recovery options.

No drive is fail-proof, so I can't definitively say "DON'T BUY THIS," but take no chances with backups. Brand new SSD's like this one are obviously no exception.

I got one.  Installation was painless.  The wheel and trackball spin nicely.  However the buttons are EXTREMELY stiff - you have to really push on them to get a click to register, and doing a double-click is hard.  Particularly since it is EXTREMELY sensitive to movement, so pushing hard enough to click twice in a row is likely to joggle it enough to move the trackball a little causing the mouse pointer to move causing the doubleclick to fail and you have to start over.  The buttons are in entirely the wrong place - the wheel is behind them.  A natural placement of the hand means moving the trackball with the tips of the index and middle finger, and clicking the left button with the thumb.  However this means you are pressing against a part of the button quite far from the part intended to be clicked.  Even if you try clicking with the index finger, if you're using the tip of your middle finger to move the trackball, your clicking finger is still behind the trackball and far from the part of the button that one should be pressing on.  I can't imagine how they let this through their QA and customer focus groups, it is very nearly unuseable.  The shape of the device - with the trackball projecting high above - leads to an odd positioning of the hand that in turn leads to new repetitive stress.  Also the cursor speed is very high, much higher than what \\"feels\\" like a similar movement with a mouse.  Easily one of the most frustrating pieces of hardware I've worked with.  As much as I don't want to, I may have to give Logitech more money for a proper device, even if it does start malfunctioning again within six months.

I have the thing on my desk here, but even before installing it & firing it up I know its going back to Staples. This would likely be a perfectly satisfactory second monitor, especially at the below a hundred price paid on black friday. Still it goes back for one key reason:

It is NOT drilled for VESA 100mm mounting. So it cannot be attached to a monitor arm of any sort. And that means it sits too low on a desk. The stand does allow angling up (but not down), but that still means the ergonomics here are awful. (I do see that there are TWO holds in half of a VESA mounting pattern. So the monitor could in a pinch be hung. But since the bottom isn't supported, that means common movements of the monitor while hung in a monitor arm will pull on the two mounting screws & eventually in a loud & perhaps catastrophic way. It also means the monitor cannot be used vertically in any manner whatsoever).

Also, I note that this product has an inferior warranty of only one year. Apparently Samsung doesn't trust their Chinese supplier's quality.

Not for gamers. Avg ping jumped +35/40ms over gigabit hard wire. Throughput was fine, and turning on prioritization helped a little, but I get better gaming performance from my WRT54G!    2/22/15 Update - These things are serious junk. If you have one and it is working for you, then great. I have now tried to rely on 3 of these in total, and all 3 have let me down for various reasons. The main issue is after about 1-2 weeks they will start to degrade in performance (like most routers) but you cannot remote reboot them. If you try the router will basically lock up and you will have to power cycle it manually. This is frustrating for a number of reasons but basically it is just because of bad programming, or hardware limitations of some sort. I have 2 Asus RT-AC68U routers that both have no loss in performance after 468 days of continuous use, under heavy load both wired and wireless. Those are what I am replacing these current routers by Linksys with.     Let me explain why people are buying these.  Linksys made great routers years ago. The WRT54G was basically their pinnacle. Those routers are STILL working to this day although they are getting out of date. The WRT1900AC looks alot like the old faithful, but I will tell you right now, I have seen 19$ routers outperform this as far as reliability goes. Thats my 2C.

This router may end up working fine in the long run, but I just spent an entire day trying to set it up to interface with a wireless printer and Homegroup in Windows 7. It has been quite an experience!

First you should know that this is NOT a router/modem combo which means that you will need a separate modem. Netgear is not at fault for my lack of reading skills, but I went to install it and realized I needed a new modem as well, so take note. At first it looked fine and all the devices connected to the internet without any problems. I thought we were good to go, until we tried to set up the wireless printer the next day.

Thus begins the saga of missing network, because, while all the devices could get on the internet, they couldn't see each other at all. We rely on a wireless printer and pull documents from one computer to the other, so this morning I set out on a quest to discover the issue.

Be aware the setup website that Netgear gives you in the N600 instructions may not work, so try 192.168.1.1 if you have problems.

Obviously, I made sure that all the devices were set to be discoverable, then I tried disabling the firewall. No Luck.

I found out that Windows 7 Homegroup communicates through IPV6 so you have to make sure that is enabled on your computers. Then I discovered that IPV6 is not automatically enabled on the Netgear N600 Router, so you need to enable that in the \\"advanced setup\\" area on the router. You will have to do this step if you want to do a Homegroup, but it still didn't solve my problem.

I also enabled UPnP for good measure, but it wasn't that. The final answer, drum roll please, was to uncheck the box titled \\"Wireless Isolation\\" in the router set up. (You also want to make sure your SSID is unhidden). It took me several hours on the internet to troubleshoot this problem and in the end I was victorious, but I would rather have spent my day enjoying my family.

To sum up; if you don't have Windows 7, use a wireless printer or care about networking, then this router may work well for you. If you are a tech guy (or gal) who needs dual band, and is good at setup, this may be a great router.

On the other hand if are looking for an easy way to network your devices in Windows 7, you may want to check out other options.

If this was helpful to you please mark it as \\"helpful\\", so others see it as well. Thanks for your time.

This Acer Iconia W510 is rather cute but I find it kind of wobbly where the tablet sits into the plastic slot of the keyboard. (other brands use metal contacts) Don't know how long that will last. The battery life is great at up to 15 hours or so depending on the kind of work you do. At 2 G RAM and 64 GB memory. it is adequate but not fast. The sound diaappeared a number of times when I left it for a while and I had to reboot from the very start to regain the sound. It freezed up on me a number of times for no reason and needed to be rebooted again as well. This is probably Acer's software incompatibility with Window 8. There is no stylus that comes with it and the after market stylus that you can buy from Fry's or Best Buy, has a little round plastic disc at the nib and got lost rather easily.  The touch screen is very responsive and has no problem but would not respond to my stylus from Toshiba. Window 8 on this device takes some getting used to. The construction is good because the back is not smooth and easy to hold. The keyboard has 2 strips of rubber to prevent it from sliding around. Once closed, you have to slip your finger nail in the front groove to open it. I find that rather clumsy. At $700, it is a great unit but I would like to see a stylus and 4G RAM configuration.

If I had to choose two words to describe this product, my choices would be cheap and bright. Not a good way to describe a laptop cooling pad. I bought this product because of two reasons. First, my laptop was heating up obviously. And second, I needed something under my laptop to adjust the height of screen. The product detail showed that it had three fans and a raised back with a very reasonable price tag.

Pros:
Correctly adjusts the height of the screen to where I prefer it to be.
USB powered
Fans are really quiet. I'll almost forget that they are there until I see..
..Cool blue LED lights.
Low price tag

Cons:
Cheaply made. It is made of acrylic-like material and is very flimsy.
Doesn't cool the laptop well. I don't see any substantial temperature drops.
Fans are unprotected and open. I ended up accidentally grabbing them my with my fingers. It didn't hurt that much though.

Noteworthy:
This laptop cooler is generic, meaning there is no brand. This is good because it is cheap, but you're on your own when it comes to customer service.

Overall, this is a cheap generic laptop cooler which is pleasing aesthetically but fails to impress me in every other aspect. I could have easily used a thick book to adjust the height instead of using this laptop cooler. And most importantly, it didn't really cool my laptop and has to be confined to my desk because of it's flimsiness. Definitely not portable.
Unless you happen to be absolutely broke, I would not recommend this product.

The product seems to operate OK for a regular HD, however what I was hoping for was a 7200RPM hard drive to off load writing HD video to my main PC's HD during video game play.  I have the suspicion that this is a regular 5200RPM drive, since I have stuttering with the recorded video.  Fantom, and other manufacturers never mention in their websites, PDFs, etc., the speed of the drive.  If you want a regular 5200RPM 3.0 USB HD this will do the job, however if you are looking for a 7200RPM drive look elsewhere, hence the 3 stars rating.

I so wanted to like (and KEEP) this Anker Bluetooth Folio Keyboard Case for iPad Air. I have tried several other models and makes and so far, this model is close to being very good but it fails in many crucial areas. The good, as others have stated is the feeling of the keypad. Key travel and tactile feel is nice. Solid feel of the case and keyboard overall is also a plus. The material that the case and keyboard are made of is pleasant and grippey (not slippery) so you can carry it confidently without fear of it sliding out of your hands. The magnet that holds the iPad in place for typing and activates the keyboard is solid and gives a comforting "click" sound letting you know it's in place. This is one of the best features of the case - the magnetic activation of the keyboard (like it's completing a circuit) and is a feature that ALL manufacturers should implement in their cases. Now the negatives: 1) only 1 viewing angle. Limits the positions that you can optimally view the screen. Not a great angle for viewing on your lap as the angle is somewhat close to vertical. 2) The pairing can be inconsistent. I've had to repair the keyboard a few times and I've only had it a few days so far. 3) The annoying clip that holds the iPad in place which you need to UNCLIP each time you want to go to typing mode. Why couldn't they have just used a magnet of some sort to lightly keep the iPad in place instead of a clip? 4) My biggest complaint/dissatisfaction with the case however is the lack of any sort of way to keep the case fully closed. There are magnets in the keyboard base below the space bar however they aren't sufficiently strong enough to keep the case closed. Additional magnets should have been designed into the unit on the portion of the case that connects to the iPad itself so that when it's in the closed position, the dual magnets connect. This issue has been addressed it seems in the later version of this case designed for the Air 2. That version has the additional magnets that actually "snap" the case closed and keep it closed so that your iPad is not waking and draining the battery while you're not using it. Having had the opportunity to use and compare both versions of this case, I can unequivocally say that the Air 2 version is far superior to the Air (1) version. Clearly the designers of this case saw this particular flaw with the Air 1 and then made this improvement resulting int the Air 2 version. Too bad for all of us Air 1 users though as we're still stuck with a case with a major flaw which is a deal breaker for me.

If the people at ANKER are truly reading these reviews, then it would be great if they could take these complaints into consideration and make the changes mentioned (all of these have been previously covered by other reviewers).

Unfortunately, this one is a big miss and I will be looking for a replacement.has the additional magnets that actually "snap" the case closed and keep it closed so that your iPad is not waking and draining the battery while you're not using it. The style shown is an HP v250w USB Flash Drive, but genuine v250w drives are only made to a maximum capacity of 128GB - only recently up from 64GB. (The genuine drives are actually made by PNY under across branding agreement.) See[...] for HP v250w product specifications and check for yourself.

Any v250w advertised with a higher capacity is one of many Chinese-made counterfeits that have flooded the market. These counterfeits invariably also have fake capacity. That is why their price is so low.

Read on...

Beware fake capacity flash drives - especially unusually low-priced generic (and brand-name look-alike) drives 64GB and up.

This and many other cheap apparently high capacity flash drives are really low capacity 4GB or 8GB drives that have been hacked (controller chip settings altered) by dishonest Chinese suppliers so that they show a false inflated capacity. That is why their price is so low. Such drives are then redistributed by a few clueless resellers and by many other fully-aware resellers who are out to make a quick profit.

These drives will show their false capacity in Windows properties, but will quietly lose or corrupt your valuable data once their true capacity is exceeded. They will seem to work at first and files will look okay in their folders, but you will eventually find some or all of your data corrupt when played, viewed, or otherwise read back. Your valuable data will be irretrievably lost.

As of Q3 2015, the *only* manufacturer of 1TB USB flash drives is Kingston with their DTHXP30 HyperX Predator drive. To achieve that capacity, Kingston mounts 8 memory chips, a controller chip and other necessary components on three interconnected circuit cards packed into a necessarily bulky package. Search for \\"DTHXP30 review\\" to see photos of the internals. Those drives cost several hundred dollars, and the lion's share of this cost is the memory chips themselves. The circuit card, case, assembly costs, packaging, and distribution only add a few dollars.

The Chinese are great at producing a wide range of interesting generic and novelty designs, but they don't have a magic supply of cheap memory chips. They also do not have the ability to make a 1TB drive using a single chip design as is contained in this drive. The technology is not there yet.

Good generic flash drives *are* out there, but the true capacity generic drives top out at 128GB for USB 2.0 drives (costing about $40), and the less common 256GB USB 3.0 generics (costing about $90). The market is also flooded with fake capacity drives offered at prices well below the true capacity drives.

Be especially cautious of sellers that offer the same style in multiple sizes, but where each doubling in size is only 25% to 50% more than the size below. For example, if the 64GB drive is only $5 more than the 32GB drive, or where the 128GB drive is only $10 more than the 64GB. Real memory is not that cheap.

If you do buy a low-priced drive, the first thing you should do is test the capacity using a utility called h2testw. This will fill the drive with data and then verify that it can be read back intact. The write phase usually completes without error. It is the verify phase that exposes the fake capacity. Testing the first 32GB is usually sufficient. For reasons stated above, you cannot trust the capacity displayed in Windows properties.

You can also test by filling the drive up to at least 35GB with videos or other large media files and then *most importantly* check to see if they can be played back. If the capacity is faked, the first few will play, but past some point, the rest will be corrupt.

Do not trust the capacity or space remaining shown in the properties display - that is exactly what is faked.

Search for \\"fake capacity flash\\" using your favorite search engine for more information.add a few dollars. If the capacity is faked, the first few will play, but past some point, the rest will be corrupt. Do not trust the capacity or space remaining shown in the properties display - that is exactly what is faked. Search for \\"fake capacity flash\\" using your favorite search engine for more information.

Guest network setup was easy enough, but note: you'll need to scroll down, SAVE, then REBOOT before anything changes. It's not that obvious until you've done it once.

On-line telephone tech support isn't working. Message is "agents no longer available"

If the unit performs well in the new few months I'll report back

I bought this for my HP Pavilion. The case was little lighter in color than I expected and the fit was way too tight for comfort. I did like the way it was packaged but reusable plastic that it came in was torn. delivery was good. I would not buy this again because the fit is too tight.

I bought the GARMIN NUVI 260W Wide Screen ClearTouch Anti-Glare Screen protector because of the touch-screen nature of using the GARMIN NUVI GPS and wanting a screen protector that would fit perfectly on my GPS without having to cut anything to size.     Thumb smudges and fingernail scratches are common fears (real or imagined) so do yourself a favor a remove all doubt, and get one of these screen protectors.     The product is designed to fit perfectly over the model that you have so be doubly-sure that you buy the correct size ClearTouch Protector meant for your GARMIN NUVI GPS model. If it's for the Nuvi 200-series, make sure it's for the Wide Screen if you have a GARMIN NUVI wide-screen model (for this review the Garmin NUVI 260W Widescreen GPS).    My only complaint is that this ClearTouch Anti-Glare Screen Protector works too well in that it can attract airborne dust. But the screen protector is removable, washable and reuseable so it's just a matter of doing these things if things get too dirty and dusty.    You see, the problem isn't the dust on top as much as the tiny particles of dust that get trapped between the ClearTouch Anti-Glare Screen Protector and the surface of the GPS screen itself (this can result in air-bubbles or dust-bubbles).     However, it's not a major problem and won't cause any distortion of the screenview. Nontheless, if you know someone with long, beautiful, lucious (and dangerous) fingernails, a ClearTouch Screen Protector will protect your GARMIN NUVI 260W Widescreen GPS!

When I started researching memory for my desktop it was very hard to get concrete answers. There's a myriad of available memory for any particular computer but paring down the choices to choose the the correct modules is a daunting task. I even contacted Crucial and they only suggested the modules that were in their finder on their website.
That wasn't telling me which memory would give me the best performance. Anyhow, since I do a lot of photo editing, I did notice some improvement but only a little.
I was expecting that doubling my memory with high quality RAM would give me a noticeable boost. I was disappointed.
Now I'm convince that the real way to improve speed and performance is a solid state drive so I'm waiting for prices to come down.
In sum, it didn't hurt, but it didn't help that much.

I understand that the unit takes time to update the Cache on-board, however it didn't seem to be any faster at daily tasks as a normal 7200rpm drive.  Its still a good drive and maybe I just didn't notice

I bought this after selling an older IPAD and it has worked great except for the fact there is no power cable provided when your purchase it and it is not very customizable. Would be nice if you could choose what menu items you want to see, what you want on the main screen, and add a personal desktop and lock image.

I don't normally liked trackpads but when I first used one on the Macbook pro, I instantly fell in love. I also own the Magic Trackpad for my iMac which feels laser precise and you can just tell that it's very well engineered when you feel and use it. I'm also a huge fan of logitech products and I purchased this to compliment my bluetooth easy switch keyboard and see well it fares. So here are some of the pro's and cons:

PROS:

It's rechargeable and not even noticeable when you charge it because you don't slide the trackpad around like a mouse

- When you install the software it adds a nice bonus gesture where you can double tap and drag to move windows

- It's perfectly level with logitech's bluetooth easy switch keyboard (just like how the magic trackpad lines up with their wireless keyboard)

- The build of the device is really solid

CONS:

- The tracking is pretty good, but not flawless like the Magic Trackpad. It's still better than any Pc trackpad I've used but I was expecting this to be just as good as Apple's.

- The clicking doesn't really click in as much as the Magic Trackpad. If you tap to click then of course this will be a non issue but it doesn't feel as satisfying when you click on it. It almost feels like half a click.

For the same price I would just stick with the Magic Trackpad and buy a cheap pack of AA's here and just replace them every 2.5 - 3 months. If the tracking was just as smooth as the Magic Trackpad then this would be a no brainer.
I am disappointed because only the headphone (green) outlet worked, but not the one for the microphone.

I have this for the iPad 3 and I like it.  I love that it rotates so I can stand the iPad in landscape or portrait mode and prop it at different angles.  It's also very protective.  My only complaints are that it's pretty bulky and the inside of the cover leaves marks on the screen.  Not scratches, but smudgy lines that I have to vigorously buff off.  Maybe I will try one of those matte screen protectors.

The case that came with the Phillips DVD Player fit much better in the car.I might keep this one to stor the DVD Player.
It was hard to try and fit it in our car. Its a good case don't get me wrong but too much work to try and figure out.

I was actually disappointed with this system. Being a music student I'm very picky about sound. I have several complaints, but first lets start off with the good. The 150 watt subwoofer is exceptional and will completely blow your mind if not your windows. There was no disappointment there.

Okay, onto the bad. The two satellite speakers hissed which became very annoying. You could hear it a good 10 feet away even with music playing loudly. The highs were extremely piercing and hard on the ears even with the treble turned all the way down. My next major complaint is that it didn't treat all styles of music equally. I listen to a variety of music and believe me I tried em all. It distorted fairly easy on music styles with a lot of highs such classical music and movie soundtracks. If you're a piano fan....forget it, piano sounds terrible on this system. It sounds like a cheap electronic keyboard with the volume turned all the way up. Okay, maybe not that bad but you get the idea. My final complaint is the placement of the treble and bass controls on the subwoofer. It is very inconvenient to reach under your desk to get at them.

Anyhow, I returned the megaworks and went out and bought the Creative T5400 5.1 system for $100 at Comp USA(I might be wrong but I believe the cambridge megaworks was co-designed by creative). While it doesn't have the power of the megaworks there is no speaker hiss, All music styles sound good, it works equally well with games and movies, and its very comfortable to listen too even at higher volumes. The subwoofer isn't as impressive but it does just fine and compliments the speakers very well. The T5400 also has tweeters on the 3 front speakers, a very nice feature.

Frankly I would suggest you get a 5.1 system because there isn't a 2.1 system out there that really sounds good and you can get them for about the same price or a little more. I was concerned about space as you might be but its worth itand you'll find the space. The creative system I bought is easy to mount on the wall. Cambridge just discontinued their only good 5.1 PC system which is to bad. My brother has it and it is a very, very good system. Why do they do that? They have something good and they get rid of it. Anyhow good luck! Checkout the creative systems you won't be disappointed.

It takes approximately twice the time to charge an iPad that the original charger would.
Then they are temperamental. Sometimes, when plugged it, it won't register at all, but a day or two later, it will charge (still with the not charging message).

My biggest problem with this case is that my Nexus does not automatically go to sleep when I close the case. Sometimes the tablet goes to sleep anyway, but that's it's own setting. I have found this wastes battery life.

Also, I have found that sometimes the keyboard falls off the magnet. This isn't a major issue.

And, as others have said -- the strap is very annoying. Velcro or something easier would be ideal.

Otherwise this is a fine case. I think I will continue using it. It looks alright and the Nexus fits very well in it.

The ProCase has a nice appearance, but when you open it up, the inside feels like felt on cardboard. The lower edge of the table pocket has velcro so it will adhere to the felt interior of the tablet case, and this can be annoying at times.

The case adds thickness to the Surface Pro when coupled with any type of cover. This case, with the Type Cover 2 on the tablet, sits at 1.3 inches thick at least. That's thicker than the Manvex case WITH a Power Cover installed on the tablet.

The stylus holder is right on the outer edge of the cover, so it seems like the stylus is riding on the edge, and catches on things as you are carrying the case around.

The cover also hangs low on the tablet itself, almost covering the interior camera.

The case doesn't "breath well" either. As a windows/i5 device, the Surface Pro can warm up during use, it doesn't seem this case took cooling into account.

The stylus/pen that comes with it is a nice touch and writes well as a pen.

All in all, I compared this to the Manvex surface pro case, and the Manvex offers the exact same protection, slimmer form factor, better storage for the stylus, and looks like it's made of higher quality materials.
I was looking for a simple router with a good range, but this router really disappointed me. Speeds drop significantly unless you are right in front of the router.

Monitor does everything it advertises...EXCEPT....  Webcam does not work with Macbook.  Computer does not see/recognize webcam for Facetime/Skype.  No known fix/driver update for this after reading forums.  Also, integrated speakers dont work if you already have other external speakers plugged into computer.  Wish this would have been noted as the main reason I went with this one was it had integrated Webcam and speakers, and Im in Afghanistan so the cost of shipping it back for return isnt worth the hassle.

The keyboard is not very comfortable to type on. It has riser legs in the front and not the back where they traditionally are. I have had to prop the keyboard up to make it comfortable to type on. Wasn't the best keyboard i have owned.

I purchased this Maxtor IDE HDD and installed it in my tower. The first thing that I noticed is that it had a whole lot of registry errors during my scan. My software caught  thousands of problems that got cleaned up by my program after a few sessions of cleaning. I then had errors with clicking noises and freezing screens.(I'd have to constantly do a hard reset, which I hated to have to do) It seemed to happen 2 to 3 minutes after boot up time. If I was lucky I could get a quick cleaning process going before it froze up, if successful the chances of it freezing was less. With quite a bit of times doing this the freezing has stopped. Every now and then I hear a click or two coming from the HDD, but it is not freezing. Was this a bad refurb unit? I don't know. Right now it seems to work fine, but I always feel like at some point it will do it again, especially if I request a function that may take some time to complete. I try to only do things that don't require too much work for this hard drive. When the light is off, I feel fine, When it's on, I think it's going to freeze up and the light will stay on like it did before. Not putting anything important on here just in case it dies.
Ports don't always work with Windows 7.

While this product does what it says it does (protects the screen from fingerprints and scratches) it also takes away from the rich view and color aspect of the iPad. Though I will continue to use the product I wish they made a clear version that resisted fingerprints and scratches.

My last portable gave out after over 10 years of service. This unit, the smallest size WD makes in a portable drive, will easily hold the entire contents of my computer, making it an excellent back-up drive. The unit comes pre-loaded with backup software, one for desktop use, the other for backing up to the Cloud; it also comes with WD's drive utilities for maintenance work. Setup is ridiculously simple, just plug it into a USB 3.0 port and its ready to go. For the price, much less than an internal drive placed into an enclosure, you can't go wrong. Add in the 3 year warranty and my reasons for a 5-star rating are obvious.

An Unfortunate Update: Shortly after I started using the drive to backup around 30 GB worth of data (not images), my hard drive monitoring program flashed a warning that the drive was running hot, which indeed it was. The max temp the software recorded was 42° C, the maximum operating temp specified for the drive is 35° C, meaning my drive was operating at 7° C over the maximum allowed for the drive. I contacted tech support and they immediately offered to replace the drive. And while I'm doing it this way ONCE, even a 3 year warranty can't make up for a device that fails right out of the box! Whatever happened to Quality Control?

FINAL UPDATE: WD replaced my brand new, never used drive and its 3 YEAR warranty with a refurbished drive with a 4 MONTH warranty. Used for brand new? This is the last WD product I purchase.

Regards,
Former WD Customer

had issues with putting this on my ipad, no matter what I did dust stuck to this and made terrible bubbles. After applying over and over again and wasting the screen protectors I only got one to work and it still has bubbles that wont go away.

About 2 weeks into using the router it displayed a steady purple activity light. With a bit of research I found out that this is a problem with this router. They're defective. Belkin has a whole support system under troubleshooting dedicated to this one problem see: [...] Why they haven't just fixed the problem is anyone's guess but for another shipping cost of sending the defective router back you too can have a "like" product. I tried calling Belkin for support and a bit more of an immediate response but nope they're never open or their hours are just inconvenient. I'm never buying another Belkin product again, don't waste your time or money, get something else it's worth the extra cost for a different brand dual band router.

Update: the Router was finally replaced by belkin some time ago and I just haven't updated my review. It worked fine although it is quirky and needs to be restarted. I wouldn't buy this now as it's old technology. Generally buy a new A/C router if you're just looking for a startup infrastructure but if you're not in an area that has a lot of interference dual band 802.11n is probably fine.

So I think the novelty of the idea got me all amped up. It was a beautiful looking machine and the setup/install was nothing major. My only complaint was that the screen's brightness was what I would call just bright enough. It is a shame really, because it has great resolution but the matte screen film (which I enjoyed) took away from the screens already mediocre brightness for whatever reason.

That being said, my biggest gripe was just the setup, Every time I got the urge to draw or create, I had to connect the power cord to the proprietary 3 way cord, then connect the USB, HDMI and finally the proprietary connection to the Cintiq screen. Fire up my laptop then my Cintiq screen, all in all the process took 5-10 minutes.

I finally realized this product is meant to be tethered to a desktop and not really for someone who wants to say use it in the living room or on the go.

Ultimately, it proved too cumbersome for me and I returned it and will be looking into the Cintiq companion. This is a great machine, the construction, design and feel is excellent. But be mindful of the capacity in which your going to work on it. I'm not a professional but I'm good enough where a Cintiq screen is optimal for me. However, I primarily do my work on the couch or on my lunch break at work, that being said mobility is important and this unit is not designed to be mobile.

These speakers sound fine, but I was disappointed at the total output. Bass sounds great, but the satellite speakers are lacking in output. I also so no like the open speaker design. It may look cool, but the lack of a grill on the speakers leaves them more easily damaged.

In hindsight I should have spent the extra money for a higher wattage set of Logitech speakers. For listening to videos/lectures on my PC which may sometimes be mixed at a low volume these speakers only just barely pump out enough volume at max level. For normal use they would be loud enough, but in some situations you may face audio or movies which are mixed with low volume or a volume that drops off where these speakers don't quite pump out enough volume. If I could I would trade some of the bass output for louder satellite speakers. For the price they are a great deal, but for my exact use they are a disappointment.

These headphones are very comfortable and sound good. Very disappointed in the noise cancelling feature therefore I am returning them.  If you want a good, cheap pair of ear phones for good quality sound, these are good, however if you want noise cancelling, keep looking.

You get a letter asking you to review on amazon so here we go.

These key caps are decent. They do their intended use but the quality control on the actual caps doesnt seem to be that great. You can see markings on the outside of a good amount of the keys as you pull them out of the packaging. Also, if your LED's are bright enough you can see the markings inside of the keycap. When I say markings I mean the numbers that are inside the actual keycap.

The packaging overall is pretty good. I like how they didn't just throw them in the bag. Also, the keycap puller is pretty good as well. Overall, I don't think I would purchase again simple because I dont like seeing the markings on the inside of the key, also its a detracting factor that you can feel the number or letter on the outside of the key much more than a normal key cap. If you are use to smooth keys, these are not for you.

Shipping was great, came much faster than Amazon's expected delivery date. It's just disappoint that you see marks on each key.

Audio, it does horrible things to.  It removes all of the lower frequencies and just leaves the upper frequencies.  I can even notice this on the free speakers that came with my pc. I guess I don't understand why they included audio if they didn't care if you could use it or not.  So just be prepared if you buy this you will have to manually switch the audio if you want sound.  I am debating returning the unit and buying something else.

This is a really nice HD for a home network (mine: Macs, PS3, iPhones). After connecting it to my router, I was able to use it immediately - no set-ups or hassles. Both my Mac and PS3 detected it automatically and I was listening to music and viewing photos through the PS3 right after transferring them to the WD NAS.

Setting up the MioNet account took a little longer (first go to [...] to configure everything and see what you can do with the NAS; then go to MioNet and get redirected to set up and account; when you're waiting for your confirmation email, make sure you check your spam folder; don't change the http to https protocol, otherwise MioNet won't be able to connect and you'll get Registration failed errors; if you do, sign out and sign back in so the applet can search for a drive; don't rename or delete the pre-configured drives!) - once set up, I was able to access it on my iPhone with the free WD Photos app - works great!

The initial transferring of files takes a while (about 20GB in about 3-4 hours wirelessly) so it's better to do it through the USB for any amount of data, if possible (did 200GB overnight). If you don't want RAID mirroring, you need to disable it before you start transferring any files over since any changes you make later will erase your data and RAID 1 (Mirrored) is turned on by default.

Overall, it's a great drive, very powerful (lots of advanced capabilities, like setting up users, groups, shares, access, downloader for automatic file downloads, automatic backups and supposed to work with Time Machine - haven't tried all these yet) and providing an easy and central access point for all files on the network. I'm very happy with the purchase!

*****
UPDATE: After using this NAS for about 1 week, some things have crept up. First, the transfer rate is appallingly slow. I understand that it's over the network and it's getting mirrored, but even over a USB connection, it's REALLY slow. Second, MioNet was \\"optimizing\\" my pictures for about 2 days straight - the HD was going the whole time. I found that there was an issue with the software before and tried to stop it per the different posts and it finally seemed to work. In the end, I'm not sure if it's been fixed or not. Third, I can't easily access the NAS configuration pages. It seems that whenever I want to do it, I have to reboot it. I have set up FTP and it also works after a fresh reboot. When I'm finally able to connect, it's again VERY slow - it takes a couple of minutes to just load the login page and any thereafter. I am keeping this NAS only because it works well with my PS3 (although it takes forever to get pictures downloaded to view). But the performance leaves much to be desired.ctures for about 2 days straight - the HD was going the whole time. I found that there was an issue with the software before and tried to stop it per the different posts and it finally seemed to work. In the end, I'm not sure if it's been fixed or not. The keyboard isn't too bad. Never had any trouble with it. The mouse is another story. It frequently needed to be reset with the receiving base. I used this combo to control my home theater PC, so I placed the receiving base by the computer about 5 feet away from where I sit. Everytime I needed to reset it, that involved playing with cabling to pull the receiving base out to a position where I can hit the "reset" button. Anyone who has an intricate wiring setup for their PC/Stereo/TV can appreciate that this is a hassle. Eventually, I grew bored of playing this game and stretched the receiving base out to the coffee table. Sure, there was an ugly cord stretched out in the middle of the room, but I was sick of having to dig it out.
Another problem with the mouse is that it seems to go to "sleep" after 20 minutes of inactivity. Which means moving it does nothing. You have to click a button to wake it up. I've had a screensaver running and having to click a button to wake up the mouse has ended up sending that mouse click to an application running under the screensaver. I try to use the keyboard to turn off the screensaver before waking the mouse.
If that wasn't annoying enough, the mouse NEVER EVER worked! It was flaky. I'd right click on the desktop, not move the mouse at all, and by the time the menu popped up, I was unable to move the mouse pointer. Distance from the RF base had nothing to do with this, as I was able to duplicate this 1" away from the base. In the middle of a mouse operation, the mouse would stop working. This happens every time I use it. Imagine the frustration of trying to control a DVD app, hitting the seek button, then having the mouse stop working when you need to hit play again. I have never owned such a difficult to use mouse, wireless or otherwise. I eventually lost my temper with it one day and through it down the stairs. Remarkably, this seemed to fix it, although temporarily.
I have since paid upfor the Gyration wireless combo and am happy I did. The keyboard may find another use in my house, but I cannot get the mouse out of my sight quick enough. Basically, if having a mouse is important to you, walk away from this combo.
It has a small problem I have to reset it but its pretty okay.

I've had this harddrive for a few months now. I don't use it to back up my computer. Instead, I put all my music and movies on it to free up space on my laptop (Macbook Pro Retina), and given that it's, you know, a laptop, I figured this harddrive would be the best choice due to it being portable. However, ever since I got it, I've had an issue with the USB cable. At the slightest movement, whether it's the harddrive being shifted or something bumping against any part of the cable, it automatically disconnects. Even if I was using a desktop computer I would be concerned about it disconnecting because I'm constantly shifting things on my desk and plugging and unplugging things from my computer - tablets and mice and keyboards and USBs and chargers, etc. etc. I'm worried that if this continues to happen the drive itself will corrupt and I'll lose all my data.

I'm considering buying a Thunderbolt adapter for it since that might be a more reliable port but at this point the adapter is more expensive than a new harddrive so I might as well get a new one. I haven't seen a whole lot of people complaining about this same issue but just be aware of the risk if you are considering this device. I will see about getting a replacement USB cable and testing this issue further, but it shouldn't be a problem in the first place and seems like poor design.

The two stars are for the BLADE cover only! I bought both the BLADE and SMARTSHELL versions of the Fintie case. While both offer hardshell protection around the corners, there are some differences:
* Corners: Blade offers slightly thicker coverage and seems to come a little more up and over the corners. Nice but not enough to outweigh other differences.
* Looks (color & texture): I ordered both cases in Magenta but they looked quite different. The Blade's texture was more subtle and the color was pinker. The Smartshell cover was a little thicker, more deeply textured, and the color had some orange undertones. Both cases were nice colors but were a little lighter in color than what I expected for "Magenta."
* Top cover: At the edges, the Blade top cover is compressed and very thin and stiff. As a result, when it was folded around back for reading, the cover felt as if it were cutting into the softest part of my hand. This is the primary reason I returned the Blade cover.
* Back: on the SmartShell, the textured cover goes all the way to the edges (or almost; there is a thin line of black plastic around the edges). It looks nice. On the Blade, in contrast, the textured cover stops short, leaving a wide black plastic margin around three sides of the Kindle (the fourth side folds over to cover the top of the Kindle). On the back, it looks like a thick black reverse C surrounding some textured cover. It looked ugly and cheap to me, certainly not what I expected of the Blade given that it is advertised as Fintie's "premium" case.
The magnetic latch works nicely on both covers and I don't mind the "bump" for the SmartShell case. In the end I kept the SmartShell because it felt much better in the hand, even though I liked the slightly better corner protection on the Blade.

I purchased this mouse to replace a Microsoft wireless mouse because I bought I new Logitech keyboard and didn't want to deal with two separate usb receivers.  In that respect, I really like the Logitech \\"Unifying receiver\\" concept because it allows you to mix-and-match a variety of keyboard and mouse combos to suit your preferences.  This mouse does indeed work on my couch and couch-like surfaces, which my previous Microsoft mouse could not.  It's a neat trick, but not really one that is a big sell on me.  The performance on couch surfaces is slightly off, so if you're doing precise work, you'll want to stick with a desk.  There are quite a few negatives to this mouse as well.  Size wise, it runs small.  And I have small hands, so I imagine it may not be comfortable for someone with normal sized hands.  Auto-off is a failed experiment.  The mouse is designed to turn off whenever it isn't making contact with your hands.  As a result, there's an ever-so-slight delay when you go from typing with both hands to using your mouse.  Also, I find that my grip on the mouse causes it to lose connectivity and turn off intermittently, which causes a frustrating staggering effect with your mouse pointer.  As a result, I make a very concerted effort to keep the palm of my hand in contact with the mouse at all times.  Connectivity is iffy, but I'm can't really say if it's 1) an issue with this mouse, 2) an issue with signal interference in my house/environment, or 3) an issue related to the auto-off feature described above.  The end result is that the mouse is usable, but somewhat inaccurate.  Due to connectivity issues, I occasionally click the wrong link or the wrong part of my screen.  Lastly, I do not like the scroll wheel.  My preference is for the clicking scroll wheels because I find them to be accurate.  What is nice is that this mouse has an option between smooth scrolling and click scrolling, which you can toggle by clicking in on the mouse wheel.  This is a rather poordesign choice because clicking in on the mouse wheel also functions as a button.  What happens if I want to use that button, but don't want to toggle my mouse wheel setting from click to smooth or vice versa?  Furthermore, I don't like the scroll wheel effect in either setting.  The smooth scrolling is intolerable in some applications.  It is so sensitive that an application will detect scrolling even when you're not scrolling and you're just moving your mouse around.  It also suffers from bounce-back scrolling, which is when you scroll in one direction but when you stop, it detects a bit of scrolling in the opposite direction.  For example, say you're using the mouse wheel to zoom in on a map on Google Maps.  When you're done zooming in, it often zooms out a little bit at the end, which is incredibly frustrating.  The click scroll setting is also flawed, because it's still so sensitive that it detects a bit of scrolling in between clicks on the wheel.  All-in-all, I would not recommend this mouse.  However, as a cheaply priced mouse (at least it was when I bought it, $17), it is serviceable.  Which is why I gave it 2/5.

The Lenovo S-10 is a great little PC if you can get around its quirks.  Keyboard is bigger than most netbooks and has a really nice feel.  I haven't used the quickstart yet much but it seems like a useful feature.  It comes with Windows 7 starter (not the full blown Windows 8) but that seems to do everything I need -- I don't really care if I can't personalize the background on my netbook!  Some people complain about the built-in mouse pad.  I don't really have any problem with it.  If I'm going to do a lot of \\"mousing\\", I use a little USB-connected portable mouse.  The two \\"quirks\\" that I had trouble dealing with are the power button and upgrading the memory.  The power button is located on the outside lower left of the screen -- exactly the place where it seems I naturally have a tendency to want to grasp it with my left hand at times.  I was continually shutting the machine down until I reconfigured the system so that the power button \\"does nothing\\".  The power button still turns the machine on and will turn it off if you hold it (for an emergency shutoff) but this prevents the accidental shutdowns.  The second quirk is trying to upgrade the memory.  You can go to 2GB (from the original 1GB) and the memory is super easy to remove and replace.  But what kind of memory works seems to be one of the best kept secrets of the universe!  The users manual says it takes DDR2 memory -- WRONG!  Obviously an outdated users manual.  It takes DDR3.  After two unsuccessful attempts, I called Lenovo Tech Support.  Although they originally said you couldn't upgrade the memory, when pressed, they finally came back with a list of two (only two) models of memory that were guaranteed to work.  One was a Hynix and the other a Micron model.  I finally located the Micron model and it did work (although it appears to be the same specs as the Samsung one I tried that did not work).  Now that I finally have the S-10 configured the way I want it, I do like it.  But it took a while!

The jury is still out on this one.  It is the original Kindle versus the latest model.  I enjoy the convenience of having it; it is as lightweight as advertised, easy to purchase books and very easy to read especially if you have poor eyesight.  The problem I seem to be running into is that I have not gotten the number of hours of battery time that it advertises and, at this writing, if I run out of battery time within the next day or two I will more than likely talk to Kindle support or return it.  I will not be happy if I have to return it as it really is everything I wanted; no more, no less.  Time will tell.

The [[ASIN:B0031RG2AG Lexar Echo SE 16 GB USB 2.0 Backup Drive]] is a disappointment. I purchase a lot of USB drives, from cheap to expensive, for a variety of needs. Even out of all the low cost budget drives I have bought, this one has one of the weakest constructions.

One reason to purchase a thumb drive is portability. The plastic surface has a tacky texture that doesn't seem fragile. I learned how easily broken this drive could be when the lanyard bar broke from simply having a lanyard attached to it to carry it. So this device would be easily lost if you were to have it break on you or if you were carrying it loose in your pocket.

PROS:
++ Data transfer speeds are better than most similar drives
++16 GB capacity allows for good sized backups
++ Fat32 formatted for compatibility
++ Compatible with Mac and PC operating systems (Windows 7, XP, Vista, OS X)
++ Very light case
++ USB 2.0 connection is backwards compatible for older computers
++ Retractable designs means no worries about lost caps
++ Easy to format and enable encryption to protect your data

CONS:
-- Body design is weak and larger than necessary; rear bar is easily broken
-- Slower mounts and stops than other USB drives I have
-- Premium cost
-- Other software alternatives can do the same and be installed on any drive

THE SOFTWARE

The included software is OK and is much less disappointing than most included software. For those wondering why it doesn't \\"do anything\\" when they insert it, you have to launch the software manually and can then have it install on your computer for automatic backups. That's actually a good thing. Companies have gotten a lot of flack over software that installs itself without giving users the choice.

The install files include \\"EchoBackup_Win.exe\\" for Windows computers and \\"EchoBackup_Mac\\" for Macs. I only tested the Windows version, but it has a sufficient number of options, including encrypting backups and setting up folders that will automatically get backed up whenever the drive is inserted. My only comment about it is that there are tons of free software programs that will do the same thing and can easily be copied to a thumb-drive. So I wouldn't choose this drive based on the added software.

There are a few ways in order to enable encryption. The best way may be to use another tool to encrypt the drive after re-formatting it. This way you can test the drive as well as use the encryption you prefer.

THE PERFORMANCE

Copying files to this drive was on the higher end of the speed range offered by USB 2.0 thumb drives.
Average Read Speed: 21.2 MB/s
Average Write Speed: 9.5 MB/s

Speeds with the included software were comparable, which is better than most software offers.

CONCLUSION

The 16 GB capacity makes this drive useful for file backups and USB storage. The retractable head means you don't have to worry about losing a cap, but you might have to worry about getting dust or debris into the tip.

Everything about this drive would have been acceptable if not for the poor build quality. Considering the premium, I would lean on choosing an alternative. This is a drive I wanted to love but it doesn't perform up to par. There are many higher end drives by Kingston, Sandisk, Patriot, Corsair and others that can be used for backups but have much better builds. I would research some of those.

So I wouldn't choose this drive based on the added software. There are a few ways in order to enable encryption. The best way may be to use another tool to encrypt the drive after re-formatting it. This way you can test the drive as well as use the encryption you prefer. THE PERFORMANCE Copying files to this drive was on the higher end of the speed range offered by USB 2.0 thumb drives. Average Read Speed: 21.2 MB/s Average Write Speed: 9.5 MB/s Speeds with the included software were comparable, which is better than most software offers. CONCLUSION The 16 GB capacity makes this drive useful for file backups and USB storage. The retractable head means you don't have to worry about losing a cap, but you might have to worry about getting dust or debris into the tip. Everything about this drive would have been acceptable if not for the poor build quality. Considering the premium, I would lean on choosing an alternative. This is a drive I wanted to love but it doesn't perform up to par. There are many higher end drives by Kingston, Sandisk, Patriot, Corsair and others that can be used for backups but have much better builds. I would research some of those. Happy shopping.

I bought this to control & measure temperatures in five separate compartments (cooled by PC fans) of an A/V center. Since the compartments contained DVRs and are closed during the day, I wanted to make sure temperatures stayed reasonable. I ran the five temperature leads to the five separate compartments, plumbed through the MDF walls of the enclosure along with the fan power/control wires.

I like how the five independent fan controls display motion if the fan is running, and the ability to manually control five fans independently is pretty helpful as well. Overall the NZXT Sentry LX looks pretty in operation, but I've found the temperature readings are wildly inaccurate and tend to stay close to one another regardless of the surroundings. To test this I tried putting a heat rock in one compartment and an ice pack in another. Both temperature readings stayed between 72-76 degrees F. I put my oven thermometer in the heat rock compartment and saw 85 degrees. My house thermometer read 65 in the ice compress compartment. The sentry temperature readings never left the mid 70s.

In manual mode I've found the unit does not always like to accept my inputs. Fans will turn on at max speed in manual mode, when I adjust down from 2200 rpm to 800, the screen changes to reflect the numbers change but the fans do not slow down. The screen itself looks nice but viewing angles are very shallow. Your eyes must be level & head-on with the screen for the digits to be viewable. If you plan on having this on a floor PC or somewhere other than directly in front of you, you won't be able to make out the numbers while it is in operation.

The last thing that irritates me is the wild price fluctuations I see for this in just the last two months (as of December 2014). Another Amazon user claims to have purchased it for $28 about eight months ago. I paid $45. Today I see it listed at $60. Different vendors are charging wildly different prices for the exact same item. If you want it, do some research on pricing. You should not pay more than $50 based on average pricing history for the NZXT Sentry LX.

if I was going to do this again, I would instead purchase the Phobya fan splitter (they make 3-pin and 4-pin versions, fed by your 4-wire molex plug). They are less than $20 and don't have a screen but distribute power evenly to the fans. I used this on another project and compared to the Sentry LX, I prefer the Phobya. The screen on the NZXT is pretty but it offers no real functionality beyond the Phobya.tem. If you want it, do some research on pricing. You should not pay more than $50 based on average pricing history for the NZXT Sentry LX.

I purchased this monitor upgrading from an old CRT (18 inch Trinitron from Dell). Because I was going from CRT to LCD and from 4:3 to 16:9, there were a lot of new variables to consider in order to ensure I got a monitor that satisfied me. I studied the specs on a number of monitors in the $200 range, considering models from $180 up  to about $250 and more. I got this model because it looked like a steal. The specs were all there: 2 ms response time, 23 inches of screen real estate, full HD, high contrast ration, you name it. It also got decent reviews online.     The trouble is that whenever you buy an item like this entirely online, you are buying based on numbers, word of mouth, and other ultimately unreliable sources of information. You should know upfront that manufacturers use different ways of computing these metrics. For example, you can't compare contrast rations between manufacturers reliably. Such a comparison MIGHT be an indication of a real difference in quality, or it might be meaningless. It's impossible to know. In fact, you can't even compare contrast ratios between models made by the SAME manufacturer from different years! Even if it's the same MODEL! This leaves us consumers in a real pinch. Especially when buying ONLINE.    When I got my monitor, I was initially very impressed with the size of the screen. The 16:9 format is really so much better. It's great for movies and it's even better for the extra desktop space. Teamed with Windows 7's nifty windows that snap to the sides of the screen, comparing two browsers or documents is really nice. The vertical height of this screen is about the same as a 19 inch 4:3 monitor. I have to say, I somehow thought this would be bigger, but it seems bigger than it is due to the extra horizontal space. Running in full 1080p is nice, too. The resolution is crisp and beautiful. Colors are fairly good and overall picture quality is good, though not stellar. After testing the monitor on monitor testing sites, I'mnot entirely sure how much of a difference the advertised 2ms response time makes. This is another instance where that number may or may not mean much, and testing the monitor is difficult without something to compare it to.     But all this is knit-picking. I would be more than happy with this purchase except for one characteristic that just leaves me anxious over whether or not I should return it and try a different model out: VIEWING ANGLE. This model has a very poor viewing angle. Granted, I am coming from a CRT where viewing angle was not really an issue. But looking at the monitor from even just a slightly up or down angle makes a huge difference in contrast, and the horizontal angle seems equally poor. It's not atrociously poor, but poor enough to make me wonder whether or not I can live with it. It is definitely NOT acceptable considering the ADVERTISED viewing angle is 160 degrees v/h (who knows how they came up with that number, but I consider it false advertising). I should also mention that I am writing this review from work on a Samsung SyncMaster 943ewx, and this monitor has a great viewing angle, almost as good as a CRT, so I do have some kind of point of reference. The viewing angle is also worse than any of the three laptops in my home, one of which is around 8 years old! To compound this drawback, the monitor stand does not allow for up and down movement. To adjust it to eye level you will need to put it on a phone book or something. Very unfortunate that one major kink should stand in my way of feeling like I made a smart buy.    I highly recommend you go into a store and look at monitors up close before buying. If you cannot do this, then buy two or more models, try them out side by side, keep the one you like the most and return the others. You will be out the return shipping, sure, but it beats having to buy one monitor individually and wonder whether or not it's a good buy and possibly having to pay for return shipping anyway if you're unhappy. At least this way you know you have the monitor you want. Also, this is the only real way to compare monitors, because the controlled conditions of a store don't really allow you to test and compare monitors, nor spend any real time with them doing your daily tasks.    Overall, this is a good value model, especially for this screen size, but it does sacrifice in at least one critical area.
