Pros:

Shape- For small to medium sized hands that like to use the claw grip, the MiCO is an absolute joy to hold. I have been through quite a few gaming mice (Deathadder, G400, CM Storm Spawn), and the simple shape of the MiCO allows me to game for hours without any soreness in my hand. While my hands were big enough to use the three previously mentioned mice, my fingers never rested comfortably in their curves as intended. The MiCO on the other hand allows me to claw it any way I want to.

Size- If you have big hands or like to palm your mice, the MiCO is probably not for you. If you like to use a claw or fingertip grip, this mouse should be the perfect size.

Teflon feet and weight- The light weight combined with the teflon feet makes the MiCO glide really smooth and fast across my cloth mouse pad (Steelseries Qck+). The weight of the mouse also makes it really easy to lift off.

Overall Build Quality- This mouse feels very solid despite its somewhat cheap look.

Cons:

Scroll Wheel Issues- The first batch of MiCO's that were released suffered from squeaky scroll wheels that would eventually break. While the problem has been fixed, you may be unlucky like me and get one of those first models. For me, the scroll wheel would make a really loud screech every time I scrolled up. However, after I RMA'd my faulty MiCO, the mouse wheel still makes quite an audible squeak every now and then, but its alot more bearable than before.

Scroll Wheel Quality- The scroll wheel just doesn't feel good to use at all. The steps are not well defined compared to other gaming mice and clicking the wheel makes it feel really flimsy. If using the wheel is necessary to your game, you will want to look elsewhere.

Quality Control Issues- I am actually on my third MiCO. As mentioned before, the first MiCO had the faulty scroll wheel. I RMA'd it, shipped it to Zowie (had to pay for shipping), and received my second MiCO. However, after about 2-3 months, the cursor would just freeze every couple of minutes and the light on the scroll wheel would flicker. After complaining to Zowie, they decided to ship me a new one free of charge. This may not happen to everyone, but seeing as it happened to me, I thought it should be mentioned. (FYI: RMA process for me took about 1-2 weeks total)

Sensor- I have read from other reviews that the MiCO has some problems tracking at 1600 dpi. The 400 and 800 dpi settings are fine. I tend to use the 800 dpi setting and have had no problems thus far. So, if you are looking at this mouse for the 1600 dpi setting, you may want to reconsider. (Disclaimer: I have not actually performed the technical tests on this mouse, so if you want more information in this area look to other reviews)

Neutral/Personal Opinions:

Cord- The thickness of the cord is average. Its not super stiff, thick, and braided, but its not as thin and flexible as I would like it to be. However, because the MiCO is really small and light, the average cord width and flexibility makes any drag or contact of the cord really noticeable. This can be solved by making enough space on your desk for the cord.

Huano Switches- Most other mice use Omron switches which are a lot softer and easier to press than the Huano switches found in Zowie mice. Some people love them because they provide a pretty satisfying noise along with a nice tactile feel. They also ensure that you will almost never unintentionally click either of the buttons (a problem I had with the Spawn). Other people hate them because they require more force to press. While it may not be that noticeable with one or two presses, it may be unbearable in games like SC2 or Diablo 3 that require a lot of clicking and could possibly lower your APM or cause discomfort.

Conclusion:

I personally like this mouse, and in my opinion the pros barely outweigh the cons. I would rate this mouse a 3/5 (taking off 1 star for the faulty mice and 1 star for the iffy scroll wheel). However, despite how comfortable it is, I would not recommend this mouse to others. The MiCO ended up costing me more time and money than I thought it would, and it is simply not worth all that trouble.

I ordered this memory module for my Macbook. At first it would not recognize the memory at all.  I removed it and installed again, just to make sure it was installed correctly - still no luck.  So I took it out, reinstalled the old memory and shot off a note to Centon support, who basically said, \\"try again.\\"  So I did try again and this time the Mac did recognize the modules. All was well - for a while. But the Mac became quite unreliable - I'd get big fuzzy lines across the screen every once in a while and would have to reboot.  Eventually this started happening all the time so I was pretty sure it was the new memory modules.  I took them out again and replaced with the original memory and all was well (albeit slower).  I sent another note to Centon telling them what happened and they agreed to replace it, which they did.  I just installed the new modules and the Mac recognized them right away and all seems well.  It did cost me a lot of time as well as the postage fee to return the first set of modules. All in all, I'd be wary of this product.

A couple weeks later, I decide I want to get my game on and install boot camp with our enterprise version of windows 7. - Has a logo that says "Premium" on it on the spine (near the bottom; it's not very visible in the product image on Amazon). A clear sign that this is a bootleg knock-off.

- The push-tab that locks the disc into place has extremely rough edges. I suggest carefully inserting and removing discs if you don't want to damage your discs. This is highly unlike actual PS3 game cases where the push tabs have refined and smoothed edges to prevent damage.

- The tabs for holding booklets are not designed for thick PS3 game manuals. They are designed for thin BD/DVD insert slips and push down firmly without leaving much space. Do not use these cases for games with thick booklets as they will be damaged.

- Blu-ray logo in wrong spot (centered like on regular BD cases, unlike PS3 game disc cases). I should have looked more closely at the pictures and my actual PS3 game cases.

- This product's title and description are thus misleading. Would not buy again unless I wanted knock-off replacement cases for regular BD cases.

I was very excited to see this item. A coiled USB charging cable for the car that is separate from the charger itself is perfect. I got a dual-USB car adapter and two of these cables--one for my AT&T Samsung Galaxy S2 and one for my wife's AT&T Samsung Infuse 4G.

My phone (the S2) has an Otterbox case (Commuter series, SKU: 77-18649), where the cut-out for the USB is reasonably small around the USB port itself. The problem I encountered is that the Micro-B plug on this coiled cable is so thick that it doesn't click into my phone's USB port. Yes, it makes contact but it can easily come off by the slightest movement. I don't understand why they had to make it so thick. Is it to make it more durable or something? The plug on my previous Samsung car charger is thinner and it clicks and hangs on just fine for many, many hours.

One day I was on a 3-hour drive, with GPS turned on, using this Mediabridge cable and it got disconnected due to vibration/movement of the car. Of course, how can I reconnect it without stopping at a rest area? Very annoying.

On the other hand, my wife's phone's case's (Case Mate's) cut-out is a bit bigger so I don't think she has an issue with this cable.

When you get this item, just make sure to test it out with your phone, if it has a case, and make sure it easily clicks and stays connected reliably.

I received my Aspire 5520-5908 on 1/29/08 and overall I am fairly happy with the product so-far.    A few things to note with it right-away. It lacks RAM which should be upgraded because doing so makes this laptop run almost twice as fast. I upgraded the RAM to a total of 4GB, which cost me an additional $90.00. I decided on a RAM upgrade after only 20 minutes of having the laptop in my hands. I also un-installed the default installation of Vista Home Premium by repartitioning and formatting the hard drive. After re-installing Windows 64-bit Vista Business Edition, I then used the drivers available from Acer.Com's support section to get things \\"up and running.\\"    Adding the RAM and installing a fresh operating system allowed this computer to run at its full-potential while also freeing up enormous amounts of disk space. I can't suggest-enough to anyone buying this laptop to add RAM to it. This laptop will only run to about 1/3 of its potential speed capabilities, simply because the system itself is a memory-hog by design. The integrated video card, as an example uses a portion of the system RAM. This means that by default, the 1GB of system RAM gives 768MB of RAM to the system, and the other 256MB of RAM is given to the video card. One \\"good\\" thing about this arrangement is that after installing additional RAM, you can actually give this video card another 128MB of RAM if you so wish. 384MB for a video card is actually pretty-good, and is so-needed in Vista because of the Aero interface. the video card, for those wondering is NVIDIA's 7000M, which is reputed to be a fairly-weak video card, even for laptops. I don't see that as much of a problem as some would. For those playing cutting-edge video games and or D/V editing software, that may be an issue. For the average user though, this card is actually a lot more than sufficient.    Here are the problems that exist...  Despite my best-efforts to find a suitable driver that would work, I still could not get the TouchPad working nicely on this Laptop. The TouchPad seems to be a sore-spot with all owners of Laptops in this series from Acer. I should mention that this problem existed when the Laptop was running under its default installation, and didn't become any worse under the new installation. Unfortunately, it certainly didn't get any better. In fact, I'm not sure a driver is the issue here, as many people on various technical forums discussing this issue have said that this is a hardware issue and that software (like a driver) isn't going to have any impact on it.    The specific problem with the TouchPad seems revolve around its sensitivity and its periodic insensitivity. At times the TouchPad will hang, and this was one of my main motivators in acquiring additional RAM. After a hang, it seems to become \\"confused,\\" and any additional attempts to move the pointer on-screen are met with what appears to be a fristrated Touchpad. Sometimes the pointer will not move at all, other times it will actually move a portion of the way, and then move backwards and away from your intended target.    Probably the most-annoying aspect of all this is when the Touchpad buttons seem to be possessed by a three year-old pianist with too-much energy. If one has any screens of importance open when this happens, this becomes an impending-disaster. Because the pointer will begin to move on its own in-tandem with the buttons which seem to be furiously \\"clicking-away\\" will do things like close the application you're working with, fill in each and every checkbox in-sight, and cause general mayhem to your work. For a demonstration without having to buy this model, hand your current laptop to any child under age four, and ask them to type you a document as quickly as possible. The results would be similar I'm sure.    THE included RAM, as I stated is woefully inadequate. Until this was upgraded, I don't think I've run-across a laptop that ran so painfully-slow.    The pre-installed software is more nuisance than benefit to anyone with serious work to accomplish. It should be noted that this is a very multimedia-focused laptop, and the included software is geared in that direction. For those who wish to *watch* (not edit) video, listen to music, or surf the web, I'm sure this laptop in its default-state would be great for that. The included version of MS Office is a 60-day trial, and unless that's something you plan on paying for (or already have a license for) should be un-installed. The running services that MS Office employs will be needlessly taking up processing power once this trial times out.    Despite those issues, I fully-recommend this laptop. At the price it's currently being sold at, this laptop is more than worth the money. With the few upgrades it needs to run at its full potential, and with a bit of work playing with the software, it becomes a reliable and powerful machine.

Pros:
Incredibly comfortable
Good sound quality in the headphones

Cons:
Instruction manual in Chinese only, but it only seemed to cover manually installing the drivers from the CD anyway
Microphone quality was abysmal; sound was too garbled to understand anything
The bulky USB jack makes it difficult-to-impossible to plug in another USB device if the ports are close together

Other notes:
They were heavier and clunkier than they looked in the picture, but they were still one of the most comfortable pairs of headphones I have ever tried on, which is a real shame considering the poor quality of the mic. The USB jack is really only a problem if you're on a laptop or otherwise have a very limited number of USB ports. The volume control on the wire also adjusts the system sound, instead of adjusting the headphones' sound independently of the system sound like I have seen on some other sets.

The backpack was OK, but not as nice as expected given the price. It arrived with the original price tag still on it, which had a retail of 30 dollars less than what we had paid. This was from an Amazon vendor--not an Amazon product. The return was easy enough, so it all worked out in the end.

In retrospect, I should have paid more attention to the price. Once I realized what had happened, I see that there is a wide range of pricing for this model. If you're wanting a basic school backpack, this one is good, just be careful that you don't pay too much.

Save your money and buy a can of air.

When i got this computer a year and a half ago, i was excited.  The touch screen was great and all and it had an i7 processor yes.  However after about 6 months things started to fall apart.  The back of my screen got a single dent in it from my dog dropping something on it.  It was a very very small indent.  And it worked fine afterwards for a while until the touch screen,  weeks later, started touching my mouse by itself into one spot.  Where the indent was.  I tried to see if there was a way to turn it off but there is no way to.  You are stuck with the touch screen on throughout the whole use of the computer.  Theres no way to turn it off.  After spending near $200 fixing it it broke again! This time it was the AC adaptor and i had to pay another $300!  And now that its about a year and a half old and despite the fact its been fixed numerous times its still lagging down in any videogame i play.  I looked at the graphics settings to find that there was NO graphics card.  Only the i7 processor.  All graphics go through the processor along with the processes of windows making the computer after a while have a habbit of overheating and crashing.  Its been a year and a half.  And im already saving for a better computer.  $800 wasted.

I got this item for my mom's birthday.  She had a Nook, but it's slow and won't be supported much longer since it's being discontinued.  She complained that her cataracts make it hard for her to see on the Nook's smaller screen, so I figured this size would allow her to make the fonts big enough that she could read comfortably, and she might like that better.  The problem is that the interface was confusing and clunky, and it was just as slow as the Nook.  I will say that, for the size, it's fairly light weight, but it does feel a bit heavier than I hoped, especially when you put it against my nephew's Kindle Fire Deluxe (the big one).  Because the glare also gives her headaches, I opted not to replace this with the Fire Deluxe, but instead returned it and exchanged for a Kindle Paperwhite.  That suits her much better despite its smaller size.

This is a review for the USB 3.0 SDXC Card Reader 65Mb/s by Unitek.  This card reader seems to work well.  I haven't had any issues with it randomly disconnecting during transfers.  It is a bit bulky though and I'm always afraid that I'm going to break is off while it's plugged in.  It is also very wide and blocks access to adjacent USB ports.  But I don't blame that on the device.  It has to be wide to accept SD cards.  The biggest problem I have is that my computer won't recognize that a card is inserted about 40% of the time when connected to my USB 3.0 ports.  It works 100% of the time when I connect it to USB 2 ports and transfers are still very fast when using high data rate cards.

I'm very disappointed in this cover for my new Kindle Paperwhite for a few reasons:

1) It's quite bulky and heavy: It comes close to doubling the thickness and weight of the Kindle. Without the cover, I can slip the kindle into my front pocket pretty easily. It's a real struggle to do so with the cover on

2) There's not really a comfortable position to hold the kindle in when the cover is attached. The bit that covers the screen is either flopping around, or it's wrapped around the back and getting in the way of holding it comfortably in one hand.

3) It feels really cheap. It's supposedly made out of leather, but the texture and pattern on the outside doesn't resemble any leather I've seen before. It's much more the texture of a plastic dashboard in a low-end econobox car.

4) Given all 3 of the above, it's really overpriced. I purchased a far-superior case for my iPad a few months back (real leather, etc.) for $20. Because of that, I think $15 or so would be a much more fair price for this cover.

On the upside, it does seem like this cover would do a good job of protecting the Kindle from drops and scuffs. I don't need that level of protection (mine rarely leaves my bedside, except when I'm traveling), but that might be important for some folks who take it out and about more than I do.

Still, all in all, I've decided to return mine in the next few days, and look for a cover that's less bulky and cheap-feeling. (Any suggestions?)

UPDATE:
Just figured I should add that after returning the defective unit, a few months later HP actually sent me a working unit for free and apologized. I still prefer the iogear that I purchased, but it restored a little faith in HP.

After seeing the great reviews for the previous version, I was excited to see that a new 3d compatible and better looking version was coming out. So I had Amazon over night it the second it came in stock. Got it the next day, hooked it up to my media center and projector....and nothing. Receiver seemed to work fine and would display \\"linking\\" on the screen, but the transmitter just sat there doing nothing. I tried it on my Xbox 360, computer, av receiver. The transmitter did nothing plugged into any of them. In frustration I tried jamming the power plug into the transmitter, and low and behold there was blinking for a few seconds. That was it though, and it never connected in those short brief glorious seconds.

So I figured I must have just gotten a dud, and ordered a replacement through Amazon's magnificent returns system. New one arrived the following day. Just plugged it in...and nothing. Tried all my devices once again, and same result. Now at this point I should probably tell you that I have studied Electrical Engineering, have numerous certifications in a multitude of different areas, and I am a IT Administrator that lives by my gadget lust. So when I call tech support on a product, I assure you it is not because I forgot to plug something in or haven't tried rebooting it. At this point, the transmitter doesn't blink to show its searching for the receiver, and the only device that even registers that something is plugged into the hdmi port is my hdmi splitter which just shows that there is a signal coming in and a device connected to the output that has a voltage coming through it. Anyway, none of that information really matters, because no one at HP has heard of the device. I read about that in the other thread on the previous version, but thought I'd give it a shot anyway. Sure enough, after no less than 7 transfers and an hour on the phone, the only think that resulted was me teaching 7 different people about this great new device they have.

If you've made it this far in the review, the obvious conclusion is to stay away. Hopefully its just a bad batch or needed update, but after dealing with the HP non support, I will try someone else. Sadly nothing else out there looks good, and support doesn't seem that great for other competing products. I guess its time to do some more shopping, and starting contemplating the horrible thought of having to run a hdmi cable.

I had this board for 13 days; most stuff worked. The board booted, I OCed my 3770k 4.2 GHz and still had more room to overclock.

My issue was simply that my mouse did not work most of the time. In the UEFI BIOS, Linux and Windows, the mouse does not work until I disconnect and reconnect it. On the Hard Forums, an ASUS representative said a patch for UEFI could take weeks or more, and that the issue with Windows may be fixed as a result, or may require a driver fix.

I've since switched to the MSI GD65 board, and everything works fine. (and this mouse worked fine on two x58 boards, and an asus P68 motherboard.)

For the record, I have two mice, the Mionix Naos 5000 didn't fix it. The Sidewinder X8 did. I like my Naos 5000 enough to have switched my board.

Additionally, even when the mouse is recognized, all mice suffer a delay on boot before they work. This also disappeared with the change to e GD65.

Finally, I never got the wifi AP to work. It worked OK as a client, and I was able to connect to my router with a rate of 150M. In AP mode however, I never was able to get a single device to to even see the network I had created. It's probably a software issue that ASUS will fix, but I remember similar issues with an old ASUS board (a socket 939 board) that had the ability to be an AP that also had awful software.

As far as the UEFI bios goes, it was OK. I immediately disabled the non-advanced UI to get overclock manually, and the advanced UI's layout was OK, and I saw no issues setting boot devices, setting my overlock and such. I will note that if you plan to overclock manually, you need to make sure you also adjust the voltage manually. With the voltage set to auto and the CPU at 4.2 turbo, my voltage would go upwards of 2.25V. Once set manually, my chip was stable (and cooler) at a lower voltage.

Lastly, resuming from suspend never worked. Everything would power back up, but video output wouldnever happen. I would have to manually reset the system (verified this occurred with no overclock.) again, my GD65 has no issues here.

All in all, I wasn't impressed. But I think my issues can all be resolved with updated firmware. In the mean time, my GD65 is a stable performer out of the box, and the only thing I lost was Wifi (and gained some PCIe lanes.)

Worked very well in my HP Pavillion Slimline for a few months. Three months after installation, I started to notice a loud rattle from the system, which I initially took for hard drive seek & write. It took until this evening to realize that what I was hearing was a bad bearing in the fan for this card. Had to pull the card and replace it with a cheapo unit as an interim measure, because it was obvious that the fan wouldn't even last another day. Very disappointing, because it was a great card while it was running. Profile of the slimline system may have had something to do with it -- perhaps it just needed more ventilation than this system can provide.

I live at a college campus and internet is quite bad. I read that this thing would tripled someone's download speed, and mine did just that. Even though I was at a 1Mbps download speed, it brings me up to a 3Mbps download speed. The problem, which after some research I've noticed the thing in common is that everyone owns this product, is that this thing will cause your computer to lose focus, not ALT + TAB, but lose focus, repeatedly. If your on a browser and your typing something, randomly it will lose focus and you'll have to click inside the browser to regain focus before typing again. If you're playing a game, depending on the game, it may end up ALT + TABBING out of the game because it lost focus, or it may just pause the game until you click back on it. I'll be playing a game and that will happen once every 4-5 minutes, which is not good. So other than that, it does what its supposed to, quite well actually, but that's quite a problem. If there's a fix for that, then I'd rate it higher.

Not very well made. I tried not to expect too much from this inexpensive part, but -
- 1 of the two USB 3.0 slots does not work at the same higher speed as the other, not sure why, probably the cable though. I've tried attaching another adapter to the same header pins on the motherboard and they work fine.
- the ports themselves are not very strong. The metal that surrounds them is split underneath by design and it came apart when I plugged a cable into the ports. Happened on both sides, though I was very careful second time I plugged a cable into a port. The frame of the adapter is not very rigid either, so you can expect to use this in a bay that uses pressure to hold it in - it will just buckle.

So, this may be worth the price, but I'd look for more value. I'm going to try a 3.5" bay adapter that has two USB3.0 ports, a 24" cord, AND it holds 2 x SSD drives (or other 2.5" devices) I'd never heard of such, but I'd like to replace this mutt, and now that I've found the other, I'll bet the quality is at least comparable, and it offers more options so it will save space by using the same 3.5 inch bay for the SSD drives and the USB3.0 front ports.

I partitioned mine into Mac OS X and Windows (FAT32) so I could use it on any computer I encountered. I do not know if this was the cause of the mounting problems I occasionally had where I'd plug the drive in and it would not be recognized--I had to unplug and replug it and then the computer would see it. This happened on multiple computers and only with this drive. Still, it worked (after un/replugging), was fast, and was certainly large enough for any file you could throw at it.

I see the negative reviews here and don't doubt them. I've had a few issues myself with this computer but overall it's been a good experience despite a couple of glaring problems.

The bad: The 2tb HD connection is likely damaged on mine. I've tried several cables and slot configurations with the same sporadic results Sometimes it boots. Sometimes it doesn't. I have to jiggle the cable. It's not the end of the world because I bought a separate SSD for my system drive. The 2tb is just storage, with another external backup.

The really bad: For the first couple of months I was getting severe lag spikes while doing just about anything. I tried to diagnose the problem and wasn't having any luck until one day I listened closely to the case and heard the LG BluRay drive repeating a read action and then stopping over and over again. I decided to try unplugging it from the motherboard and sure enough that was the culprit. needless to say I'm not happy about it but I don't own or rent BluRay disks (or any others for that matter) so it's not a big issue for me. I haven't really missed it. However for others that's a deal breaker and I certainly feel irked that it's a feature I paid for that I can't use.

The good: It runs Photoshop CS6 Flawlessly and games like Skyrim, BF3, and Planetside2 maxed out in graphics. I'm running a 2560x1440px monitor and I have all 3 of those games running in native resolution beautifully. It's only crashed a couple of times in the now 6+ months I've owned it. I REALLY like Corsair the case it comes in. It's all metal with a built in handle in the top with LOTS of room for expansion and fans with easy to remove side panels. I now have 7 fans in this thing with it overclocked to the max and it stays nice and cool all the time.

That said, I would not buy this computer again. I like tinkering with my PC but only when everything works. I think they have the foundation for a great product but their assemblage and choice of a sub-par Bluray player leaves much to be desired. This by all rights should be a fantastic computer and in many ways it is but it's not a company I'll likely do business with again unless I hear that they've improved their standards. Too bad.d choice of a sub-par Bluray player leaves much to be desired. I purchased this Modem For use with Xfinity Cable service in Northern GA. Originally I intended to use a [[ASIN:B004XC6GJ0 SB6121 SURFboard DOCSIS 3.0 Cable Modem]]. Unfortunately, the sb6121 would constantly reboot, even though the signal was within spec and had trouble maintaining the upstream channels for more than 10 hours at a time. Alas, the Zoom seems to be suffering the same issue. however, where the sb6121 would take upwards of 5 minutes to reacquire a channel, the 5341j takes about 30 seconds. I realize this is not really a fair comparison since the sb6121 is a 4/4 modem while the 5341j is an 8/4. The extra 4 downstream channels do help with downstream SNR however. Overall I am happy with the purchase.

A couple annoyances I would like to point out, the SNMP Event Log is hidden; you have to manually enter http://192.168.100.1/RgEventLog.asp to see it; this is after you login for the first time. Also the event descriptions are truncated and the modem has a really short time-out, something like 1 minute of Idle page viewing before you have to re-enter the login details.

Overall, if the sb6121 is giving you issues and your cable signal is within spec, I recommend you give this modem a try.

This case contains a sturdy plastic two-piece case for your Kindle Fire HD (2013). The inner case is really sturdy, and though I haven't tried it out, I'm sure it would protect my Kindle from a waist-high fall to the carpet. Maybe even a hard floor. The inner case is incredibly sturdy -

But, it's difficult. The two pieces form a clam shell around the Kindle. The piece you attach to the back side of your Kindle fits very tightly. It isn't difficult to mount, but, if like me, you need to remove it to add a screen protector, be prepared to use a lot of finger pressure and a lot of patience. It fits so tightly, it's as though it's a permanent container.

You place your Kindle face down onto the other half of the case for storage. This is a breeze, but you will need to zip the cover to ensure the Kindle doesn't slip out. When using my Kindle, I find this other half of the case awkward. My instincts tell me to unzip the cover, flip the Kindle face up, and let it rest in the piece of the case that is attached to the cover. But the Kindle slips around on it, so generally I set the entire cover aside to keep my Kindle stationary. This may be a mere personal peeve, because I'm accustomed to using folios.

The inside of the cover is finished in felt/suede/whatever - it's soft but a lint magnet. There are little pockets on the left inner side of the cover, and a pen loop in the center. If you plan to keep a pen or stylus in the cover, make sure it's a skinny one, because when you zip the cover. Oh, goodness, if you put a pen in it, the cover is so tight it's difficult to zip.

It is a good zipper, by the way. But altogether, I find this product fulfills two out of three \\"Fs.\\" Great form and function. The fit is too tight for my liking. It is nice looking. If you're on the fence, and I would be if I was considering purchasing this case, base your decision on whether you prefer style or fit. If you want style, get it. If you want a good fit, don't.If you want a good fit, don't.

I'm using this in my iPad 2, which is the same dimensions as the iPad 3 -- just a little thinner. It fits fine but does tend to slide around very slightly inside the case.

The case itself is nice; black, fairly plain, with a magnetic closure. Of course, the keyboard is the big deal here, though, right?

Well, when I received this item, one of the keys was already broken off, which didn't speak to its long-term durability. And while the keyboard itself is nice and light and attaches (or detaches) easily from the case with velcro tabs, I just don't find I'm using it as much as I should. I don't tend to leave it in the case, because I'm afraid of it getting bumped (I have three small kids whose main goal in life is to steal my iPad), and so if I want to use it, that means I have to go find it, attach it, go into \\"settings,\\" turn on Bluetooth and pair the keyboard and the iPad. (I don't leave Bluetooth on all the time because it makes my battery life sink like a rock.)

So, honestly, I find that most of the time when I think, \\"Gosh, a keyboard would be nice right now!\\" ...I still mostly just end up using the on-screen keyboard. And this case is too pricey (fortunately, I received a free one to review) unless you're VERY sure you're going to use the keyboard on a regular basis. Maybe if you're really careful with your things, you have a place to keep the keyboard nearby, and you can frequently charge your iPad, it would work well for you.

I read my first novel on the Kindle over the weekend, and having owned it now for a week, thought I would write my review.

The Good:
- The format is immersive. I really did forget I was reading from an electronic device, and even pawed at imaginary pages to turn every now and then. Super easy on the eyes, and I really like the fact that it mirrors a paper reading experience - if the light is bad, the device does not compensate by way of a backlit screen.
- The Kindle store's shopping experience is very smooth, very transparent. I have bought a few books, a magazine, and currently on a couple of free trial magazine and blog subscriptions. The latest editions of the New York Times and The Onion are waiting for me first thing in the morning, once you get the hang of how the \\"Back\\" button works (versus \\"Previous Page\\"), navigating is a snap.
- The size of the device is just right - it is very easy to hold and read in bed, at a table, on the couch etc. More on this in the \\"Needs Work\\" section. But to be clear, my Kindle goes everywhere with me - the doctor's office, the park, the bus etc.
- Pricing on Books is good - I would easily pay $9.99 on a title, especially as we run out of library space at home. I read my first novel in a long time thanks to the Kindle (the book - \\"A Thousand Splendid Suns\\", Khaled Hosseini is a trifle predictable and irritating after The Kite Runner ')
- Text is very crisp and easy to read - as I said above, very immersive.
- Love the quick charging and overall battery life.
- Love the integrated web and Wikipedia search. I also checked my gmail account from time to time - horrible user experience, but had to be a true geek and say that I did it '

Needs Work (in no particular order of priority)
- The case is a disaster. The device does not sit in it firmly, and while it looks nice when closed with the elastic band etc, what is really more practical is a sack of some sort, because you really need to take the device out of the case to read effectively and ergonomically. This has to fixed, hopefully through a rich third party accessory community.
- As I read my novel, I often hit the side buttons accidentally and lost my place in the book (either fell asleep with my hand on the buttons, or was walking somewhere with the device without putting it to sleep, or kids got a hold of it etc etc). Bottom line, getting back to the right spot was very hard. I had to remember to bookmark every time I anticipated a disruption. Remembering location numbers is not too practical, since they can run into 4 digits in a long book. Accidentally pressing the wrong buttons is a also a problem when holding the book out of the case (which is more intuitive for reading)
- One thing that is physically intuitive while reading a paper book is knowing exactly where you are, as measured by the pages completed/remaining. Making that same leap using location numbers and the indicator at the bottom is not (yet) that intuitive, so I was bit disoriented when people asked me questions like \\"how far are you into the book?\\"
- The silvery indicator to the right (above the wheel) is not very visible in low light conditions or when there is some reflective directly in front of the device.
- It would be nice to have an option (on the Home screen) to group all your content into Books, Magazines, Newspapers etc.
- Charging for papers and blogs does not make too much sense - this content is available for free, with rich graphics and color, on the web. Over time, I see myself reading books and documents on the Kindle, not newspapers and blogs unless the format is made more rich on the device.
- Graphics is very rudimentary. It's nice to see the device render pictures with stories in the Times etc, but the quality of the images harkens back to 1991 x486 computing.
- Keyboard latency is a bit painful, but am sure this will get fixed soon.
-Perhaps I have not had the device long enough, but it was not clear what the archival process is going to be for newspapers etc.
- In mirroring actual paper/ink, I think the screen background needs to be a bit brighter, without being backlit. Right now it is gray-ish.
- I am sure a million others have already said so, so let me be #1,000,001 - $399 for the reader does not make sense for broad penetration. And this SHOULD be broadly adopted - it is a no-brainer device in the classroom, for textbooks, course handouts, teacher communications etc. It's a brilliant device, and it needs to be $199 or less. People will pay for the books, and other content. It's all about the blades...rchival process is going to be for newspapers etc. - In mirroring actual paper/ink, I think the screen background needs to be a bit brighter, without being backlit. Right now it is gray-ish. - I am sure a million others have already said so, so let me be #1,000,001 - $399 for the reader does not make sense for broad penetration. And this SHOULD be broadly adopted - it is a no-brainer device in the classroom, for textbooks, course handouts, teacher communications etc. It's a brilliant device, and it needs to be $199 or less. People will pay for the books, and other content. It's all about the blades...

In my opinion, this Amped unit is not worth the higher price over a standard wireless router.

On the upside, the Tech Support person I dealt with to get the router set up initially, Andrew, was great.

My mom just received this for Christmas, so I've been helping her set up.  My Kindle is a Touch, and I am really disappointed my mom got stuck with this newer Kindle.  I've even looked for a used Touch to replace it.  Entering my mom's account info by clicking arrow keys was just excruciating compared to typing on my touchscreen (which is how I'm doing this review).  My mom does not want to visit the Amazon store using her Kindle, or do anything else that requires typing.  In contrast, I look for items or information on Amazon or the web browser at least once a day.  It's also sad that there are no speakers.  It takes quite a few more steps to turn wifi on or off.  Definitely a step back from the Touch, which was the entry level reader.

Ok, overall it's a good router, looks really good, easy to set up, but I wish I would knew one fact before I bought it. Even that it says it's a dual band, you can operate only one band at a time. Wireless b/g can only be operated at 2.4Ghz, so does a/n, but at 5Ghz no b/g support, only a/n. So if you set up for Wireless N, it works great with your PC, but if you have iPhone/Touch, or PS3 using wireless internet, only have b/g support you out of luck. So in my case, if I knew this before, I would rather paid more and bought DIR-855 model. For those that don't know 2.4Ghz band is slower, and in most cases over crowded.

All in all its not a bad case with keyboard. Though this version of the case lacks the ability to rotate the screen of the ipad ( its only held in landscape mode) which really should have been added from the get go.  Also it could use something to hold the case shut from opening again. Other than that its a good product doing what you would expect.

The plastic cover goes on easy and looks good.  However,  the keyboard cover blocks the caps lock light - so you can't tell if the caps is on or off!  The cover prevents the keyboard backlight from showing the letters on the keys.  It also makes the keys harder to feel if you are on the right keys and to type quickly.  Also, the paint lines around the keys are uneven, given a cheap look.  Also, after three weeks one of the plastic feet on the bottom fell off.

I didn't expect the product to be mind-blowing at $15, but it is much much flimsier than the actual iPad smart cover. It stands up only if you don't touch it - I tried to prop it up in class (at the steeper angle) and check my email. It collapsed almost instantly. Uneven surface? Good luck.
Yes, the smart cover function works and it will prevent your front screen from scratching if you put it in your bag, but that's about all its good for.

Oh, yes. I forgot. Sony wanted to keep the cost of the system down. Yeah, right! A poor excuse for having to make countless gamers shell out an additional .... dollars for a multi-tap. Sony could've better spent their money putting an additional two controller ports into the system, instead of giving it a moterized tray. Sony could've also made it so that the original PsOne multi-tap, that many people already owned prior to owning a Ps2, was compatable, but they didn't because their new Ps2 memory cards are too big for the slots. They could've just made the card smaller. The one for the Game Cube is even smaller than the PsOne memory card! I think Sony just went with whatever decision would put the most money in their pockets.
I once owned a short-lived game consule that was made by Panasonic called: 3DO. It was the first 32 bit system, which was later beaten into the ground by its high price tag, lack of third party support, and the combined strength of the Sony Playstation and the Sega Saturn. However, there were some qualities about the Panasonic 3DO that I liked, that I'd never seen before on any other game console. The 3DO was a system capable of allowing as many as 10 players to participate in a game at once, with only 1 controller port, and no multi-tap. How? The answer was in the controler. At the top of each controller was a controller port, that a second player could attach his/her controller to, and so on, and so on. It was like building a chain, and the gamplay never slowed down either. I also liked how each controller featured an earphone jack and volume control. Its too bad Sony didn't take a few lessons from Panasonic's 3DO, or the Sega Dreamcast, or Microsoft's X-Box, or Nintendo's Game Cube and 64 system.

I bought this router a little over a month ago. It set up fairly easily and I got it up and running. Then I added my daughter's computer to the router with some restrictions on internet time. I added the link to my computer so that I could access it, and I 'thought' that I had written down the password. Yesterday my daughter had computer problems, and I had to do a system reset to an earlier date. I can't get her computer to connect to the internet at all. I have tried to go to my router controls, but now I can't remember my password - totally my fault since I should be able to find it. So then I go to the Finnoxa tech support - only there isn't any. On their web page there is tech support for setting it up, but that is all. There is no phone number or chat, only FAQs that have nothing to do with daily use outside of setting the router up. There is an administration heading, but when I clicked it I got "page not created yet." The page hasn't been updated since Dec. '13. Not a good sign. I have also posted on their Facebook page but haven't gotten any responses. It also doesn't seem to have much activity. I have also googled the problem, and I can't find any relevant links. Without tech support this router is worthless. I will be buying another one if I can't get help soon, and so far I don't see how that is possible.

Update - I got an answer from my facebook post telling where to go for help. They also told me to use the black button on the back of the router to reset it back to default. I did this, so I was able to access the router and do everything that I need to do. I was ready to give 1 star, but gave 3 since the router works. It is fairly easy to use to block content - which is why I bought it. I still think help should be easier to get. I don't think that I should have had to turn to facebook - hence the 3 stars instead of more.

Like the previous poster, I'm going to be able to build this on my own but I'm pretty shocked that no rudimentary instructions came with the kit. Although I mostly bought this to build my parts inventory, I did intend to build the thing the way it was intended as a potential starting point to future projects. I've already spent a couple of hours just deciding where things are supposed to be mounted and just general layout. My first dilemma was figuring out that the motors needed to be mounted on the yellow base and the clear acrylic was presumably there so that you could see the lower layer of the car through the top. Not a big deal since you're going to want to take everything off so that you can remove the protective paper on the acrylic. But moving the motors then led to the realization that the yellow base is quite thinner than the clear one and the screws were bottoming out on the mounting posts. Also, if you're not careful, the wheels will bind against the sides of the platform. You'll have to make sure you spin them and make sure they move freely before you tighten the screws down... and you'll need some standoff washers if you put the motors on the thinner base.

I can only hope that whoever put together the kit built it at least once to make sure all the necessary parts were included and everything fit together and wiring reached all the appropriate places. You'd think if they did a test build, they'd have at least taken a few pictures and put it on a website somewhere.

My hope is that this forum will become a help site for this product as more people purchase it. I'll add updates as I continue to put everything together and discuss problems I encounter.

The product page on the StarTech.com webpage is misleading about dual monitor support. It says "For dual display configurations, you can connect one HDMI monitor and one Thunderbolt monitor simultaneously." Which means that it only supports dual monitors when one monitor is HDMI and the other is a thunderbolt display (no adapters to DVI or VGA work). That basically limits you to the Apple thunderbolt display and nothing else.

To summarize: secondary monitors do not work with a mini displayport to VGA or DVI adapter.

I've owened this laptop since June. I have the older version with the i7 720 processor as opposed to the i7 740.    The laptop is fast, love the matte finish and it runs my favorite game (Flight simulator X) very well.    Other reviews on here will tell you the wonderful assets of this laptop, my two main gripes with this thing are:  - The mouse pad. I've never used a worse pad in my life, the technology used confuses all the capabilities it can do. for instance, when I lay one finger on it to move the mouse it'll either increase or decrease the zoom lvel, sometimes the pad won't recognise my finger, and I'll be sitting there tapping it and moving my finger on it for sometimes more than 30 seconds until it actually registers I'm trying to MOVE the dang mouse.  - The wireless card is very poor in my opinion. On networks that have 1 to 3 bars out of 5 in terms of reception , this computer is terrible in bandwidth and the internet is very very slow. I compared it in exact smae conditions with my Asus EEE PC 1000HE and it blows it out of the water. Kinda sad when you think this gaming rig is 8 times the price today!    For these two reasons this laptop loses 2 stars in my opinion.    Otherwise it's a good machine, just get a wireless optical mouse like the Ligitech VX Nano and replace the wireless card!

When I first turned it on and played some music - it was incredibly LOUD with gear CLARITY. People say this all the time but I really could not believe that such high quality sound was coming out of this tiny thing. The bass is best at higher volumes. I think that the bass enhancement simply doesn't work at lower volumes. I like my music loud, so this didn't phase me. The unit pairs quickly and easily with multiple devices at the same time. They make a big deal about the LED lights, but they are not really impressive at all. They communicate information - like the battery is low- just fine. But you are not going to sit there and watch the LEDs. It's Anker, so it's great quality with few frills. I spent weeks trying to find the right speaker at a price I could afford, and this was definitely a great find. I got it on sale for $30.

UPDATE: August 28, 2013
The speaker had a lovely sound at Medium volume, but the higher the volume went the greater the distortion. At the highest volume level, I ran to turn the thing off BECAUSE THE SOUND WAS AWFUL. Buyer beware.

I'm also a Amazon Student Prime member, and I thought okay I can upgrade for half off in April to a full membership, so I'll just do it now. Because it seems that the only real way to get a bang for my buck with the Kindle is to spend money on a Prime membership to get any worth while content. Only when I emailed Amazon about upgrading they told me to call. Call? Really?

Oh, and the Kindle Free Time for kids. Okay I do like that I can limit what my kids use on their 'accounts' and that they can't mess with the rest of the Kindle or it's settings, that is something you will NOT find on an iPad (which is stupid because you can on thier computers). That's where my liking of that feature ends. The content is for toddlers and babies. Dora. Thomas. Caiou, Mr. Rogers (really?), Reading Rainbow, stuff like that. I have a 3 year old and a 9 year old. So far I'm debating returning this Kindle despite it's online uses for school to me because I shouldn't have to work so hard to figure out how to put stuff on here. I'll admit I'm a Mac user, and have been for years so I understand there will be some what of a learning curve on my end, but in todays tech savy age nothing should be this irritating to figure out.

I haven't put a ton of these on, but I do follow instructions well and consider myself to be above average in mechanical inclination. The instructions for application were very clear and straightforward and the process for installation was just as clear. So after washing my hands in a hospital grade manner, sterilizing the work area and using the supplied spray to wet my fingers as instructed, the screen went on easily just as described. I I used the supplied squeegee and got what appeared to be a first rate application. So after I got the screen on, I noticed "micro bubbles", which are clearly identified in the instructions as a normal occurrence, which go away after a few days according to the instructions. So, as the instructions indicate, I pulled the screen off and did it over, with the same disappointing results. So, it's been a few weeks now, and those areas are now permanent imperfections on the screen, which although does not impair the functionality of the screen, but is a visual impairment to my obsessive nature for a perfectly clear screen, which was  Apple's intent when making these wonderful devices. Also, this screen protector scratches easily, so be prepared for that as well, even though this is supposed to be a self- healing screen protector. Overall, it does what it's supposed to do, which is to protect the glass, but unless you've applied many of these consistently, do not expect a perfect application. If given another opportunity, I would try another brand to see if I could get a better application and one that does not show the scratches and hazing that this one does.

When I bought this laptop, I was so excited! It came in a sleek box, and it looked beautiful. I was upgrading from an old desktop, so this was a great improvement for me. A few months have gone by, and I am exiting my honeymoon phase and am getting a realistic view of what this computer is like.   This is a very good computer. It's fast with the Intel i5 processor, and games run very well with high settings. The battery life has been great for me so far (I can usually get in at least 3 hours online), but it is still pretty new. I know some people complain about the keyboard, but I like it.   Now for the flaws... The biggest problem I have is that it gets really hot, especially gaming or watching videos, and the fans are not placed in very good locations to work properly. I do have a whining noise that is bearable, but kind of annoying sometimes. ALSO, the CD drive sounds like it's about to take off or die when a CD is put in there. Cool idea of slot load, but terrible sound and shaking. The speakers are alright. For being Beats Audio and supposedly amazing quality, they are not. I also don't like the position of them, because when I hold my computer on my lap, the speakers are muffled and covered up by my stomach. I usually just attach other speakers instead, so I don't have to deal with that. I like that this has a metal case, but it makes it quite a bit heavier. It gets really heavy carrying around in a backpack.  Overall, it works great, but with some annoying flaws.

Bought this to replace a SB5100 that Comcast just increased to $10/month to lease, which I had been doing since 2012. After ~1 day of use, no complaints about function - this one seems to work just like the old one and an "A to B" speedtest.net test shows no change in speed. Also, the modem was shipped quickly and arrived only a few days after I ordered it.

I give it only three stars for two reasons:
1. The item received is not the item advertised. This is advertised as a Surfboard SB5100. I received a Surfboard SB5120. They are visually indistinguishable, except for the number on the front, and I have no idea what the differences are, but I purposely ordered the SB5100 because that was what I was leasing from Comcast so I wanted to be sure they couldn't refuse to activate the one I purchased (which they did, see below). Also, the photo rather deliberately shows a Motorola box, but the item I received did not come in such a box but rather in a brown box (i.e. it may have been repackaged at some point).
2. This modem is considered "end of life" by Comcast and has been since 7/2013. When I tried (1/2015) to activate it over the phone the customer service representative refused to do so because of this, despite the fact that the SB5100 that I was leasing had also been declared end of life since 6/2013 and they never bothered to notify me or give me a new modem. Turns out that all I had to do was plug it in and try to use it and I was presented with Comcast's self-serve activation webpage through which I was able to active it in a manner of minutes. So far I am satisfied with the product (and my SB5100 gave me no problems for 2+ years), but since this product is considered "end of life" it is probably only a matter of time before Comcast renders it incompatible, forcing me to buy a new one. I would therefore advise others in a similar situation to purchase one that is newer and on the supported list.

This case is stylish and has a phenomenal foam lining that I'm sure will provide very good shock absorption and scratch prevention. However, if you have anything more than a slim-line backplate on your iPad, don't count on it fitting in this case. I have a Speck Candyshell on my iPad, which adds minimal bulk, and it absolutely will not fit. The plus side, of course, is that it is a nice, snug fit for your iPad (no bouncing around). But if you don't want to carry a \\"naked\\" iPad around, or if you want more protection than basically a back cover, this is not the carry case for you. Also, the inner foam will probably not do well with the rubberized silicone skins based on fit and texture, but this is not something I have tested.    This carry case has no handle or option for a handle, nor is there a good place to put any kind of identification card if you (*gasp!*) lose it.     So, overall, it's a nice, stylish case and it'll probably do a good job of protecting your iPad from minor bumps and scratches, but it prevents you from using a decent case and lacks functionality.

I have a pair of older Altec Lansing speakers with an accompanying sub attached. I paid $69 for them. The clarity and sharpness is MUCH better on those and they cost half the price. If you want loud banging sound these Logitechs Z-2300's will do the job but if you want better sounding better experience I would go with another pair of speakers. I assume the Kilipsh competing brand mentioned in some of these reviews here will sound much better.

If my older Altec Lansing speakers can beat these on sound then I'm sure the Kilipsh set will do much better than these Logitechs.

Nice mouse, with one caveat: I use three monitors, even at the highest sensitivity setting this Anker mouse only moves the cursor half as far across my screens as my other mouse. (I use the Razer Abyssus at its 1800 dpi / 125 hz setting, it can go higher but I find 3500dpi and/or 1000 hz to be overkill.) The Razer is slightly better suited for navigating across three 23\\" screens without having to repeatedly pickup and reposition the mouse. The vertical/ergonomic design of this Anker is comfortable after you get used to it, but if I have to move my wrist 2x as much, it might be a zero sum game for me. It just arrived today; I'm going to try it for at least a week. I'll post back here if I stumble across mouse nirvana.

UPDATE:
I've spent a few more hours with it and can now say I'm also not a fan of the middle-click of the mouse wheel. It's too difficult to push compared to my other mice.

Also, please note that I'm reviewing the CORDED version, not the wireless mouse with similar features.

UPDATE:
Anker is sending another mouse in case the one I have is a dud. Their support is fast and friendly.

Another thing I've noticed, the mouse seems to revert to the low DPI setting upon each computer restart which is especially annoying if you want to use the higher DPI setting. I've noticed this twice in the past couple days. I'll do some poking around when I have time to turn the system on and off a few times to confirm.

UPDATE:
Either the middle button is now easier to click or I've been trained how to do it correctly. Either way, all's well now.
I can confirm that the dpi resets to the lower setting on every restart, but this also is bugging me less as I get used to it.

i was attempting to increase my wifi signal from neighbors and this product did that well.  my relatives live about 300 ft away and with a clear line of sight the signal went from 1 bar to 4-5 bars.  i was easily browsing and using their wireless printer.  other networks i picked up also but i do not know where they originated from and do not know the distance.  that was the obvious positive.    now the negatives-  before i got the antenna my laptop battery would routinely last two hrs on power saver and it was over a yr old.  this antenna must be plugged into usb for its power supply and iwthin a short time my laptop battery was drained and now only holds a charge for maybe 10 minutes.    it works best when placed in a window.  the cord is about six feet long, so you have some flexibility.  it does work when not placed in a window but much depends on the signal and what room you are in.  clear LOS and by windows i worked much much better    durability- we have cats, and when placing the antenna in a window and stringing out the 6 ft long antenna to a nearby chair the cord is leftlaying around, sometimes even suspended.  they run into and down comes the antenna.  we continued to take steps to weigh it down so that they couldnt knock it down, but after about 6 times it broke and no longer works.  not really manufacturer fault, but just something to take note of    final thought- excellent solution for the price but there are drawbacks.  i tried the cheap way and a friend with tech knowledge recommended an engenius wireless repeater which set me back $75 but will not further drain my battery, or my new battery when that time comes.

Got this mouse to replace my broken Anker CG100 (was a good mouse but I dropped it). Saw this for around $10 and thought "why not" since it has good reviews. Wanted to try another mouse too.

*First impression* : The mouse tracks well, but it's little too light for my taste. Buttons have a satisfying click, sidebuttons feel a little cheap but they all work responsively. DPI adjustment fit what I wanted. Cord is really nice, but the mouse itself feels a tad flimsy.

*BIGGEST GRIPE* (and dealbreaker for me): The ridges where you rest your pinky and ring finger on the right make it impossible to grip it like I want to. It's impossible for me to game without being able to "fingertip grip" the mouse. My wrists hurt trying to use the more natural grip the mouse allows.

*Bottom line* : If you use a fingertip grip (google it), this mouse might not be the best for you.

I feel bad giving it a 3/5 based on my own view on the grip. It's really a deal for how cheap it is, but realistically the mouse build is also not that great compared to mice I've had.

I purchased this direct from J&R and received it about 3 weeks ago.  As stated, the shield covers only the rear of the iPad 2, and installation was a snap (literally).  Once on, it's very slim and unobstructive and offers a very good nonslip feel, making the iPad easier to hold.  The fit is excellent.  Finish was good, with the exception of a couple grains of grit which I could feel (but not see).  In my opinion, this cover adds to the utility and very much to the appearance of the iPad.    However, I recently noticed what appeared to be a hairline crack on the case near one of the corners.  After very gently removing the shield, I noticed that there were in fact several hairline cracks, all located at/near three of the corners (and no, I didn't crack it during installation or removal).  As the iPad 2/shield had always been handled gently and never dropped, I could see no reason for the appearance of these cracks, except as through defects in manufacturing and/or design.  It's disappointing that a simple plastic cover (which was already overpriced for what it is) would develop cracks at critical stress points in such a short amount of time (if ever).  If you Google \\"Belkin Snap Shield iPad 2 cracks\\" or something similar, you'll find similar complaints.    I left a message for J&R to see if they will refund or replace the item (possibly a temporary fix, but I'm hoping I just got a bad unit).    If not for the corner cracks, I would have no problem giving this product five stars.    EDIT: J&R issued an RMA, but I'm stuck with the return shipping costs [keep ALL your packaging material, if you buy this].  I opted for a refund, as I think it's a design flaw.  I will be looking at other rear covers on Amazon, which is unfortunate since I really like this one.

Worked great, but I think it's way overpriced. I was looking to buy about 30 of these for a project, but given the cost, it wasn't worth it. I went with another lower quality product to save on cost. I only took off stars for the cost so, if you are fine paying full price, go for it.

I guess everyone's mileage varies with a product like this. I too like other reviewers am an IT Professional -- admin, developer, network jockey, consultant, etc. But I'm also very busy and don't have the time to diagnose and fully root cause like I used to.

The goal of my purchase was to extend the wireless signal in the home to some places where the signal is weak. Two Rokus were under consideration, one in the bedroom and one in the family room.

On first look out of the box, the two I bought set up nicely, though I did notice some glitches with the Web UI on each extender. Pages that had to be reloaded or wouldn't fully load, etc. I do some Mac address mapping on the firewall for the Rokus and a couple of other devices, and there was a documented workaround for that and everything was fine there save for some run around one of the extenders gave me by setting a static address seemingly on it's own but reporting dynamic or DHCP. Another status page helped me to see the extender had neither a gateway nor a DNS set for it's static (though reporting dynamic) and a reboot of the device set everything straight.

All in all though I found myself rebooting the devices more than I cared for. It was not "set it and forget it" as I need and ultimately, the wireless in the household became SLOWER. It seemed to drown my main Netgear AP, the one to which the extenders would have to and were sync'd up to.

So while everything "looked" good (after some hassles and glitchy pages and a weird "I'm dynamic but no I'm not" moment), ultimately these weren't working with my AP very well, which is odd -- it too is Netgear (and a newer model to boot).

I've been using Netgear for years because in the early days of the internet, they were offering equipment and doing things no one else was doing. Their embedded firewalls where great. It seems the company has taken a turn in the last five years. I'm not as impressed any more and it's probably time to upgrade the inhouse brand. I'll be returning these extenders. Once I finally gave up and unplugged them, everything is back to normal. I never figured out exactly what was going on, but considering everything was "reporting" as connected (these were sync'd to the main Wifi AP using DHCP), the problem probably has to do with something lower level that I don't have the time to dig in and figure out -- and shouldn't have to really.

Wouldn't recommend though it seems from other reviews to be working well for others.as impressed any more and it's probably time to upgrade the inhouse brand. I'll be returning these extenders. Once I finally gave up and unplugged them, everything is back to normal. I never figured out exactly what was going on, but considering everything was "reporting" as connected (these were sync'd to the main Wifi AP using DHCP), the problem probably has to do with something lower level that I don't have the time to dig in and figure out -- and shouldn't have to really.

Wouldn't recommend though it seems from other reviews to be working well for others.

This is a great little ultrabook, it's fast and boots up quick, the display is nice and I have no complaints about how it runs.  The physical device itself is a bit flimsy though, it has warped such that all 4 corners do not touch and just typing on the keyboard makes the lid rock back and forth.  It's extra noticeable due to reflections in the glossy display.  I kinda wish I had spent more on a sturdier device.

Microsoft's new Bluetooth entry into the keyboard and mouse market is a very nice looking pair. However, after a little time using them you realize that you are actually getting form over function at least when it comes to the awful mouse. While they look lovely on your desk the mouse is functional but not comfortable. After only a few minutes of use my hand began hurting. So if you plan on using this mouse for a lengthy period of time you may find it uncomfortable - after 20 minutes using this I was missing my logitech mouse which was much more comfortable.'The mouse is very shallow and takes a lot of getting used to coming from a more substantiation device.

The keyboard on the other hand is very nice and the key response is very good. There is only a slight noise when typing and the key travel is good. I have been using a Logitech wave keyboard as my daily driver in the office and a Logitech solar k750 at home. The Microsoft keyboard has given me reason to consider ditching one of the two listed. The unit is listed as compatible with Win 8 or newer and I was able to successfully pair the mouse and the keyboard with my Win 7 laptop & a Win 8.1 desktop along with a Win 8.1 tablet.

If you are more concerned with how your desk looks than how the tools on your desk function then this is a good combination for you. The bluetooth did not have any issue with 15ft distance when using it from the couch. If you do not utilize your computer for lengthy periods then these are a great combo as they look nice and clean sat on the desk. If you demand productivity and comfort you may want to look elsewhere.

I was impressed as this was during the set up portion, and I did not even plug in the antenna they provided. Also, my house is all brick no dry wall here, so wifi can be skecy. It was 2/5 bars reception, but then I plugged the antenna and bam 5 bars. SpeedTest.net 15ms Latency, 96.8mg download, 15mb upload. The fit and finish seems strong looks like a sturdy board. Fan lay out is great all on the edges and not center of a board, so a clean look.

The bad: The board could not take 64gb 8x8gb of Adata Ram at 2400mhz with the factory settings would boot loop. However, when I set it at 2133mhz it worked just fine. The Asus power boost/auto OC failed to post due to the fact it can't boot the XMP ram profile of my ram. However, at 32gb it booted, and I swapped out the ram thinking that batch was bad same story. The bios settings look pretty, but do not always apply had to re-apply settings a few times to make it work.

Conclusion I am going to keep this board, as its to much work to take it all apart. I just got the system stable so sticking with it. However, next time around I think I will try a different manufactory or do more research very disappointed. Customer service is the major problem here honestly. If the people on the phone were a bit brighter then the dark end of the universe life would be easierwith them. Honestly, I have had deeper conversations with my Lab then them wow...

The board will work after back and forth with it, and it don't like all ram slots filled I need the ram. So your OC ability will vary, and again this is all due to my configuration yours will probably be different, but that customer support is with all of us. Sadly, the customer support is a part of this product and it sucks.

Herein, I review the Samsung Series 9 after three months.

Bottom line review (specifics below): This is an Ultrabook, designed for and intended as a superlight, portable machine for school, coffeeshops, and lightweighti stuff you'd do there (surfing, office stuff, listening to music). As an Ultrabook, the SS9 is an excellent product that competes with the best on the market, and generally suffers flaws similar to other ultrabooks, with caveats (keyboard and touchpad delight some and horrify others - your mileage may vary). As anything else (eg desktop gaming, graphics, etc.) or when used beyond what it was designed for (like running 3 monitors while writing a paper while running powerpoint while checking email while running winamp off a portable drive), the SS9 becomes mediocre and hard to recommend.

***Do not buy this as anything other than an ultrabook, because most of the features quibble about relate to uses beyond its design.***

I bought this because my huge Quad-core desktop replacement was too heavy to lug around on campus. Wanted something light with a decent screen and great battery life. Its limitations frustrate me, but it does what I wanted it to do otherwise.

**********Pros***********

As a machine for school it has very fast boot and transfer via USB3, it's light, I get a full day's worth of use out of a single charge, and it recharges quickly. Has a nice screen that allows outdoor use.

Build is aesthetically pleasing, nice webcam, fairly useful system software, minimal bloatware.

Designers eliminated ports/components that don't enhance the intended ultraportability (namely the DVD ROM and full-sized ports) and replaced them with mini-ports.

Runs very cool and quiet - I've never heard the fan kick on before.

***********Features that have mixed reviews**************

Touchpad: Essentially, people who like or dislike the pad make the same observations: It's large, sensitive, and designed to be used in a specific way based on gestures and zones. So, if you've got big hands and long fingers like I do, and you take time to learn how to use it, and of course if you patch it from original drivers to current, it ranks among the best pads to be released (IMHO) in spite of a few bugs. Those with smaller hands, clumsy fingers, impatience, or those who expect the pad to do what they want it to do in the manner that they want it (instead of how it was programmed) will hate it. If you plan to buy this laptop, if at all possible you should testdrive the pad because it's a make/break feature for many.

Keyboard - Keystrokes are shallow, not much recoil, keyboard is sort of cramped, and the ease by which you can accidentally hit the touchpad and move the cursor while typing is a huge deal-breaking annoyance to many. I had that problem often, depending on the angle that I'm typing from. It's irritating as an ant bite between your toes. That said, we all have different tastes in keyboards. Those with smaller hands or people who have nimble fingers probably won't mind the keyboard. Personally, I prefer deep keys on a full-sized keyboard with lots of recoil. My hands are big and I type like I play the piano - percussively.

**************Minor Cons********************

HD could have been bigger, and having to pay extra to get Win7 on the machine (given that Win8 is geared towards touchscreens) ticked me off.

*********************Cons************************

It appears that when closed, the keyboard contacts the screen. This lead to a nick in my screen, and requires me to clean the screen fairly often.

The Intel HD card SUUCCCKKKSSS. I've experienced all sorts of graphical corruption with certain applications, acceleration is non-existent, the control panel interface can't be configured for three monitors (which I do run at home using my Series 9), and the driver has a tendency to crash. I run my computers hard, so it's possible that single-taskers / surfers won't run into the same problems. Worst of all, though - when you hook up a second or third monitor (via the mini-HDMI), the second screen has a tendency to momentarily disconnect and reconnect (takes about 5 seconds) and at this time there is no fix. ****One more thing - my mini-hdmi will do the same thing (on/off) if I bump the cord even slightly. Has anyone else experienced this? In any event, these problems relate primarily to uses of the machine beyond its intent (ultraportable), so take that into consideration. This isn't a desktop replacement.

Some folks say that the HD is cheap and should be replaced - I can't comment on that.

The ports are all fairly tight - it's kind of hard to fit the power adapter and mini-hdmi adapters into the ports. It worries me given the lightness and build of the machine. This is one aspect of the design that might prove detrimental in the long run.

The backlit keyboard is marginally useful - only in a dark lecture room has it actually been useful.

Could have used a fourth USB port. Assembly feels a little flimsy in some places.

I boughtis b ecause my desktop replacement Dv6 Quad Core Edition (8g RAM, 1 Gg dedicated video card) was too heavy to lug around.h I was a little skeptical about the Series 9's video capabilities because it has the intel HD 4000, whereas at home I ran three monitors off the Dv6. After a couple of weeks, here are my thoughts --

First and foremost, the Series 9 is capable of three monitors, but the Intel Graphics Manager is clunky and doesn't seem to support the configuration. Rather, I use a USB adapter for the monitor and it works fine, with the caveat that switching between the configurations (eg, from desk to school and back) is kind of annoying because it doesn't always snap back to the native screen. Also, having multiple monitors running seems to screw up other software aspects - for example, because a monitor has speakers, bluetooth seems to no longer pick up my bluetooth wireless speakers.

The laptop runs cool at all times, and handles basic stuff like office, browsing, movies, streaming video, etc. with speed and fluidity. It isn't as fast as my old desktop replacement, but I can forgive this because it has one half the processing power. One thing that puzzles me - for some reason, Google Chrome seems to hang when opening multiple tabs on this laptop - I have no idea if it is the laptop or some addon, but I can't reproduce the error on other machines.

The screen is fantastic, if a bit bright. Works fine outside as well as it does inside. The hinge for folding the screen back and forth is nice and tight. The webcam is a basic webcam, no frills.

Could have used a fourth USB port. Assembly feels a little flimsy in some places.

Adaptec is reselling the Highpoint RocketRAID 100 as their own product. This is not a hardware RAID implementation, but the BIOS on the card support booting from the RAID array, which would otherwise be impossible using RAID0. The chip used (HPT370A) is nothing but a ATA100 controller, and can be used as such.
All the magic is in the drivers. Adaptec only supports Windows OSes, but it actually works out of the box for FreeBSD, and Linux supports the chipset as well. I'm running a RAID1 configuration for a file server, using matched HDs. Read performance is noticably faster, and write performance does not seem to have suffered much.
One issue: when one drive fails the RAID1 keeps on running, but rebooting requires manual intervention at the console until the drive is replaced and the mirror rebuilt.
It's not an issue for me, but continuing the boot after a timeout would have been nice.

Pros: The finish is nice, and it has a smooth, thin feel to it.
Cons: The battery life is really poor. I have even reset to defaults and installed minimal apps, disabled GPS, etc., and it still doesn't last as long as many of my other devices.
