I purchased this router on 10/3/2014 to replace a NETGEAR R6300v2 (which was beginning to fail). The first five days with the ASUS RT-AC87U were great, the speeds were terrific, coverage was good and connections were stable. Then, while working this morning, the router died. The router lost communication with the modem and all devices on my LAN that were attached to the router lost connection with the rest of the network. The 5Ghz light went out, and the internet connection light intermittently went from blue to red and back again.

I tried rebooting (and resetting the router, rebooting the modem and replacing my ethernet cables...still, nothing. I connected a desktop directly to the modem and was able to get online...which leads me to believe that the ASUS RT-AC87U is the source of the problem.

It is a shame, for the first few days my experiences with the ASUS RT-AC87U were promising. Now it is has caused me a morning of missed work and troubleshooting headaches.

This unit will be going back and I will begin searching for a new router.

UPDATE [October 10, 2014]: I decided to try to reset the router to factory default settings one final time before returning the router (this was the third time doing so)...and the router began working again. I will still probably return the ASUS-RT-AC87U, as I don't trust it stability...but I Just wanted to update to say that, after a day of trying, I was able to get it back up and running.

I got this mouse on recommendations of some MMORPG gamer friends.  The mouse looked fantastic and exactly what I was wanting to have: the side buttons where the big deal. Sometimes it would be OK but most of the time the pointer would jump all over the screen.  I could even have the mouse stationary on the desk with nothing touching it or pulling on the cord and watch the mouse travel across my screen. I received a Long Email from Razer TS about what to do about this but it seemed that the mouse was defective so I ordered a replacement. The replacement came from Amazon fast and I tried again. I even bought a new mouse pad that was light in color (the Razer TS said use a white piece of paper!) and while it was improved the mouse cursor still traveled and it seemed that if the mouse was being used a lot (like in a MMORPG game) then the cursor became impossible to control.  And even though it has a nice hand-feel my hand got cramped just trying to re-center the mouse all the time.  So it's a nice mouse but if you don't have the right computer rig then it might not work for you.  It certainly did not work \\"out of the box\\" for me.

The good? Wireless speeds are in excess of the 802.11g spec, so I am getting 100-110Mbps (12.5-13.5 MBps) from the basement to the living room easily. Once the initial horror of setup was over, I've been happily connected ever since. And you can't beat the price: Linksys gear is dropping in price, likely due to a ramp-up of pre-N gear on the horizon. (That's the new 802.11n standard which promises 6x the g-rate, and pre-N Belkin gear is delivering triple the speeds, so 150Mbps, or nearly 19 MBps).

The bad? Customer support, or lack thereof. I had a problem with the client not seeing the router. The *real* problem was the firewall on the basement machine. However, mention the words \\"Workgroup\\" or \\"file and printer sharing\\" to a Live Chat Specialist and watch how fast they come back with \\"we don't support configuring Windows\\" and a link to a knowledgebase article that will not give you a step-by-step diagnostic.

That's a shame, because a troubleshooting map would come in real handy. I fixed the problem myself -- I usually do with rare exception -- but for the non-IT professional, I fear for you. It's Belkin or Netgear for me next time.

And even more: the DHCP server on these routers are apparently very flaky. I could never get mine to give up an IP address to my WMP54GS card, so in the ened I configured it for a static IP and was connected. Woe to the inexperienced customer who tries to get an IP from one of these automatically. This issue is known throughout the Internet, but good luck trying to get Linksys to admit the problem and fix it.

The ugly? Try installing it. IF you manage to see your router on the first shot, your karma is perfect and heaven awaits you. Sinners like myself are forced to install the Linksys drivers only after the failed promise of Wireless Zero Configuration fails. Yes, you'll be switching between the Windows config and Linksys config a few times until you get it right. My suggestion would be to ensure you can see the router first (channel selection being the biggest 'gotcha' here), then worry about encryption and such.

Also, don't be surprised if the DHCP server on the WRT54GS router doesn't give you an IP address. It's a known issue to the outside world, which is waiting for Linksys to admit it and fix it. Configuring your WMP54GS with a static IP will get you fully connected in every case.

I have companion reviews for the WRT54GS and WUSB11, also Linksys gear. They won't be very flattering, either, but it's XMas time, and readers should not be giving bad gifts.

The Linksys WRT54G and WRT54GS routers have been the number one most popular wireless router devices available for the past few years. So this begs the question why Cisco would snatch defeat from the jaws of victory by needlessly changing an almost perfect product.  The fact is that versions 1 -4 of the G and the GS (with Speedboost) versions of this router were fantastic. Those earlier routers run a flexible and powerful Linux based firmware that has been perfected for the past few years a numerous updates and tweaks. However, the earlier WRT54G product has now been replaced with a less powerful wireless product (version 5) that has had its onboard flash RAM chopped in half from 4MB to 2MB and its system RAM cut from 16MB to 8MB.  Instead of the flexible, reliable and powerful Linux firmware the new WRT54G version 5 routers run the licensed VxWorks firmware instead. There is nothing wrong with using VxWorks and over time Cisco will probably work out the bugs but for now the newest wireless routers are not reliable.       Why would Cisco do this to its most popular Linksys brand of wireless routers ?  Apparently it might be a case where the first four versions were too flexible for their own good. The open source Linux firmware with the large amount of flash and system memory was attractive to many third party independent software developers that were turning the WRT54G and GS routers into powerhouse micro Linux wireless computers with a functionality approaching and often surpassing the $600+ wireless routers that Cisco sells.  There might also have been an excess number of product warranty returns for the WRT54G routers due to so many people flashing them with non-Linksys third party firmware that sometimes can \\"brick\\" a router or make it unusable.    Your solution is to either look for a previous version of the \\"WRT54G\\" router before version 5 or purchase the \\"WRT54GS\\" (SpeedBooster) version 4 which as of the posting of this review is still available in the stores and it still uses the popular Linux firmware. You will pay $20 more for the GS model but compared to the version 5 of the G model it is worth the extra money. The GS models 1 - 4 are all good with GS version 3.0 and 3.1 reportedly being the most flexible of the bunch and GS 4.0 being the latest. If you want to use third party firmware you may want the GS versions 2.0 - 3.0/3.1 since they have the most flash RAM while still having newer Broadcom based processors. Finally, if you do plan to flash your WRT54G with third party firmware the  ones before version 4 of the WRT54G wireless routers are supposed to be easier to work with.     How do you find which version you are looking for? Look on the bottom of the box near the scan tag for the serial number of the router. For the WRT54G wireless routers look for CDFA or a CDF9 or lower (CDF8, CDF7, 6, etc.)  Any serial number with CDF5 (v2.0) through CDF9 (v3.1) are the most flexible for use with third party firmware. Unless you want to use a more risky third party firmware I recommend that you read the manual instructions on how to carefully flash these older router models with a newer Linksys firmware which is designed for that specific router version. The latest official Linksys firmware for each specific version of router can be obtained from the Linksys support site.  Completely avoid the WRT54G routers with the \\"CDFB\\" (v5.0) serial numbers since those are the buggy VxWorks versions. You could also simply purchase the WRT54GS (v4.0) routers that say Speedboost on the box. You will see the \\"CGN6\\" serial numbers on the box and as of this review these were still using Linux firmware with software based SpeedBoost enhancements but the RAM and hardware inside seems to be essentially the same as the older WRT54G (v4.0) version 4.  The WRT54GS v2.0 (CGN3) through v3.0 (CGN5) are also good and will have more flash RAM available if you want use the wireless router with third party firmware. I would like to note that flashingthe router with firmware other than an official Linksys releases obtained from the Linksys support web site will void the warranty and can result in a \\"bricked\\" or damaged router.      PROS: The most popular, flexible, reliable and highly rated wireless router on the market before the WRT54G version 5. Previous versions could be flashed with powerful third party firmware. The latest WRT54GS v4.0 routers can still be purchased and except for the SpeedBoost software enhancement (including a different version of Linux based firmware) they are essentially the same as older WRT54G v4.0 routers.    CONS: The latest version 5 has less Flash and System RAM and uses a buggy non-Linux based firmware.  There is no rumor of this yet but in the near future Cisco might also release a newer WRT54GS router non-Linux based router (WRT54GS v5.0 ???)     CONCLUSION: With all the changes to the memory and the firmware this latest G model is really a very different product and Cisco should have changed the model number altogether. Neverless, I hope that Cisco works out the bugs in their current version so that the G version can at least partially return to its glory days. There are rumors that a still newer model popular Linux based router might be re-released with the model name of WRT54GL but until that happens we can still purchase a very good WRT54GS v4.0 Speedbooster model.     THE BOTTOM LINE: I give five stars to the older WRT54G models and five stars to the latest WRT54GS model. But I give only one star for the newest WRT54G version 5 which averages the score to only 2.5 stars (rounded down to 2 stars since v5.0 is the newest and most abundant WRT54G model that you can find in the stores).

This mouse has the best features of any mouse on the market, unfortunately, it is not built to last. I own two of those babies, one on my Mac, the other for my PC. Soon after I bought my first Intellimouse, it started to work erratically. I returned it and it was exchanged for a new one and it worked fine. I then decided to buy a second one since I was so pleased with the product. Fast forward to one year later, just after warranty expiration. Both of them have started to work erratically a few weeks ago. At times, the mouse does not respond at all. After some troubleshooting I found that in both cases, the problem stems from the connection between the USB cable and the mouse. After the mouse stops working, if I wiggle the cable that comes out from the top of the mouse, the red light inside the mouse comes on again for a while.For this problem to occur on both my units, it is unlikely just bad luck. There seems to be a design flaw that Microsoft will have to adress. In the meantime, I might just try my luck with Logitech's optical mouse. It only has 4 buttons instead of 5, but I hope that it will outlast Microsoft's offering.

So I have had this for about a year and a half thus far and came to post here about my troubles: This is going to be the second time I send this in for repair. The first time the left ear stopped working after about 4 months of use, now after what seems like almost no time at all the right headphone has broken off the right side.    These issues along with the frequent charging issues, example: It will have spastic battery life, sometimes it lasts for 4 hours sometimes 1 or 2, its so random I end up having to just have it plugged in most of the time. The battery icon is inaccurate, and apparently is known to fail.    Reading online about these parts I learned these companies participate in a practice where when the product is first shipped they use high quality parts but over-time they just outsource to Chinese companies and replace most of the parts with cheep knockoffs shortening the lifespan of the product.    Another issue you will face is the drivers for the \\"5.1 surround sound\\" which is actually just a software hack to make it appear to be 5.1...this would not be an issue for me except it likes to break half the games I play, you can flip the switch on the headset to toggle stereo but a lot of the times it just does nothing.    Volume. The newer drivers for this headset limit your ability to increase the sound...I assume for safety reasons, but there are some games like wolfenstein where the audio is just naturally low and you would like to increase it....and you cant. If  you downgrade the drivers you get more access to sound options and even the ability to go higher than normal, at the cost of the play/forward/back buttons.    All together I would say spend your money else-ware, the bass on these suck.

The Iview certainly looks good on paper: Quad core, 8gb ram and a lot of extras, like an SD card slot and HDTV dongle. Coming from our Hisense Sero 7 Pro (nice tablet btw), we expected some drawbacks in buying a generic. The screen resolution was the most obvious one but we figured for the price we paid, we could deal with it. The equivalent specs were there, so good to go, right?

Well, no. Battery life was the first straw of many to break this camel's back. During a session of normal WiFi usage, you can literally watch the battery drain percent by percent. Even with brightness turned down and gps/location settings locked down, it leaks power like a sieve compared to my dearly departed Sero. Secondly, the screen was a disappointment as well. 1080x600 is adequate, but the overall resolution lends a muddy appearance to display. It also makes for a lot of home screen dead space along the edges.

Besides the battery life and poor screen quality, there was the fact that the Android OS will eat up about 4 of your 8gb, leaving you with about half the memory you're expecting. It also seemed to have trouble maximizing memory usage, though how much of that due to the Android OS or iview's hardware configuration is unknown. The on-board cameras are usually a lost cause with any device in this hardware class, and the Iview is no exception. Expect a blurred mess and hideous shutter lag with every shot.

And it's just ugly. The two tone black and white plastic clamshell is tacky, inspiring no build confidence in the device.

In the end, I could probably live with the rest if the battery could do it's job. Instead, I traded to an uglier, fatter device and it's worse, slurping up power like an alcoholic on St Partick's Day.

Perhaps I could get used to it, but there's a second problem: it doesn't stand up well. The place I would expect to position the "monitor" to stand (right behind the keyboard) does not allow it to stand. The only logical place for it is slightly over the keyboard top. This in no way impairs your typing (there's nothing in that inch of keyboard plastic you need), but it still isn't the best angle for it. Best yet is to slide the keyboard out about halfway, and THEN place the "monitor" behind the keyboard - this angle allows it to sit natually. But of course, if you were hoping to use this anywhere but on a desk or table, forget it. It's flopsy-mopsy as it is, let alone with the keyboard hanging off the edge magnetically. My dreams of typing on my lap in the park or on a train are gone.

I gave it 2 stars for it's potential in cooler systems and because it fits and htpc case nicely.
I subtracted 2 starts because it covers to dimms and requiring me to remove the heat sink from my dimms and because it doesn't work (for me).

Details...

It may say 130W but running on my phenom II x6 1090T I nearly dropped a brick when doing a video conversion ran my CPU temp from 38c (where it was idling) up to 73c! I could shut the app and system down fast enough. If all you're doing is word processing and net surfing this will work fine or if you have a 95w system I expect this will keep the temps in control. I would also recommend getting a different paste than the one shipped.

Solution...

I ended up replacing the htpc case I have with a Corsair 330R silent and used the Cool Master 212 evo for a sink. This is so quiet that my typing is now the most annoying sound in the room and it dropped my temps to 20c idle / 30c load. This is 10c less than stock and 20c less that the IS-50 at idle.

I bought the Kindle II with the idea that my 85 year old mom, instead of having a small subset of books in Large Print available to her, would now have ALL books at her fingertips by using the larger font size.  Alas.    The first problem was the box.  The outer box opened as all boxes do, but inside was a very nicely made cardboard rectangle.  I studied it for 3 minutes.  Tried various methods.  Ten minutes.  Tried brute force.  There was no conceivable way to open it.  I have never had a problem opening a box before.  This was puzzling.  I took my pen knife to it, but this was some high grade cardboard and it was ineffective.  A steak knife made more progress, but was still too slow.  A chef's knife did the trick.    The next problem was how to register it at my house, but allow her to use it at her house.  I went online and created an Amazon account for her, but, of course, it wanted her email address.  If there were email messages sent to finish the registration process I'd never see them.  Hmmm.  I probably made some wrong assumptions, but in any case instead of a 5 minutes, registration took an hour.    So now we were ready to download a book.  But although I could set the text of documents at a larger font, there didn't seem to be a way to make the UI larger too.  My mom couldn't read it.  Ignoring that for the time being we made our way to History books.  The books were listed in two columns.  My mom had to click down twice and once right to check out a D-Day book.  She held the toggle down instead of clicking and I have no idea where we ended up.  Five minutes later I got us back to the same spot and reminded her how to click.  Clicking is not pressing.  She held it down again and all was lost again.  With her lower lip trembling she said, \\"This is too hard for me.  I don't want it.  You take it.\\"    So now I have a new Kindle and mom has a big new monitor instead.    To sum up I would not get a Kindle for anyone with poor vision.  This gadget is very wellmade, delicately made with precision, but my mom could not see the very light grey labels on the buttons.  Could not see where one button ended and another began.  This gadget is made for three foot elves I think, with great vision and very tiny fingers.    P.S.  If you envisioned reading with the Kindle on a plane with the overhead light off ... nope nope.  In the dark the Kindle is like a brick.  No light.  No glow.  Nothing.  You need light and lots of it to use the Kindle.
I bought this product and from the get go is the corners and sides are peeling off.. i feel like i wasted my money... i dont recommend it to anyone.
It works in MacBook Pro 13inch mid 2012 but there are no holes to screw it in Mac. I secured it with only one screw and SuperDrive had three. It does work with original hdd

Pros:
- Screen display is excellent. I have a Nexus 7 also, and this screen looks just as good. Bright, high resolution, excellent viewing angle.
- Touch. Works very well. Onscreen keyboard is reliable.
- Speed - Nice and snappy response for apps and internet browsing.
- Build - Very good. Seems solid and well crafted.
- Reliability. No crashes, no nonsense (except for GPS)
- Wifi - fast and reliable

Cons:
- GPS!!! The GPS is pretty much junk. Occasionally would get a lock, but more often than not, would not work. I'm a software developer and wrote a GPS app that uses the windows sensor API. (I also downloaded a GPS app off the app store to make sure that it just wasn't my software that did not recognize a valid lock very often) Basically, the GPS is present and does work maybe 10% of the time. When it does work, it may choose a particular constellation, but then all of a sudden changes the chosen constellation for the solution, and gets out of lock. Interestingly, it is seeing GLONASS satellites as well as USA satellites when it's in a good mood! Does not use the GLONASS satellites for the lock however.
I researched the GPS chipset in this thing, and it seems fine. They are using the Broadcom BCM4752, which, according to the website, is a highly sensitive, "modern" GPS. I'm not sure what Lenovo did wrong. Perhaps it's a poor antenna? Perhaps interference from other high frequency signals on the motherboard? Who knows? Lenovo has a driver on their website called the "
Hiking GPS Driver". There is no description on what the term "Hiking" means. I think this is just the standard GPS driver. I tried installing it after poor results with the unit out of the box, but this did not help. The driver is written by Broadcom, not Lenovo. The driver is very new. Perhaps it is buggy? Maybe have to wait for a new driver.

In summary, a great unit, but if you need GPS, look elsewhere!

My boyfriend bought this case for me on Amazon and I loved it at first!  After about a week, the front cover started to warp.  It doesn't close flat and is bowing in every way possible.  Now, after 3 weeks of owning it, I'm on the hunt for a new cover.

I received the 1 terabyte drive as a gift one year for Christmas. It was certainly a pleasant surprise; it meant I wouldn't have to move the internal hard drives between computers for the gigabyte file transfers or tie down network traffic while waiting for data to move back and forth.

When it works, it's great. The transfer speed for reading and writing is quite nice.

My issue is that it inconsistently \\"drops\\"; my computers (I have three and a laptop running a variety of operating systems) just stop seeing them. Occasionally the hard drive will make a mechanical noise before it temporarily stops working, generally akin to an arm bouncing off a platter. Other times, neither Windows nor Ubuntu will recognize it in certain (random) USB ports. \\"What? There's nothing there.\\" If I unplug it and reseat it, sometimes sees it. I can move it to a different port, and it might work.

Truthfully, I can't say that I'm pleased with this product. I wouldn't recommend it.

Judging by the other user comments, I guess some people are lucky and don't have a problem with this router.  I am not one of them.  It worked great when it actually worked properly, but I found the proformance to be inconsistent and the router often dropped packets.  Their tech help is in India so you have to wait about an hour to get through and then the help, although friendly, was difficult to understand. tl;dr this is a failure from Logitech.  I was a long time user of the M555. It was a great mouse and hoped it'd last longer knowing Logitech discontinued it years ago. When I saw the M557, I thought Logitech brought it back with new technology (maybe better tracking? maybe longer battery life?).  While this mouse looks strikingly like the old M555, it is nothing like it at all.  I used the M555 in a Linux environment. The M557 seems to hate Linux bluetooth. If it gets disconnected at any point, it will not automatically reconnect. It has to be removed in Linux, then re-added.  The scroll wheel is no longer a dual mode wheel (notched vs free wheeling) and is now the middle click button. I had 3 Logitech mice in the past, including the MX Anywhere mouse and the old M555, where this was not a button and got use to using the button behind the wheel. This mouse has a button behind the wheel but it is NOT a middle click button. It sends the Windows key.  Lastly, getting to the batteries is a challenge. Perhaps the claimed long battery life overcomes this problem, but the old way from the M555 was much better.  I'm honestly not sure why Logitech released the M557 to pose as the old M555. Sure, it's bluetooth like the old M555, but in terms of function outside of that, it is nothing like the M555. This mouse does nothing but frustrate me. I give it 2 stars simply because it at lest functions, and maybe someone will be okay with it.
It doesn't came with the gift box announced. It's really annoying

This mouse came with my Dell computer. I loved it at first. I didn't care much for the buttons but this mouse allows you to adjust the speed of how fast you want the cursor to move. I like mine on fastest so it was a great feature BUT after a year the left click function is too erratic. Copy pasting is very difficult as it doesn't highlight all the things you want. I edit pictures so when I zoom in/out it makes it very difficult. Sometimes it doesn't zoom and sometimes it zoom in but out the next second. Basically there is something wrong with the mouse. I tested my old ball mouse from Dell which is probably 5 years old and it worked perfectly except I don't like the ball feature. So here I am looking for another mouse online. Saw the one I already own and thought might as well review it. If any of you know a good laser mouse please suggest because too many of them have bad ratings. Maybe laser mouse break down fast. If that's the case with all of them then buy this because it really was a great mouse until it broke after 12 months. It's still useable but it's very frustrating.

The first thing I noticed when I turned it on, was every page or program with a white background flickers when I use it. Plus, the SD card reader doesn't work. Every few minutes it disconnects the SD car automatically and then reconnects it a second later. This is tremendously inconvenient if you try to view any sort of media that's on an SD card. Finally, the icing on the cake was the wireless card. For some reason, the internet randomly disconnected and the laptop no longer could find any of the 2 internet connections available in my house during my last session of using this product. I tried everything I could think of to solve the problem and nothing worked. I called Samsung and they told me the only way I could fix it was if I connected my laptop to the internet. Well that's great but I shouldn't have to go out and buy an ethernet cable just to fix the faulty product they made.

Bottom line: I would not recommend this product.

I wish I used the device for myself more often, but most of the time my 4-year old is using it. I want her to have access to HER apps, not ads. If she swipes the wrong way, she does not know how to get out of the potential purchase.

Once unlocked, the apps at the bottom are all SUGGESTIONS for you to purchase .. not ones you already have. Again, this pisses me off, because she sees them and thinks they are available, when they are not.

In this day and age of smart phones and tablets, all which have customizable home screens with apps we already own, this is a VERY annoying experience. If I had known about this, I would not have purchased this device.

I use this with my TiVo Premiere 4, which does not have wireless connectivity. Setup was quick and easy; it works as expected and I haven't noticed any problems to date. That said, it does seem pricey, especially as its maximum wireless connection speed is on the slower side (I believe it's 150 Mbps), it has just one Ethernet port, and that port is limited to 100 Mbps. I think a better choice would be to instead pay a bit more for an alternative that can connect at a faster wireless speed and has multiple Ethernet ports that can support up to 1000 Mbps. I bought this because I needed something quickly, and for the time being it suits my needs as I'm only streaming content from the Internet. In hindsight, however, I wish I had instead bought an alternative for just a bit more that would cover potential future needs, such as connecting multiple devices and streaming content at higher speeds over my LAN.

When reading the warranty I discover that no accidents are covered!!!It looks like they do not cover anything! An accident is an accident, but the way it's written they can use their discretion and say you did the damage intentionally.

Maintenance, repair, or replacement neccessitated by loss or damage resulting from any cause other than normal use and operation of product in accordance with the manufaturer's specifications and owners manual, including but not limited to exposure to weather conditions, failure to properly clean, maintain product, operator negligence, misuse, abuse, improper electical/power supply....on and on....Cosmetic damage to case cabinetry or other non operating parts or components which does not affect the functionality or the covered product.

The service agreement including ADH does not provide protection against theft, loss, reckless, intentional, or abusive conduct associated with handeling and use of the product, cosmetic damage and/or other damage that doesn't affect unit functionality, or damage caused during shipment betweenyou and Our service providers.

*****Basically they have covered their butts and will not cover anything. This is a big money maker for them....because it looks like nothing is really covered. I would love to hear from anyone that has had to make a claim, to find out how it was handled.

Purchased one of these in Feb/2010, used it on and off without any issues for the best part of these 2.5 years, and just had it fail on me.

This does not sound good to my ears, as I still have the first SD card I ever purchased (a Ridata 2GG, back in 2003 or so), and it still works great. I know flash memory has a limited life due to the number of write cycles each cell can endure, but 2.5 years seems rather short for a card that wasn't under constant write pressure.

Lost 5 files in the process, thankfully nothing irreplaceable as I was using that specific card on a PDA (a Nokia N800, if you need to know) and have an up-to-date backup (by the way they were MP3 files and rarely if ever written to... according to their timestamps, they had been sitting on this card for at least 2 years). I bought a pair of these a few months ago to relieve elbow pain I was suffering due to long hours at my computer desk. While the pain I was suffering did decrease, the fact that these are filled with small, hard-plastic beads (and they are only loosely-filled at that) meant that the more narrow point of contact for my elbows did not receive the same level of cushioning that my wrists would have received had I needed these for that purpose.

The other problem is that while the cushions have a non-slip backing, if you change positions throughout the day (such as when using your mouse or swapping between your keyboard and a book, etc.) the back surface will begin to lose traction as dust begins to adhere to the surface over time. While this might actually be a positive if you are using it as a wrist rest for your mouse hand, considering their small size, they are problematic as elbow rests.

Why? Well once these start to slip, they'll either end up on your lap or on the floor. And heaven help you if you roll over one in your office chair. If you do, there's a good chance that the elastic fabric will run up into the more hollow interior of the caster taking with it a good number of the beads. When this happens, it is essentially like inflating a balloon in an enclosed space -- one that you can't get the air back out of. As of now *both* my cushions have met a messy end as no amount of care was able to get them dislodged without tearing the seams and spilling the trapped beads everywhere.

So just beware that while these cushions may work fine as wrist rests, they make for mediocre elbow pads that you may very well end up ruining.

With this monitor I have found the following after a few months of use (followed by a premature full retirement):
CONS
- detailed focus is not achievable. You are better off buying a loupe as the the resolution, brightness and controls for this monitor aren't up to the job unless you are in the lowest light situation.
- I have yet to be able to achieve a good color representation with the monitor and have gone through every setting twice. I am close with what I have now - but not close enough.
- controls are not intuitive and the control markings are invisible without bright light.
- sharpening the image would be nice. Can't be done.
- Instructions are horrible. Some would say that is expected for the price - but I am sick of excuses from these foreign manufacturers. Documentation is an easy problem to fix.
- The sunshade is useless in my opinion.
- If you plan on using it for any extended period away from an outlet buy extra batteries. I bought an extra and for the limited use I made of this thing I had to use both batteries a lot.
- Cheap
PROS
- Cheap
COMMENTS
This is not an HD monitor. I knew that going in. What I didn't really understand was how poor the resolution really is. Unless you have great eyesight - this monitor will add little value in my opinion. If you have great eyesight I am not sure why you'd use this over a loupe or even a small HDTV. I have replaced this with a 24" Samsung that was $50 cheaper and light years ahead in image quality and control. I rigged a tripod mount for the TV for around $10 and it is stable. Yes - no battery. But see comment on battery above. I carry a Hoodman loupe that is fantastic when I don't have power.
This will gather dust and my wallet will be permanently lighter.

According to Amazon, I purchased this about 1 year and 3 months ago so I think that's a pretty adequate amount of time and usage to be doing a review (I've used it on my 1st gen Macbook Pro). I would not recommend purchasing this again for the $25 as I'm sure there must be a better cover - here are my reasons why:  1. I noticed sometimes moisture can collect between the keyboard cover and the keys itself. I'm not sure if that's due to heat from my laptop, the cover itself reacting to the heat, or what. I would try to wipe down the keyboard every now and then with a paper towel and wash the keyboard cover with a sponge in the sink.  2. After a short while, the cover stretches and doesn't fit the keys exactly as it first did. It's gotten to the point now that if I were to try to lay down the cover completely flat against the keyboard like how it's supposed to be, half of the cover doesn't fit the keys properly.  3. There are now tears that have formed on some of the keys on the cover - namely A, S, D and E and very small tears on R and T (probably because they are the most used letters?). I do not always have long fingernails nor do I use anything that would cause the cover to tear so I'm not sure why it would tear (maybe it is the fingernails but I'm not sure because my nails are usually kept very short). I think maybe it's just natural wear and tear. Because of this, I need to check under the cover more frequently to see if there is any buildup of dust or dead skin cells and such, which there are and then I have to clean the keyboard, negating the purpose of this cover.  I hope this helps - I'm going to try a different cover now that this one is basically dead and see how it goes.

It was the least expensive Mac-compatible camera available. I thought, \\"How bad can it be?\\" Hmmmm, \\"Atrocious, Baleful, Contemptible, Deplorable, Execrable, Frightful...\\" Too bad the English alphabet has only twenty-six letters; there are so many more words to describe how truly awful it is.     Although you can adjust the sharpness slightly by moving the tiny ring on the lens, the displayed image appears as though viewed through waxed paper. Without the additional purchase of eCamm's iUSBCam software it doesn't work at all, and you'll find even that software truly and still requires the additional purchase of the sister product, iGlasses, to get a picture that doesn't approximate the glowing blobs described by someone who has been abducted by extra-terrestrials. Lighting is tricky ... it doesn't like low light or shadows. but too much light, as from a desk lamp set to illuminate your face, makes your image glow as though it were radioactive.    The field of vision is oddly short and long, like a 3x5 index card. The preview app, if left in the dock, is helpful for adjusting the ambient light before attempting to use iChat and, despite complaints, will turn off both the camera and its little green light.  The USB connector must be connected directly to the computer or a powered hub. But the twisty cable is only about twelve inches from connecter to lens, and so rigid at the ends that it protrudes inconveniently far, wasting a good bit of the gooseneck type coil. Oddly, this coil, with all the strength of overcooked spaghetti, actually strengthens when bent or twisted lightly. However, that action further lowers the positioning on my eMac, requiring me to look down and to the side to appear as though I am looking into the eyes of the person I'm iChatting. If I try to look at their image on the display, what they see is me looking in any direction but theirs.     Yes, it's portable; but aren't they all? Yes it's inexpensive; but the add-ons more than double the price.Overall, a purchaser would be a thousand percent better off buying another brand that's plug-and-play compatible. This is pretty much a waste of money, time, and effort ... unless you're doing a report on disabilities. If you are writing about eyesight and want to experience for yourself how severe cataracts affect the vision of someone before surgical removal, this camera is IDEAL. And, just as people who've had their cataracts removed marvel at how clear and bright the world becomes post-op, shifting from this camera to just about anything else will have you shouting, I'VE BEEN CURED!  I CAN SEE AGAIN!   IT'S A MIRACLE!

My first adventure into tablets began with the original iPad. While it was an introduction, the limits of iOS drove me to look further. I then discovered the Motorola Xoom. What a FANTASTIC device at the time. I only recently sold it, after owning it for several years. It reached the end of its software updates. Then I bought a Samsung Galaxy Note 8.0. Another GREAT tablet, but ATT decides not to update it to the latest versions of Android, and it gets left collecting dust. (DO NOT BUY A TABLET FROM A CELL PROVIDER. They don't keep up with the updates). I then thought I would give Apple another try, and bought an iPad 4. That lasted about 3 days, and I gave it to my 5 year old daughter. No offense to her, but iPads are designed for the dumb people who cannot comprehend technology. I doubt I'll EVER go back to a mobile Apple device. To limited. I decided to look into getting a Nexus 10. I am all about the Vanilla Android experience. Nothing is better than good ol stock Android. But, about that time, they discontinued it, assuming to make way for a new device for Q4 2014.

So what do I do in the meantime?

Well, thats where this beast caught my eye. 12.2\\" of pure Android goodness. Or so I thought.

I will begin by saying the screen is sufficiently pleasing to look at. I don't care if it has the most dpi, or 4K resolution. Its a TABLET. It is very lightweight (unless you put an Otterbox case on it) and easy to hold. It doesn't make my arms tired. I also like the dual speaker placement on the side of the tablet. Makes watching movies a pleasure, especially if you hold it in that area and use the cups of your hands as acoustic amplifiers. The new charging cable, I don't care for. It causes me to have to buy a few more to carry in the car, or to have in different rooms. Not a deal breaker, but more of an annoyance. The deal breaker has been that with the specs this tablet boasts, the software is buggy and laggy. Often times I have to repeated press an app, or a link in a browser just for it to recognize that I am trying to DO SOMETHING. This is unacceptable. The mail app freezes. Often times I have to restart the tablet just to get it to function again. I have had issues with apps just suddenly stopping and closing. Most often YouTube, or another video app. Could be the apps themselves, not sure. But the response time of scrolling, and switching from app to app is abysmal. For a new release tablet, it behaves like one from 2008. It's running Android 4.4.2 which is nearly the latest. But the downside is that it is Samsung TouchWiz, which is garbage. From past experiences with Samsung, getting to the latest 4.4.4 will take eons.

I have experienced slow wi-fi, and frequent disconnects. I wonder if the wifi radio is bad. Sitting next to other devices with full signal, this will only report 2/3 of of the signal strength my phone does. Also, the battery life is TERRIBLE. I used it on a recent trip, and even an 1/4 brightness, I only got around 6 hours before I had to recharge it. Thankfully the airports have charging stations.

I'm not knocking the Android platform. Just the way it is poorly incorporated into THIS tablet. TouchWiz sucks. Android 5.0 comes out this fall. Good luck EVER receiving that update to this tablet. I will wait and get it in vanilla flavor on a tablet that will actually perform properly. All in all, I am pretty displeased with the Tab Pro 12.2. I wanted to LOVE it. But I just cannot. The performance is too off to justify keeping it. I don't know if I got a bad one, or what, but it's going back to Amazon for a refund. I will just wait and see what Google introduces this fall. You cannot go wrong with the Nexus lineup.

Sadly, I am now stuck with a $120 Otterbox case I cannot use.

***11/18/14 UPDATE***

This tablet sucks. Battery life at 50% brightness is 4 hours at best. Normally, batteries take some time to balance out and become better...this one got worse. I can take it off the charger, read the news, check email, maybe Facebook a bit while enjoying my morning coffee, and within a few hours, I am at less that 30% battery left. Just sitting unplugged overnight from a full charge, it will guzzle 20% of the battery. This is unacceptable. They do not seem to have any clue about what decent customer support is. I ordered a 4gb ram upgrade from them direct. They do not have a distribution center here in US, it had to come from China. They take 2 weeks to process the order then ship UPS ground. I also ordered the 3 year extended warranty. They took my money right away but never sent the warranty. called customer support, was told they would email me in 2 days, never heard from them again on the issue. Luckily I paid with PP and have filed a dispute to get a refund. Their support is totally unsatisfactory. They have a forum, before you buy any of their product I recommend you visit the forum and see for yourself the nightmares owners of their products are having. I wish I had done this before buying. I figure if their support is this bad I can not imagine the problems one would have should you ever need to send it back for warranty work. I recommend if you are looking for a computer before buying, look at support reviews first, then you will not waste your hard earned money and make a good decision. Bottom line, if your going to spend this kind of money you should be entitled to good support. Without good customer support your really taking a chance on a product or manufacturer. I hope this review will help people considering buying anything from this manufacturer, it might be a nice unit out of the box, but there it ends.

I just sent back my Kindle Fire HDX after three days. The blue hue that everyone is complaining about did not bother me at all. In matter of fact I did not notice it unless I was viewing it in the dark and even then it was not bad.

The bad parts were first the battery life sucked big time. I would fully charge the device to 100% then I would play a puzzle game for 5 minutes and watch the battery drop down 2%. Then I would surf some pages and it would drop down to 1% after about a minute. Even when the device was sleeping it would drop down about 10% and overnight it would drop down to about 25%. Also I was not even able to plug the USB cable into any type of extension cord. If I did it would pop up a annoying error message saying the device may not charge when sleeping.

The user interface is also terrible.. Loading, organizing and switching to apps was a pain in the neck. I could note even fully close them without going through a bunch of menus. Browsing the web also sucks as some webpages I was not even able to click on anything they would just do nothing as others would keep stalling. Also when I would click on a link it would instead click on the wrong link. It was annoying to say the least when I was reading forums and I went to click on the comment and instead it clicked on the comment on the top or bottom. Then when I was typing on this thing it would keep auto correcting words so badly that they were not even right. For example I would type in br (a HTML code) and it would change it to breadcrumbs automatically without even asking me. Backspacing and typing br again it would change it back to breadcrumbs. I felt like tossing this thing out the window after that.

I hated having the power and volume buttons on the back. It was so easy to just have them on the side like other devices especially when it was in the case. I would go to adjust the volume and I would have to lift the device to get to the back buttons. I could not even have the device flat down without having to lift it up to adjust the volume. That is so unnecessary.

Then Amazon store app selection also sucks so badly. There was not even a Speedtest.net app. I was only able to find a few of the many other apps I use everyday. I tried so much to like my Kindle Fire HDX but in the end I ended up returning it.uld not even have the device flat down without having to lift it up to adjust the volume. That is so unnecessary.

Comments: I bought this HDD because it was cheap for 1TB. It works fine and has plenty of storage. My only complaint is that it makes a lot of noise when it is being read from or written to. I have only had this hard drive for 2 days and I am already annoyed by the amount of noise it makes. My experience with this device was a big disappointment. First, a couple of positive comments. Amazon delivered the product very quickly and very well packaged. The d2 is a solid feeling device and is very attractive. The feature set is impressive for the price. In terms of hardware quality, it seems like a nice product.

But, it did not work well at all in my OS X Lion environment. LaCie says it is Lion compatible, but my experience is otherwise. It was easily found on my network - attached on a wired ethernet connection administered by a gigabit hub Airport Extreme combo. The problems came with stable access to the drive and the inability of Time Machine to reliably find the disk. Time Machine would work for about a day, and then lose the disk. The Network Assistant software was clunky and not user friendly. Reconnecting to the disk when it was lost by Time Machine, or when shares did not show up, was akin to setting up anew. Having to tend to settings and administer the drive on a daily basis is simply not acceptable performance.

The provided instructions are of no help. I did better searching Google and Apple communities. I called LaCie on two occasions to see about what set up I might have over looked. They were very nice, but not helpful. They basically tinkered much the same as I did - which is not good as I am FAR from well versed with NAS devices. The stability of connection to the drive was never corrected. In fact, when it was obvious that LaCie had no ability to rectify the problems with the interface with Lion, they could not even provide accurate instruction on how to wipe the drive of my data before returning it. Ultimately, I was able to restore it to factory setting, which then enabled reformatting. My conclusion, this is a product to be avoided if you are running OS X Lion. I never made it work on my Mac to even endeavor to set up any other devices, so I cannot comment on Windows performance or media streaming, so I will give it the benefit of the doubt and not go all the way to one star.it the benefit of the doubt and not go all the way to one star.

I have had my Dell Precision M3800 laptop now for almost a week. I use the machine for MathCAD engineering, Adobe Photoshop CS6 and office apps. It is incredibly fast for all applications.  The Windows 7 Performance Information and Tools performance ratings place it on par with the Dell XPS 8700 desktop that I just bought last month. That is impressive for a laptop that weighs less than five pounds. The 510 GB SSD boot drive is really fast.  With the screen set to 3200 x 1800 pixels, the colors and contrast are amazing. It looks like my iPad Retina display...just bigger.  However, there are some issues when processing images with CS6. The menus and icons in Photoshop are really small regardless of the screen resolution you select. I hope that Adobe is smart enough to come out with a version for upgrade (not a CC version) that works well with the screen.  When not using CS6, I change the screen to 2048 x 1152 for some jobs just so I can read the fine print.  You should be aware that the M3800 is not as advertised by Dell, and it does not have the options shown in the user manual. Thus, my four star rating.  First, the only option for batteries is the 91 Wh battery; there is no 61 Wh battery in stock at Dell and there may never be one available according to their parts dept.  Second, and more importantly for those of you who want internal storage and backup, you cannot get the laptop with an internal 1 TB HDD in addition to the 510 GB SATA SSD because the 91 Wh battery consumes the space where you would install the HDD. If you want a spinning HDD, your only option is to use an external USB-connected drive.  If Dell ever decides to make a 61 Wh battery for the machine, you will be able to install one and a spinning HDD, or maybe a second SSD drive for data storage and backup. In the meantime, I will just use my UDMA2 HyperDrive Colorspace or another external drive for backup in the field.  Update January 18, 2014:  I decided to buy an external portable drive to use with the Dell M3800. I selected the WD My Passport Ultra 2TB USB 3.0. Not only is it twice the capacity of the Dell drive that they "sell" for use in this machine, it is also just as fast even though it is an external drive. My ATTO and CrystalMark tests show a data transfer rate of 105 MB/s. Some of my 7200 RPM external 2TB USB 3.0 drives don't run any faster than the WD Ultra drive. However, it does add 8 oz to my total computer/battery weight that is already heavier than the 4.15 lb that Dell advertises because of the 91 Wh battery inside.  Update 4/16/2015:  I have had a Dell M3800 for 13 months. I use it for high-end structural engineering MathCAD modeling as well as professional-level Photoshop image development. I have never abused the unit, but it has traveled with me to several international locations and worked really well until the last trip. The M3800 decided it would not come out of hibernation. I had closed the lid many times, and it always came right back to life when I opened the lid...but not that time.  I tried all combinations of power button pushes and lid openings to no avail. Finally, the unit started beeping...eight beeps followed by a pause then eight more beeps, etc. It stayed that way for four days while on the ship...keeping me from getting my work done.  When I got home, the M3800 suddenly decided to start working again. I was pleasantly surprised and assumed the failure had something to do with the ship I traveled on...until it happened again four weeks later. This time it did not recover.  The unit was just one month out of the one year warranty when it started to fail, but I initiated repair through Dell anyway. To make a long story short, Dell initially misdiagnosed the problem as a system board failure. When their contract repairman came to my office and replaced the system board, the problem was still there. The repairman came back a few days later with a new LCD screen/cover. That fixed the blank screen and beeping, but the unit would no longer charge when plugged into a power outlet. The Dell repairman came back a third time to fix the charging problem and replaced the system board again. That fixed the charging issue, but one fan no longer worked. The one that did continue to work made way more noise than both fans made before this failure.  A contract Dell repairman came to my office a fourth time to repair my M3800. He brought the repair parts Dell had ordered and shipped to him. The kit included two new fans, a heat sink as well as a new mother board and back cover. That repair finally worked and the computer now seems to work fine.  So during the past month my M3800 has had one LCD replaced and the system board replaced four times in order to get the M3800 to work properly.  The repairman said the unit probably overheated which caused the initial failure and he showed me how much heat comes out of the vent on the bottom and how close to the table the unit sits. When I reminded him that the system board had been replaced four times to correct the problem and none of them had had time to overheat before the failure was detected, he just smiled.  Just to be certain over heating is not a future issue, I ordered a fan pad from Amazon. That will add 1.6 lbs to my laptop bag...so I will be back to lugging the same weight I had with my old Lenovo that never failed.

Actually never had an issue with the remote itself.  The lack of instructions that came with it wasnt so bad as I was able to figure it out on my own. When I emailed the seller all I got was a sorry about your luck...  Guess these things cannot be replaced or interchanged?..  In this case its safe to say that you get what you pay for. I had to return it.  Hesitated giving this a poor rating because it may be very good.  Some mother boards do not work well with USB 2.0 unless it is a powered USB hub.  The power from the back of the of the desktop is good for this hub, but when you have all the slots filled with printers, etc..... it does not work.  The power from the front of the computer is not really powered enough to attach hubs.  When I installed it my computer completely crashed as it would not accept this hub.  I had to call Dell and work with the tech rep for hours to get everything back working correctly.  This Dell rep explained so much to me by having USB hubs.  If using windows 7 professional it will not recognize a 2.0 USB hub without a driver.  Now I have a powered 2.0 USB hub and it works just fine.  It also has to do with your power management system for USB hubs.  To be fair to this device, I have a complex computer system in my house with many devices.  3 different printers, 4 different scanner types, a weather station, IPAD, IPods, portable Photo viewer, Snap Scanner to digitize all my paperwork, bills etc. and 3 external hard drives all requiring USB connections.  If I did not have all of these, I would imagine this work just fine.  The powered USB hub that I use and got from Amazon is a D-Link Hi-Speed USB 2.0 7-Port Powered Hub (DUB-H7).  It works well with my system now that Dell got everything back.  And yes, I am a computer, gadget nut....but I use it all at different times.

I had this modem for two/three years. Initially it worked great, but for the last year I had many intermittent hangups. I thought the problem was with Time Warner cables. Finally I got fed up when the hangups got more frequent and called Time Warner. They sent a technician twice who said he adjusted some filters outside my home. The hangups got more frequent, several times per day. I got a new Motorola SB5101U modem today, got it connected and it seems to work fine now. In the reviews here, I see other people have similar problems, especially related to Comcast. Time Warner bought the network here from Comcast several years ago, so I wonder if this is still this\\" Comcast compatibility\\" issue? As suggested by some users, I went to Dlink site to download \\"Comcast version\\" of the firmware. Well, there is NO firmware whatsoever available on their site. Looks like this product is unsupported by them anymore...    Update: looking at the FAQ for the Motorola modem, I think I understand why there is no longer any firmware update for Dlink modem:  \\"Any and all firmware upgrades to your Motorola cable modem, or any DOCSIS cable modem, is completely under the control of the cable operator.  Motorola does not, nor is capable of, controlling the firmware upgrade process.\\" - this seems to apply not only Motorola, but also any DOCSIS modem, including Dlink. So, the problem could be with Time Warner not loading correct firmware into my Dlink modem. It could also be that the modem just started malfunctioning. I guess I'll never know.

I had the same problems as the lost person did, the router would drop connection for no reason. Very frustrating!!!. Replaced this Belkin with a Netgear....haven't lost connection once. Would not buy another Belkin.

This isn't worth a full review because it's such a simple product that does such a simple task, and STILL manages to screw it up.

This is a 24 slot case that doesn't hold 24 games. Two of the slots are DEDICATED to SD cards. I can't imagine anyone needing more than two SD cards for their 3DS, but that means that one will always be in the console itself. A lot of people don't even upgrade the one that comes with the system! So why exactly do we need to sacrifice valuable capacity for SD cards we probably don't need?

The wings (for lack of a better word) that hold the games are also very, very flimsy in the wrong place, and overly stiff in another bad place. It's extremely difficult to put in and take out game cartridges, and sometimes you can break the whole wing off trying to get at a game. The inner section is also inverted, so you'll have to flip the whole thing over if you want to read half of your cartridges. That's more of a pet peeve than a real problem though.

All in all, instead of buying thing and replacing it who knows how many times, buy a [[ASIN:B004K6LQAS Nintendo 3DS Game Card Case 24 - Black]]. For five bucks extra, it's infinitely better.

There is a problem with this computer and monitors. When the computer goes into energy save mode, it may take a long time do \\"wake up\\" again. This is a known issue. Just check the Apple Support pages, or make a Google search with the words ´Mac Mini monitor sleep mode´ or something similar. I find it strange that I haven't seen any reviews in this site mentioning this problem.   In my case the problem is not only that the monitor won´t come out of sleep mode: worse than that, it would enter sleep mode EVEN WHILE I WAS TYPING. I was using the HDMI - DVI adpater that came with the Mac Mini, plus a DVI cable I bought at Best Buy. I tried with three different monitors, one from LG, one from Dell and the other from HP, with the same result. Sometimes I could work for hours without any problem, but sometimes the monitor would go black in my face three or four times in ten minutes.  I live in Brasil, and I bought the Mac Mini in the US, so I have no warranty. I ordered a mini Display Port to VGA adapter from Apple in Brazil, to see if it would solve the problem. Well, it didn´t. I changed the setting to make the monitor enter sleep mode after a few minutes (I had changed it to \\"never\\"), let the monitor go into sleep and couldn´t make it wake up again. I had to access the computer via VNC from my iPhone, turn it off and then turn it on again to be able to use it again.  I´ve been using the VGA adapter since yesterday, and at least until now the monitor has never entered sleep mode while I was working. I don´t know if it will stay this way, because, as I said above, the problem is intermittent. As it is now, I´m using the VGA adapter and I configured the computer to never put the monitor in sleep mode. It is not ideal, but I can live with that.  The Mac Mini has a good price and the design is very nice. I´m new to Mac OS and the track pad, and it has been fun working with them. But I think this issue with the monitors is serious. And it has been happening for some time, and Apple apparently doesn´t care. I hope sony will fix this in the comming updates and let us have solid stable connectivty.

thank you.

I bought this router in August 2014.  I was operating the router as an access point for a Verizon FIOS router to get n and ac bandwidth and 5Mhz broadcast frequency. [Wired connection between router LAN ports]. Only the Trendnet router has wireless radio enabled.  After 6 months I noticed wireless Internet access dropping despite maintaining connection to Trendnet router.  Of course I could not determine which router was at fault.  My office computer then failed with a direct connection to the TrendNet router.  Ironically, the wireless connection still worked.  This indicated to me that the TrendNet was failing.  I updated the firmware and tried for several more months, but dropouts continued which required power recycles of the TrendNet router to correct.  I have taken the router out of service and replaced it with a MoCA wireless extender form ActionTech.  Much faster and much stronger signal. Unfortunately this extender has a 16 device capacity that seems to push my STB's out of the network occasionally.

This is a opinioned review. Everyone has a right to an opinion and this is mine. Anyway last spring I bought an Ipad 2. 64 gig, biggest hard drive they have. It's like another world of computing. It surfs, e-mails, plays videos without even a hiccup, stores over 3,000 of my photos by category, has apps for everything at a fraction of the price of Microsoft, you can buy the open office for 8 dollars most apps I use are free. Others cost one or two dollars. I have a zaggfolio which turns it into a laptop with a wireless Bluetooth keyboard.
Now along comes windows 8, which looks just like my iPad. If you want a keyboard, which costs 129.99 plus tax, which you need because it does not have a virtual keyboard like my iPad. Now of that 64 gig the OS requires 1/2 the space for it to function. so all that is left is 32 gigs, keep in mind if you add a app that takes space. Your storage will be in the \\"cloud\\" which you pay for. I collect data like people would collect books. So I have 6 TB of data stored on misc hard drives and I am about to buy a 3 TB hard drive to eliminate the misc hard drives. This all video, no music. Music takes up minimal space maybe 1/2 of a GB. Windows 8 is touch screen which in my opinion they stole the concepts from apple like Bill gates stole the concepts of windows from Macintosh. The only thing they have is a sd port to increase storage, and a USB port. Big whoop since my iPad has Bluetooth capability. Due yourself a favor and look at iPad 2 not 3. Because you get more bang for your buck that way. I am sure there is a desktop version But the heavier the OS the more ram and video memory you need to drive it. Windows 8 laptops are touchscreen like my iPad2. Just a few thoughts.

It worked great for 5 months and then just died.  I never dropped it and kept it in a soft case.  So disappointed.  I only had it for 5 months.  When I tried to check on the warranty info...it might have been a case in the supreme court...so much leagalesee.....NOT!  Much easier just to pay $20 for a new Logitech.

I really wanted to like this product because I wanted something that was protective yet not bulky. On those two points, it was protective and it was not bulky but it all ends there.
The fit was off so the openings for camera etc were not spot on, but the feature that truly turned me off was the material. It was soft urethane material that had the feel of suede, which was not all bad. Unfortunately the material attracted everything it came in contact with. I was constantly attempting to wipe it clean or pick off the lint. The iPad always looked kind of dirty. That said, I've returned the item.

Everything else in my rig is okay, the mobo is the only serious weak link, and I mean serious.

Waiting to hear back from Amazon- will keep you posted.  UPDATE- WITH IN AN HOUR AMAZON HAS CONTACTED ME. THEY HAVE EMAILED ME A PRE-PAID PACKAGING LABEL AND HAVE OFFERED ME A FULL REFUND. UNFORTUNATELY MY GRANDAUGHTER (3 years old) IS IN TEARS WANTING HER TABLET. ORDERING HER A REPLACEMENT. THANK YOU AMAZON..
Got it much faster than i expected but I am not too satisfied with the anti glare. If i'm outdoors it's still hard for me to see on my screen due to the glare.

I have a 5341 and this dpc3010 hooked up. Activating on Comcast had to be done manually.

8 downstreams with 38 SNR, and 3 upstreams conencted with reasonable signals of ~40 dbmv.

Now the jitter on this modem is insane. Yes, I do get 105 megabits and 20 upload on speedtest sites, but for gaming this is the biggest pile of garbage you can get.

It does not handle a noisy signal at all, I had my ping spiking in tribes ascend and quake live to insane levels. I was warping all over, and this happens everytime I use this modem. I have a 5341, and used that at the same time to test the difference and only 1-2ms of jitter on the 5341.

This modem does not handle a noisy upstream at all.

Do not buy this if you are planning to game. Used the quakelive netgraph extensively, it is the modem.

Also comcast won't even activate this unless you get a top tier person.

This is the 3rd Sandisk USB drive I've owned (256MB and 1GB being the other two). With each new device, they've cut corners and made it more and more cheaply. Which is sad, because they used to have solid devices.

My 256MB model was constructed of metal with a permanent clear plastic housing that really gave it a solid feel. Most importantly, the loop through which you attach a key chain was also metal and molded into the device itself.

With the 1GB model, they removed the permanent plastic housing in favor of a removable rubberized sleeve. Not an improvement to be sure, but it worked okay until the rubber sleeves lost their grip and slid off, to be lost forever. The key chain loop was also plastic and fused onto the metal body.

The 2GB model has lost even more sturdiness. There is no longer a cap -- the USB socket retracts into the device. This can be good or bad depending on your viewpoint. The good is that you no longer have a cap to lose (never a problem for me anyway). The bad is that there is no cap to protect the USB socket from dirt and dust accumulation from sitting in pockets and such.

Unlike the previous models, this one is completely plastic and feels very cheaply made. The key chain loop is a flimsy little metal ring attached to one end -- one good tug and your USB drive will be quickly separated from the rest of your key chain and lost. I went so far as to remove it altogether and replace it with a sturdier ring.

I don't see the retractable design as an improvement, frankly. In fact, it adds to the overall length of the device, since it must now house the USB socket and the mechanism to retract it. It is easily 10% longer than my previous models.

Finally, I removed the U3 software because I had no use for it. I just wanted a backup storage device to shuttle files between computers in different locations (work, school, home). Sandisk should have offered the U3 software as an option that the user installs themselves if so desired, rather than forcing it upon us.

I had trouble removing the U3 software as well, and had to call Sandisk technical support. I must admit they answered fairly quickly and walked me through the proper uninstall procedure. Apparently my problem was that I have a USB hub attached to my PC (doesn't everyone?), which confuses the device and makes it difficult to uninstall the U3 software. Another bad oversight by Sandisk.

The device works fine now, and seems fairly speedy. But I don't think I'll be buying any more flimsy plastic USB drives in the future. Better off spending a little extra and getting a solid build like the Titanium drive (also from Sandisk).
The speaker sounds fine and looks fine, easy to connect, but it's supposed to reach 30ft but only reaches no more than 10ft in plain view. Thinking about returning it

The power supply just died after three years of use... fortunately it has a 5 year warranty, and the RMA process is pretty simple. It is just a hassle to pull everything apart and have the entertainment server down for a couple of weeks.

Corsair PSUs generally are fine, but I would recommend a sticking with their higher rated PSUs and avoid the hassle.

For a battery with 10400 mAh I expected more than 4 hours.  The last extended battery I purchased was 9600 mAh and lasted almost 8 hours.  Battery took nearly 5 weeks for delivery, which was within range of expectations. 2 stars for the low price.
It isn't the proper for for my Brst Buy Insignia 9 inch Tablet, but I kept it anyway because of the price and because I figured a way to use it to some limited extent.

When I got this keyboard about two weeks ago, it was great, everything worked perfectly.
The keys feel great, the backlighting is good, but the key placement takes a little getting used to.
The touchscreen works well as long as you don't plan on using the numberpad extensively or if you don't mind typing on it really slowly because it has low responsiveness.

Problems I've had with it so far:
Is not functional when I boot my computer - had to plug in my old keyboard so I could hit the f-key to get into the BIOS

Touchpad does not load when the computer wakes up from sleep/hibernate. What's really strange about this is that the common keyboard backlight works but the touchpad backlight doesn't so you still see a faint glow on the touchpad but no keys.

Touchpad doesn't always load when I boot the computer; sometimes, you can still click the (mostly invisible) keys and they work but more often now it's not working at all. I've reloaded drivers and have resorted to just unplugging and replugging the keyboard so I can use the keypad touchscreen

Worst and most unforgivable problem: Character dropping.
Lately (and I'm not sure if I just didn't notice before,) the s key plain does not work. Sometimes I'll press it three or four times to get it to work. This is the only actual key I have a problem with so far but I'm not sure what the problem is; is my keyboard faulty? Am I just not pushing it hard enough (probably not since I definitely push harder the second and third times?) I'm worried that other keys are going to follow suit. I noticed today that o is starting to act strangely too.

Reinstalling the drivers has not helped any of these problems.

Final thoughts:
I've always had trouble with Mad Catz products, and if I'd known they were behind this, I wouldn't have bought it.
If my dad hadn't thrown away the box, I would be returning it right now and picking something else.

I was excited for this case and keyboard combination.  What drew me to it was the built in mouse on the keyboard and the built in rechargeable battery.  Those features are still great but the keyboard is cheap and the keys are too close together.  If you plan to type then this is not the product for you.
I love the size and it worked great for 6 weeks but then dead as a door nail. Frustrating, I would not buy again.

UPDATE:
The plastic near the power key completely broke off a few months ago and this folio will no longer hold the iPad. I really wanted to like this, but the poor craftsmanship makes it difficult. At this point, I may as well have a separate keyboard, as this is what this product has turned in to, since the iPad will no longer stay in.
**********************************************************************************************

This keyboard portion of this keyboard folio performs as expected. The keyboard is very small, but beats typing on the virtual keyboard.

The one problem with this, as noted in many other reviews, is that the plastic holding the iPad in is very thin and cracks easily. Mine cracked near the power key within a few weeks of light use. It has never been taken out of this folio, so that is not the cause of the crack. It hasn't caused problems yet, but if it cracks any further, it will no longer hold the iPad. This is a design flaw that has been pointed out many times and should be a concern for the manufacturer. A little sturdier plastic would make this a quality product, but I'm not sure I would recommend it to my family and friends with its current design.

This case didn't fit for me! It was about half an inch too large in length! My tablet slides around in the case. It was also missing cut outs for the headphone jack, power button, and volume buttons. I think they might have redesigned this case because mine came with a latch to hold the tablet in the case no matter what direction it's tilted. That's nice, but I can't even use this case with the current design flaws! I have to take the tablet out in order to use the cameras and the buttons. It even slides to block the autobrightness sensor. I have the wifi only version of Galaxy Tab 10.1 (GT-P7510) I don't reccomend this case if you have the same model as I do. Grrr Vipertek.

While overall it's a nice product, it has a very serious problem with it. Despite their claim of an \\"outdoor\\" product it is NOT for outdoor use!

That would be the best use for this, plug your christmas tree lights into the thing and swith on and off conveniently. I was fooled by the words "extension cord." The sound was quite good and I suppose if you have a small head or a high threshold for pain, you'll enjoy them but they're just not right for me.

Disappointed in the case. I am gifting an iPad air 2 for my fiancé for Christmas and had been looking for weeks for good cases for the iPad for him. I purchased two. This one for the combined stand, sleep/wake magnet feature and rotating function. Another that was supposed to give it better \\"military\\" grade protection. When I made the purchase, there weren't any reviews for the product yet online so I was dissapointed to then come back online and find that the first reviewer had stated that the case did not have the magnets for the sleep/wake function. The magnets not being there, alone is not enough to discount the case in my opinion, just don't put it on the description. However, the swivel function makes me feel like the iPad is going to fall off or something. It feels very loose and floppy. Makes me think of rotting, zombie flesh hanging off the body. Thinner than the original Versuvu but still added quite some heft to the iPad since it's so light. There's also a tiny gap between the front cover and where the iPad sits but the elastic band holds the right side of the front and back together pretty well. The stand is very sturdy and I like the fact that you can choose three different angles for viewing where a lot of cases only have one. Fix the magnet/sleep wake feature and I'd probably rate a three. Fix the swivel feature and I'd rate a four.

it has hardly any storage. i even puy an sd card in and it wont let me save to my sd card. it turns off randomly in the middle of me playing a game. i wish i would've spent $30 more for a better quality tablet.

not really the same as the elite apple keyboard..works fine but the keys get a little sticky if your a fast typer like me.

There is a malfunction with the volume control. Others here warned me about this and I should have listened. It needs to be always turned all the way up to actually hear the bass, and after some use it gets stuck. The microphone is low quality as well. The only pro is that it's pretty comfortable.

First complaint with this headset is there is no point in having two speakers for each ear. You're not hearing in game sounds, only other players. So by having both ears covered and being filled with player chat, it's very hard to hear the actual game unless you blast the volume, which still sounds like you're missing out on something. I found myself lowering one side of the headset and placing it above my ear so I would have one free ear.

The second complaint is it is extremely uncomfortable. The only way you will find any comfort is if you place it entirely over your ears in one exact position and never move it. The speakers only move up and down, and don't have any kind of "joint" movement, so it's very uncomfortable.

Third complaint is it broke within two weeks of use. The microphone just stopped picking up any sound. I took the headset apart to see if a wire was loose, and all of the wires are very poorly installed. I honestly didn't even bother trying to fix it.

I would suggest getting one of the headsets that has a one ear speaker. Much more comfortable, and actually cheaper some places than these type of headsets. I feel like the only reason this headset exists is because it "Looks" like one of the high quality headsets that have in-game sounds. Or maybe it's trying to act like having two speakers is a good thing... it's not.

I bought this adaptor to run a projector in a church.  Sounded great, I could mount a projector from the celing and not run 150 ft of cable, it would even be cheeper.  We just run powerpoint, this unit slows your computer down drasticly.  I have tried 2 different laptops, both with core 2duo processors.  I have to keep away from slides with very much transitions.  Image is jumpy, not just on the projector, but on the computer monitor when connected.  Tried to show a movie at the church, and forget it.  At the lowest res. video was jumpy.  As for the sound you can easily bypass having to use this box for sound by going into your audio properties and switching to your normal audio output.  You just have to do this every time you connect.  Tech Support has very limited knowlage on this item.  Great idea, needs much work in todays HD world.

I prefer skins over hard covers, don't like adding any bulkiness to the apple design. The material of course isn't actually carbon fibre, its a large plastic sticker (tack-paper?), with a surface that's been molded to look like carbon-fibre, which is pretty cool. Installation is best achieved on the larger surfaces (i.e. top and bottom) by pulling back an edge of the sticker, lining it up with an edge, and then pulling the backing paper back, while the sticker adheres to the Mac as you pull it back. The sticker can be removed without residue for repositioning, but it is tough to do without ripping the cover.

Bad rating is due to poor fit of the sticker on the item, its about a quarter of an inch off at all dimensions, I've had other brands which were cut better. Even if placed perfectly centered, you will have an 1/8 to 1/4 gap at all ends of the cover.
