I wanted a PCI-E Wifi card for my computer since the router was upstairs and wired was outside the question unless I wanted to drill holes in the wall and hire someone to pull it through to connect it. Strangely, it would get a faint signal, but would lose it randomly. I would be able to download  several Steam games in one day and just leave my PC off the next because the card just felt like staying offline. Apparently, I got one of the "bad" cards since other reviews I've seen had the same result. What aggravated me the most about this was that every program on my PC said that the connection was fine except Steam and the GeForce drivers. I tried reinstalling the card's drivers numerous times to no avail and even reconnecting it. I decided to just get a Medialink USB adaptor and be done with it. If you think you'll get a good one like a majority of buyers, go right ahead. Just make sure to get some better antennas before heading to checkout because the stock ones are weak.
I bought because it appeared that it was going to sit flush in my express slot.  It does not and as other reviewers have stated almost impossible to plug usb in and out without causing it to eject.

I was expecting a traditional ThinkPad trackpoint, but that's not what this keyboard has.  This one isn't \\"pushed.\\"  To move the cursor, you have to keep sliding your finger across the top of the trackpoint.  For me it's not as good.
Drive works ok but power-on switches off lots of times. I will ask for a replacement.

I bought this card because the capacity was good for the price, and speed typically isn't a big concern for us. In my wife's Rebel T2i, just about the most common DSLR on earth, this card worked OK for about a month before it started corrupting files. Eventually any kind of burst shooting or even single shots in quick succession led to corrupted files, and error messages from the camera saying the card was faulty. After some confusing back-and-forth emails with an overseas customer service agent, Duracell did send a replacement - I had to ship the faulty one back at my expense, and the process took about a month. Now we have a new card that we don't trust at all. I guess you get what you pay for.

First, let me say I've been an Amazon customer from the beginning. I've had every Kindle version and been very happy. Until now. I bought myself the Kindle Fire HDX at Christmas for myself. Last weekend, while unplugged and off, it began making pinging noises. Suddenly, it stopped working. Called customer service--very helpful as usual and said they would send me a replacement as it was still under warranty. Great. Got it today. It is a refurbished model! I bought the upgraded 32 gig, and they send me a refurbished model. NOT ACCEPTABLE. Called and said this. Was given complete run around. My question to them was--if I bought a TV and it stopped working and I returned it, would I be given a refurbished model? They said no. WELL, why the deal here? This is my first disappointment from Amazon and it was HUGE. I buy many products through the year. Time to rethink. I could buy refurbished from eBay lots cheaper. Buyer Beware!

Just received this today and am asking for a refund and am returning it. I purchased directly from El Gato rather than going through Amazon.

There are two VERY important items listed in the description which contradict each other and will make many Playstation 3 owners unhappy.

The first item...
* Input: Xbox 360 (unencrypted HDMI), PlayStation 3 (A/V In)

Note the \\"PlayStation 3 (A/V In)\\". This means the Playstation will not work with an HDMI connection. That's right... the HDMI out port on your PS3 will be rendered useless with this device. The GameCapture ONLY WORKS WITH THE PLAYSTATION RF OUT. What does this mean? Well, for starters, no 3D at all. No 3D games, no 3D Blu-Ray viewing. Because those features only work via the Playstation's high-speed HDMI out port. So, if you connect the GameCapture \\"inline\\" as it's designed to be and your'e told to... you actually cripple the output from the Playstation. The HDMI 3D and high speed output of the Playstation is one major reason many purchase the Playstation to begin with. El Gato ruins that completely with the Game Capture connection limitation.

The second description item to be aware of....
* Output: HDMI (pass-through)

\\"Pass-through\\" indicates you can plug in HDMI cables on both ends of the GameCapture device and the HDMI signal simply passes through the device. Note this is ABSOLUTELY NOT TRUE for the Playstation. You will get absolutely NO PICTURE if you attempt to use the Playstation's HDMI out port with the GameCapture. El Gato states this is due to \\"DHCP copy protection issues\\". Fine, whatever reason, it should be made ABUNDANTLY CLEAR that the device does not allow full operation of the Playstation if connected in line. It's annoying to spend the money, wait for the device, find out about limitations only when it arrives, then wait for a refund. If they simply mentioned the limitations with the Playstation on the web site, my purchase would havenever been made. But I'd guess they are hoping many Playstation 3 users are merely using the RF output from the PS3 and won't even notice how crippling this device can be to a Playstation.

If you want to use the GameCapture device AND get 3D features from a Playstation, you'll need to connect the PS3 HDMI out to your TV or receiver, then connect the PS3's RF out to the GameCapture and then the GameCapture to a different input on the TV or receiver. Then, you'll need to swap the PS3 video output signal whenever you switch as well as any input signals on TVs or receivers. Did anyone at El Gato actually try all this? What a nightmare.

This may be a great device for Xbox owners. However, for Playstation 3 owners this thing basically takes all the high end video output features of your Playstation and makes them pointless. Of course, if you're simply outputting the Playstation 3 via the RF connector already, you won't notice all the limitations. But if you've got HDMI possibilities, you really want to dump the RF output and switch to the HDMI output.

For PS3 owners, this thing MAY be worth $50. It is absolutely NOT worth $200 though.
